DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 16.--In the last ten days I have come to understand the earnestness with which Mr. A.E. Burr of Hartford spoke when he said that the Democratic National Committee was "murdering" the party in Connecticut.
New-York's Giants showed their superiority over the St. Louis Browns yesterday in the opening game for the world's championship when they won a game by the closest possible score--2 to 1.
OKMULGEE, Indian Territory, Oct. 16.--A committee representing the Creek Council took a step to-day that will go a long ways toward encouraging the Oklahoma boomers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16.--The Managers of the Wisconsin Central Railroad and the Minneapolis and St. Louis appeared in person to-day at the meeting of the Northwestern Passenger Association and explained the difficulties under which they have been laboring.
The ship Steinvora of Pictou, Nova Scotia, Capt. MacIntosh, which arrived yesterday, 103 days from Singapore, had a rough time of it about Aug. 5 in latitude 23 south; longitude 54 46' west.

The history of Gov. Hill's relation to the New-York Aqueduct was insufficiently told during the investigation by the Senate Committee. It was impossible to tell the story thoroughly at that time because of the great volume of testimony.

The only drawback to the opening day at the Guttenberg track was that the large and unwieldly fields of starters so bothered the new starter that in consequence of the long delays at the post it was almost dark when the last race was decided.

There is promise of a very lively political rumpus at the annual National Convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, which is to be held at the Metropolitan Opera House during five days beginning to-morrow.

The wills of Robustiano Herques and his wife, Ana de Rivas Herques, which were filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court by the Executors, Coudert brothers, marked the closing acts of a tragedy enacted last March at Monte Carlo.

The Democrats of Westchester County held their County Convention in Lafayette Hall, White Plains, yesterday afternoon. William Ryan of Rye was chosen Chairman and Joseph W. Riley of Yonkers, J.B. Lockwood of ...
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The situation in Clinton County grows brighter every day. The Democratic County Convention was held here to-day, and the Hon. Charles E. Martin ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 17.--The Purchasing Committee of the Wabash Railway made a motion before Judge Gresham to-day to consolidate the various foreclosure proceedings began under the several division mortgages on the road east of the Mississippi River. There were lawyers present representing all the bondholders.

As a conclusion to their three days' convention the brew masters gave a banquet at Terrace Garden last evening. The company numbered over 600. Among them were representatives of nearly every large brewery in the country and many gentlemen prominent in State and municipal politics.

Between 3,000 and 4,000 clay pigeons were shot at Dunellen, N.J., yesterday, where the Middlesex Gun Club is holding its annual tournament. The attendance was not as large as on the previous day, but there were large entries is all the events, and some fine shooting was done.

While the fast St. Louis limited express on the West Shore Road, which left this city Tuesday evening, was passing through West Point tunnel a portion of the brick arch near the centre of the tunnel gave way, and a mass of earth and quicksand fell upon the forward portion of the train, completely burying it.
Alfred H. Gillam, the young, artist who cut his throat Tuesday night, in an attempt at suicide, died at an early hour yesterday morning.

HAVANA, Oct. 13.--At the age of 114 years there died here a few days ago a negress, Marcolina Campos, leaving a 90-year-old son, (her second one,) many grandchildren, great grandchildren, great-great-grandchildren, and a 12-year-old great-great-great-grandson.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 17.--The wholesale jewelry firm of J.M. Chandler Co., doing business at 185 Superior-street, went into bankruptcy to-day. George L. Case was appointed Assignee and his bond was fixed at $40,000. The liabilities of the firm are estimated at $50,000, and the assets the same.
There is one point, that has not been much dwelt upon by the orators and the publicists during the present canvass which is yet very well worth making.
Mr. Gibson Putzel will address the members of the Young Men's Union of the Society for Ethical Culture on "Tariff Reform," this evening, at the Workingmen's School, 109 West Fifty-fourthstreet.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 17.--Betting on the result of the Presidential election is becoming very spirited in Pittsburg. This afternoon bets aggregating $10,000 were arranged for, and it was surprising to many people to find ...
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 17.--The Princeton football team defeated the Rutgers College team this afternoon in a game here by a score of 78 to O. Collier of Rutgers was injured and had to retire.

The suit of Sarah Rapon, a domestic, aged 24, against Samuel Tucker, aged 18, for $5,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage, was tried in the City Court yesterday. The woman claimed that on Aug. 10 last Tucker agreed to marry her.

Francis Morris was convicted yesterday in Part II, General Sessions, of getting money under false pretenses from May Ford, to whom he sublet the house 265 West Sixteenth-street, telling her he had a three-years' lease of it when his lease expired next July. Mrs. Ford was asked on crossexamination to explain an advertisement which she inserted in a newspaper. She replied, "That's nobody's business. It has nothing to do with this case."

OTTAWA, Oct. 17.--A member of the Government said to-day there was not a word of truth in the report that immediately after President Cleveland's retaliation proposals Lord Salisbury cabled the Canadian Government ...
MONTREAL, Oct. 17.--A most peculiar accident occurred at Bertbier last night by which Mrs. Smith, the wife of a wealthy resident, lost her life.

Assistant District Attorney James Fitzgerald said yesterday that the District Attorney's office was in possession of knowledge concerning certain specific attempts at colonization of voters for the forthcoming election, and that every effort would be made to prevent such a fraud.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17.--The driving of the silver spikes completing the extension of the Derby Railroad was witnessed today by nearly 100 newspaper men, who were conveyed to the spot by a special train gayley decorated with bunting.

PETERSBURG, Va., Oct. 17.--Complications have arisen here relative to the duties of Supervisors of Election and the Registrars. The Republican Supervisors for the Second Ward made a demand upon the Registrar for a copy of the registered voters in the ward.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17.--The Harvard Freshman football eleven defeated the Cambridge High School team to-day by a score of 28 points to 6. A pouring rain made good playing almost impossible, but the Freshmen made a fair showing. The feature of the game was a goal kicked by the Freshmen near the end.
QUEBEC, Oct. 17.--A sensation was created here this morning on the news circulating that the Count Premio Real, Consul-General and Political Agent of Spain for British America, had committed suicide.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct.17.--The day of the big barbecue dawned clear and bright, and early this morning the crowds began to appear on the streets. Fort Wayne's 40,000 people were reinforced by the inhabitants of the county.

George Taylor, the clever young jockey who rode so successfully this season on the large tracks, will be the chief jockey for the Dwyer Brothers' Brooklyn stable next season. He received very flattering offers from D.D. Withers, Capt. S.S. Brown, "Snapper" Garrison, and two or three other owners, but it is stated on good authority that he has concluded to accept the offer of the Dwyers.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 17.--M.J. Horpmann of this city, who has been investigating the condition of the farmers in Ramsey County, Dakota, who were reported to be starving to death, returned last night.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 17.--The rifle tournament of the Connecticut National Guard occurred here to-day under tha direction of Major Jarman, Brigade Inspector of Rifle Practice.
CALCUTTA, Oct. 17.--The Afghan rising has been crushed. Ishak's troops have surrendered and Ishak has taken refuge in Bokhara.

About 6:15 yesterday morning a heavy thunderstorm broke over this city. The lightning was very vivid, the thunder heavy, and the rain copious during the following three-quarters of an hour. A wing of the cold storm that is wetting down New-England and the great lakes region reached the Orange Mountains early in the morning, and, striking against the ...

LAMARIE, Wyoming, Oct. 17.--Dilds Black, manager of the Western Union Telegraph office at this point, who was fined $100 and committed to jail on Monday for his failure to produce certain telegarams bearing on a case being tried in the District Court, was released yesterday. He was advised by the General Solicitor of the company to furnish the messages asked for. Judge Saufley then remitted the fine, but required the Manager to pay the costs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17.--The Sioux chiefs appeared at the Interior Department to-day to hear the conclusions of the President and the Secretary of the Interior as to what modifications of the new law, if any, would be recommended to Congress. After all had been said Secretary Vilas addressed the Indians through an interpreter, He said:

At the meeting of the Board of Police yesterday a communication was received from Cornelius N. Bliss and associates of the RapublicanState Committee transmitting a sample of a placard announcing that $25,000 had been deposited in the Garfield National Bank as a reward for information which shall result in the ...

During the present Administration decided improvement has been apparent in the condition and progress of the Indians. It is safe to say that more substantial advancement has been made toward civilization and self-support during the past three and a half years than during the preceding twenty years.
The master brewers completed their three days' convention yesterday. In the morning the adjourned business session was held in Terrace Garden. Louis Frisch presided.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17.--Mr. Llewellyn Lloyd, known on the turf as "Mr. Rossmore" of New-York, who was crushed by the steeplechaser Zangbar while jumping a stone wall at the City Troop races yesterday, is still lying in ...

The freight troubles between the rail and lake lines have been settled at last and all lines have agreed to restore rates on Oct. 26. On west-bound business, beginning on that date, the rates between New-York and Chicago and ...
WOODSVILLE, N.H., Oct. 17.--The Weeks block at North Haverhill, which is occupied as a store by N.C. Wright and by the Post Office, was entered by burglars last night.
Charges of wrongdoing in the purchase of stationery and the procurement of printing in the bureau presided over by Thomas Costigan, Supervisor of the City Record, having been made by a newspaper.

The Coquelin-Hading Company will give nine performances next week, one of which, on Thursday afternoon, will be in the Park Theatre, Brooklyn. The success of yesterday's special matinee at Palmer's has decided Mr. Abbey to give another performance next Wednesday afternoon, when "Frou-Frou" will be presented, ...

BOSTON, Oct. 17.--Atchison caught it again to-day in the local stock market, selling to the extent of 30,865 shares. It opened 2 lower, at 67 . Then, when it leaked out that a prominent State-street operator, a special friend of the Atchison Company, was said to have learned from official sources that the report ...

Mr. FONG'S case is worth attention, for it raises some of the hardest questions in the restriction of Chinese immigration. Mr. FONG was quietly making his way across the Canadian border like any other traveler when, on Monday last, the United States customs officers told him that no Chinese need apply for admission to what DANIEL WEBSTER need to call "the refuge of the oppressed of all nations."
Senor Don Pedro Perez Zelidon, United States Minister from Costa Rica, arrived here yesterday in the West India steamship Ailsa. He was accompanied by his family, and went to the Clarendon Hotel.
Prof. A.M. Wheeler of Yale College is at the Murray Hill Hotel. Ex-Gov. John Lee Carroll of Maryland is at the Victoria Hotel.

If Chairman Edward Murphy, Jr., and the other managers of the Democratic State Committee are not in favor of the "knifing" of the national ticket in order to promote the election of David B. Hill they should attend at once to the doings of David A. Dishler of Utica, the Democratic "boss" of Oneida County.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 17--The Michigan Fish Commission have been investigating the catch of whitefish in Lakes Michigan and Erie, to ascertain how large it is the present year and whether it is probable that the large plantings of spawn in the past few years has really been productive of appreciable results.

The jury in Part IV., of the Supreme Court, before whom the troubles of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. McBride have been thououghly ventilated, when they came into court yesterday were given seven questions to answer. Judge Beach carefully explained that they were to deal only with the questions, and were to answer each yes or no.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Oct. 17.--The case against Charles I. De Baun, the New-York defaulter, entered upon a new phase this morning. when the Hon. George Irvine, Q.C. and Judge of the Vice-Admiralty Court, Quebec, and W.B. Ives, member of Parliament, Q.C., the prisoner's attorney, applied for a writ of habeas corpus bofore Mr. Justice Church, in Chambers.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 17--The Republicans of the Second District of Monmouth County at Matawan to-day nominated Edward M. Fielder, a lumber merchant of this town, for the Assembly. Mr. Fielder was the candidate last year for the same office, but was defeated by Dr. Archibald A. Higgins.

HELENA, Montana, Oct. 17.--A week ago news was received from Billings that Lewis Sweet, Assessor of the county, had committed suicide. Later developments prove that instead of suicide it was an assassination. The position of the body when found showed that deceased was undressing preparatory to retiring when the assassin fired through a window screen, six buckshot lodging in Sweet's heart. Gov. Leslie has offered $1,000 reward for the capture and conviction of the murderer.

LONDON, Oct. 17.--A dispatch from St. Paul de Loando gives the official account of the killing of Major Barttelot. Barttelot had been much annoyed by Manyemas practicing singing and drumming early in the morning and in the evening and threatened to stop the practice.

Frankie L. Raymond, the dashing young woman who is accused by Mrs. H.C. Mills of 790 Sixth-avenue of having last Thursday stolen $3,000 worth of diamond jewelry and $100 in cash from her apartments, occupied a cell at Police Headquarters last night. She was brought from Boston by a New-York detective last evening.
Steamship Wergeland, (Norw.,) Wiese, Baracoa 6 ds., with fruit to H. Dumois Co. Arrived at the Bar at 9:45 P.M.

The second game of the championship series between the New-Yorks and St. Louis sttracted 5,600 lovers of the national game to Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, and although the day was rather cool and cheerless they witnessed one of the best exhibitions of ball playing ever seen in New-York.
When Dr. M.B. Hutchins of the Cancer Hospital at Fordham Heights was arraigned before Justice German yesterday on the charge of assault preferred by Mathew Flynn, guard of a Sixth ...

The United Labor Party of Kings County, which has decided to put in the local field only candidates for Congress and Assembly, held its Congreesional Convention last night at the headquarters, Joralemon-streat, Brooklyn. In the Second District Thomas Seward was nominated; in the Fourth, William E. Robinson, and in the Fifth, John J. Clancy. The Third District Convention was adjourned.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17.--Rain interfered with the college tennis tournament to-day, but the following games in singles were played: Hale against Brown, 6--2, 6--4. Lee against Brooks, 6--3, 6--3. Shaw against Codman, 7--5, 6--2. Chase against Hale, 6--2, 6--4. In the preliminary rounds for doubles Lee and Taliant defeated Brown and Sturgis, 6--3, 6--4, and Wilds and Wrenn were beaten by Orcott and Potter.
A Jersey City genius named Hobart has invented a snow plow which be confidently believes will prove the salvation of railroads in the event of another blizzard such as that of last March.

A lawyers Cleveland and Thurman Club has been formed irrespective of party affiliations. Among its members are Frederic R. Condert, exGov. George Hoadly of Ohio, Everett P. Wheeler, Wheeler H. Peckham, Ashbel P. Fitch, David McClure, Albert Matthews, Albert Stickney De lancey Nicoll, Hugh L. Cole, ex-Gov. Deon Abbett of New Jersey. Theodore Connoly, and Hugo S. Mack and others.
The Board of Trustees of Normal College met yesterday and transacted a vast amount of routine business. Several changes were made in the proposed by-laws for the government of the board, the ...

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 17.--The twentyfifth annual International Convention of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers was called to order this morning, in Belvidere Hall by P.M. Arthur, Grand Chief Engineer. Mayor J. Taylor Ellison delivered an address of welcome, and Gov. Fitzhugh Lee extended a greeting in behalf of the State. Grand Chief P.M. Arthur delivered the annual address, in which, among other things, he said:

BALTIMORE, Md.,, Oct. 17.--The annual statement of earnings and expenses of the Baltimore and Ohio Road was given out to-day. It shows that during the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 the earnings did not meet the expenses by almost $500,000. The dividend was passed for the third consecutive time.

The Casino was crowded last night with a brilliant and expectant audience. It was not an ordinary first-night assembly, but such an array of representative persons as can only be called together in a comic opera theatre by the magic names of Gilbert and Sullivan, aided by all the arts of advertising known to the experts of the theatrical world.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The Republicans of the First Otsego District to-day nominated William E. Dante of Worcester for Member of Assembly. TROY, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The Democtrats of Clinton County to-day nominated Charles E. Martin for Membbr of Assembly.

Among the passengers on the steamship Saale, which sailed for Bremen yesterday, were W.C. Brayton, W.H. Bradley, J. Cameron, member of Parliament; H.W.O. Edye, W.C. Hill, the Rev. D. B. Minor, J. Hopkins Smith, R.J.C. Walker, and Ernst Peixotto.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17.--W. D. Welch, a traveling man, who was frozen to death in Minnesota a year ago, had his life insured in the Royal Arcanum for $3,000, the money being payable to ...

"Gross earnings for a year, $12,600,000. Expenses for the year, $14,400,000." These figures, (given in a special dispatch from Topeka yesterday to THE TIMES, summarizing the sworn report of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company for the year ended June 30 last,) spread consternation in Wall-street.

DETROIT, Oct. 17.--The Republicans of Michigan are waking up to the fact that they have got to make a special effort to carry this State. There are signs of concern manifested. Speakers from the East and from Western States almost as doubtful as Michigan have been put on the stump, and more are coming.

The fact that the Governor openly and shamelessly violated the law regarding the expenditure of money in elections would be sufficient condemnation. But what follows is still more shameless. He did worse than refuse to pay the note for $10,000. He made the city of New-York pay it. This is what occurred.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 17.--At Oriole Park this afternoon about 200 people, mostly ladies, witnessed a rough game of lacrosse between the Princeton champion team and the Druids of this city.

There is a considerable proportion of the Republican Party, possibly a majority of its members, who are ready to admit that the tariff of this country needs a thorough and careful revision, with a view not only to getting rid of the mischievous surplus but to reducing the burdens of taxation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17.--Proposals to bring the present session of Congress to a close on Saturday next have been made in both houses to-day, but decisive action has been taken in neither. In the Senate the proposal came from the Republican side of the chamber, and in the House it was brought forward by a Democrat.
According to a dispatch from Boston yesterday it appears possible that a challenge for the America's cup may come from some quarter other than England.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Oct. 17.--Mr. Garrett rested well last night. He slept seven hours and was up at 6 o'clock this morning. He was quite calm all day long and chatted pleasantly with his attendants and did not become violent or excited at any time.

WARSAW, N.Y., Oct. 17.--Floyd A. Hayward, a wealthy lawyer of Warsaw, claims that the Republican Party has left him. He feels rather grieved about it, because he is a man of about 70 and has been identified with that party for years and intimately connected with its leaders.

The Hudson County Republican Congressional Convention at Weedon Hall, Jersey City, spent all of yesterday afternoon in an effort to persuade some one to stand for Congress against Congressman William McAdoo.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 17.--At the annual meeting of the Baptist Social Union of Connecticut, held here this evening at the conclusion of the State Baptist Convention, Major E.V. Preston of this city was elected President Fred A. Betts ...

Ah Ling, a Chinaman, 28 years of age, arrived at Castle Garden among the steerage passengers of the steamship Ludgate Hill from London. Secretary Jackson of Castle Garden reported the case to the Collector, who immediately ordered that the Chinaman should not be permitted to land in NewYork.
CALAIS, Oct. 17.--The force of the explosion of petroleum yesterday on board the French steamer Ville de Calais, which arrived here on ...
Section 5, Chapter 128, of Laws of 1875, Revised Statues of the United States, reads as follows:

William J. Moffett and Joseph Wood, partners in a new building being erected in the Rosenth section or Newark, N.J., dashed out of the cellar of the house yesterday, and up Orange avenue to Sayre's drug store.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17.--There was a much larger attendance at to-day's races of the Maryland Jockey Club, and the racing afforded much better sport. The weather was again delightful, and a large proportion of those in attendance were ladies.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 17.--One of the many ridiculous features of Hill's Gubernatorial campaign, and which shows to what extremes he will resort for success, is the circulating of a circular appealing to all firemen to support him for Governor on the ground that he is an exempt fireman of the Elmira Fire Department.

Mayor Hewitt seems glad of an opportunity to meet every charge that is made against him by his foes. He disposed of quite a number of calumnies yesterday. In conversation with a reporter of THE TIMES, he said:

Two of the most prominent cricket clubs of Brooklyn, the Manhattan and Kings County Cricket Clubs, have completed their schedules of the last season, with the following results: The Manhattan Club playod 29 matches, winning 22 ...
LONDON, Oct. 17.--The steamship Crystal, (Br.,) Capt. Stannard, sld. from Shields to-day NewYork.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 17.--President Neal Mitchell's official bulletin for the 24 hours ending at 6 o'clock this evening is as follows: New cases, 36; deaths, 3; total number of cases to date, 3,663; total number of deaths to date, 321.

When Mrs. Alfred Redfern, who lives at 71 Lexington-avenue, Brooklyn, awoke yesterday morning she found her husband dead in his bed. Death had taken place about 10 hours previously. On a table near the bed was a glass containing eyanide of potassium. It is supposed Mr. Radfern took the fatal dose on Tuesday night as soon as his wife had failen asleep.

The Wisconsin Central Road has agreed to defer its threatened withdrawal from the Northwestern Passenger Association, the Minneapolis and St. Louis having promised to adhere strictly to rates, and the danger of a lively passenger rate war among the Northwestern ...

Belva Lookwood's Presidential campaign received a sorry set-back yesterday. Two women who think they have a right to vote tried to get themselves registered at 17 West Fourth-street yesterday morning. They wereMrs. E.B. Burnz, who teaches shorthand at Cooper Union, and Miss Silli Martin, the former's assistant.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 17.--The Republican campaign in Indiana may be said to have reached its flood tide of enthusiasm and interest to-day in the great rally held in the historic battlefield of Tippecanoe.

Commissioners Hess, Moss, and Gibbens were present at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Electrical Control, but Mayor Hewitt, as usual, did not attend the meeting. The board not having met for some time before there was considerable routine businees on the table.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 17.--The Presbyterian Synod of New-Jersey closed its annual session to-day. The hall in which the meetings were held was crowded at every session. At the morning session the Rev. Dr. Alfred Erdman read a long report on the work in Germany.

Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court yesterday denied the application of Robert Garrett and others for an injunction to restrain the New-York Transit and Terminal Company from dispo sing of the corporation property while the suit in the State court is pending. The reason for the denial is that the plaintiff does not mean to prosecute the suit in the Federal court.

After the heavy and frequent rains of late the Clifton track has become so soaked that it will take days of good weather to thoroughly dry it out, especially on the inner part of it. Yesterday it was very heavy, and on the new parts of the course was fetlock deep.

A former sister of the Third Order of St. Dominic was married last night at the residence of the Rev. Father Malone, Pastor of Saints Peter and Paul's Church, in Brooklyn. In religion her name was Sister St. Mary, in the world it was Miss Mary Julia Holly, now it is Mrs. Antoine Betz.

Mr. Gubbine, James Godfrey, Thomas Gubbins, and Norman Gubbins, all young men, arrived at Castle Garden yesterday by the steamship Wyoming, from Liverpool. Two of them were accompanied by their wives and children.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 17.--There will be a fair average crop of potatoes in New-England, according to the New-England Homestead, a yield below the average in New-York State, and not a full crop at the West.

A few weeks since it was gravely announced in the Republican organs that there would be no surplus this year worth speaking about. It followed, of course, if this were true, that there was no need of reducing taxation, and, in fact, no proper means of doing so.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 17.--Warner Miller arrived here this afternoon from NewYork and was welcomed at the railroad station by ex-Mayor White, Assemblymen Platt and Mase, and other leading Republicans. This evening the Republican clubs of the city and vicinity, which have a membership of 800, ...

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The trial of Richard Barber, changed with the murder of Mrs. R. Mason of Ulysses Hamlet, near Ithaca, began yesterday at the Circuit Court, Judge Walter L. Smith presiding. The jury was impaneled to-day and the written ...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 17.--The Democrats had a parade, raised two banners, and held an open-air rally last night. Among the meetings arranged for in the future is a big barbecue on Nov. 1, after which Congressman Roger Q. Mills and Senator John R. McPherson will speak. The meeting to be held Friday evening will be addressed by (Gov. Green and Attorney-General Stockton.

Primaries for the election of delegates to the Republican City, County, Assembly, and Congressional Conventions were held in each of the 26 wards in Brooklyn yesterday. There were contests in nearly every ward between rival bosses, and the interest involved brought out so many votes that at midnight no results had been reached.

Wayfarers in Park-row were startled by a loud explosion in Dr. Perry's pharmacy, in the Sun building, about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. They were not half so much startled as the throng of customers in the place. The latter hurried toward the street.

The New-York Board of Underwriters held its regular monthly meeting yesterday and considered, in addition to a mass of routine business, the suggestion by the Fire Commissioners that additional and more efficient fireboats be provied.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 17.--Secretary Bayard is at Mattapoisett, spending several days with his daughter, Mrs. S.P. Warden, Jr.

The troubles that have been brewing in the Eleventh Regiment for some time have culminated in the resignation of Major Jones and one or two other officers, with a prospect of more following their lead.

Wall-street found lots of interest yesterday in the rather delicate situation in which 100 brokers of the Stock Exchange find themselves through the claim of the official directory of the Consolidated exchange that the same 100 are members, too, of that "little" institution.

New-York was deprived of the honor of enjoying the presence of Senator Quay's kitchen cabinet at an early hour yesterday. When they got up and called for the daily papers, they read in THE TIMES a description of themselves and their doings which by no means pleased them.

BOSTON, Oct. 17.--The athletic controversy at Harvard College has been settled by mutual concessions from the Fellows and Overseers. Before the close of the last term a Conference Committee was appointed on the disagreements between the President and the Fellows and the Overseers, and the plan agreed upon was presented by President Eliot to the Board of Overseers to-day, by whom it was adopted. It is as follows:
Abram S. Hewitt, Ashbel P. Fitch, and several others were elected members of the Harlem Democratic Club last night at the most largely attended business meeting the club has held this Fall.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17.--There was a wellattended conference to-day between representatives of the Western roads and the lines of the Central Traffic Association to consider improvements in the exchange of passenger business between Eastern and Western roads.

BOSTON, Oct. 17.--Republican office holders at the Custom House in Boston--and about half the force would come under that head--are kicking over the traces at the persistence with which they are assessed for Republican campaign purposes.

Julius F. Cheesebrough sued Daniel D. Conover in the Supreme Dourt to recover $10,000 for services rendered. He alleged that in 1876 Conover, having an interest in the Forty-second-Street and Manhattanville Railroad, engaged his services to bring about the construction of the road, ...

NEW-BEDFORD, Oct. 17.--Cerebro spinal meningitis has broken out in some of the NewBedford stables. About a dozen horses are ill and four have died. The disease attacks horses which have been used most, while those which have been kept in the stables are not affected.

All the Congressional Conventions of the County Democracy were adjourned from last night until to-morrow night. The purpose of this was to permit the Tammany Hall leaders to think longer over the proposition for a union made to them by the County Democracy on Monday.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 17.--Marmaduke Shannon, at one time the leading Whig journalist of Mississippi, died at Vicksburg this morning, aged 84 years.

A communication just received in this city from one of the jurors of the Brussels Exposition shows that, though the number of American exhibitors was somewhat limited, the reputation of American artizans for ingenuity and talent was fully sustained. The communication says.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 17.--The racing of the Kentucky Association to-day was under a bright, warm sunshine, but with a muddy track, the results being as follows:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The Prohibitionists have nominated Albert K. Smiley for member of Congress from the Sevententh District, comprising the countries of Ulster, Greene and Delaware. QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 17.--The Democrats of the Second Congresstional District this afternoon nominated Josiah Quincy for Congress.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 17.--Maggie Watts went to the Middle-street grammar school yesterday and demanded the dismissal of her brother. The Principal would not let the boy go, and she produced a pistol and threat ened to shoot him. The teacher put her out and the pistol was not fired, but a warrant has been issued for her arrest.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The Republican city of Oswego gave the Thomas Jefforson a reception to-night exceeding anything hitherto in its voyage.

Suppose the worker has by years of industry and saving succeeded in acquiring a home of his own in spite of the extra cost of building and furnishing a house caused by tariff taxes. The comfort of his family is still subject to a constant burden of taxation.

The Reform Club of this city has accomplished a great coal in its short life and has been particularly successful in attracting large and intelligent audiences to meetings held under its auspices for the purpose of spreading the principles of tariff reform.

Mr. Daly stood at the door of his theatre yesterday and saw a throng of ladies pass through the gate to witness the first Wednesday matinee performance of "The Lottery of Love," and thus gained ocular evidence of the fact that his new play is destined to repeat the record of other great successes at this house.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 17.--The rearranging of the Russian troops in the vicinity of the Austrian frontier is proceeding actively, in response to the movements of the Austrian forces. No special change in the relations between the two countries has taken place; the movement of the Russian troops is merely a measure of precaution.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 17.--William Leeder, a peddler employed by James Laney Co. of Rochester, skipped out with $400 worth of goods in July, 1887, and was not heard from until this month. A Deputy Sheriff went to Ionia, Mich., and brought Leeder here this morning. He is held for grand larceny.
The Directors of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad finally leased their property yesterday for 99 years to the Richmond and Danville Company.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 17.--The rearranging of the Russian troops in the vicinity of the Austrian frontier is proceeding actively, in response to the movements of the Austrian forces. No special change in the relations between the two countries has taken place; the movement of the Russian troops is merely a measure of precaution.

Certain allegations in a bill recently filed in the United States Circuit Court at Chicago by the Atkinson Car Spring Works tend to throw some light upon the methods of combinations formed to suppress competition.
While railroad men generally believe that freight rates will be firm throughout the Winter, many shippers think they will not. Particularly is this the case with shippers of grain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--The following letter to all concerned was sent out by Presdent N.E. Young yesterday:

Richard Dudley, who shot James Smith be cause he tries to prevent him from robbing a woman, was held for trial in the Essex Market Court yesterday. Dudley told the officer that he was the "toughest man alive," and was sorry he did not kill the woman, as he intended to.
SOFIA, Oct. 18.--Prince Ferdinand has summoned the Sobranje to meet on the 27th inst.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 18.--A report was circulated yesterday that the Northern Pacific had contracted for the construction of eight new vestibuled passenger trains, which were to ba completed in March and put on the road as through trains between Chicago and the Pacific coast, running over the Wisconsin Central Road.

BOSTON, Oct. 18. --When Joseph Fowle, a picturesque old negro of Boston, was arraigned in court this morning and held for trial under $4,000 bonds, on the charge of swindling John H. Appleton, a well-known lawyer, a very singular story was revealed.

The latest tidings from Apia show that the adherents of the deposed King MALIETOA have followed up their defeat of TAMASESE'S forces by holding them under siege at Mulince Point, while the Germans of the town are trying to supply them with provisions.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18.--A special car attached to the 3 o'clock train from the Broadstreet station took to Bryn Mawr a party of distinguished gentlemen members and guest of the famous Farmers' Club. From Bryn Mawr they were driven to Mr. George W. Childs's country seat, Wooton, where of 5 o'clock Mr. Childs entertained them at dinner.

At 7 o'clock last night two big policemen had theif hands full keeping in some sort of order a crowd of nearly 200 rollicking youngsters of the Gansevoert Market neighborhood, who were waiting in front of 55 Little Twelfth-street for the opening of the doors of Central Assembly Hall, in which a mission was to be inaugurated by the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. J. Sumner Stone.

PAUL, Minn., Oct. 18.--ChairmanLeeds of the Transcontinental Association telegraphed from Washington yesterday to the Northern Pacific, saying that the tariffs against which Chicago merchants have made so much complaint were declared illegal by the Interstate Commerce Commission, because they discriminated ...

The "Soo" Line has given notice of a rise in freight rates, taking effect Oct 20. It is excessively heavy, ammounting to more than 50 per cent. From New-York to St. Paul, Minneapolis, and all points on the Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie Railway the rates will be 95 cents per 100 pounds on first class, 87 on second, 68 on third, 45 on, fourth, 39 on fifth, and 33 on sixth.
In Part III, General Sessions, yesterday one of the few Chinese women in this city appeared as a witness against Bridget Lee and Patrick Hayes, whom she charged with assault and robbery.

Stone on behalf of 10 national banks in the East against the Minnesota Thrasher Company, in which the banks ...

ALBANY, Oct. 18.--In the Court of Appeals today, the Hon. W.C. Roger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following cause was argued: No. 60--Anne Harnickall, Administratrix, respondent, vs. The New-York Life Insurance Company, appellant.--Argued by William B. Hornblower for appellant, John M. Bowers for respondent. Following is the Court of Appeals day calendar for Friday, Oct. 19: Nos. 68, 75, 76, 50, 13, 55, 1242, 64.

Brown of Allegheny, John A. Jordon of Adams, and F.A. Wilson of Lancaster, comprising the Executive ...

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct, 18.--While piling leaves on a bonfire to-day a 4-year-old child named White ley was so badly burned that he will die. Every article of clothing on his body was burned off except the shoes.
BOSTON, Oct. 18.--Tariff reform has received several notable accessions in this vicinity recently.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 18.--One of the most enthusiastic demonstrations seen in this city during the present campaign was witnessed this evening, the occasion being the speech of Daniel Dougherty at the Opera House.

DETROIT, Oct. 18.--At the same time that the Republicans who are running the campaign work at New-York are assuring everybody out West that the Empire State is safe for Harrison it is learned that they are very reluctantly parting with the speakers who are drawn from New-York to help keep the Michigan Republicans in line.

WASECA, Minn., Oct. 18.--A correspondent to-day met J.A. Henry, editor of the Janesville Argus, whose wife's sensational elopement with the Rev. David Seymour excited so much interest all over the country.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 18.--Morris A. Thomas, whose appointment as an Indian Inspector by President Cleveland, at the recommendation of Senator Gorman, caused something of a political sensation, was to-day nominated by the Democratic ...

JACKSONVILLE, Oct. 18.--President Neal Mitchell's official bulletin for the 24 hours ending at 6 o'clock this evening is as follows: New cases, 29; deaths, 1; total number of cases to date, 3,692; total number of deaths to date, 322. The death to-day is Eldwood B. Holliday.

The Manhattan Savings Institution has purchased the property on the north side of Bleeckerstreet, between its present building and the BleeckerStreet Savings Bank, and will erect thereon a handsome office building, covering the entire space between Broadway and Crosby street, with a frontage of 53 feet on Broadway.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18.--The arguments on the motion to consolidate all the foreclosure suits in the Wabash Railway litigation were resumed before Judge Gresham to-day, and the court reached a decision in the matter.

Trunk Line Passenger Commissioner Pierson yesterday declined to say whether or not the trunk lines would agree to withdraw the boycott from the Chicago and Alton Road in the event of such an agreement being effected between the lines of the Western states Passenger Association and these of the Central Traffic Association.
DENVER, Col., Oct. 18.--A number of New-York capitalists with a capital of $1,000,000, filed papers with the Secretary of State here to-day forming the corporation of the San Rafael Mining Company.
Wheat declined in price again yesterday on the New-York Produce Exchange. Trading was extremely light, amounting to only about 2,500,000 bushels, nearly all of which was in December and May.

Golden year services will be held on Sunday at the Chelsea Methodist Episcopal Church, on Thirteenth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, to commemorate the establishment of the society of that church 50 years ago.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 18.--Hamlet S. Briggs, of the firm of M. Briggs Son, Statestreet, left Rochester on Tuesday night, and his whereabouts are at present unknown. It is alleged that Mr. Briggs is a forger to the amount of nearly $15,000, and that he left town to avoid the consequence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--Col. Rufus Saxton, Assistant Quartermaster-General, will be placed on the retired list to-morrow on account of age. His retirement will promote Lieut.-Col. H.C. Hodges to be Colonel, Major George Weeks to be Lieutenant-Colonel.

A meeing of the General Passenger Agents of all the Trunk and Central Traffic Association lines will be held in Buffalo early next week to settle the question of excursion rates which has kept these lines in hot water throughout the Summer.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18.--The George T. Down's Tariff Reform Circle of New-Haven, which is composed entirely of colored voters of New-Haven, who are pledged to vote for Cleveland and tariff reform, held an enthusiastic meeting this evening at its rooms in Weir Hall. The meeting was addressed by the Hon. Talcott H. Russell of New-Haven and the Hon. Charles H. Fowler. The club numbers about one hundred colored voters.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 18.--A cable dispatch from London says that the Times continues to publish letters pointing to the importance of the coming to a decision by the Canadian Government respecting the Atlantic mail service.
The General Eastern Freight Agents of Western lines will hold a meeting in this citysoon to discuss the question of a uniform classification. At present there are several freight classifications.
WILMINGTON. Del., Oct. 18.--The Right Rev. J. Leighton Coleman, D.D., of Sayre. Penn., Bishop-elect of the Episcopal diocese of Delaware, was formally consecrated to that ...

BALTIMORE, Oct. 18.--President Spencer of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad will publish a statement to-morrow in answer to comments passed upon the financial statement made yesterday of the road's condition.

Dr. J.T. O'Connor, Professor of Nervous Diseases in the New-York Homeopathic College, lectured upon the "Localization of Brain Function" at a special meeting last night of the Homeopathic Medical Society at Third-avenue and Twenty-third-street.

The Jewish Order of the Harp of David has been conducting a series of Hebrew grand operas, tragedies, and high comedies at Poole's Theatre for the benefit of its charitable and mutual benefit funds, and has gotten into trouble.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 18.--The apple market has collapsed and the bottom has fallen out of prices at an alarming rate.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 18.--Harry C. Mace, aged 22 years, resided at Berrysburg, this county, until a few days ago.
Delia Dondican, an Irish immigrant, 18 years old, fell from the rear platform of the Sag Harbor express on the Long Island Railroad Wednesday afternoon and was killed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18.--James G. Blaine passed a quiet day at the Grand Pacific Hotel. He arose in the morning much refreshed by a sound sleep, and free from the nausea which had been troubling him.
WHEELING, West Va., Oct, 18.--The Ravenswood Bank, at Ravenswood, Jackson County, was raided by a gang of boys last night, and between $300 and $400 stolen.
The order recently made by Judge Andrews of the Supreme Court in several cases against the Manhattan Elevated Railroad for damages to property was to have been settled yesterday.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 18.--The Democrats of the Senond District of Westchester County to-day nominated Samual Conover for member of Assembly.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18.--Very quietly and easily Nat C. Goodwin, the comedian, committed matrimony in this city a few days ago. He is now finishing an engagement at Hooley's Theatre, and the secret was kept for two whole days, or until Mr. Good win's manager started for St. Louis.

By the breaking of some planking used to cover a half-dozen freshly-made graves at Greenwood Cemetery Wednesday 20 persons who has gathered about the open grave of David B. Gladding, who died at 150 Park-avenue Monday, were thrown into the graves.
ST. PAUL, Minn.., Oct. 18.--Observer Lyons reports that the advance of the cold wave was felt at Helona, Montana, early this morning, of the temerature was 24 there then.
ALBANY, Oct. 18.--Frank Herdic, the bookmaker, offered to bet $1,000 to $600 in the Delavan House yesterday that Grover Cleveland would carry New-York. His offer was not taken.
The New-York Giants and the St. Louis Browns will play at Washington Park, Brooklyn, this afternoon.
The Conference Committee of the DownTown Business Men's Cleveland and Thurman Club met yesterday at the Stevens House.

KINGSTON, Oct. 18.--Whoever undertakes to navigate the sea of politics in the Nineteenth Congressional District, and particularly in Ulster County, must make frequent observations and take many soundings. The landmarks of one year are no guide a twelvemonth later.

Nothing was done yesterday toward the settlement of the question of union between Tammany and the County Democracy. In the afternoon the Tammany Committee of Twentyfour met and discussed the interesting note sent them by the County Democracy on Wednesday night.

The present session of Congress will end to-morrow. Both houses have adopted a resolution to that effect, the proposition coming from the Senate. For a month past, the question of adjournment has been purely a political and even a partisan one.

Two indictments against Ann O'Delia Salomon and "General" Diss De Bar were dismissed yesterday on the recommendation of District Attorney Fellows.

After a display of even unusual inactivity attended by weakness the stock market suddenly strengthened yesterday afternoon and went upward quickly on big transactions. Just as the pieayune bears were growing confident they found themselves sprawling.
CHARLESTON, West Va., Oct. 18.--Two weeks before the election both the great political parties are claiming the Electoral vote of West Virginia. No such campaign has ever been known here.

NAPLES, Oct. 18.--Emperor William went to Pompeii this morning. He was attired in an Italian Admiral's uniform. He was intensely interested in everything he saw at Pomseii, especially in an excavation made in his presence, during the progress of which several valuable bronze objects were unearthed.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 18.--A strong antiHill movement is being worked up among the tariff-reform Democrats of Cornell University, ...

Wall-street was treated to a taste of Prohibition oratory yesterday. The forces of that party concentrated themselves on the steps of the Sub-Treasury. The leading lights of the party were there. Candidate Clinton B. Fisk, ex-Gov. St. John of Kansas, and Prof. Samuel Dickie were the principal speakers.

NEE-HAVEN, Conn., Oct.--18.--If the religious proclivities of the prominent football captains are not temporarily laid aside pugilism ought to be pretty thoroughly eliminated from the great college game this season.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18.--Drafts--Sight, 2 1/3 @5; telegraphic, 7 @10.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 18.--For a long time there has been in the courts of the States and Territories through which the Northern Pacific Railroad runs a great deal of litigation concerning the alleged trespasses of the Northern Pacific Railroad upon the timber land of the Government.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 18.--"I see an effort is being made to have the inter-State commerce law altered so as to allow the existence of railroad pools," said President H.B. Hammond of the Indiana, Decatur and western Railway Company, who is here from New-York on business.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18.--There was some lively betting on the election to-day. Charles D. Wells, a retired commission merchant, ...

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 18.--An extraordinary case of negro superstition, reported today from Aiken County, furnishes a striking example of the strange hallucination that still holds sway in the mind of the negro after years of residence in an enlightened land.
Yesterday was "live bird day" at the Middlesex Gun Club's tournament at Dunellen, N.J., and it attracted a number of sporting men and a fair proportion of the general public.

One of the weakest and most absurd devices of the Republican League for securing votes is in course of circulation in the form of an appeal to merchant tailors to save them selves from starvation by voting against tariff reform.
World's championships from a baseball standpoint come high, but judging from the manner in which the New-Yorks have been playing lately they must have one.
There was a lively time for a while yesterday morning at the Metal Exchange. October lead developed decided signs of activity accompanied by no little excitement.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 18.--A somewhat novel controversy has arisen between Mr. A.C. Raymond, Chairman of the local Democratic Campagn Committee, and Mr. James McMillen, the well-known capitalist and prospective candidate for the United States Senate.
DENVER, Col. Oct. 18.--One of the most rich and marvelous strikes that have been made in Colorado has just been made in the Aspen Mines at Aspen.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 18.--John Teemer, the champion carsman, arrived home to-day. He has accepted O'Connor's challenge, and will post the money on saturday. The race will take place on Nov. 24 at Washington. Teemer will go into training at once.

The Democrats of Brooklyn held primaries last night in all the wards for the election of delegates to the City, County, Assembly, and Congressional Conventions to be held next week There were no contests of any moment.
Capt. Abram Jones of Sing Sing, who went through the war and did not receive a scratch, came very near being killed in his own gun store yesterday with a gun that nobody knew was loaded.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 18.--The First District Republicans to-day substituted the name of Charles B. Wilson for P.B. Pinchback on the Congressional ticket. Mr. Wilson is a handsome young mulatto, a graduate of Straight University, a printer by ...

A concert for the benefit of the Parnell defense fund was given last evening at Cooper Union under the auspices of the Municipal Council of the Irish National League. There were a thousand people present, and the receipts from ticket sales and subscriptions amounted to $398.
Fredericka, the wife of Henry Willanth, an engineer at 419 Brooms-street, whose home is at 126 Thorn-street, Jersey City, came to New-York on Wednesday.

LONDON, Oct. 18.--Mr. Michael Davitt has written a letter to the Times in which he says that the Irish will not accept the scheme proposed by the Liberals for the government of Ireland unless an Irish Parliament is allowed to solve the land question and fix the compensation to be paid to the landlords.
The Society of St. Luke's Hospital held its annual meeting last night and re-elected its Board of Managers. The report from the officers of the work done during the last year was very encouraging.

Abram Hewlett, who was reputed to be the wealthiest man in all Hempstead Township, Long Island, was found lying on the floor of his barn in Woodsburg by one of his farm hands, Wednesday afternoon, suffering from a stroke of paralysis.
The Hon. Henry R. Pierson of Albany has written a letter in which he announces his intention to vote for President Cleveland.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18.--Llewellyn Lloyd, the gentleman rider, who was caught under the horse Zangbar while jumping a stone wall in a steeplechase on the last day of the City. Turf races at the Point Breeze track, on Tuesday, is more badly injured than was at first supposed.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 18.--Dennis Scanlan, aged 60 years, tied a stone and iron bolt around his neck yesterday and leaped into the river at high tide. His body was exposed to view at low tide and recovered. Last Winter he attempted suicide by leaping from the ferry boat in mid-river.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will say that a syndicate of New-York capitalists to-day bought from the United Gas Improvement Company a block of 21,900 share of stock of the Chicago Gas Trust Company, paying an average price of $3,875 per share. This closes out the entire United Gas Improvement Company's holdings of Chicago Gas Trust securities, and involves the sum of $848,625.

Senator Gorman and all the members of the National Democratic Campaign Committee are greatly pleased with the remarkably large registration this year, especially in the Assembly districts which always give great Democratic majorities. Gov. Hill yesterday took pains to assure everybody who called upon him that New-York would give Cleveland and Thurman a plurality of 10,000 at least.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 18.--The Louisville, Association's Fall trotting meeting began at the Driving Park to-day with a fair attendance.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 18.--The second day of the celebration of the battle of Tippecanoe at the battleground can hardly be called a success.
CHAMBERSBURG, Penn., Oct. 18.--A fatal wreck occurred on the Cumberland Valley Railroad near Shippensburg this morning.
The semi-centennial anniversary services at the East Baptist Church, Madison and Gouverneur streets, last night were of a somewhat unusual character.
Subscriptions to the Florida relief fund received at the Mayor's office yesterday amounted to $255 26.
It is interesting to housekeepers to note the result of the tests of baking powders made from time to time by the official chemists.
CASTILE, N.Y., Oct. 18.--Ex-Sherift Daniel. W. Hough, who owns a beautiful and extensive farm in this village, is out for Cleveland and Thurman.

The Electric Club in East Twenty-secondstreet last evening opened its regular lecture season. Capt. E.L. Zalinski, United States Army, was the lecturer, and his subject was "Electricity as Applied to Sea Coast Defenses."

Another very pretty Fall wedding took place yesterday in the marriage of Miss Florence M. Dickinson, daughter of A.D. Dickinson and niece of Postmaster-General Dickinson, to Frank Coit Johnson, at Bay Ridge, Long Island.
PERU, Ind., Oct. 18.--Judge Thurman and party arrived this afternoon at 1 o'clock to attend the big barbecue for which this place has been preparing for some time past.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 18.--Gov. Hill had an enthusiastic reception at Elizabeth to-night. He arrived early and was the guest of Gov. Green.
Controller Myers decided yesterday to pay Messrs. Brown, Howard Co. $224,445 65. Having deducted all the money they have received improperly for alleged extra excavation in ...
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18.--At a meeting of last year's '89 crew this week Frank E. Parker of Brookline, Mass., was re-elected Captain.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18.--Chauncey M. Depew, with the party inspecting the Vanderbilt railroads, left Chicago for St. Louis yesterday, but before departing Mr. Depew talked to an interviewer about the railroad situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--The longest session of Congress in the history of the United States will come to as end on Saturday next at 1 o'olock. This decision was reached by both houses of Congress to-day as the result of a complete back-down on the part of the Republican Senators.

Henry E. Abbey and Maurice Grau have arranged for a season of French drama and comic opera in Lodnon next year, which will be the first time in 17 years that an American manager has directed a foreign operatic company in England.
Capt. Watkins, commander of the Inman Line steamship City of New-York, which arrived yesterday, reported that his ship behaved admirably on this voyage, the machinery giving but slight trouble.
The theatre-going public of this city having failed to take kindly to "The Quick or the Dead," Miss Estelle Clayton ventured on a change of bill last evening.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 18.--The third day of the Maryland Jockey Club's Fall meeting terminated in one of the most ridiculous exhibitions of incompetency ever seen on the Pimlico track.

The certificate of association of a new bank, to be known as the Empire State Bank, and to be located on the southeast corner of Broadway and Bleecker-street, was filed yesterday in the office of the County Clerk.

One of the largest organizations of young men connected with the Protestant Episcopal Church began the sessions of its annual convention yesterday in St. George's House, on East Sixteenth-street, near Third-avenue.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 18.--The Democratic electors of the Seventeenth Congressional District, comprising the counties of Ulster, Greene, and ...

Matters ran smoother at the Guttenberg track yesterday than on the opening day. The management enforced the new rule not permitting more than ten horses to run in one race, and this prevented crowding at the post.

NEWBURG, N.Y. Oct. 18.--The widow of the Rev. John Forsyth, late Chaplain at the Military Academy, has presented over 900 volumes for the library of her husband to the city. Among them a Martin Luther Bible 325 years old.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 18.--FIRST RACE.--Selling purse, $250; $50 to second; for 3-year-olds and upward. Six furlongs. Starters--Lulu May, Helen Brooks, Blue-Eyed Belle, Superior, Mirth, Walker, Tommy R. Gilford, Quindaro Belle, Procrastinator, Stuart. Gilford won, Lulu May second, Stuart third. Time--1:22 .

The following officers were elected at the annual meeting of the Manhattan Cricket Club at Dister's late on Wednesday night: E.C. Squanne, President; H.S. Jewell, First, and C.D. Beasley, Second, Vice-President; J.G. Davis. Secretary; S. E. Hosford, Treasurer; S.J. Fisher, Captain, and Mr. Jewell, Sub-Captain. Additional members of Executive Committee--Messrs. Cobb, Coyne, Fisher, and West.

I told you a few days ago that Mlle. de Sombreuil had been arrested at Aix-les-Bains. Although the fair adventuress has been formally expelled from France, she persists in returning to this country, and yesterday she was tried at Chambery for this offense, besides the further...
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 19.--The annual inspection of the canals of the State was begun to-day by State Superintendent of Public Works...

The wet weather in Brooklyn last night had no effect in dampening the enthusiasm of the Democrats who crowded the Academy of Music to listen to speeches by Gen. Black and Gov. Hill and express their ardor for the national ticket.

It is all over. Tammany and the County Democracy have got through writing letters to one another. The Tammany rhetorician has confounded the County Democracy letter writer, and union will happen as happen it may. It happened in several Congressional districts last night, notwithstanding the independent tone of the letters that were addressed to one another by the rival Democratic organizations.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 19.--Mary Dismore has been very successful recently in robbing fashionable houses near Mount Vernon-place.
BOSTON, Oct. 19.--The Attorney-General, at the request of Insurance Commissioner Morrill, to-day obtained from Judge Field temporary injunctions against the Provident Fraternity...
WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 19.--The Baltimore and Ohio express, due here from Cincinnati this morning at 6:12 o'clock, was nearly two hours late.

It will be reassuring to friends of Cleveland and Thurman to know that Gen. Knapp, the Chairman of the Republican State Committee, one of the most exuberant of politicians, does not claim that Harrison will come to the High Bridge with more than 75,000 plurality.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 19.--Gov. David B. Hill is not only posing in the role of an exempt fireman, but he is also claiming to be a sporting man and an athlete.
Mr. Parke Godwin read a paper last night before the Reform Club on "The American Idea."

The Metropolitan Opera House was filled yesterday morning at 10 o'clock when Miss Frances E. Willard, President of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union, rose to call the fifteenth annual convention of that body to order.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 20.--"Talk about sport," said Mr. Theodore S. Hewke of New-York to a TIMES reporter in this city today; "I never had more fun or better shooting in my life than I have had for the past two weeks in the Adirondacks.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 19.--Sir John Macdonald, the Premier, indicated Canada's policy at the banquet given here last evening in honor of the Hon. J.A. Chapleau, Secretary of State.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 19.--Judge Brewer, in the United States District Court here to-day, rendered an important decision which overrules opinion given by Justice Lamar while Secretary of the Interior. He decides that the Northern Pacific Railroad Company has a second indemnity land belt.

The annual convention of the Young Men's Christian Association in the First District of New-York State began under very inauspicious conditions as regards weather at Tompkinsville, Staten Island, last evening.

FREEPORT, Ill., Oct. 19.--A heavily-loaded freight train on the Chicago, St. Paul and kansas City Road broke in two near here yesterday. An extra, which was following close behind, struck the caboose of the regular, causing a bad wreck.
The Manhattan Railway Company paid its taxes for 1887 yesterday by sending Controller Myers a check for $275,400. Included in this sum is a penalty for the non-payment of the tax when it became due.
NASSAU, New-Providence, Oct. 15.--General business is very dull. The sponge market is lively. The offerings are quite large and prices are well maintained. .

Republicans had a mass meeting last night at the rooms of the Federal Club, Fiftyninth-street and Madison-avenue, presided, over by Charles E. Bidwell, the second Vice-President of the club. The first speaker was Judge J. J. Weed of Washington, who went over briefly the questions with which the Republican Party has been confronted--slavery, resumption, and now the tariff.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19.--The games to-morrow of the Yale Athletic Association have been thrown open to other colleges and associations, and as a consequence there have been 200 entries.
Among the assets of the firm of Grant Ward were 24 one-thousand-dollar bonds of the New-York Concert Company, of an issue to the amount of $100,000 on a mortgage on the property of the company.
Yesterday saw the conclusion of the Middlesex Gun Club's tournament, all in all one of the most successful and admirably-arranged pigeon shoots ever held in this part of the country.

LONDON, Oct. 19.--The case of Mr. Dunleavy, (Nationalist,) editor of the Clare Independent, who was arrested on the charge of stealing a watch, came up for a hearing in the Limerick Sessions to-day and the charge was dismissed. CHICAGO, Oct. 23.--The case of Howard Potter against James Couch, involving the Ira Couch estate, was decided by Judge Gresham to-day. The Judge held that by the terms of Ira Couch's will there was no forfeiture or alienation by James Crouch of the letter's share in the estate, and hence James Couch's nephews and niece's were net entitled to James Crench's estate.

D., of the Rochester-Avenue Church, was the Moderator, and William H. Ingersoll was the Scribe. The number present was unusually small, but the exercises were of an interesting character.

LEXINGTON, Mo., Oct. 23.--A fire broke out in a frame shanty on Sixteenth-street early this morning. The flames spread rapidly, soon getting beyond control. The occupants, Mrs. Julia Therkeles, aged 36, and her daughter, aged 14 years, tried to save their personal effects. While they were in the house the roof fell in and both were burned to death. When found the mother's body was minus the limbs and the girl's body was headless.
POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 23.--The boiler of locomotive No. 430 of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company exploded about noon to-day at Glen Carbon.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23.--The Boart of Registration had that troublesome question, "The Student Vote," to consider to-day. Alexander Milne of the Senior Class of Thealogical School appeared shortly before 5 o'clock. He said he was born in Scotland and was 26 years old.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 23.--A memorial meeting in honor of the late Judge Julius Rockwell, who died some months ago at his home in Lenox, was held by the Berkshire Bar to-day in the Superior Court room, Chief Justice Brigham of the Superior Court presiding.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23.--The pavement in front of the sailors' lodging house 522 South Front-street was the scene of an affray shortly before 1 o'clock this afternoon, during which Peter McGuigan, a boarding house runner, was shot and killed by Henry Graff, a runner for a rival house.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 23.--Sitting Bull, John Grasse, Gaul, and the other Sioux chiefs arrived in this city this morning on their way to Standing Rock Agency from Washington.

HAVANA, Oct. 23.--A party of bandits recently visited the Maria estate, near Corraifaiso, and threatened the manager that they would kidnap his child, but after seaching his house they departed, only taking with them what money they could find.

MADRID, Oct. 23.--Senor Castelar in a a speech at a Republican banquet at Barcelona, spoke very favorably of suffrage and the postponement of military reforms in order to show the military that they must desist from interfering in politics.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 23.--Gangs of Italian and Bohemian pauper laborers left here, to-day for New-York. They refused to toll who paid their fares, but said they would remain in New-York two weeks and then sail for Europe.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Oct. 23.--A party of Union Pacific carpenters, pushing a hand car along the track 24 miles west of this city, were run down by a train in a deep cut at a sharp curve to-day. LONDON, Oct. 23.--Several thousand Yorkshire miners have gone on strike. It is expected that many others will join the strike to-morrow and Thursday on the expiration of the notices to their employers. Coal has advanced from 30 to 40 per cent. in price during October.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 24.--Mr. D.P. Morris, a well-known merchant, gave bond in a case against him, to-day, for violating the postal law Mr. Amons, a business rival, alleges that his letters to his wife fell into Morris's hands and were by him opened, Morris denies the whole story.

The unpleasant weather of the last few days prevented the Brooklyn Hill Tennis Club from resuming the tourney on its grounds in Brooklyn until yesterday afternoon.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 24.--The largest political parade ever seen in Paterson was held to-night, when 5,000 or 6,000 men, including 30 carloads from Newark, marched in procession shouting for Cleveland and Thurman and for the reduction and reform of the tariff. The line was more than a mile long, and the march was not concluded until long after midnight.

READING, Penn., Oct. 24.--There is a regular revolt among the miners in the iron ore district along the East Penn Railroad, between this city and Allentown.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 24.--Fire broke out in the large brick stables of Undertaker A. R. Rutan, on Godwin-street, in Paterson, N.J., at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24.--While Joaquin Miller was shooting quail yesterday his horse jumped unexpectedly and a bullet went through his left head. It missed the bones and only made a painful fresh wound.

Judge Dugre of the Superior Court yesterday, on application of Philip A. Morris, appointed Susan Corrigan guardian ad litem of her son, Joseph, for the purpose of bringing a suit for $5,000 damages for illegal arrest and false imprisonment against Daniel Riedemann, a baker of Greenwich-street.
LONDON, Oct. 24.--At the Newmarket Houghton meeting to-day the race for the Dewhurst Plate was won by the Duke of Portland's b.c. Donovan by half a length.
Scribner for November has at least two articles that deserve and will command wide interest--Gen. Sheridan's promised "From Gravelotte to Sedan" and the second part of Lester Wallack's reminiscences.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 24.--The fourth annual conference of Connecticut Christian Endeavor Union commenced in this city to-day. A large number of delegates representing various sections of the State were present.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 24.--This afternoon J.M. Wood, proprietor of the National Hotel, died from injuries received while separating two fighters in the billiard room last Saturday. He was about 50 years old and leaves a widow and two children. His remains were taken to-night to Whitehall, N.Y., for burial.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Oct. 24.--Mnason Huntsman, the religious crank of Park Ridge, N.J., who enticed two young girls from this place last week, has been arrested on a charge of blasphemy and lodged in the county jail. The charge is brought by Mrs. Rickers, the mother of the girls.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct 24.--Margaret Mather, whose services as a star have been the cause of considerable litigation during the past six months, opened her season here to-night in "The Honeymoon." The supporting company is the best that has ever appeared with Miss Mather.

BELGRADE, Oct. 24.--The Official Journal publishes a pastoral prepared by the Metropolitan, Theodosius, in which he says that in the exercise of his power as leader of the Servian Church, and by virtue of rights consecrated by precedents, he dissolves the marriage of King Milan and Queen Nathalie, and declares that it is no longer existent.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Oct. 24.--A deplorable accident on the Erie Railroad by which one trainman was instantly killed and four others were dangerously injured occurred early this morning in the mountain cut just west of Otisville.
NEBRASKA CITY, Neb., Oct. 24.--John Hall, a drunken laborer, attempted to beat his wife to-day when she drew a revolver and shot him through the neck. The wound may prove fatal.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 25.--It is said here that Swann Chisholm, Percy Pine, and others are preparing to oust Alexander from the Presidency of the Georgia Central and put back Ravel, now President of the Mexican Central. It also stated that the Georgia Central will abandon the extension from Eden to Americus, now under way.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 25.--Local papers are in receipt of a special dispatch from Pueblo stating that the Missouri Pacific Railroad, or Gould's Southwestern system, will, after Nov. 1, assume control of the Denver, Texas and Fort Worth line, which is valued at several millions. Officials at this point express ignorance of any such change.

PARIS, Oct. 25.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Peytral, the Minister of Finance, spoke in defense of the budget. He said it was an imperative necessity to retain the extraordinary war budget for several years longer.

The Brooklyn Young Republican Club held a meeting at the Clermont-avenue Rink last night, at which ex-United States District Attorney Tenney spoke. He advanced a few arguments on the tariff, but devoted most of his time to a fierce attack upon Mr. Cleveland for vetoing private pension bills. His audience became weary and before the address was half over hundreds had gone away.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 25.--Senators Hampton and Butler addressed an enthusiastic Democratic mass meeting here last night, deploring the spirit of apathy which seems to have overcome the party in this State, and urging a full vote for the Electoral and Congressional tickets.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 25.--The Prohibitionists of Monmouth County held a ratification meeting to-night in Educational Hall. The building was crowded, and there was much enthusiasm. John Lloyd Thomas of New-York, Secratary of the National Prohibition Bureau, and Mrs. E.A. Blair of Nebraska, were the speakers. Before the meeting there was a torchlight parade, nearly 100 voters being in line. Many of the business houses and cottages were illuminated.

Ninety-six pieces of unredeemed and unclaimed baggage were sold at auction in the office of the International Hotel, in Park-row, yesterday morning. It was a sorry-looking collection of bags, valises, and small trunks.

BOSTON, Oct. 25.--The Fitchburg Railroad falls into line with other New-England roads in passing its dividend. The Directors unanimously voted to-day to pass the next semiannual dividend. The charges and the dividends paid last year were $122,658 in excess or the net revenue. As far back as modern records go, or to 1859, Fitchburg has uninterruptedly paid dividends ranging from 9 to 5 per cent.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 25.--Intelligence from Yellville to-day says an investigation of the books of the school and county funds in the office of Treasurer M.H. Wolf, who mysteriously disappeared Sept. 23, has just been completed, and shows that no deficit exists. Wolf was Treasurer four terms, and was defeated at the recent election. The general opinion is that defeat drove him crazy, and that he is hiding in the mountains.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Oct. 25.--Mr. Garrett slept soundly last night and to-day passed the entire day out of doors and seemed much improved by the clear and bracing atmosphere. Dr. Jacobs says that Mr. Garrett is in better health and mind than at any time since he left New-York.

DETROIT, Oct. 30.--In response to numerous telegrams of inquiry it is learned that the missing Gen. Clitz arrived at the Rossia House, Toronto, Saturday night, and spent Sunday there. He is evidently wandering about in an erratic manner and without definite purpose.

Yesterday's stock market had life in it of the sort that ought to have made everybody happy. In the morning all the stocks went down; in the afternoon they all went up. They slumped in the morning (so the bulls said) because the bears were pounding them. They rose in the afternoon (so the bears said) on the covering of shorts.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 30.--The advance in lake and rail rates, west-bound, which was that announced to go into effect Oct. 26, then postponed until November, has been declared off, and there will be no advance this season.

All four of the trucks engaged in the cart-tail crusade of the Reform Club were on duty yesterday, and the work done was much more encouraging than that of Monday. The projectors feel much encouraged to continue their work through the week, as planned.

As usual political discussions are very lively in the Eighth Assembly District. The "Republicans for revenue only" who have run affairs there for years have settled their domestic differences, and are now intent on bearing down all Democrats who dare show themselves.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30.--Last night Henry Lange, a river contractor, quarreled with his sister-in-law, a Mrs. Sudbeck, and slapped her in the face.
DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 30.--The Rev. Adrien Derente, a Catholic cleryman, committed suicide here this morning by shooting himself with a pistol.

For the first time in many weeks English shippers entered the flour market yesterday. They purchased on through freight from the West and from local sources about 15,000 sacks at prices ranging from $3.60 to $4.35 per barrel for No. 2 and bakers' extras.
The annual report of Mrs. Philip J. Joachimsen, President of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society of this city, containing a resume of the work done during the year, has just been published.
In his speech at Goshen, Ind., Mr. BLAINE scoffed at the idea that the new English Salt Trust and the Michigan Salt Association would "prove rivals to each other."

"Who is Harrison, anyway?" shouted a man in the gallery of the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night as Prof. Samuel Dickie, in the course of his remarks, referred to the Republican Presidential candidate. Mr. Dickie gazed into the gallery whence the shout had proceeded, and repiled: "He's Blaine's hired man."

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 30.--In order to check any spread of scarlet fever, which has prostrated one of the Cornell University students, the authorities have obliged six other students, who roomed in the house with the patient, to leave the city at once. Strict preventive measures are being taken to confine the disease to this one case.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30.--Harry Smart was to-day found guilty of the murder of Meisner Green and Belle Ward, who were found floating in the river with their throats cut four months ago. His sentence was fixed at imprisonment for life.

Miss Matilda Grosvenor Goodridge was quietly married at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon to Mr. Gouvereur Morris Carnochan, at Springhurst, the country seat of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Goodridge, in Riverdale-on-the-Hudson.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 30.--It is reported here this evening that ex-Gov. Hoadly, now residing in New-York, has pronounced the entire four-million-dollar issue of street improvement bonds of 1885 invalid.

All the States will elect Presidential Electors by popular vote on Tuesday, Nov. 6. The Electors then chosen will meet at their respective State capitals on Monday, Jan. 14, 1889, and cast their ballots for President and Vice-President of the United States. The whole number of Electors is 401; necessary for a choice, 201.

Vandergrift, a well-known conveyancer of this city, has disappeared, taking with him various sums of money given him by friends to invest in mortgages, and said to aggregate about $15,000. Sargent to have the lease and the Lyceum Theatre property sold and the proceeds applied to the payment of bonds on which the Lyceum has refused to pay interest since February, 1887.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 31.--Rose Coghlan was received here to-night with abundant hospitality. The theatre was filled by a fashionable audience.
