The Music Hall at Orange, N.J., held last night one of the most brilliant and select audiences which that pretty suburban theatre has ever contained.

LONDON, Oct. 31.--The steamship Brooklyn City, Capt. Fitt, from New-York Oct. 16, arr. at Bristol to-day. The steamship Amsterdam. (Dutch,) Capt. Lutz, from New-York Oct. 20 for Rotterdam, passed the Lizard to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, OCt. 31.--One of the largest and most attractive church weddings of the present season took place to-night in the Fifth Baptist Church, which was crowded with a notable and brilliant assemblage of guests, including many from out of the city.

The dangerous stove as a means of heating cars will soon cease to be used on trains of the New-York Central and Hudson River Road. Already the vestibule train to Chicago and the express train to Chicago, Cincinnati, and St. Louis have been fitted with steam-heating apparatus.

Albert Waterbury of Port Washington, charged with robbing his employer, William Frieke, of $300, escaped from the Queens County Jail Tuesday night or early yesterday morning. Waterbury had been allowed to sleep with the jailer, John Quinn, and it is supposed that he got up during the night while the jailer slept, took the keys, and let himself out. Waterbury was to have been taken before Justice Morrell yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31.--Harvard defeated the Massachusetts Institute of Technology at football to-day by a score of 42 to 0. The college men outplayed their opponents at every point and won almost with hands down. Thirtysix points were scored in the first half hour and the other six were made in the first five minutes of the second half, when time was ended on ac count of darknees.

The consecration of the new memorial chapel of the Good Shepherd of the General Theological Seminary of the Episcopal Church, in Chelsea-square, attracted a large number of clergy and Alumni of the church yesterday morning. PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 31.--The finest political parade ever seen in this town was made by the Democrats to-night. Over 2,500 men were in line, comprising besides the local organizations, delegations from Trenton, Newark, Elizabeth, Westfield, and Somerville. A prominent feature of the procession was a stageload of Jacksonian Democrats who cast their first ballots in 1828. The town is fairly ablaze with illuminations and brilliant fireworks.

Chief Engineer Church reported to the Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday that the new aqueduct will be completed to its connection with the mains at Tenth-avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street by July 1, 1889, and to the Central Park Reservoir six months later.

Constable, will submit a report to the Chamber at its meeting to-day on the location of the new Appraisers' store authorized by the recent act of Congress. NEWARK, Ohio, Oct. 31.--The train carrying Judge Thurman and party had a quiet trip until Zanesville was reached. Several hundred people were at the station with a band to greet the Judge and accompany him to this city.

The annual report of the Directors of the Connecticut River, as approved at a meeting of the Directors in Springfield, Mass., yesterday afternoon, shows that the total income for the year was $1,035,669, against $973,207 last year. The current operating expenses have been $649,055, and for construction and equipment $238,707 has been expended.

O'Shea as a witness, as that gentleman wanted to go immediately to Spain. Sir Charles Russell, counsel for the Parnellites, declined to cross-examine Capt. O'Shea at the present point. Dr. Samuel H. Linn, son of a Rochester policeman, is a prominent dentist having offices at St. Petersburg and Paris. In 1867 he married Amella Linn in Philadelphia, and after living with her for 10 years in various parts of the world left her in the same city. His wife sought for him everywhere in vain, and finally opened a boarding house in Paris in order to support herself and child.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 31.--News has just been received here of a cold-blooded murder committed near Mount Pleasant, Monroe County, in this State. John Williams, returning home, found his house locked and his wife absent.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 31.--A curious breach of promise suit was tried here today. Miss Henrietta C. Brandt and Frederick William Koening, Jr., were engaged, and after the invitations for their marriage were out they discussed the question of the ceremony. Moss Brandt, desired a brilliant reception; Mr. Koenig objected. A quarrel ensued and the engagement was broken. Not long afterward Koenig married another girl. The jury to-day gave Miss Brandt $500 damages.

Nilsson Hall, in Fifteenth-street, held a large military audience last evening. The soldiers gathered to give expression to their belief and trust in President Cleveland as a man and in his Administration.

Sheftel Zutick was arrested last night for robbing the Jewish synagogue at 254 Broome-street. He was caught coming out of the buildng, which had been broken into, with a bundle containing $200 worth of articles. The police have had several complaints about burglaries in the synagogue.

The Pope has received jubilee gifts of money to the amount of 1,150,000. France has been the most liberal donor of cash, (the monks of the Chartreuse sent 20,000,) while the smallest offerings came from Spain, Portugal, and Poland.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov 1.--Fred J. Marcy Co., Jewelers, made an assignment this morning. The assets are $35,000 and the liabilities $65,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1.--The Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad to-day declared a dividend of 2 per cent. to the shareholders. This is the same as was declared in last May, making a 5 per cent. dividend for the year.

WATERLOO, N.Y., Nov. 1.--Bishop McQuade confirmed a very large number of children in St. Mary's Church to-day, and consecrated the Catholic cemetery. The Bishop informed the congregation most emphatically that Father Hic key was the permanent Rector of St. Mary's Church until he appointed him to another position.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 1.--The execution of the threat by some of the orthodox ministers to bring President Northrup and other members of the University Faculty to task for allowing Dr. Simmons, a Unitarian, to lecture before the students on Sunday seems likely to be indefinitely postponed.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 1.--For a year past George H. Vanderbilt has been buying real estate in Western North Carolina. He likes the climate of Asheville, believes in its future, and, like his grandfather, the veteran Commodore, has an eye to business.
The 21st of October was the eightieth birthday of the Rev. S.F. Smith, D.D., our Nation's poet. Such an event could not pass without special notice by his more intimate friends.

An extraordinary suicide has just occurred at a village near Angers. A peasant named Bordereau was working in a field with his wife and his brother-in-law when a trifling dispute took place. Bordereau left the field and returned to his cottage, whither his wife soon followed him.

QUEENSTOWN, Nov. 1.--The Guion Line steamship Wyoming, Capt. Rigby, from New-York Oct. 23, arr. here at 10 P.M. to-day on her was to Liverpool. LONDON, Nov. 2.--The steamship Duke of Buckingham, (Br.,) Capt. Burnside, from Java for NewYork, passed Perim yesterday.

NORWICH, Conn., Nov. 1.--Mr. Blaine, accompanied by Gen. Adam E. King of Baltimore, arrived from New-York by special train at about noon. He was driven to Washington-square, in the centre of the city, accompanied by the Reception Committee, headed by the Hon. John T. Wait and the Hon. H.H. Osgood.

BOSTON, Nov. 1.--A cable message in the Science Observer Code, received to-day from the European Union of Astronomers, announces the discovery of an asteroid (No. 281) of the twelfth magnitude by Dr. Pallisa of Vienna. The discovery position is the following: Oct. 31, .5165 Greenwich mean time, right ascension 2 hours 2 minutes 46 seconds; declination north 13 degrees; right ascension 17 minutes; in declination south 1 minute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1.--The Sisters of the Academy of the Visitation were started last night just as they were about retiring by the loud noise of an explosion which rattled the window frames but did no damage.

LONDON, Nov. 1.--The news of Lord Sackville's summary dismissal has revived interest in the affair over here at a leap, and to-day a very angry tone is perceptible, not only in the Ministerial papers but in general conversation.

There was an old-fashioned rally in Tammany Hall last night. The hall was not large enough to hold the crowds that swarmed to it. When the big hall was packed, as it has been many times before, two outdoor meetings were organized for the entertainment and instruction of the overflow which extended the width of the broad thoroughfare.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1.--Michael Quinn, while making a water pipe connection to-day, was buried by the caving in of the sides of the ditch in which he was at work. He was nearly rescued, when a second slide buried him so deep that before he could be dug out he was smothered to death.

HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 1.--The Democrats of Columbia County at their convention decided that it was inexpedient to nominate a candidate for Assembly. Consequently Mr. William Dinehart, the Republican candidate, like Congressman Ketcham, will have a "walk-over."

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 1.--Edward Hugh Mackenzie, who sprang into notoriety recently as an heir to unto d wealth and married Miss Johnson, a farmer's daughter, on the strength of the claim, has been lodged in the Somerset County jail, charged with obtaining goods under false pretenses. His wife has gone to the county poorhouse.

Ex-Supervisor Christopher Larkin of the Fourth Ward, Brooklyn, resigned from the Republican Ward Association last night because he finds himself compelled, by principle, to vote for Cleveland and reform. He has been a Republican all his life, but the platform of the Chicago Convention was too much for him.

The New-York City Women's Suffrage League held its first regular meeting of the season last night at 4 Lexington-avenue. Lillie Devereux Blake presided, and during the evening delivered an interesting talk entitled, "A Trip to the Pacific." Dr. Thomas Lozier presented to the league a handsome bust of his mother, the late Mrs. Dr. Clemence Lozier, at one time President of the organization.
We are informed that a careful canvass of the famous town of Hull shows a majority of two to one for Cleveland and Thurman. This settles it.

The wheat market almost went to pieces again yesterday. Soon after the opening a strong bearish feeling became manifest, and it lasted all day. The causes were expected freer arrivals at Northwestern points and heavy realizing by Chicago.

The citizens of New-York cheered the Hon. Abram S. Hewitt last night in Chickering Hall until the shingles on the roof rattled with the force of the accumulated enthusiasm. The occasion was a mass meeting without partisan complexion to further the re-election of Mr. Hewitt to the Mayoralty, and the hall was filled to the doors.

William Allen Butler yesterday finished his cross-examination of James E. Bedell, who was again brought into Supreme Court, Chambers, to continue his testimony in regard to his fraudulent transactions while the trusted employe of Shipman, Barlow, Larocque Choate. One more hearing will be had next Thursday to give counsel an opportunity to clear up all loose ends.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1.--In his annual report to the Secretary of War, Gen. Benet, Chief of Ordnance, says that the bureau expended $1,507,382 during the last fiscal year, and that 41,130 rifies and carbines were manufactured at the national armory.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 1.--The race between the steam yachts Nymph and Dolphin, owned respectively by Dr. Seward Webb and Major W. Boeram Wetmore, was sailed to-day before numerous spectators. The race was over a course six and a half miles long, and was won by the Dolphin in 34:08, beating the Nymph 32 seconds.

The stock market went through another day of dullness yesterday, scoring few changes of any interest. There was strength of a gentle maidenly kind shown in some directions. Trusts continued the bull stars. Chicago Gas Trust certificates and Cottonseed Oil Trust certificates boomed. The Chicago gas buoyancy was due largely to the pretty well supported report that that trust will begin to pay dividends within the next 90 days.

That conundrum is. "What shall I call it?"

The attendance at the opening of the half-mile running meeting at Waverly was not very large, it numbering probably 1,200 people. There were only seven bookmakers present, and the betting space was very limited. The track was in excellent condition and the racing fairly good.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2.--The Cushman Telephone Company filed a petition in the United States Circuit Court to-day for a rehearing of the case of the Bell Telephone Company against it, which was decided by Judge Blodgett last July in favor of the Bell Company.

The Kings County Democrats will parade to-night for the last time in the present campaign. They have exerted themselves, and the result promises to be one of the finest political parades Brooklyn has ever seen.

Capt. Muller of the German steamer Sorrento, which arrived yesterday from Hamburg, reports that his vessel and the 315 steerage passengers who were on board were pretty thoroughly shaken up on the way over.

JACKSON, Minn., Nov. 2.--A prairie fire raged yesterday in the Sioux Valley, in Jackson Township. Henry Ray was burned so badly he cannot live. A 4-weeks' old baby, a 16-year-old girl named Mollie o'Connor, and a wowan and her son, name unknown, were burned to death.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio., Nov. 2.--At 12:30 this morning Gen. Asa S. Bushnell, who was the central figure in the Republican demonstration held here last evening, was assaulted by a gang of roughs, as he was going home, and badly injured.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2.--Col. W. H. Stevens, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee of Delaware, was at the Girard House to-day. CHICAGO, Nov. 2.--The dethroned lead king, Nathan Corwith, and his son, Gurden S., are defendants in an assumsit suit for $200,000 brought this afternoon in the Superior Court.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 2.--According to returns received by the Department of Agriculture over 200 Mormons have emigrated from Utah to the Canadian Northwest during the past season. The settlements already established south of the Canadian Pacific Railway are thriving. The Mormons cannot take up land before agreeing to abandon the practice of polygamy. They are devoting themselves to cattle raising.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 2.--To-night, at Knoxville, about 1,000 men and boys indulged in a Mother Hubbard parade in honor of Belva Lockwood. The demonstration was the most notable one of the campaign in Tennessee.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 3.--James O'Connors, a section boss, and Patrick Kinney, a laborer, were struck and instantly killed by a Philadelphia express train on the Central Railroad at Divisionstreet, Elizabeth, this morning. BELVIDERE, N.J., Nov. 3.--The Catholic church at Stanhope was entered by thieves a night or two since. It was robbed of all the sacred vessels, several hundred dollars' worth in all. The residence of Hugh O. Allen was entered the same night, and $200 worth of sold silverware was stolen.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 3.--The registration in this city closed at 9 o'clock last night with a registration of 28,000. Yesterday, on affidavits prepared by a Citizens' Committee, a total of 2,339 names were removed from the lists, including those of voters who have died or removed.

OLD ORCHARD Me., Nov. 3.--Burglars entered the Post Office here early this morning. They blew open the sale and stole cash and postage stamps amounting to $500. The Italians derive star board from questa borda, "this side," and larboard from quella borda, "that side," abreviated into sta borda and la borda. Their resemblance caused so many mistakes that, by order of the Admiralty, larboard is now thrown overboard and port substituted. "Port the helm" is even mentioned in Arthur Pit's voyage in 1580.--Smyth's Sailor's Word Book.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5.--William Courtenay, brakeman on the Shenanadoah Valley Railroad, last night while running to catch a train, in order to return to his home at Marksville, Va., to vote, fell from a bridge near Hagerstown and received injuries from which he died this morning.

TRINIDAD, Col., Nov. 5.--An explosion occurred at Starkville coal mines at 5 o'clock this morning. Two miners were killed and the mine badly wrecked. The bodies have not yet been dug out. Had the explosion occurred an hour later at least 50 men would have perished. The explosion is thought to have been caused by natural gas coming from the earth into the mine.

The campaign of 1888 is finished. The Democratic State Committe announces to the supporters of the cause of Democracy and of Cleveland and Thurman, Hill amd Jones that victors has perched upon their banners.
Steamship Horrox, (Belg.,) Rendle, Rio Janeiro 22 ds., with coffee to order--vessel to Busk Jevons. Arrived at the bar at 7:40 P.M.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 5.--The Teachers' Institute of Monmouth and Ocean Counties will be held at Educational Hall, Asbury Park, Thursday and Friday, Nov. 8 and 9. This is the programme announced: Thursday--Address, ...
MONTREAL, Nov. 5.--Jack Kehoe to-day was found guilty of the murder of Thomas Donnelly and was sentenced to be hanged on the 14th of December.

The New-York Academy of Anthropology held an unusually interesting meeting, yesterday afternoon at its rooms in the Cooper Union. The following members were elected: Dr. F.G. Welch, Dr. B.F. Dexter, Albert Day, Dr. J.W. Bartlett, Miss Ada Schwab, Paul C. Browneman, Miss Fannie L. Strouss, H.M. Requa, C. Geroge W. Busteed.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 5.--Buck Trexler, general merchants, of Crawfordsville, Ark., have failed. Liabilities, $100,000; assets, $90,000, principally in accounts.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 5.--An Italian named Prospero was probably murdered in North Adams yesterday. He was last seen going toward the agricultural fair grounds in company with Patrick Shea. As he did not return, his friends searched for him and found his ...
The Columbia College Trustees at their regular monthly meeting yesterday elected Harry Thurston Peck Professor of Latin to fill the vacancy caused two years ago by the death of Prof. Short.
Elder Evans is said to be the head of the Shaker family, although we always supposed that Chills and Fever occupied that position.-- Boston Bulletin.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 5.--The weather and track were good to-day. A fair crowd witnessed the racing. Most of the favorites got in their work. There will be no races to-morrow on account of the election, and there are no entries to-night. Following were to-day's events:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5.--Last night Mme. Cottrelly appeared at Baldwin's Theatre for the fourth time in her San Francisco engagement, presenting the very amusing play of "Twenty Thousand Marks Reward" before ...
NICE, Nov. 5.--The King of Wurtemberg is much irritated over the newspaper reports charging that he was under the influence of three Americans, whom he had made his favorites.

The Board of Managers of the New-York Home for Convalescents held their annual meeting in the parlors of the home, 433 East One Hundred and Eighteenth-street, yesterday morning, and after listening to the reports of ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 5.--Frank Day, a young Canadian, was stabbed and killed at the corner of Clark and Jackson streets at midnight by an unknown man who is still at large. Day with two friends was on his way to the Bolk-street station.

In several of the headquarters of the Labor Party in this city and in Brooklyn, along with the names of the Labor candidates for President, , there appears this inscription: "For Governor, the Candidate of Ballot Reform." This is very significant and very hopeful.
DES MONIES, Iowa, Nov. 5.--The parents of Miss Ada May Thompson, a girl of 16 years, living in South Des Moines, were startled about 10 o'clock last night by a pistol shot in the kitchen.

A rumor was in circulation that the steamship Saginaw, which cleared Saturday and sailed yesterday afternoon for San Domingo City and other ports in Hayti, had certain arms and other contraband goods on board. Color was given to the rumor by the fact that the steamer came to off the Lightship and remained all the afternoon, but at 6 P.M. she ...

The old feeling that it was hardly safe for ladies to appear in the streets on election day is rapidly passing away, and as the fair sex become more and morn brave on this point theatrical managers are falling into the notion of giving special matinees on election day.

Zachariah Mead, a banker of Wall-street, living at 174 Lee-avenue, Brooklyn, was found in the tunnel at Fourth-avenue and Thirtyeight-street last night with two cuts on the nose and other injuries about the head. He had checks and notes on him representing $15,000. Herman Flammer, conductor on a Fourthavenue car, said he fell off the car and so received, his injuries. He was taken home.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 5.--Gen. J. Rowman Sweitzer, Prothonotary of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court for the last 15 years, is dying at his home in this city of blood poisoning.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 5.--The political situation in this part of the State is difficult to define. The most exciting campaign ever known in this city has closed, and both parties are hopeful.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5.--The Harvard University Athletic Association held its postponed meeting on Holmes's Field to-day. The events and winners were as follows: Trial heats in 100 yards' dash were won by O.K. Howes, ...
A good programme of six races is announced for to-day at Guttenberg. The entries are as follow:

The failure of W.V. Caroline, a prominent member of the Stock Exchange, was announced yesterday. The liabilities are not large. Mr. Caroline said yesterday that his creditors had been very kind and he thought he would soon be able to resume.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5.--Drafts--Sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.
LOCK HAVEN, Penn., Nov. 5.--An inquest was held this afternoon by the Coroner of this county on the bodies of the 17 victims of the Kettle Creek mine explosion.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 5.--William Walls, the special organizer and lecturer of the Knights of Labor, returned from the East to-day, where he had been for the past 10 days.
The following table shows the pluralities in the several counties of this State for Governor, compared with the pluralities given for Governor in 1885:

BOSTON, Nov. 6.--The fishing schooner Goldsmith Maid, Capt. Hines, returning from a voyage to the Middle Bank with 30,000 pounds of fresh fish, was run into and sunk in Boston Harbor last night by the steamer Glaucus of the Metropolitan...

The Berkeley bicycle race meeting, which had been twice postponed, was held yesterday on the Berkeley grounds at Morris Dock. It was well attended, but the track was not in first-rate condition, and the management was poor.

J.M. and A.B. Jones, while shooting on the farm of G.O. Massey near Chesapeake City, Md., yesterday gathered about a quart of fine ripe strawberries of the May King variety. The berries are quite large, perfectly developed.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 6.--Pennsylvania has given a tremendous Republican majorty, is being placed at midnight, from official figures and reasonable estimates, at at least 80,000.
The wealth and fashion of New-York turned out in full force at the Horse Show yesterday both in the afternoon and evening.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 6.--Colorado has been carried by the Republicans by from 8,000 to 15,000 plurality. Every Repulican on the State ticket has been elected, and Hosea Townsend (Rep.) has been elected to Congress.
CHATHAM, N.Y., Nov. 6.--Andrew S. Ford was this morning acquitted of the charge of poisoning his wife. It was his second trial.
The following is a list of members elected to the House of Representatives of the Fiftyfirst Congress, according to the latest returns.
It was an unusually quiet day at Police Headquarters yesterday, for a day of a general election, and up to the time the polls closed not a single disturbance of any kind had been reported.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 6.--Returns show that a light vote has been polled in nearly every part of the State. The majority for Cleveland is estimated at 20,000, as against 22,000 in 1884.

Since GOETHE puzzled his readers with a theory of colors which no man of science has indorsed, the effect of bright hues upon human beings, animals and plants has been studied to little profit. GOETHE held that there were only two pure colors, blue and yellow.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 6.--Returns from 66 percincts indicate a plurality for the Republican ticket not much less than the Republican majority in June, but 430 precincts are still to be heard from. Republicans had conceded that the vote of their party would scarcely exceed that of 1884.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 8.--All the returns are not in, but everything points to a majority of 45,000 for Cleveland.
The Guttenberg track had its share of the holiday race-going patronage, and a crowd numbering fully 3,000 was present. The racing was good, but the same cannot be said of the starter's work.
LONDON, Nov. 6.--This was the first day of the Liverpool Autumn meeting. The race for the Knowsley Nursery Stakes of 500 sovereigns, was won by Capt. L.H. Jones' b.c.
LONDON, Nov. 6.--Henry Arthur Bloke Governor and Commander-in-Chief of Newfoundland, has been promoted to Knight Commander of St. Michael and St. George.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 6.--The farmers' deliveries of wheat in the country have fallen off about as last as they increased last week. Reports of counry buyers Saturday show that on the St. Paul line the average receipts were only about two-thirds as much as they were in the middle of the week.
MONTPELIER, Nov. 6.--Montpelier's vote is as follows: Harrison, 593; Cleveland, 316; Fisk, 9. The Republicans lose 66 from the September vote, and the Democrats gain 14; the Prohibitionists gain 2.
JACKSONVILLE, Nov. 6.--President Neal's official bulletin for the 24 hours ending at 6 o'clock: New cases, 26; death, 1. Total number of cases to date, 4,342; total number of deaths, 367.
One of the intercollegiate championship series of football games was placed at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon by the teams of Princeton College and Wesleyan University.

The Manhattan Athletic Club's Fall games at Eighty-sixth-street and Eighth-avenue attracted a fair attendance yesterday. The first heat in the 100 yards' dash was a tie between Copland and Westing in 0:10 2-5, the former having two yards the start.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 6.--Returns from Maryland incomplete. They indicate that the State has gone Democratic by at least 10,000 majority.
LONDON, Nov. 6.--The papers in the Sackville case were made public this evening. The first is a letter from Lord Salisbury to Lord Sackville and is dated Oct. 27.

The vote cast in this city yesterday reached the aggregate of 271,221 out of a total registration of 286,640. Of the votes polled the number for the Democratic Presidential Electors was 162,710, and for the Republican, 105,653.
The following table shows the pluralities in the several counties of this State for President compared with the pluralities of four years ago:

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 6.--Returns from the Fouth District, which is usually overwhelming Republican, show large Democratic gains. Venable (Dem.) is almost surely elected over Mahone's candidate, Arnold, and Langston, colored Republican.
HARTFORD, Nov. 7.--Connecticut will surely go for Cleveland, though it will be a tight fight. The total vote now in gives Cleveland 66,791, and Harrison 66,017.
The next Assembly will consist of 81 Republicans and 47 Democrats. The senate, which holds over another year, contains 21 Republicans and 11 Democrats.

Forty-one of the forty-six students of the Union Theological Seminary who registered in the Twenty-first Election District of the Twenty-first Assembly District marched to the polling place yesterday in groups of 10 and deposited their ballots.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 6.--The returns from the State are very slow in coming in, but the indications are that the Cleveland Electors in Missouri have a plurality of 30,000.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 6.--The election in this State passed off very quietly and an immense vote was polled everywhere. Returns, however, come in very slowly, a fact due entirely to the manner of counting ballots.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 6.--Cleveland and reform have swept the State by over 3,000 majority. Meagre returns indicate that Cleveland has carried the city by about 700 majority and New-Castle County by about 1,300.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 6.--A dispatch from Winnipeg, Manitoba of to-day says: "This morning Inspector McGibbon and 14 mounted police left for points in Southern Manitoba, where some detachments will be...

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 6.--The weather was very fine, and indications are that the vote cast is the largest ever polled in the State. The Legislature to be elected will elect a United States Senator to succeed Ransom.
David Hostetter, widely known as a mill-- ionaire and a manufacturer of patent medicines, died Monday at the Park-Avenue Hotel, aged 69 years.

CONCORD, Nov. 6.--Returns from 150 towns and wards indicate a plurality for Harrison in the State of about 2,000. Goodell, the Republican candidate for Governor, falls behind largely, but has a small majority, about 300, over all in the returns thus far received, and is probably elected by the popular vote.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 6.--Returns from the State are much delayed because of the multiplicity of candidates. There are State, county, and Legislative tickets in the field.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 6.--Indications point to Cleveland's majority in Mississippi at from 30,000 to 40,000. It will not be under these figures and may exceed them. The Democrats, according to latest telegrams, elect all their Congressmen.
At the hour of writing, the returns of the national election are not entirely conclusive. This State is very close, with the result doubtful.

The first Wednesday matinee of the Madison-Square Theatre will take place on Nov. 21, on which occasion the comic play of "Kerry" and the drama "Hunted Down" will be performed. Between these plays will be introduced a selection from "Kind John."
MONTREAL, Nov. 6.--The Coquelin-Hading combination opened here Monday night at the Academy of Music to a crowded house.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6.--Intense excitement prevails in all sections of the city to-night. Great crowds surround every bulletin board, and the newspaper bureaus are packed with men eager to get the latest news.

The United States revenue marine steamer Hugh McCulloch, Capt. John C. Mitchell, for the last seven years on the Charleston (S.C.) station, arrived here yesterday morning and will await orders from the Treasury Department to put her out of commission and permanently withdraw her from the Revenue arine Service.
WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Nov. 6.--Adam Hart resides on a farm in Clinton Township, this county. He is over 100 years of age, having celebrated the centenniary of his birth on the 6th of May of this year.

Election day in this city proved warm and pleasant as to weather. Crowds thronged the streets, business was generally suspended, and the city had a holiday appearance, except immediately around the polling places.

The attempt being made under English auspices to tap the trade of Siberia by the water route of the Kara sea and the Yenisei has suggested to several Russian authorities interested in that province alternative schemes...
ST. PAUL, Nov. 6.--Returns from the interior of the State are coming in very slowly, but the indications are that Harrison's majority will exceed 20,000.

At the National Democratic Headquarters yesterday all was peaceful. Nobody of the magnates was present except Col. Brice. Senator Gorman and B.B. smalley of Vermont, who was visiting him, staid at the Fifth-Avenue and received messages every minute.
The crowd of people that swarmed to the Clifton track yesterday was beyond doubt the largest ever attracted there, and good as the accommodations are, they were inadequate.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 6.--The polls opened here in a pouring rain which lasted till 8 o'clock, but the clouds hung heavy and threatening all day.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6.--A large vote has been cast in this city, which has probaly gone Democratic by 2,000 majority, although nothing positive can be known of the result for some hours.

There is every reason to relieve that the Clyde Line steamship Saginaw, which cleared from this port Monday for San Dimingo, did not, as was yesterday reported, have on board any contraband goods for Hayti or for any other port.
COLUMBUS, Nov. 6.--The election in Ohio to-day was for Secretary of State, Supreme Court Judge, and member of the Board of Public Works. The best of order generally prevailed throughout the State.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 6.--Treasury Department statistics show the total exportations of the fiscal year ending June last to be $48,885,908, which is within a fraction of the exportations of the previous fiscal year.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 6.--A man answering Tascott's description has been seen at Selkirk, Manitoba, where he arrived recently from the Lake Winnipeg fisheries. Chief McRae of the Winnipeg police is investigating the case.
The wisdom of the managers who decided to give special matinees at their theatres yesterday was amply justified by the result of their ventures.
William F. Peers, a Brooklyn printer, was shot and dangerously wounded, yesterday afternoon by Daniel Harrington, a Sixth Ward ruffian, during a row at the corner of Pearl and Centre streets.
HUGH J.GRANT, the Tammany candidate, has been elected to the office of Mayor of this city.

TYLER, Texas, Nov. 6.--Accurate information of the vote of Texas cannot be ascertained at this early hour, but it appears from information thus far received by me that Cleveland's majority in 1884 of 132,000 has been considerably increased.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 6.--It is impossible to state the results of the election in Alabama to-day further than that the State has rolled up a big majority for Cleveland and...

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 6.--On the morning of Jan. 1, this year, in the heat of a political campaign, while drinking in a barroom, the Hon. Patrick Mealey, Commissioner of Police and one of the principal adherents of Gov. Nicholls, was assassinated by some partisans of the other wing of the Democracy.
The North German Gazette publishes tonight a long article dealing with the relations between the Emperor William I. and the Emperor Frederick.

The crowd that filled Madison-Square Garden last night, in spite of the universal interest in the election, gave an impressive demonstration of the enlightened curiosity of the public concerning horses.
DETRIOT, Nov. 7.--Michigan has gone Republican on President by a plurality apparently not far from that of 1886. The total vote is very much larger than it was in 1884.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 6.--Arthur Haywood, aged 19, while driving a milk wagon across the New-York Central tracks here this morning became excited by the approach of a freight train and jumped from the wagon. His foot caught in one of the wheels, and he was thrown under the cars and killed.

LOS ANGELES, C.I., Nov. 6.--The Evening Express of this city publishes a statement this afternoon in which it says that the real name in of the author or the Murchison letter, sent to Minister West, is Francis G. Haley, and that...
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 6.--Cleveland's estimated majority in this State is between 30,000 and 40,000. Democrats will elect five of the six Congressmen without serious opposition.

Banker to his dude offspring-When I was your age I went to work at 7 in the morning and worked till 7 at night for $2 a week, and never had a sick day, and I didn't look like a dried up, yellow dyspeptic, as you do.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6.--A dispatch from San Francisco says: "A desperate fight occurred in a disrepatable Chinese house yesterday between the proprietor and a gang of highbinders who attempted to rob the place.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 6.--New-Jersey promises at 2 o'clock this morning on returns here from one-third of the State to return the Cleveland Electoral ticket by about 5,000 plurality.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 6.--From Western man prominently identified with the cable railway systems of the great cities information is obtained to-night that Elkins and Widener, having...

The returns of the national election are still far from complete, but the latest reports justify the hope that Cleveland and Thurman have received the Electoral votes of a sufficient number of States to continue for four years more the control of the Democratic Party in the Administration.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 6.--Kansas election returns are coming in very slowly. At this hour 11:30 P.M., estimates based upon reports received by the Republican and Democratic State central Committees give Harrison a plurality of 65,000 over Cleveland, Streator, and Fisk, and a majority of 40,000.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 6.--The city's vote is light. Slight news comes from the State Fleming (Dem.) is elected Governor. In the second District probably a Republican is elected in place of Dougherty, (Dem.)

LONDON, Nov. 6.--The Parnell Commission met again to-day. Mr. Parnell was present. The first witness called was Mr. Ives, a New-- York correspondent, who testified that he obtained an interview with Mr. Parnell, which was published on Jan. 2, 1880. Several witnesses gave testimony in relatian to outrages.

LONDON, Nov.6.--Parliament re-assembled to-day. In the House of Lords Lord Salisbury stated, in response to an inquiry, that papers relating to the Sackville affair would be issued by the Government to-morrow.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 6.--The State gives the usual Democratic majority for the national ticket.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 6.--Rochester complete shows Democratic gain of 249 over 1884.

At the present writing the returns at hand indicate that Gov. HILL is re-elected by a very slender plurality. Whether this is the result of treachery to the national ticket on the part of his friends it is too soon to judge, for the evidence has not come to the surface.

The managers of the Waverly track did not meet with much encouragement yesterday. Although it was a holiday, the crowd did not number over 400 people, and they were mostly from the adjacent towns. The racing was fairly good.
ALBANY, Nov. 6.--Gov. Hill fears that he is defeated. He received special and regular dispatches by direct wires in the Executive Chamber to-night.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 6.--The vote in the cities and towns of Iowa to-day is unprecedented and great interest is manifested over the State ticket, the fight on Railroad Commissioners being especially sharp.
WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 6.--Partial counts of precincts in this city allow that Pendleton (Dem.,) for Congress, will carry the county by 400, and is probably elected.

"Greenwich."--Send to the Mayor of Jacksonville. The Society of Medical Jurisprudence and State Medicine will most at 12 West Thirtyfirst-street to-morrow evening. Protective legislation relative to tuberculosis and typhoid fever will be one of the topics of discussion.
The swindler Prado, who, since his arrest, has been enarged with the murder of Marie Aguetin, will, it is announced, be tried early in November.

The second competition for the Kilpatrick Challenge Bronze occured yesterday from the residence of J.H. Reed at King's Bridge over a cross-country course of five miles. There was a large attendance on foot and in carriages.

The football teams of Yale University and the Crescent Athletic Club played a very interesting match at Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. Nearly 1,500 spectators were present, and their expectations of seeing a fine game were not disappointed.

Notwithstanding the widespread reports to the contrary and the wholesale issue of warrants for the arrest of illegal voters yesterday's election in King's County passed off without unusual excitement.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6.--Election returns from all parts of Illinois are coming in very slowly. From what have been received up to 11 o'clock, the national ticket is in doubt, while Gen. Palmer...
The blood which was expected to flow freely at Gravesend yesterday was not spilled, and the broken heads that were looked for were found wanting.
Two trains on the Brooklyn Union Elevated Railroad came in collision last night at the crossing of the newly-opened branch with the main road at Myrtle and Hudson avenues.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 6.--Harrison carries the State by something over 4,000 plurality in the largest vote ever cast. The vote which will be affected by less than 100 by corrected returns is as follows: Harrison, 21,968; Cleveland, 17,496; Fisk, 1,276. Blaine's plurality was over 6,000. The city of Providence gives Harrison 6,903, Cleveland 6,495. Fisk 489.
F.H. Knowlton, one of the curators at the National Museum, read a paper before the Biological Society last night on the fossil woods and lignites of the Potomac formation.
VIRGINIA CITY, Nov. 6.--It is likely that Harrison has carried Nevada by a reduced majority. The Democrats have elected the Supreme Court Judge and probably the Congressman.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 6.--There was nothing to disturb the election in this State to-day. Voting was light and will not exceed 90,000.
BANGOR, Nov. 6.--Returns from towns in Maine come in slowly, but all received to this time indicate a Republican plurality of 23,000, a gain of nearly 5,000 over the September election.
There are 401 members in the Electoral College, and a Presidential candidate in order to be elected must receive a majority of the whole number, or 201.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6.--Henry Koehler last night, While suffering from delirlum tremens, threw himself into the North Branch of the river. His wife, Garoline, tried to drag her husband out and was herself dragged into river. Before help came both were drowned.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 7.--Last night the steamer Rhode Island Left Stonington for New-York with an unusually large cargo on board.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 7.--The Presidential and Gubernatorial returns come in slowly. It is now believed by the Democratic managers that Cleveland will have a majority of 20,000, and Taylor, candidate for Governor, a majority of from 14,000 to 17,000.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 7.--The annual meeting of the Iron Steamboat Company of NewYork, which is incorporated under the laws of New-Jersey, was held in Long Branch to-day. The company has 200,000 shares of stock.
Steamship Halley, (Br.,) Hoit, Santos and Rio Janeiro 37 ds., with mdse, to Busk Jevons. Arrived at the Bar at 5:30 P.M.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 7.--Returns have been received from every county in Kansas. An estimate by Chairman Booth from there ports received gives Harrison 70,000 majority over Cleveland and 65,000 for the entire Republican State ticket.
The comic New Testament and burlesque Bible which offend the eye on the bookstalls in the streets of Paris have now a rival on the Parisian stage.
BOSTON, Nov. 7.--All but two towns in the State have been heard from and they give Harrison 183,447; Cleveland, 151,990, and Fisk, 8,641.

Prof. Drisler, Acting President of Columbia College, yesterday morning announced in chapel that the long interregnum in the Latin department, caused by the death of Prof. Charles Short in December, 1886, was at last filled by Harry T. Peck, ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 7.--Returns come in slowly, and very few counties are completed, but enough is known to justify the prediction that Harrison will have 20,000 to 25,000 plurality, and Merriam (Rep.) for Governor about 10,000 plurality.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7.--Official returns have been received from only a few counties. Careful estimates have been made of the vote elsewhere, and according to these figures Harrison's plurality in the State will be about 71,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 7.--President Corbin arrived at the Reading Railroad office today. He is preparing a reply to the committee of the Board of Trade, which will state in unequivocal terms the position of the Reading in regard to the elevated and terminal tracks.
COLUMBUS, Nov. 7.--Judge Thurman was called upon this evening by your correspondent and found in one of his happiest moods.

DETROIT, Nov. 7.--Returns from the State are so slow and conflicting that it is impossible to give precise returns. No Congressional district in the State has yet returned all precincts, and many that have been reported are disputed.

Attending the horse show is now quite the correct thing in fashionable circles. Ladies and gentlemen crowded into Madison-Square Garden yesterday afternoon and remained there until the time for recess arrived. Then they went home, had luncheon, and returned in evening dress for the gas light session.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 7.--The workmen on the Colina Railroad having become dissatisfied with their wages have gone on strike. All work is suspended.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 7.--Clarence McPherson was thrown out of a wagon yesterday and had both bones of his right wrist broken. A few weeks ago, on his twenty-first birthday, he lost his left arm by a buzz saw. He is now entirely helpless.
The New-York Horticultural Society will this afternoon open a chrysanthemum show at the northwest corner of Fourteenth-street and Broadway.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 7.--Gen. Harrison has been quietly at home all day, and to all appearances is, and has been, the least disturbed person in the house. The weather has been very bad, raining all day, and as the election news was being received at the Journal office, and the General's residence is a mile or more distant, ...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7.--One hundred recruits have been ordered to the Seventh Cavalry, in the Department of Missouri.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 7.--From present indications it looks very much as if Harvard and Yale had got into a peck of trouble over the annual football game which is played on the Polo Grounds in New-York every Thanksgiving Day. The Harvard Faculty have refused to allow the Harvard eleven to play in New-York, ...

LANCASTER, Nov. 7.--Calvin M. Dellinger, whose wife was found murdered on the banks of Little Conestoga Creek on Oct. 5 last, was rearrested last evening charged with the murder. Dellinger was arrested when the crime was discovered, but was discharged for want of evidence. It is asserted that important new evidence has been discovered.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 7.--A nest of four boilers at the Lancaster Chemical Works, this city, exploded this evening, killing John Reidel, an employe, and injuring Alonzo Hambright, Michael Dorr, and George Smith. The cause of the explosion is unknown. The boilers were all new and of the best make. The plant furnished power to the electric light company, lighting the city.

LONDON, Nov. 7.--Judge Kinnear, in his decision in the Parnell-Times case at Edinburgh yesterday, allowed proof as to what debt had been arrested and what debtor-and-creditor re lations existed between the person arrested and the defender.
LONDON, Nov. 7.--A terrible collision occurred yesterday on a railway line in Southern Russia, near Kovel. Many persons were killed.

Mrs. Jay Gould is dangerously ill. Her family last night were much concerned over her condition. She is suffering from nervous prostration.

BUENA VISTA, Ga., Nov. 7.--A train on the Savannah and Western Road, containing 125 passengers bound for the Macon Fair, was wrecked near Ellaville this morning. HARRISBURG, Nov. 7.--Gov. Beaver has granted a respite to George Clarke, the Greene County murderer, until Feb. 21, 1889. He was sentenced to be hanged on Nov. 21. His case has been taken to the Supreme Court.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 7.--The latest estimates from the returns already received by the State Journal give Nebraska to Harrison by between 30,000 and 35,000. For Governor Thayer (Rep.) will have 25,000 majority.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 7.--Careful estimates, based on election returns received up to 6 o'clock this evening, give the State to Cleveland by a majority of 20,000. This is the Democratic estimate; the Republican estimate is 14,000.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 7.--State reports come in very slowly, but from best data at hand Cleveland and Fleming, the Demo cratic candidate for Governor, carry the State by 3,000.

Company C of the Thirteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, of which W. Atwood French of the Seventh Regiment was recently elected Captain, held a meeting in the armory last night, after a drill and inspection, and received Mr. French's letter of acceptance.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 8.--A blistering rainstorm did not prevent Mrs. Potter from being greeted by a large and fashionable audience at the Euclid-Avenue Opera House to-night. Chief-Justice George W. Stone of the Supreme Court of Alabama celebrated his birthday at his residence in Montgomery, surrounded by over 70 children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Justice Stone is in excellent health, and enjoyed this family reunion immensely.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 8.--The Monmouth and Ocean County Teachers' Institute met in Educational Hall to-day with nearly 300 teachers present. Prof. Samuel Lockwood, Superintendent of the Monmouth County Schools, presided at the morning session and made the address of welcome.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8.--Ex-Senator William H. Barnum is seriously ill at his home in Lime Rock, Conn. He came home from the National Democratic Headquarters in NewYork on Monday broken down from overwork. Through communication with his son by telephone it is ascertained that his condition during the day was such as to alarm his family. At 10 o'clock to-night he was reported better, and no fatal result are expected for the present at least.

The Trustees of the projected Protestant Cathedral, which will be built on the present site of the Leake and Watts Orphan Asylum, near the lower terminus of Morningside Park, expect to have plans submitted to them which will enable them to start building operations by Spring.

Thousands of people in walking strike the ground hard with their heels. In this way they kick out the heel of the best rubber in a fortnight. There being no cobbler of rubbers, as far as we can learn, numbers of comparatively good gum shoes, with only a hole in the heel, are consigned to the ash heap. There is room for some "heelers" in this line.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8.--The leave of absence granted First Lieut. Lea Febiger, Twenty-third Infantry, has been extended two months, and the leaves granted Lieut.-Col. J.S. Fletcher, Second Infantry, and Capt. George Mitchell, Second Artillery, have been extended one month. AssistantSurgeon A.E. Bradley (recently appointed) has been ordered to duty at David's Island, New-York.

LONDON, Nov. 8.--At the Liverpool Autumn Meeting to-day the race for the Liverpool Autumn Cup was won by W. Winn's 3-year-old b.f.Lady Rosebery. Bismarck was second and Aureoline third. There were 12 starters. The last betting was 12 to 1 against Lady Rosebery, Fullerton, who was unplaced, being the favorite.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 8.--"With a Republican President, House, and Senate the party cannot escape any responsibility for the manner in which the Government is conducted," said Gen. Alger this morning. "The party is entirely willing to assume this responsibility, and I am of opinion that one of its first duties will be to revise the tariff.

Samuel Wood of Cooleyville has a dog that beats everything on record. A hawk caught one of his hone and flew away with it. It got eight feet in the air, when the dog gave a jump and the hen got away all right, but the hawk is on exhibition.

There was a slight increase in the attendance at Waverly yesterday, but not sufficient to make it profitable to the management. Five bookmakers were present, and there was enough business to keep them busy. Gabe Caldwell started the horses.
Old Isaac Sublett, an innocent, hardworking farmer and saddler of Denton, a small town a short distance east of here, had a most remarkable fight with a cowardly black bear some time ago.
Harrison and Morton are elected, but Higgins's carpet factory in West Forty-thirdstreet will shortly employ only one-third of the force necessary for ordinary work.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 8.--It is announced that John M. Langstone, the defeated colored candidate for Congress in this district, will contest the seat of E.C. Venable, Democrat, on the ground of alleged irregularities, and also that Judge Waddell will contest Congressman Wise's seat in the Richmond district.

MONTREAL, Nov. 8.--The Coquelin-Hading company, with Coquelin in "Les Surprises du Divorce," appeared to-night. Never in the annals of the Academy of Music has such a large assemblage been seen inside its walls, and rarely did they resound with such merriment.

If the ideas of the committees on the centennial celebration of the inauguration of George Washington as President of the United States are even partly carried out, the day and night of April 29 and 30 next will be filled with the blare of trumpets, the thunder of guns, and the roll of drums, and pageants will be provided that will appeal to patriotism and the impulses of fashion.

A peculiar counterfeit was received yesterday at the First National Bank. A bank in Dubuque, Iowa, sent on a ten-dollar note on the Bank of New-England, at Fairmount, Me., and dated Oct. 1, 1857. As there is no such place as Fairmount the bill, which is finely executed, is evidently not genuine.

PARIS, Nov. 8.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Dreyfus moved that the 42,000,000f. asked by the Government to fortify the harbors of Brest and Cherbourg be spent in building cruisers and torpedo vessels.

The funeral of Lucius J.N. Stark, late President of the Board of Dock Commissioners, took place yesterday afternoon at the MadisonAvenue Reformed Church. The Rey. Dr. Abbott Kittredge officiated. The congregation was largely made up of representative business men.

OTTAWA, Nov. 8.--Smith, Lyman, and Taylor, three members of the Mormon Church, representing the Mormon colony at Loe's Creek in the Northwest Territory, are here on business with the Interior Department.

AUGUSTA, Nov. 8.--The Augusta National Exposition opened to-day under the most auspicious conditions. The weather was perfect and the attendance large, the exhibits are nearly all in place, and by Monday everything will be complete.

Chrysanthemums, bewildering in their variety of form and color, and each one a perfect study of beauty, were yesterday afternoon displayed with all artistic effect at the annual exhibition of the New-York Horticultural Society held in a marquee erected especially for the purpose at the northwest corner of Broadway and Fourteenth-street.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 8.--Nothing having been heard from Gen. Clitz since the letter received from him at Niagara Falls, some of his friends fear that he may have destroyed himself by plunging into the cataract of that river.
Revised returns of the vote for Mayor, Counts Clerk, and Sheriff are given below. The total vote for Mayor was 269,787, and Mr. Erhardt comes in second, beating Mr. Hewitt by 1,126 votes.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8.--Secretary Hayes of the General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor said to-night that important changes would probably be made in the election of officers at the General Assembly at Indianapolis next Tuesday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 8.--The Northwestern Miller of yesterday says: "Although there were two less mills running last week the flour output touched good round figures. The week's production was 150,600 barrels, averaging 25,100 barrels daily, against 163,300 the week before and 155,300 barrels for the corresponding time in 1887.
CITY OF MEXICO, NOV. 8, via Galveston.-- The Mexican International Railway Company has decided to build a branch road from Benito to Monterey, connecting with Tampico.
HAVANA, Nov. 8.--The sugarhouse on the Flor de Sagua estate collapsed to-day, killing one man and injuring nine others.

The accommodation train which left the Grand Central Station at 8 o'clock yesterday morning on the New-York Central and Hudson River Road had reached Fishkill station at 10 o'clock and was receiving and discharging passengers when a freight train, bound in the same direction, came along and crashed into the rear coach.

ALBANY, Nov. 8.--The south wing of the historical Albany Academy Building was damaged by fire to-night, and it is feared that all the records are destroyed. These cannot be replaced. In this building, which has stood for nearly a century, Joseph Henry, while Professor of Physics on 1828 to 1832, made his first experiments with electricity through circuits of wire. The building holds an important part in the State's history.

A number of members of the sub-committee appointed by the conference committee of the Down-town Business Men's Cleveland and Thurman Club for the purpose of manning the polls on election day are satisfied that votes were purchased by the wholesale in spite of their strenuous efforts to prevent it.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Nov. 8.--The raw and stormy weather to-day did not prevent Mr. Garrett from spending part of the day out doors. He was unusually quiet and cheerful. It has not yet been decided where Mr. Garrett will spend the Winter.

BIRMINGHAM, Nov. 8.--Mr. Gladstone was not affected by his long speech last evening, and was in good condition this morning. He received an address from the Birmingham Nationalists, in his reply to which he said that the Irish cause was no longer dependent upon one life.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 8.--Michael Dinwoodie, who disappeared from Toronto 30 years ago under circumstances which led to the belief that he had been murdered, has turned up and is now looking for his relatives. He has been among the mines of Central America, where he made a large fortune.

Philip Baer, a young salesman, was killed last evening by falling into the street from a moving train of the Second-avenue elevated railroad at Canal and Allen streets. His death was due, primarily, to his own recklessness, but the guard in charge of the car from which he fell is greatly blamed by the friends of the dead man.

ALBANY, Nov. 8.--A strike, which now looks as though it might lead to serious results and extend considerably, was begun by the switchmen in the New-York Central and Hudson Railroad freight yard here last night.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8.--Joseph Schlemmer, the convicted wife murderer in Jersey City, was given a chance for his life by the Supreme Court to-day. The judgement of the Hudson County Court of Oyer and Terminer in refusing to admit certain evidence was reversed and another trial granted.

Before the Society of Medical Jurisprudence and State Medicine last evening J.D. WASHINGTON, Nov. 8.--The success which followed Miss Julia Marlowe's appearance as Parthenia in "Ingomar" at the National Theatre on Monday evening was more than equaled to-night, when she played Julian in "The Hunchback."

BOSTON, Nov. 8.--The residence of E.F. At kins, on Concord-avenue, Belmont, was broken into last night and a large quantity of silver plate, diamonds, and jewelry was stolen, all valued at $5,000. The thieves gained access to the house by forcing a window in the laundry.

The football team of the Manhattan Athletic Club has arranged for two games with college teams. The first will be played to-day with the Fordham College team and the second next Saturday with the team of the Yale Freshmen. RICHMOND, Nov. 9.--Complete official returns from the First Congressional District show that T.H. Baily Brown (Rep.) is elected over Kendall (Dem.) by 27 majority. The Democrats have elected 8 of the 10 Congressmen, leaving the Republicans the First and Second Districts. The Democratic majority on their Electoral ticket in this State will not exceed 3,000.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 9.--John Drake, who lives with his wife and family on Cross-street, South Norwalk, is missing, and his friends think he has taken his own life. "Willie" Anderson, a jockey, got into an altercation with another jockey, Peter Ford, yesterday afternoon at Jerome Park, and during the dispute Anderson fatally stabbed Ford with a knife. BERLIN, Nov. 10.--The chief event of the week is the African agreement among the powers. CENTRALIA, Ill., Nov. 11.--During a family quarrel yesterday George Bridenbaker, a farmer residing four miles northwest of here, became crazed and shot his wife and two children. Mrs. Bridenbaker received a dangerous wound in the abdomen and will probably die. A little daughter of the frenzied man caught one of the bullets in her arm, which was badly shattered, and his son received an ugly wound in one of his hands.

READING, Penn., Nov. 11.--Great excitement prevails among persons in this section who bet on the recent election. There is an old and almost forgotten Pennsylvania law which makes betting illegal, and provides that money put up on an election shall be sued for, to go to the maintenance of the poor of the county.
At the eighth anniversary services of the Bowery Mission yesterday a statement was presented which showed that during the present year the total attendance at the meetings of the mission was 31,720.

The great mast which has stood in Unionsquare since August, 1881, and which until a short time ago was used to sustain a nest of electric lights, has finally been removed, and will no longer prove an eyesore to people living near or frequenting the square.

Mills, was hanged in effigy on Friday night on the public square, and after hanging all day the effigy was cut down, an inquest was held, and the body was consigned to the flames of a Demcoratic fire. LIME ROCK, Conn., Nov. 11--10 P.M.--Mr. Barnum has been more comfortable to-day, and his condition is no worse. Dr. Cragin, however, gives but little encouragement. Mr. Barnum is now taking some nourishment, and there is a prospect of a comfortable night.

SHARON, Penn., Nov., 11.--The managers of the Spearman, Douglass, Mabel and Claire furnaces have raised the wages of their employes 15 cents per day. The prospects are that all the furnaces will be in blast all Winter. The Henderson furnace will resume next week after a long idleness.

LONDON, Nov. 12.--Gen. Sir Charles Warren, Chief of the Metropolitan Police, has tendered his resignation. It is understood that this action is due to the severe criticisms that have been made upon his efficiency recently in connection with the Whitechapel murders.

The Cunard steamer Umbria sailed yesterday noon, the rents in the iron plates of the bow caused by her collision with the Fabre Line steamer Iberia on Saturday having been patched up to the entire satisfaction of the inspectors.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12.--Judge Joseph E. Gary, who presided at the trial of the Anarchists, was to-day appointed to the Appellate Bench to succeed the late Judge McAllister.

MADRID, Nov. 12.--The authorities have issued an order prohibiting street assemblies, and instructing the police to disperse all gatherings that may be attempted. The city is now quiet.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12.--Mrs. James Brown Potter opened a two weeks' engagement tonight at McVicker's Theatre, which promises to be a success.

Gen. Roger A. Pryor and Attorney-General Tabor will appear for the people, in whose name the suit is brought, and John E. Parsons will defend the trusts.

After that the Cabinet of the President-elect, then the loaves and fishes, and then--It will probably be determined in a day or two whether there shall be any contest over the Speakership, and who, if there is to be a struggle, the contestants shall be.

FATHER POINT, Quebec, Nov. 12.--The steamer Oregon, from Liverpool, was unable to land her mails at Rimouski on account of a gale, and she has proceeded to Quebec with them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12.--Lieut. Richard Mitchell has been detached from the Kearsarge, and ordered to report for medical treatment at the Naval Hospital, Chelsea, Mass.

The embers which have been smoldering away in Castle Garden for the past three months have been fanned into flame at last. The enormous commissions which are being paid there to secure immigrant business threaten to absorb half the revenue of the railroads represented in the Garden.

"A Brass Monkey" and its amusing antics filled the Bijon Opera House with the usual crowd of laughter-loving people last night. This is a fifth week of its engagement, which is to last till Dec. 8. As the end approaches there are no signs that the monkey's tail will be frozen off.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 12.--The Burlington bobbed up this morning and threw a bomb into the enemy's camp, the explosive being a reduction of seaboard rates to St. Paul. A sweeping cut of 25 per cent. on first class was made, to take effect immediately.

SHARON, Penn., Nov. 12.--A gas refining tank at the Sharon Gas and Water Works exploded with terrific force about 6 o'clock this evening, demolishing a large portion of the works and fatally burning Charles Smith, the gasmaker. The loss will reach $15,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12.--The order for the equestrian statue of Gen. Grant, to be placed in Lincoln Park, in this city, has been given to Mr. Rebisso, a Cincinnati sculptor.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 12.--The employes of the Trenton China Company were startled this morning, by the attempt of Austin Myatt, one of their number to murder James E. Cavanaugh, another workman.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Nov. 12.--News was received here this morning from Tishomingo, capital of the Chickasaw Nation, that Gov. Guy was assassinated last Saturday night. Advices from Chickasaw Nation are that serious trouble is brewing between the followers of Gov. Guy and his opponent in the late election, Byrd. The report of the assassination of Gov. Guy is not yet confirmed.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 12.--Reports of the late election still come in very slowly, and what come in are very unreliable. The Second District is still in doubt, although the Democrats claim it by 1,300 majority.

OTTAWA, Nov. 12.--Prof. Wiggins, the weather prophet, was indignant to-day. He received by mail notification of his election as anhonorary member of the Ananlas Club of Boston, Mass.

BOSTON, Nov. 12.--The Supreme Court (full bench) has ordered that Prof. Egbert Smyth, D.D., the appellant in the case of Smyth against The Board of Visitors of the Theological Institution of Phillips Academy, Andover, shall file additional specifications. There will be no decision by the court until after the preliminary hearing upon the bill in equity, which will take place Dec. 3, and to which time the court is adjourned.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12.--A private dispatch from St. Louis to-day said that a rate of 32 cents per 100 pounds was being made on provisions from Kansas City to New-York by one of the Chicago routes.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 12.--Phineas Rogers of Mechanicsburg was arrested to-day and placed in Cumberland County Prison charged with setting fire to Hauck Comstock's agricultural works, Seidel's spoke factory, Rhinehart's net factory, and other buildings, involving a total loss of over $100,000. He makes a confession implicating several other young men in the crime. Rogers was the leader of the gang.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 12.--A sudden turn has been given to Georgia politics by the determination of many members of the Georgia Legislature to prevent the re-election of Senator Colquitt next Tuesday.

The decision rendered yesterday by the Supreme Court sweeps away the pleas by which the Bell Telephone Company sought to prevent a trial of the suit brought by the Government for a cancellation of the Bell patents.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12.--Official returns from every county in the State show a plurality for Harrison of 79,779. Blaine's plurality in 1884 was 81,019.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Nov. 12.--Mr. Garrett continues to improve, and his condition at present is reported by Dr. Jacobs to be more favorable than it has been for some days. Mr. Garrett was out all day and is growing stronger.

WENONA, Ill., Nov. 12.--This village is in a fever of excitement over a double murder, followed by the suicide of the assassin, this morning. The victims of the assassination are Peter Howe, senior member of the banking firm of Howe Son of this place, and his wife, the former aged 73 years and the latter 69.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 12.--Returns from the election are nearly all in, and place Kentucky's Democratic majority close to 30,000. The Congressional delegation stands nine Democrats to two Republicans.
Vice-President-elect Levi P. Morton took a trip down to his office yesderday for the first time since the close of the campaign. There he found a very pretty surprise awaiting him and Mrs. Morton.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 13.--About the hotel corridors this morning the delegates to the Twelfth General Assembly of the Knights of Labor were busily engaged discussing matters of interest and importance to the order. General Master Workman Powderly arrived early this morning.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 13.--At a meeting of the creditors of the Winslow Packing Company this morning Gen. C.P. Mattocks offered to purchase the indebtedness of the company for 10 per cent. His offer was accepted by all the creditors, payable Jan. 15, 1889.

There are no signs yet that the County Democracy is going to pieces in consequence of its defeat at the recent election. Last night's meeting of its County Committee at the Cooper Union was the largest and most enthusiatic which has been held for a long time.

The wines and liquors belonging to the estate of the late Samuel J. Tilden were sold at public auction yesterday in the auction rooms of C.F. Wetmore, at 240 Fifth-avenue. A curious mixture of clubmen and liquor dealers were present, and did some brisk bidding as the different lots were offered. The opinion of the dealers was that the goods brought fair prices.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13.--George Cooper, who cut his wife to pieces in Portland, Conn., Sunday, was at first placed in the lockup in that town. Before he could be removed an excited crowd surrounded the place and demanded that he be brought out and delivered over by the officers. A struggle ensued, in which the officer offered a successsful resistance. Cooper has been removed to the jail in Middletown.

It is as follows: Total income, $6,693,350; increase, $1,556,042; total expenses, $4,810,595; increase, $1,105,124; net income, $1,882,755; increase, $440,918; surplus for year, $l78,065; increase, $138,874.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--In spite of the efforts of the Treasury Department officers to keep the matter concealed, the fact has leaked out that some enterprising thief has been helping himself to bright, new silver dollars out of the coin that is being received daily from the NewOrleans Mint.

HAMBURG, Nov. 13.--A grand farewell was given to-day to the Hon. Carl Schurz on the occasion of his departure from Hamburg for the United States. Prussian Minister von Kusserow, the Presidents of the Senate, the Board of Trade, and the steamship lines, and many other distinguished persons accompanied Mr. Schurz to the steamer.

DUBLIN, Nov. 14.--A saloon passenger named Pyne fell overboard last night from one of the steamers running between Holyhead and Dublin and was drowned.

GARY, Dakota, Nov. 14.--Prairie fires had been raging southwest of this place, in the midst of a 40-mile gale, all day yesterday. Considerable damage has been sustained. At the present writing the wind has gone down, and to all appearances the fires are out.

Booth and Barrett have decided to send the scenery and properties of "Othello," "The Merchant of Venice," and "Julius Caesar," complete, to San Francisco when they go there to open the new California Theatre. WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 15.--Limited express train No. 5, coming west on the Baltimore and Ohio Road at 8:30 last night, ran into an open switch at Valley Falls, 93 miles east of Wheeling, and collided with the engine of an east-bound freight which lay on the siding. Both engines left the track.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 15.--"The present appropriation of $25,000 is totally inadequate to supply our needs," said Edwin Dunn of the State Board of Prison Inspectors. "We have been strictly economical, however, and can go to the State Legislature next Winter without having exhausted our allowance.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Mr. Smith, the Government leader, intimated that in order to shorten the Winter session several measures would be abandoned. These would include the Tithes bill, the Irish Drainago bill, and the bill for the creation of a Minister of Agriculture. He stated that the Government proposed to ask the House to vote 5,000,000 for the extension of the Ashbourne act.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 15.--The official canvass, completed to-day, gives for President: Harrison Electors, 3,633; Cleveland, 3,329; Fisk, 158; Woman Suffrage, 1. For Governor-- Miller, 3,640; Hill, 3,305; Jones, 157; scattering, 7.

DETROIT, Nov. 15.--The announcement from Ottawa than an order in Council has been passed increasing the export duty on pine logs from $2 to $3 per 1,000 feet, board measure, creates a lively interest here. The large lumber firms in Michigan have taken up enormous timber limits in Ontario, and are cutting down the choicest timber very rapidly.

The steamship Lake Superior of the Beaver Line, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday, re ported that the weather had been so severe as to have probably caused the death of six valuable horses which were among her cargo. Five of these horses, valued at $1,000 each, were consigned to James Hayton of Newton, Iowa. They all died within 15 minutes of each other.

BOMBAY, Nov. 16.--The coasting steamer Vaitarna, which left Cutch, India, for Bombay with 900 natives on board, is a week overdue. It is supposed she foundered in a recent cyclone and that all hands were lost.

OTTAWA, Nov. 16.--Lord Sackville, exBritish Minister to Washington, has abandoned his proposed visit here to his relative, Lord Stanley, Governor-General of Canada. He will sail from New-York for France shortly and will go direct to Paris. This was the official information given out at the Government House to-day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--There does not appear to be any probability, in the light of the latest information, that the Democrats will be able to maintain the contention put forth by some of them, not authoritatively, but anxiously, that they will have a majority in the Fiftyfirst Congress.

LONDON, Nov. 16.--Parliament will be questioned on Monday with reference to the appointment of a successor to Lord Sackville as British Minister at Washington. On Thursday the fisheries dispute will be brought up.

Patry as the Baronne de Vanbert completed the cast and ware excellent.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 16.--On Thursday of next week a meeting of the citizens of Monmouth County "who are in favor of temperance reform from a non-partisan basis" will be held here. If it is thought advisable, concerted action will be taken to obtain the benefits of local option for the county.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov 16.--The crest of the cold wave passed over the Northwest to-day and left the following records of its intensity: Duluth, 12 above zero; St. Paul, 16 ; Moorehead, 6 ; St. Vincent 2 ; Bismarck, 12 ; Fort Custer, Montana, 2 ; Winnipeg, zero.

The Central Railroad of New-Jersey several months ago began to substitute soft for hard coal for use by freight engines. It was not long before residents along the line began to complain of the dense volumes of heavy black smoke.

ERIE, Penn., Nov. 16.--A storm of unparalleled severity swept a belt of country south of the Lake Shore this morning, and snow fell to such a depth as to blockade the roads and impede travel. The lake craft had been warned by signal officers, and there are no marine losses reported. The live stock in the belt of country in which the snow and sleet fell suffered to such an extent that losses are anticipated.
Mr. Dorman B. Eaton talked on the subject, "Can there be a Reform in the Civil Service?" yesterday morning at Packard's Business College.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 16.--On the night of Oct. 15 C.J. Myers, living about 13 miles north of this city, drove away a strange dog which was biting his sheep. A few days ago some of the animals began to act strangely, attacking every one who came near them, and after a few hours would drop dead. A veterinary surgeon pronounced the disease to be hydrophobia.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 16.--The Wells, Fargo Co.'s Express have issued circulars offering a liberal reward for the apprehension of Benjamin F. Allen, Jr., who absconded Sept. 10, and was last seen at La Junta, Col. Young Mr. Allen is from this city. B.F. Allen, Sr., who left for Mexico about six weeks ago, is said to have asserted that he would do all in power to assist in his son's capture.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 16.--This morning as a train on the Northern New-Jersey Railroad pulled out from the station at Monsey, Rockland County, the body of a dead man was discovered in the ditch. The body was recognized as that of George Conklin, a man well known in Spring Valley. He must have been struck and killed by a train last night. An inquest was held and a verdict of accidental death returned.

CORNWALL, Ontario, Nov. 16.--The Cornwall Canal is once more open, and vessels lightly loaded are passing up. All the vessels at the Eastern end were allowed to pass up first. The heavier laden vessels will be allowed to proceed to-morrow.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 16.--Returns from all but three counties in this State give Cleveland 181,394; Harrison, 153,732; Cleveland's plurality, 27,662. The remaining counties will make the Democrat plurality abot 28,000. The total vote is the largest ever east in Kentucky.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Nov. 16.--At the rolling mill of the Centre Iron Company this morning John Flack, 15 years of age, employed as a scaler, started to shut the gates that stop the machinery, when he tripped and fell on the coupling of a line of shafting, was thrown under it, and a bolt on the coupling caught him in the abdomen and injured him so that he lived only a few minutes.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 17.--Detectives assert that murder preceded the burning of the European Hotel, in this city, Monday night. Three charred corpses were found in its ruins, and one man died from hurts received by jumping. The matter is being investigated.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 17.--In the District Court at Boone, in the cash of the State against the Rev. W.F. Laidley, a Methodist minister at Ogden, who was charged with immorality, a verdict was ordered for the defendant upon the ground that action was barred by the Sigtute of Limitations. WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--The Superintendent of the Recruiting Service has been ordered to assign 30 recruits to Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, for duty in the First, Fifth, and Sixth Cavalry, and 50 recruits to the Fifth Cavalry to such points in the Department of Missouri as the General commanding that department shall designate.

LONDON, Nov. 18.--Discount during the past week was quoted at 3 to 1 . There was no demand. The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 3 .
