BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 18.--James Connors was found dead at 7 o'clock this morning at the foot of the stairs in the hallway of his flat on West Liberty-street. Connors lived with his daughter. His wife died in the hospital two weeks ago.

Charles Eicks, a German cook, 27 years of age, was to have been married at 8 o'clock last night. His dead body was found last night on the second floor of 331 East Twenty-first-street by the housekeeper. The body was lying upon the floor fully dressed, and a huge knife was alongside of it.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 18.--There can be no doubt that but very little yellow fever actually exists in the city proper at the present time. In the suburbs, however, it is still raging. A most virulent type has developed in South Jacksonville, nearly all of the cases proving fatal.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18.--The large stable of Dr. James Marshall, veterinary surgeon, at 914 and 916 Brown-street, was discovered to be on fire about 4:30 o'clook this morning, and before the flames were extinguished two blooded horses were fatally burned and 20 sleighs, from 20 to 25 buggies, and several dozen sets of valuable harness were consumed, making a total loss on the stock and building of nearly $10,000.

The last tributes of respect to the memory of Gen. William H. Brownell were paid by a multitude of his friends at the Lee-Avenue Congregational Church in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. The building was crowded to its utmost capacity, and many persons remained in the churchyard and adjoining streets during the long service.

The report that the Rev. Dr. Burtsell, Rector of the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany, was to be summoned to Rome for publicly upholding the right of John McGuire, a deceased member of the Anti-Poverty Society, to burial in Calvary Cemetery, did not occasion much surprise among the members of his congregation.

ZANZIBAR, Nov. 18.--All the ladies of the Magila Mission have arrived here safely. They were accompanied by three male members of the mission. The rest of the missionaries remain at Magila with the Bishop.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 18.--The date fixed for the dedication of the spacious and elegant new Presbyterian house of worship at Oneonta is Nov. 20.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton, Pastor of the Church of the Divine Paternity, Fifth-avenue and Forty-fifth-street, prefaced his sermon yesterday morning with remarks in tribute to the late George H. Forster.

In the bright, crisp air of yesterday, with its hint of frost, but glorious in clear sunlight, the ships which have been looked for anxiously the last few days began to come in from the sea. As had been expected, they brought news in every case of fearful storms.

William H. Kenney, 23 years old, of 319 East Thirty-second-street, and James McDonald of 417 East Twenty-second-street, both blind and both drunk and unable to take care of themselves, were found by a policeman on Third-avenue yesterday morning. Later in the day they were fined $10 each at the Yorkville Police Court.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 18.--James E. Cavanaugh, the potter who was shot at the Trenton China Works last Monday by Austin Myatt, a fellowworkman, died from his injuries this afternoon.

Signor del Puente, who is to sing baritone in Campanini's concert company this year, arrived on the Etruria yesterday afternoon and was at once taken in charge by his friends.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 18.--The Bancroft Hotel, containing 80 rooms, at Ocean and Third avenues, was burned early this morning.

Cotton smoked and smoldered and blazed under the Brooklyn Bridge last evening. There was a lot of it, and it furnished a most cheerful but expensive glow as it floated up the East River. The blazing cotton was part of a lot that was piled on the Clyde Steamship Company's pier, 29 East River.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18.--There is trouble in Mr. Aronson's "Nadjy" company, now playing at the Grand Opera House in this city. Two or three days ago, during a rehearsal, Stage Manager Freeman asked for the names of all the members of the chorus who had made engagements for next Summer.

LONDON, Nov. 18.--The Socialists of London held an immense meeting in Victoria Park to-day to commemorate the Trafalgarsquare and Chicago riots. Speeches were made from three platforms. Mrs. Parsons advocated the use of bombs.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 18.--Sunday has been a quiet day with the delegates to the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor, although many of them were actively and closely engaged in committee work. This evening a lecture for the benefit of the poor of this city was given by General Master Workman Powderly in Masonic Hall. The subject was "Temperance."

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19.--The famous Doris mansion, in the West End, burned this morning. The imposing structure, which cost in the neighborhood of $100,000, was totally destroyed. The insurance is not more than one-fourth that amount.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 19.--John Hodell, a native of switzerland, aged 32 years, a life prisoner in the State prison from Tolland, committed suicide this morning in his cell in Wethersfield.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 19,--The Rockland County canvassers, after a contest of several days, decided this afternoon that the election for Sheriff of this county resulted in a tie, and called a new election for Dec. 18.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Nov. 19.--The United States Marshal at this city has been authoritatively notified that all reports of amicable adjustment of the Chickasaw troubles are incorrect; that no subclief has been declared elected, and that Indian Agent Owens has been appealed to for assistance to settle impending difficulties.

ST. ANDREWS, New-Brunswick, Nov. 19.--The trial of John Nailor for the murder of his wife at Clarendon Sept. 29 was concluded to-day. The jury returned a verdict of manslaughter and the prisoner was sentanced for seven years in the penitentiary.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 19.--The surprise at the meeting of the Baltimore and Ohio stockholders to-day was the election of seven new Directors and the dropping of the representative of the Johus Hopkins University interest. Everything was carefully prepared and the election was a unanimous formality, all of the 68,106 shares being cast for the one ticket.

A large and enthusiastic meeting of gentlemen and ladies, under the auspices of the Church Temperance Society, was held at Steinway Hall last evening. The Chinese colony in Mott-street puts in its spare time of late sympathizing with Moy Chung, general manager of Yuet Sing's grocery store, over the awkward predicament in which he finds himself placed since the passage of the Chinese Restriction bill.
LONDON, Nov. 19.--A dispatch from Zanzibar says the Italian flag has again been hoisted on the Italian Consulate and has been saluted by direction of the Sultan.

A very startling report was circulated at Castle Garden late yesterday afternoon to the effect that the Aurania, which left New-York Saturday at 4:30 in the morning, had met in collision with the westward-bound steamer Suevia of the Hamburg Line, which left Hamburg Nov. 8 for New-York.

LANESVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 19.--A day or two ago Asa Cronley, accompanied by an old trapper named Guilfuss, tramped through the Catskill Mountains in this vicinity to a point known as Diamond Notch to ascertain if steel traps which they had set contained any bears.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, Nov. 19.-- The telegraph was yesterday brought into service in a way that not only afforded a good illustration of the extent of the system, but furnished a unique example of the possibilities of modern science.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 19.--A special from Summerfield, Ala., to-night, says the family of William Morgan, a farmer, were poisoned to-day, and all are very sick. Some of them may die. They are food for dinner prepared by a negro servant, and immediately all fell ill. The food has not yet been analyzed. The negro was arrested and confessed. The family numbers six.

In spite of the efforts of Col. Elliott F. Shepard to prevent the running of stages on Fifth-avenue on the Sabbath they will continue to perambulate that thoroughfare every day for at least one year to come.

Although six members of the County Democracy were elected to the Assembly only five will sit in that body. Assemblyman-elect August Strassburg of the Twenty-third District yesterday resigned from the County Democracy and last night he was elected a member of the Tammany Hall committee of the district.

ST. PAUL. Minn., Nov. 19.--There was announced yesterday from the Canadian Pacific headquarters what is of a good deal of importance as marking a stage in the development of the passenger traffic to and from the East via the Soo line.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 19.--There has been a bitter strife going on between the supporters of Richard Crowley, the Republican candidate for Congress, who was defeated, and the other section of the party.

ALBANY, Nov. 19.--All Saints' Cathedral, the church of the Right Rev. William Croswell Doane, Bishop of the Albany Episcopal Diocese. will be dedicated to-morrow with pomp and high church ecclesiastics.

Many prominent Brooklyn citizens went to 123 Henry-street yesterday afternoon to pay the last mark of respect to the memory of the late Prof. Robert R. Raymond. The parlors contained many beautiful floral tributes from friends and former religious associates.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 19.--A Post (EriePenn.,) special says Mrs. Patrick Durkin quarreled with her husband at the supper table tonight and threw a teacup of vitriol in his eyes, totally blinding him and terribly disfiguring his face.

Mayor-elect Grant joined the Aqueduct Commissioners in their meeting room yesterday forenoon to hear citizens opposed to the proposed Quaker Bridge Dam and favoring a system of small reservoirs. When the Commissioners fixed the time of the meeting they decided to hold daily sessions for three days.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 19.--The plans for the proposed railway across the isthmus connecting Nova Scotia with New-Brunswick have been approved by the Minister of Railways.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--The Supreme Court of the United States to-day rendered an opinion in the case of Lewis M. Clark, plaintiffin error, against the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, on appeal from the Court of Quarter Sessions of the Peace of Allegheny County. Penn. Clark was part owner of ...
Charles C. Haight, the architect, is at work upon plans for the new Christ Church that is to be erected at Seventy-first-street and the Boulevard.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 19.--The Beaver Falls Rolling Mill at Beaver Falls was burned tonight. Nothing was saved. Loss, $15,000. Six men were seriously burned, two of whom will probably die. The fire was caused by experimenting with Lima oil for generating gas. The mill was leased by Whitaker Co. of Wheeling, West Va. A large number of men are thrown out of employment.

Compared with Guttenberg, the Clifton management has been favored in point of weather thus far during its meeting. But yesterday was about as bad as could be imagined. Rain fell in torrents all day, fog interfered at intervals, and the track was very sloppy.
NASSAU, New-Providence, Nov. 13.--A Cuban named Isidore Cejas committed suicide in his cell in the prison here yestarday by hanging himself with a strip of canvas.

PHILDELPHIA, Nov. 19.--Harvard beat the University of Pennsylvia at football to-day, after a rough battle in mud and water. It was a one-sided score of 42 to 0, and Pennsylvania was whipped worse than was expected, but the home lads gave a plucky battle to the Boston boys.

The banquet of the Chamber of Commerce this evening is expected to be a less formal one than the banquets have been in the past. Among the gentlemen invited to be present are President Cleveland, President-elect Harrison.

A homicide occurred in front of 210 Broadway, near the corner of Fulton-street, at 6:30 o'clock Sunday evening, and the slayer, after being confronted with his victim, who refused to make a charge against him, was let go. His name is unknown and his address is only surmised.

There is trouble ahead for Mr. HARRISON, and in no small quantity. Already throughout the country, though the Republican victory is not yet a fortnight old, there are signs that the clansmen are preparing for a general onslaught upon the White House so soon as the successful candidate shall have taken position.

A meeting of prominent gentlemen was recently held at the office of C.V. Sidell, 146 Broadway, for the purpose of organizing a company to build a railroad from San Domingo City to the city of Azua, a distance of about 100 miles.

TORONTO, Nov. 19.--The latest developments in regard to the suicide of Fred Barber, the middle-aged English commercial traveler who blew out his brains at the Suspension Bridge on Friday last, are of a very painful character.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 19.--Another chapter was added to the McClure-Flannigan tragedy to-day. On the 19th of Ootober last Barney McClure and Hugh Flannigan were shot down on alonely mountain road and robbed of $12,000, which they were conveying to the railroad works to pay off the men.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., Nov. 19.--Fire broke out at 11:30 to-night in the large four-story wooden block, corner of Market and Main streets, the business centre of the town, and completely destroyed it. Loss on building and contents, $60,000.

NESSAU, New-Providence, Nov. 15.--Pilot Evans and his boat's crew of four men were drowned off the bar Nov. 12, by the capsizing of their boat during a squall. They were attempting to speak the steamer Cienfuegos from New-York.

Efforts are still making to end the troubles existing among the trunk lines and to restore freight rates.It was announced in Wall-street yesterday that a satisfactory arrangement would be effected to-morrow.

One James McCloud of Lodi, Wis., has a horse on his Dakota ranch for which he has refused $2,500 for a half interest in, and for which he wants $5,000. McCloud's horse is a marvel neither as a trotter nor racer.
JANESVILLE, Wis., Nov. 19,--A case in which suit was brought by Catholic taxpayers to prevent the reading of the King James version of the Bible in the public schools was decided to-day.

The strongest evidence of the loss the community has suffered through the death of Dr. Henry B. Sands, the famous surgeon who died in his carriage on Sunday afternoon, was furnished by the constant stream of carriages which drew up at his residence on Thirty-thirdstreet yesterday.

MERRILLAN, Wis., Nov. 19.--The body of C.E. Lucas was found to-day five miles east of here, about 60 rods from the railroad track, near some logging shanties. Mr. Lucas left here the night before the election to go to Spalding to attend the election.
The six-inch water main crosses Delancey-street at Pitt-street succumbed to the pressure of the big main which extends through the former street yesterday morning, and broke like a pipe stem.

Capt. Akermark of the Swedish bark Edward, which came to this port Saturday night and until yesterday lay at anchor in the Bay, told a story on his arrival of a most mysterious electric phenomenon which was observed on his vessel during her voyage from Havre.
A plan is under consideration by the Southwestern roads to regulate traffic in the interest of security holders as well as in that of shippers.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 19.--In the inquest into the cause of the recent Rochester Steam Gauge and Lantern Works disaster this afternoon and evening John Vankorff, the engineer of the factory, was placed on the stand.

PARIS, Nov. 19.--After counsel for M. Numa Gilly had stated in the Nimes court on Saturday that M. Gilly's attack was not made upon M. Anderieux, but upon the Budget Committee, an attempt was made to introduce evidence in support of the charges of malfeasance against the committee.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 19.--The Senatorial fight is the one absorbing topic with the politicians of the State. Beside it the question of who shall be the next Speaker of the House is but a side issue.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 19.--Senator Morgan, by invitation, addressed the Alabama Legislature to-day. The election for Senator takes place Nov. 25, and he will be re-elected without opposition.

Capt. William V. King of Company B. Twenty-second Regiment, and Senior Captain in the regiment, was elected Major last night, to succeed Major Miller, who had been elected Lieutenant-Colonel, vice Lieut.-Col. Harding transferred to the Thirteenth Regiment.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 19.--S.R.W. Heath of New-York, the Chairman of the Finance Committee of Rutgers College's Board of Trustees, has resigned on account of continued ill health. With his resignation he sent a gift of $10,000 to the college.

CHIPPEWA FALLS, Wis., Nov. 19.--The report which, seems prevalent, and had been sent from Washington, that the Land Department had approved of all the contracts on the reservation of the Lac Court Oreilles is unfounded.
Two years ago Michael Mullone, who owned the Argus, an afternoon paper published in Jersey City, sold it for $25,000 cash to a corporation of which Charles S. Clarke was the active promoter.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 19.--The eager discussion by the Southern newspapers of what they call Gen. Harrison's Southern policy is giving an undue relative importance to that subject all over the country.
The members of the Central Turnverein of the city of New-York gave a very successful entertainment and ball last evening in Terrace Garden, Fifty-eighth-street, between Third and Lexington avenues.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Gustave Werschte was lodged in jail here to day on a charge of murder. He is the man who clubbed Michael Shaken to death Friday night at Perth Amboy in a row in front of one of the saloons there.

Since the recent election politicians of both parties are disposed to look with more favor upen propositions to reform election methods. Especially does that provision of the Saxton bill prohibiting electionearing "on election day within any polling place or within 100 feet of any polling place" commend itself to their enlightened minds. Such a law as this is already on the statute books of some of the States.
A great many persons visited Mayor Hewitt yesterday to give him advice respecting the selections he should make to-morrow for School Commissioners and Inspectors.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 19.--Cleveland's vote in Mississippi, according to official returns just tabulated by the Secretary of State, is 85,476, Harrison's 30,096, Fisk's 218, Streeter's 22; Cleveland's plurality 55,380.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19.--The old State House which stands upon the City Green has long been an eye sore to the people of NewHaven.

Frank Clark, the energetic Superintendent of the Coney Island Jockey Club, isn't giddy as a rule. But last Thursday he came up to town to see the British burlesquers make tools intial bow to an American audience. Frank told his driver, or thought he told him, to meet him with a team at Prospect park, Brooklyn, at midnight, so as to take him back to the track that night.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 19.--Louis Brooks of Columbia, freight conductor on the Pennsylvania Railroad, met with a terrible death east of Leamanplace this morning. As he was stepping from the tender to the next car the coupling broke, and, the engine pulling away from the train, Brooks was thrown to the track. Eight cars passed over his body, cutting him to pieces. He was 35 years old and leaves a widow and four children.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 19.--An important matter before the next Legislature will be a bill presented to amend the present tax law. Gov. McGill will recommend this in his message to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--The leave of adsence granted Capt. Thomas M. McDougall, Seventh Cavalry, has been extended six months on account of disability, Major Alexander M. Miller, Corps of Engineers, has been ordered from St. Louis to Fort Russell, Wyoming, to examine the question of water supply for that post.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 19.--The trial of James Palmer for the murder of Henry E. Whitehouse of Burwick, Mo., on the 27th of last May, was concluded to-night, returning a verdict of murder in the first degree. Palmer was sentenced to be hanged on the first Tuesday of December, 1889. He will be taken to Concord State Prison to-morrow. While being handcuffed after his sentence, Palmer smiled and appeared perfectly unconcerned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--Major-Gen. J. M. Schofield, commanding the army, has made his annual report to the Secretary of War. In it he calls attention to the reports of the various division and department commanders and other commanding officers.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 19.--Last yearthe people of Charleston determined to celebrate the restoration of the city from the mire of the earthquake and organized a carnival which in all respects was the most brilliant event in the history of the State.

Signor Campanini's company has been completed by the arrival of the always popular baritone, Signor Del Puente. The company starts on the road to-day as one of the most excellent concert organizations that could be brought together.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 19.--The Post Office at Lyons Farms was broken into early yesterday morning. There was no safe in the office and the thieves opened and scattered the letters. Going upstairs they robbed Postmaster G.C. Looker of $150 and a gold watch. When Looker was a wakened he found an open razor on his pillow. Two overcoats were left by the thieves in a blacksmith's shop opposite the Post Office.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted $100,000 4 per cent. registered bonds at 108 , and $2,200 4 per cent coupon bonds at 125.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 19.--Mrs. Thomas Fitzpatrick attempted to light a fire this morning with a parlor match. The head of the match fell off and set fire to her clothing. She ran down stairs enveloped in flames. Her father and son tried to smother the flames and both were badly burned. Another son threw water over all of the unfortunate persons and quenched the flames. Mrs. Fitzpatrick and her father were fatally burned.

An inquiry was begun by the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday into the charges recently made that Thomas Costigan, the ponderous Supervisor of the City Record, has been awarding printing to William P. Mitchell, one of his associates in the County Democracy, and buying stationery in small lots without contracts to the disadvantage of the city.

James M. Dougherty, the book canvasser who so persistently pursued Miss Mary Anderson and who was arrested at Palmer's Theatre last Tuesday as the curtain was about to be rung up, was pronounced insane by the physicians at Beilevue Hospital yesterday. Drs. Field and Fitch have been watching his actions since he was removed there. He will be taken to Ward's island asylum to-day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 19.--The Managers of the Hartford and Connecticut Western Railroad here confidently expect that connections will be made with the Poughkeepsie Bridge by Feb. 1, 1889.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Nov. 19.--No arrangements have yet been made for the removal of Mr. Garrett from Ringwood, and he is likely to remain at the Miller mansion for another month. Mr. Garrett's condition was reported to-day to be unchanged.

There was a notable assembly of men interested in the liquor traffic in Part II, of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday to present their evidence or informal statements to the commission appointed by the State Legislature now considering the revision of the excise laws.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 19.--The canals of the State will be closed at midnight, Nov. 30.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--The bursting of the blowing trough at Whitney's Glass Works in South Camden, N.J., to-day, released 40 tons of molten glass, which ran in a fiery stream, setting the works on fire and causing consternation among the workingmen.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 19.--At a meeting of river coal operators this afternoon it was unanimously decided to shut down all the lines along the Monongahela River for an indefinite period.

The General Missionary Committee of the Methodist Episcopal Church at its sessions yesterday finished up the appropriations for foreign missions by alloting $60,166, including $6,000 for university purposes, to Japan, one of the most encouraging fields of the church.

With curious inconsistency some of the high-tariff men who were saying in the recent campaign that the foreign market was a delusion and a share are now asserting that the foreign market is something very desirable, and are urging that we should build up a great trade in certain foreign countries by subsidy legislation.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Word is raceived that Henry C. Stoll, Sheriff of the adjoining county of Sussex, in New-Jersey, who was elected to the office in 1887 for a term of three years, has through oversight and omission of duty vacated the position and put himself and the county in rather serious plight.

ALBANY, Nov. 19.--A 19-year-old lad, styling himself Prof. C.W. Oldreive, and hailing from Boston, started for New-York on foot by way of the Hudson River this morning. He is small for his age, and his clean-shaven face gave him an exceedingly youthful appearance.

"The prisoner of Chillon" at the present moment is Miss Charlotte Stirling, an English young lady of good family, who two years ago left a home of comfort and luxury to serve in the Salvation Army in Switzerland.

The Baptist ministers, at their weekly meeting yesterday, enjoyed an hour of good advice from Prof. Richard T. Ely of Johns Hopkins university, who read them a paper on "The Church and the Workingmen."
Another attempt will be made to-day at the meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Education to obtain money for the introduction of sewing classes in some of the local public schools.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19.--The hotels are crowded to-night with delegates to the joint convention of the International Range Association and the Butchers' Protective Association. The Senate committee on dressed beef investigation held a brief session, but, beyond issuing a dozen subpoenas, very little was done.

ATHENS, Nov. 19.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Delyannis attacked the budget submitted by Premier Tricoupis, discrediting the Prime Minister's statements, and expressed the belief that the end of the year would see a deficit of $2,500,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--Dispatches from points in Northern Illinois, Indiana, Eastern Iowa, report the first heavy fall of snow of the season last evening.

The trial of a suit by ex-Congressman Philip B. Thompson, Jr., of Kentucky, to recover $10,000 counsel fees and $72.60 expenses from the Knickerbocker Ice Company was begun yesterday in the Court of Common Pleas before Judge Allen and a jury.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Many lawyers and people in general have an idea that the collateral inheritance tax law is obselete, but a case has recently arisen in this county which goes to prove the contrary.

Water color paintings met with much greater favor yesterday at the auction sale which has been going on for the last few days at the Fifth-Avenue Art Rooms, 240 Fifth-avenue.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 19.--The muchtalked-of Hibbard-Fry breach of promise case, in which the plaintiff asks damages in the sum of $100,000, was called for trial in the Beaver County Court this morning. The case has attracted widespread interest on account of the prominence of the parties.

The Captain of the steamship Claribel of the Atlas Line, which arrived yesterday from the West Indies, reported that on his arrival at the first port on his way south, Gonaives, in the island of Hayti, a Haytian gunboat fired a shot across his bow, ordering him to leave that harbor at once, as it was under blockade.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--A dispatch from Little Rock, Ark., says: "A stockman named William Durant was brutally murdered at his home near Tushomma, I.T., Friday night last.

The body of the old German who died in the Brooklyn City Hospital last Wednesday from the effects of a fractured skull was identified yesterday as that of Alexander Kiesling, a piano maker, 63 years old, who lived at 559 West Forty-seventh ...

The inheritance of $5,000 by Mrs. Carrie Wilson, who lives with her husband and chil dren at 497 Pacific-street, Brooklyn, has caused such a rumpus in the family that Mr. Wilson took his children Sunday and left the house to his wife.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19.--A special to the PostDispatch from Fort Smith, Ark., says: "Samuel Holmes, a well-known planter, while drunk yesterday, attacked his sister-in-law, Mary Thomas, and the girl driven to desperation, seized a shotgun and fired at him. Holmes dropped dead."
A common office door, with lettered glass, was a witness before Judge O'Gorman and a jury in the Superior Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--The Department of State has received official conformation of the reported condemnation and seizure by the Haytian Prize Court of the American steamship Haytian Republic.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--Mr. Francis Wilson to-day lost 20 of the 22 Aronson chorus singers he had engaged for his production of "The Oolah" at the Broadway Theatre May 15 next and Mr. Max Freeman, stage director of Mr. Aronson's "Nadjy" company, now playing at the Grand Opera House, in this city, gained one or two black eyes and a bruised face.

MONTOGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 19.--Alabama is proving a profitable field for the Mormon missionary just now. Thirty converts in charge of a Mormon elder passed through here to-day, all coming from this neighborhood. Most of them were women, all ticketed for Utah. A carload went from North Alabama a few days ago, and a big gang went from South Alabama a week ago.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19.--James P. Fairley, grocer, made an assignment to-day to John E. Vogel for the benefit of his creditors. Liabilities are placed at between $40,000 and $50,000. Assets, $10,000. Mr. Fairley's position is said to be very embarrassing, as it is alleged he is also $6,000 behing on real estate of which he is Administrator.

Chrysanthemums went for rather low prices yesterday morning at the auction sale of the New-York Horticultural Society's specimens which were on exhibition last week at the marquee, Union-square and Fourteenth-street. The sale began at 11 o'clock under rather depressing influences from the heavy rain.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 19.--Thomas J. Goodin was arrested here a few days ago on a charge of embezzling funds while Treasurer of Rawlins County, Kan. A few months before his term of office had expired Goodin fled.
The stock market had a good deal of pernicious activity in it yesterday and quotations genarally went down. Some stocks were so weak as to show very plainly the selling of large blocks of long stock.

Before Surrogate Ransom in the Surrogate's Court yesterday was begun the trial of the contest over the will of Alfred G. Myers. There are plenty of counsel in the case--Gov. Green of New-Jersey appearing in behalf of the validity of the will, and ex-Surrogate Rollins, Andrew Shiland, Jr., and George M. Thomson for the contestants.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--L.S. Norton, the distinguished Erie lawyer, who has been confined to the Pennsylvania Hospital for the Insane since March 23 last, will leave the asylum to-morrow or next day in company with his friend, Charles Kriem, a member of the City Troop.

LONDON, Nov. 19.--In the House of Commons this evening Mr. Madden, Solicitor-General for Ireland, in the absence of Mr. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland, who is ill, brought in the bill further to facilitate the purchase by tenants of land in Ireland by adding 5,000,000 to the amount applicable under the Ashbourne act. Mr. Madden, in explaining the proposed measure, described the Ashbourne act as a great success.
CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 19.--Great interest is felt in the State of Chiapas regarding a proposed railway to be built by New-York and London capitalists.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 19.--At Youngstown, Ohio, early this morning, Mile. Goudart, a French governess, committed suicide at the residence of the well-known iron manufacturer, Henry O. Bonnell, in Wick-avenue. She arrived in Youngstown 10 days ago from New-York, and soon after showed symptoms of melancholy.

James Cruise, carefully wrapped in cotton batting, was brought from Ward's Island Hospital yesterday to testify in Judge Cowing's Court in General Sessions against Thomas Glynn, whom he accuses of being the cause of the frightful burns he received on Oct. 31 of last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--"Jake" Kilrain and "Charley" Mitchell, who appeared as "classical statues" at the Central Theatre tonight, were mobbed after the performance and narrowly escaped without injury.

Between Melrose and Morrisania the tracks of the Harlem and New-Haven Railroads yesterday presented an unwonted aspect of bustle. While an army of workmen were putting in switches and ballasting the tracks anew.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 19.--The hunting party left here for the fields early this morning. It was raining, the ground was very muddy, the birds scarce and hard to find. First series, the Derby Stake--Santinnella beat Glan Morgan, Oliver Twist beat Roi d'Or, Lady Piedmont beat Guy, Lindo beat Potrach, and Orlando beat Hopes Lass.
BERLIN, Nov. 19.--Gen. von Schellendorf will soon resign from the Ministry of War and assume command of the First Army Corps. Gen. Habuka will succeed to the Ministry of War.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--The President will to-morrow go to Oak View to remain until after he has completed the writing of his annual message to Congress, which is not yet begun, and which he finds it will be utterly impossible to prepare if he does not escape from the interruptions unavoidable while staying at the White House.

PETERSBURG, West va., Nov. 19.--A colored man named Austin, employed as brakeman on the Richmond and Petersburg Railroad, was knocked off his train to-nignt and, falling between the cars was instantly killed, his head being cut from his body and his right aim crushed to pieces.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--The Very Rev. Maurice A. Walsh, LL. D., Rector of St. Paul's Roman Cathelic Church, this city, and ViearGeneral of the Archdioeese of Philadelphia, is dying of Bright's disease.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 19.--The Rev. L.P. Gray, Pastor of the Methodist Episcopal church at Earlville, has forwarded to the Presiding Elder of the district a letter resigning the charge.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Nov. 19.--First Mate G.G. Tibbetts of the schooner W. Jewett of Portland, Me., and a Swedish sailor, were drowned here this morning by the sinking of a small boat. Tibbetts was from Boothbay, Me., was a widower, and leaves three children.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 19.--The desire of the delegates to the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor to continue T.V. Powderly as their chief has been expressed to him formally.
LONDON, Nov. 21.--The steamship Critic, (Br.,) Capt. Davies, sld. from Leith for New-York yesterday. The steamship Colorado, (Br.,) Capt. Jenkins, from New-York Nov. 7, arr. at Hull Nov. 19.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Nov. 20.--William B. Moran, Fred Moran, and other Detroit parties have secured an option from Peter E. Gingrass on 40 acres of ground in Gold Range, paying therefor $20,000. A 40-foot quartz vein carrying free gold extends across the property. Mining will be begun at once, and the same parties have the refusal of the ground at $150,000, which will be paid if the developments turn out satisfactorily.

WATERTOWN, Dakota, Nov. 20.--This afternoon fire broke out in one of the cells of the jail. Hans Nelson from Webster, Dakota, had been in the cell about an hour when the alarm was sounded. Although heroic efforts were made to rescue the man before he could be reached he was burned to an unrecognizable mass. Nelson has a sister living at Webster.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 21.--Several Iowa towns are suffering severely from epidemics of diphtheria and scarlet fever. PARIS, Nov. 21.--Gen. Boulanger attended a performance at the Renaissance Theatre last night. The audience recognized him and applauded. A crowd outside also cheered him when he left the theatre. There was some disorder and the police made several arrests.
LONDON, Nov. 22.--The steamship Monkseaton, (Br.,) Capt. Beazley, from Liverpool Nov. 14 for New-York, passed Kinsale last evening en route for Cardiff, having broken her propeller.

Thomas Verren, a lawyer residing with his wire at 304 Fifteenth-street, Brooklyn, has been missing since Monday, Oct. 22. On that day he went to his office, 52 New-street, this city, returned to dinner at home, and in the evening went out, saying he was going to attend a meeting or the Vestry of the Church du Sainte Esprit, West Twentysecond-street, of which he was Treasurer.

Edward Finkelstone, President of the Barbers' Union and delegate to the Central Labor Union, has just resigned his office, and written a letter bitterly attacking the Socialists and Anarchists because they threatened to boycott all union barber's shops in the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21.--Pennsylvania thrashed Lafayette on the football field to-day, the boys in blue and red winning by a score of 50 to 0. It was a bad defeat for the lads from Easton, but they fought a brave and plucky battle against the aggressive campaign of Pennsylvania's warriors.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21.--J. Motte Martic this morning was made Receiver of the Fairbanks Palmer Publishing Company, with bonds of $10,000. The action was taken on a bill filed in the Superior Court by Mrs. Elizabeth A. Hull, Fairbanks's mother-in-law.

Edward De Benyons, who claims to be a Spanish Count, and who is the proprietor of a hotel at 241 West Fourteenth-street, was brought before Justice Duffy at the Jefferson Market Police Court to answer a charge of assault, preferred by his wife, Mrs. Mary J. De Benyons.

LONDON, Nov. 21.--Great excitement was occasioned this morning when it was reported that another woman had been murdered and mutilated in Whitechapel. As was predicted exclusively in THE TIMES some weeks ago, the Cleveland Club was admitted to membership in the League yesterday at the meeting in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel to take the place made vacant by the retirement of Detroit.

Forty crisp, new one-thousand-dollar bills were handled by more than one person in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, when the hearing in the suit of Mrs. Annie Jarrett against William Ziegler was resumed.
Dora Earnes of 78 Broome-street was run over by a Sixth-avenue car at Thirtieth-street last night and found to be several injured at the NewYork Hospital. The driver of the car was arrested.

John Hogan, a convict in Sing Sing Prison, was found lying dead upon the floor of his cell at 7 o'clock yesterday morning. Coroner Mitchell of Yonkers held an autopsy, which showed that he had died from a hemorrhage at the base of the brain. The prison authorities testified that the young man had been subject to epileptic fits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--Teemer of McKeesport and O'Connor of Toronto, the oarsmen, will row a three-mile race with a turn on the Potomac here next Saturday for $1,000 a side and the championship of America. Both men are in good condition and a close race is expected. Mr. J.R. Elder of the Columbia Athletic Club has been selected as referee.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21.--Executions were issued to-day against John B. Reed Co., shoedealers, at 439 Market-street, aggregating $9,800, on judgment notes issued Nov. 17 and payable in one day. After the executions had been issued a judgment was entered against the firm for $12,094 in favor of Mrs. P.M. Crosswell, the mother of one of the members of the firm. The cause of the firm's difficulties is said to be lack a of sufficient capital.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., Nov. 21.--It is rumored here to-night that the negotiations for the sale of a controlling interest in the great plant of the Connellsville Coke and Iron Company to the H.C. Frick Coke Company were consummated to-day. The plant is the largest in the Connellsville coke regions, and embraces 9,000 acres of coal land, 1,800 coke ovens, and miles of railroad track. The price paid is said to be several million dollars.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 21.--Following are the official returns of the vote of Virginia: Cleveland, 151,977; Harrison, 150,442; Cleveland's majority, 1,535. The vote in 1884 was: Cleveland, 145,497; Blaine, 139,356. Total, 284,853; Democratic loss, 4,606.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--Second Lieut. Willoughby Walke, Second Artillery, has been ordered to the Engineer School of Application at Willet's Point, New-York, for instruction in field fortification. Col. Thomas G. Bayler, Ordnance Department, has been granted leave of absence for four months on account of disability.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 21.--Prof. Clareive, who is attempting to walk on the water from Albany in New-York, reached here at 6 o'clock to-night and left at 7. He will try to make Sing Sing by Thursday night and New-York Friday. He complains of the cold.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 21.--A full house greeted the Campanini company here. De Vere, del Puente, and Signor Campanini received an ovation. The concert was the musical event of the season.
The reports that are to be found in the papers these days concerning the desire of Mr. WANAMAKER of Philadelphia to be made Secretary of the Treasury have, at least, a strong measure of probability.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Nov. 21.--Mr. Garrett was calmer to-day, although suffering from nervousness. He rested fairly well during the night, and this morning was able to go out for a short walk. He appeared weak. Dr. Jacobs said that he expected Mr. Garrett would have a good night's rest, and that he looked for an improvement in his condition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The Republicans who are anxious to secure a majority in the Fifty-first Congress are calling upon the public from day to day to assume that the Republican politicians of the country are entitled to a monopoly of virtue.

George S. Knight, the well-known actor, is ill at his residence in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J. His malady, many of his friends think, is akin in some degree to that which killed John McCullough and Bartlay Campbell and that compelled Tony Hart to leave the stage.

It was expected that more changes would be made yesterday in the staff of the Aqueduct Commission, but the expectation was not realized. The new chief engineer of the aqueduct, Alphonee Fteley, did not assume his duties yesterday.

The sale of property belonging to the estate of Joshua Jones at the Real Estate Exchange yesterday proved to be one of the largest sales ever made at the Exchange, and it was important, inasmuch as it is regarded as fixing the price of property in all that part of the city in which the majority of the Jones estate is situated. On the whole the sale was regarded as a very satisfactory one.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 22.--For the third time this season the oyster police have been routed by the piratical dredgers. The fight took place yesterday afternoon near the mouth of Little Choptank River. Several of the dredgers were shot, one of them, G. Castis of Northampton County, Va., being mortally wounded. He was brought to a hospital in this city.

LIVINGSTON, Ala., Nov. 22.--Last night Henry James, colored, and his wife went to a church supper, leaving their three children locked up in the house. Upon their return they found the house in ashes and the children burned to a crisp.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22.--Marquand Chapel was very prettily decorated to-day with roses and evergreens for the wedding of Prof. James Mark Baldwin of Lake Forest University and Miss Helen M. Green, daughter of the Rev. Dr. William Henry Green of Princeton Seminary. More than 600 invitations were issued, and most of them were accepted.
The Mail and Express shows real fidelity as an organ of the Republican Party by reading it a very salutary lesson on the subject of its management in city politics.

VALPARAISO, Neb., Nov. 22.--The State bank of this place has closed its door, and the proprietors, F. Scoville and G.A. Crafts, have fled the country, leaving many debts unsatisfied. As nearly as can be ascertained this evening the liabilities will reach $200,000.

The attendance at the Waverly track yesterday was very small and five bookmakers were more than enough to supply the demand for speculation. The racing was fairly good. In the fourth race Edward F. and Vitello fell, but neither of the jockeys were badly hurt.

An accidental fire and stampede of children took place in the First Ward School at Hunter's Point yesterday, but without serious injury to any one. The school building is in Sixthstreet, between East and Vernon avenues, and the average attendance of scholars is 850.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted the following bond offers: $550,000 registered 4 s at 109 1/8: $20,000 coupon 4 s and $12,350 registered 4 s at 109, making a total of $582,350.

BEAVER, Penn., Nov. 22.--The interest in the Hibbard-Fry breach of promise case increases as the end draws near. When the defendant went upon the stand this morning it was in the presence of a much larger crowd than has been here any day this week.

BOSTON, Nov. 22.--A jury's verdict rendered this morning in the United States Circuit Court, awarding an inventor trifling damages in a test case, will, unless overruled, involve the payment of millions by the canned goods manufacturers of this country.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday considered the provisional estimates of the sums needed by the various city departments and bureaus next year. These estimates were made by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 22.--A few days ago a man giving his name as Henry Hunter was arrested here, charged with successfully working the confidence trick on a newly-arrived young Scotchman. The case was remanded, the police meantime making an investigation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22,--In the absence from this city of Senator Blackburn it is impossible to ascertain what that gentleman is likely to do in regard to the letter of "Judge" Rucker of Colorado, published this morning. The dispute between the two men most concerned has not attracted a great deal or attention until ...

ALBANY, Nov. 22--Fremont Cole reached here this evening from Watkins with no special object in view, he said. He was the only prominent arrival, excepting Supervising Inspector of Steam Vessels James A. Dumont, from Washington, and his assistant, George H. Starbuck, from New York.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 22.--Patrick McManus of Milton, charged with mayhem, and William Dobson, who claims to be a boatman on the Delaware and Hudson Canal, charged with grand larceny, are prisoners in the same cell in the Ulster County Jail.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--The third day's session of the General Managers, who are endeavering to agree upon a basis for the reorganization of the Western States Passenger Association, demonstrated two things.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 22.--Capt. Sears of the Harvard Football Club has decided to forfeit the Thanksgiving inter-collegiate game to Yale. An invitation, however, has been sent to Yale to play an exhibition game on the Cambridge grounds on Thanksgiving Day.
CITY OF MEXICO Nov. 22, via Galveston, The Cabinet Ministers to-day handed in their resignations, to take effect Dec. 1, that President Diaz may have full liberty to appoint a ...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The Treasurer of the United States, the Hon. James W. Hyatt, has submitted to Secretary Fairchild his annual report of the operations of the Treasury.

The Princeton Club met at the Hotel Brunswick last night, and after a business meeting ate supper. The Treasurer reported a surplus of $1,180 in his hands, and the Executive Committee was instructed to consider the advisability of renting a clubhouse and to report at the club's next meeting.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 22.--The bay yearling filly by Baron Wilkes, dam by Enfield, has been sold for $2,500 by R.G. Stoner of Paris, Ky., to H. J. Williams of Anaconda, Montana. The same gentleman has purchased of W.R. Brasfield, this city, ...

WELLINGTON, Kan., Nov. 22.--Last evening about 8 o'clock Levi Meeker, wife, and 8year-old daughter, who live two miles east of Oxford, in Cowley County, were found dead on the Southern Kansas Railroad track by a son. It is supposed that they were struck while crossing the track in a wagon by the east-bound passenger train, which leaves Oxford usually at 7:20, but which was late last evening.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22.--The utmost consternation prevailed among the business community to-day at the report that Mr. SamueGreenshields of the firm of Greenshields Brothers, wholesale dry goods merchants, had died last night under very mysterious circumstances.

Two years ago ground was broken in the pretty town of Norwich, Conn., for a hall near the academy to commemorate John F. Slater, a citizen who crowned a life of philanthropy by giving to the Southern States a million dollars for the education of the blacks.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 22.--The official canvass of the vote of this State at the recent election was declared to-day. It is as follows: Harrison, 236,370; Cleveland, 213,404; Fisk, 20,942; Streeter, 4,542; Harrison's plurality, 22,966. The Prohibition vote was 2,539 greater than on President to 1884, and 4,237 less than on Governor in 1886.

Business ahead for Thomas C. Platt! The Owego Gazette reports that five Republican candidates for the Waverly Postmastership are already in the field with their petitions. One is an editor, another is a dentist named Snook, a third is a one-armed soldier, a fourth is the Town Clerk, and the fifth is a plain American citizen, without an "ex" to his name or a record in the army.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 22.--The deliveries of wheat from farmers' granaries in the north continues very free, and yesterday there was considerable stored wheat sold by farmers in the country elevators. The elevator companies and other country buyers continued to pay old prices to farmers, but dropped this morning.

After making threats for half a dozen years, the Baseball League passed what is known as the salary-graded list at the meeting at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday, and from present appearances a war between managers and players is imminent.

BERLIN, Nov. 22.--The German Reichstag reassembled to-day. Emperor William opened the session in person. In his speech he said that the tours he had recently made had convinced him that, the desire for imperial unity was deeply rooted in the people.

Judge Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday said that the laws of this State in regard to the commitment of children to institutions by Police Justices were very unjust and should be changed by the Legislature. HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 22.--A romance in real life is reported from Zelienople, Butler County. The story seems incredible, never theless it is authentic in every particular. Eighteen years ago Louis Leitz resided in a small village in France.

Versions of the Nathan murder, which, it will be remembered, occurred July 29, 1870, and has remained a mystery, crop out periodically. The latest one was given by a gentleman who called at THE TIMES office yesterday.

The Woman's Hospital of the State of New-York observed its thirty-third anniversary yesterday. Among those who gathered to listen to the reports and addresses were many prominent New-York ladies, whose names are included in the list of the supporters of the institution.

LONDON, Nov. 22.--The debate on the Land Purchase bill was resumed in the House of Commons to night by Mr. Parnell. He declared emphatically that he approved the bill, but be believed that it was so designed that, under the present circumstances, it would be impossible to put it into effective operation.
Yesterday was another day of bear jubilation on the Stock Exchange, and quotations melted away. The market was not a big one, but the declining prosperity of the whole list was marked.

It is not surprising that the "out-andout" Republican partisan organs should affect a good deal of scorn and indignation at the idea that any one but themselves should venture to suggest what course Mr. HARRISON may or ought to follow regarding civil service reform.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 22.--The question of elections still agitates the minds of the delegates of the Knights of Labor General Assembly. Every one now acknowledges the certainty of Powderly's re-election, and his choice for other positions will be the choice of the convention.

In the Church of the Ascension, where the late Rev. Dr. John Cotton Smith so long ministered, his daughter, Miss Julia James Smith, was married yesterday at noon to George B. Post, Jr., son of the noted architect.
It is the intention of the Directors of the Museum of Natural History to have all American animals represented in the museum in groups, embracing the species of each class.

JACKSONVILLE, Nov. 22.--President Neal Mitchell's official bulletin for the 24 hours ending at 6 o'clock this evening is: New cases, 13; deaths, none; total number of cases to date, 4,659; total number of deaths to date, 405.

Mrs. Yetta Greenbaum, a poor Jewess, has for a month past occupied a small rear room in the attic of the two-story dwelling 165 Delancey-street, with her three children. Yesterday afternoon Mrs. Greenbaum locked two of the children in the room while she went on an errand.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 22.--A big insurance case is on trial in the United States court here, involving insurance money to the amount of more than $142,000. One year ago the Cotton Compress Company was burned out, ...
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 22.--An atrocious murder of a colored woman who was trying to protect her son from drunken white men is reported from Lake City, Williamsburg County.

PINE CITY, Minn., Nov. 22.--S.K. Erwin, an old resident and a prominent Grand Army of the Republic man, was shot and killed today at Hinckley, where he was employed by the Eastern Railroad Company, by H.H. Scott, a neighbor, Family trouble is supposed to be the cause. Erwin was married and had three children.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 22.--The State Board of Canvassers met here to-day and announced the result on the Presidential ticket. The State gives Cleveland 147,902 and Harrison 134,784. Cleveland's majority is 13,118. Cleveland's majority in 1884 was 17,650. Fisk, the Prohibition candidate, received 2,788, falling far below what the third party claimed before the election.

The sixteenth annual meeting of the choirs of Trinity Parish, held in Trinity Chapel, West Twenty-fifth-street, last night was an impressive affair. When Dr. Gilbert began the organ prelude--an original andante--the crowd about the doors and in the aisles was so dense that a number of priests found it necessary to clear a passage.

OSYKA, Miss., Nov. 22.--Felix H. Vanardo, a prominent druggist and a man of family, was assassinated at 7 o'clock to-night. The assassin, hiding behind a pile of lumber, emptied both barrels of his gun, loaded with buckshot, into the breast of Vanardo, killing him instantly. There is no clue to the murderer.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22.--The Senate Cattle Trade Investigating Committee met at 11 o'clock this morning. The first witness was T. L. Leonard of Saline County, one of the largest importers of black cattle in Missouri. He said cattle markets were paralyzed by the control the dressed beef men had secured.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--M. Coquelin appeared this evening at Albaugh's Grand Opera House in "Les Surprises du Divorce," a very amusing comedy, full of mirth-provoking incidents.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 23.--B.L. Brown, a guest at the Hotel Albion from New-York, dropped dead to-day about 2 o'clock. An inquest was held and his family notified.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--After four days of earned effort to reach an agreement the General Managers of the lines in the territory of the Western States' Passenger Association were forced to adjourn to-day without having accomplished their purpose.

DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 23.--The survey for the Mandan and Black Hills Railroad has been completed, and a report from parties now in the East in the interest of the road gives assurance that work on this line will be pushed in the Spring. It is estimated that the road will cost about $30,000 per mile, and that it, will be one of the best paying lines in the Territory.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 23.--The two houses of the Alabama Legislature in caucus to-day nominated Gen. John T. Morgan for the United States Senate. Gen. Morgan has no opposition and on Tuesday he will, be elected by the Legislature to succeed himself as senior Senator from Alabama. Gen. Morgan has represented Alabama in the United States Senate since 1879.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 23.--The Presidentelect has been visited during the past week by a number of Dakota Republican interested in the immediate admission of that Territory as two States and anxious for a special session of the Fifty-first Congress for that purpose.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--Another legal proceeding to enforce a trust under an assignment was begun against the insolvent firm of Lindauer Brothers Co. to-day. The proceeding this time is in the Circuit Court and is in the form of a bill in chancery.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 23.--The Journal de St. Petersbourg denies that a secret treaty has been entered into by Corea and Russia. It admits that Corea has granted to Bussia facilities for trade across the frontier.
Norman E. Mack of Buffalo is at the St. James Hotel. Senator G.A. Deane of Copake, N.Y., is at the Murray Hill Hotel.

The managers of the Welcome Lodging House for Women and Little Children, 234 West Fourthstreet, have recently published a statement of the work accomplished during its third year, which closed Sept. 30. The report shows that 17,309 women and children have been lodged and 18,578 meals served during the year.

Thompson of Ohio is not the only Republican who is talking about a Republican bolt and the organization of a rump Congress in case a Democratic majority should appear and take charge of the next House of Representatives. AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 23.--The National Exposition has now been in progress two weeks and the exhibits are completed.

WINONA, Minn., Nov. 23.--The Winona and Southwestern Railway was formally opened to-day by an excursion over the first 20 miles of the road, tendered by President William Windom and other officials to about 200 business men and representatives of the press of the State.

Olaf Sunde, cashier of the New-York Daily News, who has been employed by that newspaper for 13 years, is missing, and the proprietor of the paper has reason to believe that Sunde has taken with him about $4,000 of the concern's money. Sunde has been cashier for several years, having long had the confidence of Col. Brown, the publisher.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 23.--This morning's session of the Episcopal Church Congress was well attended. The topic discussed was, "What Principle Should Govern Church Extension in Our Country in Fields Already Occupied by Others?" The first paper was by the Rev. T. R. Harris, D.D., of Morrisania, N.Y.

PORTAGE, Wis., Nov. 23.--D.S. Woodworth of Marcellon reports that an unknown disease is almost exterminating the cattle in his neighborhood and also further toward Kingston. The malady is immediately fatal. Cattle that are apparently all right at evening are dead at dawn.

The twenty-first anniversary of the death of the Irish "martyrs," Allen, Larkin, and O'Brien, who were hanged at Manchester for shooting the English policeman Brett, was celebrated by nearly a thousand of their country people at Cooper Union last night. A brass band played a number of stirring old Irish airs and a mixed quartet sang several of Tom Moore's pretty songs.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 23.--The Gala Week Association made a flank movement on the weather to-day by postponing the further celebration of the carnival until next week.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 23.--The weather is clear and cool and the track good. WABASH, Ind., Nov. 23.--David Hamilton, an extensive real estate dealer and owner of several business structures here, has failed with liabilities amounting to $30,000 and assets of $25,000.

Foley of Baltimore, the newly-consecrated Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Detroit, arrived in this city this evening and was the recipient of an imposing demonstration. Mayor Hewitt yesterday cleared up the mystery surrounding the lady whom he appointed on Wednesday a Commissioner of Common Schools. As THE TIMES suggested on Thursday, she is not Mrs. William G. Rice as her name was written on the list of appointments, but Mrs. William B. Rice of 17 West Sixteenth-street.

The Christmas number of Harper, which is just ready, must rank as one of the earliest of the holiday publications in the form of a periodical. There could scarcely be a more pleasant reminder of the approaching season.

DENNY, the King's Counselor and Director of Foreign Affairs.

LONDON, Nov. 23.--In the House of Commons this evening Mr. Sexton asked whether it was true that seven Irish members were about to be prosecuted, and, if so, whether there was any relation between the prosecution and the delay of the debate on the Irish estimates.

Messrs, Carter Brothers have issued a volume of sermons by the Rev. Dr. James McCosh, ex-President of Princeton College, which cannot fail to make a deep impression upon the Christian world and have a profound effect upon the religious status of the time.
BOSTON, Nov. 23.--The statement telegraphed from New-York on Wednesday that a conference of the large carpet manufacturers had agreed to advance the price of carpets has caused considerable comment.

Peter Baer, aged 45, a carpenter, residing at Concord, Staten Island, was arrested yesterday on the charges of abduction. The complainant is Joseph Naegengaest, a brewer, residing at Stapleton, who accuses Baer of having run away with his wife and $40 of his hard-earned savings, leaving behind her two children.

At 6 o'clock yesterday morning the temperature was recorded at 18 at the Weather Bureau, Equitable Building. Not since 1883 has the cold weather come on so early and so sharply. The lowest temperature for Nov. 13 of that year was 8 . Other early cold snaps occurred in 1880, when the thermometer recorded 14 Nov. 22 and 16 Nov. 23.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 23.--The State Board of Canvassers has at last concluded the canvass of all the State and Federal returns, and has declared the result, which is the election of the entire Democratic Electoral ticket by the following vote: Cleveland, 65,825; Harrison, 13,740; Democratic majority, 52,085.

The butchers and range cattle growers who met in St. Louis to put an end to the distribution of dressed beef from Chicago have thus far accomplished nothing. Garfield, as a student at Williams College, united with the social fraternity which was organized as an anti-secret college ...

The funeral of Nathaniel Currier, the publisher, took place yesterday afternoon at the residence, 28 West Twenty-seventh-street. If Mayor Hewitt can help it the next Board of Street Opening will not fail to ascertain that it is the opinion of himself and Gen. Newton, Commissioner of Public Works, that Elm-street should not be widened and lengthened at its down-town end. Yesterday Mr. Hewitt had spread on the minutes of the board a declaration to that effect. Gen. Newton assisted him to put it there.

The apparently ungovernable temper of "Andy" McCarthy, at one time one of the most promising light-weight jockeys of the country, has resulted in his banishment from both the New-Jersey Winter tracks, his dismissal from Guttenberg on Thursday being followed by a similar action on the part of the Clifton management yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23.--Brig.-Gen. Nelson A. Miles assumed command, of the Division of the Pacific this morning. Gen. O.O. Howard, the retiring commander, greeted his successor. Gen. Miles issued immediately a brief order to all military posts setting forth that he had formally taken command and stating that Lieuts. Gatewood and Depray will act as his aides. Gen. Howard and Lieut. Greble started to-day for New-York.

POCOMOKE CITY, Md., Nov. 23.--Fire broke out here at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the drug store of D.O.J. Truitt. This building was situated in the heart of the town, and from the first it was a hopeless case.

An entertainment consisting of a Kaffeekiatsch and tableaus will be held this afternoon and evening at 356 West Thirty-third-street to raise funds to further the work of the Society to Befriend Working Girls. Since the organization of the society the house has been filled to its utmost capacity and it is found necessary to wise a considerable amount of money to meet the running expenses.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 23.--Arthur L. Kending, Sr., a prominent resident of Riverside, was instantly killed shortly before noon to-day by an east-bound train on the Consolidated Road near Stamford.

For more than a year the railroads of the Southwest have been engaged in a bitter rate war. Prompted to the fight by jealousies growing out of encroachments upon one another's territory, all of the great lines west of the Missouri, all plunged into a cutthroat competition that has stopped at nothing to work mutual disaster.

BOSTON, Nov. 23.--The statement in sevral papers this morning that Harvard has agreed to forfeit the championship game with Yale on condition that Yale will play an exhibition game at Cambridge Thanksgiving Day is unauthorized. No decision has yet been reached.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 23.--Gov. Larrabee to-day sent a letter to the Clerks of the Courts of Webster County in which he says: "The daily papers contain the information that Federal officers have evicted quite a number of river land settlers in your county and that more evictions will be effected in the near future.

An important special meeting of the Woolon Goods Association was held yesterday at 65 Leonard-street. Representatives from Providence, R.L; Rockville, Conn,; Webster, Mass., and Philadelphia, Penn., were present at the meeting. The New-York manufacturing interests were well represented.
The fifty-second annual convention of the Theta Delta Chi fraternity was brought to a close last evening at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel with a banquet.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23.--The borough of South Chester to-day caused judgment to be entered in the Prothonotary's office in Philadelphia for $25,679 40 upon promissory notes given by Samuel R. Bullock, the water works contractor of New-York, who recently failed for a heavy amount.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 23.--The temperance people of Monmouth County, nearly 500 strong met here to-day in convention, Delegates, many of them ladies, were present from 11 out of the 16 townships comprising the county.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 23.--Another railroad is to be added to the network of the systems in the Northwest. The new project has for its object an air line to Kansas City from the Twin Cities, via Des Moines, and over a route almost equi-distant from the Kansas City and Omaha lines.

MONTREAL, Nov. 23.--At a private meeting of the shareholders of the Canadian Pacific Railway this afternoon, it was resolved to lease, in perpetuity, the Detroit extension of the Ontario and Quebec Railway. The Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, member of Parliament, and his recently-married wife, accompanied by Lord Sackville, with his two daughters, arrived in this city from Washington yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock. The party passed the night at the Brevoort House.
RINGWOOD, N.J., Nov. 23.--Mr. Garrett did not have a comfortable day. He was out of the house and walked in the grounds with his attendants.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23.--The official canvass of the Fifth Congressional District elects Thomas J. Clunie. (Dem.,) he having received 42 majority over Phelps. The latter, it, is reported, will contest Clunie's election. The California delegation in t.e. Fifty-first Congress will stand exactly as predicted in THE TIMES, two weeks before election.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Prof. Oldrieve, Who is walking on the water of the Hudson from Albany to New-York, was reported at 9 o'clook this morning below Fort Montgomery, 17 miles south of this city.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--Twenty-two of the lines in the Central Traffic Association have responded favorably to a request that a meeting of the General Managers be held next Friday for the purpose of considering the restoration of east-bound freight rates.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23.--A special from Shawneetown, Ill., says that George W. Milliken paid the penalty for wife murder on the scaffold here to-day. At the scaffold Milliken broke down completely and had to be assisted up the steps. His neck was broken in the fall. The execution was private, though fully 1,000 people surrounded the jail.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23.--The Senate investigating committee was late in coming to order this morning, it being nearly 12 o'clock before the Chairman's gavel fell. Senator Plumb was not present, and Senator Cullom was too ill to be present and had gone home.

The selection of Seth Low for the Presidency of Columbia College, which is soon to become vacant by the resignation of President Bernard, would secure for that institution the services of a young, vigorous, and intelligent man, who has proved his executive capacity in the successful management of the affairs of a great city.

LONDON, Nov. 23.--The race for the Lancashire Stakes of 500 sovereigns, at the Manshester meeting to-day, was won by Tommy Tittlemouse. Arundel was second and The Shrew third. There ware 15 starters. The betting was 10 to 1 against Tommy Tittlemouse.

The switchmen on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad are bestirring themselves in an attempt to gain an increase of wages. For some time past they have been sending in petitions to the officers of the road, and on Friday a committee of the men called in upon Superintendent Toucey and asked that an increase of pay might be awarded them.

In the case of Samuel W. Lewis against Charles G. Wilson, as President of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange, the General Term of the Supreme Court has decided that his suspension from membership was legal, and incidentally that speculative contracts for future delivery are also legal.

BOSTON, Nov. 23.--It now seems probable that the little zinc trunk that furnished the detectives a promising clue for the capture of the Braintree murderer has developed only a case of mistaken identity and that the trunk and its owner are entirely innocent of criminal connections.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 23.--The strike of railroad switchmen is taking on an ugly phase. Not a single switch engine in the city was moved this morning. The railroads during to-day have been considerably embarrassed, although the movement of passenger trains has not been interfered with except in the necessity of bringing other employes to the work of making up trains.

Judge Beach, in the Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday, heard the testimony in the contested will case of Catherine McCoskry, the widow of Robert McCoskry, one of the founders of tho Chemical Bank. Mrs. McCoskry died April 22, 1886, leaving property said to be now worth $800,000, and leaving no issue.

DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 23.--Harry Blasser, chief clerk of the La Pointe Indian Agency under James Gregory, is in the city. He says that the Indians of the Grand Portage Reserve are in a bad state; that they are almost starving, and have sent in a pitiful appeal for aid.

The revelations will affect several members of the Chamber of Deputies.

The figures given to the Electoral ticket are the same as those printed in THE TIMES yesterday, and represent the vote received by the largest number of Electors on each national ticket.

BOSTON, Nov. 23.--The statement published yesterday that Silas Gurney, proprietor of the Tremont House, had gone into insolvency is incorrect. Mr. Gurney is not the proprietor of the Tremont House and has not been connected with that hotel since a year ago last January. The proprietors of the Tremont House, H. M. Hartshorn Son, are not insolvent. The financial standing of the firm is unquestioned.

Madison-Square Garden was the Mecca of a host of people yesterday afternoon who worship at the shrine of athletics. The reason for this was the meeting of most of the 40 pedestrians who at midnight to-night will start out on a six days' tramp in an effort to beat the world's record at this sort of sport--621 5/8 miles--made by Peter Albert over the sawdust track in Madison-Square Garden last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--William J. O'Connor, the Canadian oarsman, defeated John Teemer of McKeesport, Penn., holder of the title of champion oarsman of America, this afternoon in a three-mile race on the Potomac River, opposite Washington, for the championship of America and a stake of $2,500 aside. O'Connor rowed in splendid form and led from start to finish, Teemer at no time being able to overtake him.

Dr. Sallo Callmann, for nearly 25 years a physician in this city, died suddenly on Friday afternoon, probably of apoplexy, at this home, 178 East Seventy-fifth-street. This composition was the severest test to which the Roumanian pianist's powers have yet been put, and he emerged from the trial triumphant. The Superintendents of all the lines held a conference this afternoon, and it was unanimously agreed that no concessions should be made. The number of freight trains leaving the city during the last 24 hours was not more than a dozen.

SAUK CENTRE, Minn., Nov. 24.--Parties from here, while on a hunting expedition near Lake Itasca, discovered that neither Lake Itasca nor Lake Glazier (properly Elk Lake) is the source of the Mississippi River. The true source is a number of large springs that pour out from the mountains about three miles southeast of Itasca.

LONDON, Nov. 24.--All Europe is watching with excited anxiety for further developments in French politics, which have suddenly tumbled into anarchic confusion. Such a jumble of personal rivalries, personal feuds, and personal treacheries go to make up this threatening situation that it is impossible for even well-informed Parisians to pretend to explain it.

PANAMA, Nov. 16.--Nicaragua has accepted the United States Government's invitation to join the proposed conference of American Republics Oct. 2. 1889.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Edward Egbertson of Syracuse, for illegal registration, was sentenced today to one month in the Onondaga Penitentiary. Eugene Wyckoff, for a like offense, was sentenced to two months. They are to pay the costs of prosecution.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 24.--The next Legislature will be asked to enact additional fishery laws. It is proposed to make the laws relating to the opening of the fishery season the same in Pennsylania, Delaware, and New-Jersey. By such a course further misunderstandings may be avoided, and the interests of all three of the States protected. The Fish Commissions of the three States are preparing the proposed new law.

WINDHAM, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Henry Sutton of Conesville, while hunting a day or two ago with his fox hound, Pete, "started up" a variety of game. Among the animals bagged was a lynx, which Sutton pursued for six hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--The plea of President Lucius B. Swift of the Indiana Civil Service Reform Association for local examination boards which shall be "absolutely independent" of local appointing officers is not a new one to the friends of the merit system here, and it does not attract very much attention.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24.--The examination of the returns from many wards of the Fourth Congressional District has, it is said, revealed errors and inaccuracies in the counting of votes. In many precincts the sum of votes credited each candidate far exceeds the total number of votes polled.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 24.--The sensation of the day has been a circular issued to the taxpayers of this city by Mayor Oilver, showing the way the city is being annually fleeced by the electric light company that is lighting the city.

The Prospect Harriers of Brooklyn held their first moonlight run of the season late on Friday night. The club members and their friends assembled on their new grounds at Washington Park, Brooklyn, to witness the start of 14 of the best runners in the club. C.E. Nicolls was first on the run in, closely followed by G.J.L. Wilson, C.S. Donaghue, and T.G. Ryan. The distance was slightly over four and a half miles.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 24.--Chancellor Gibson rendered an opinion to-day enjoining the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company from operating the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia system under the lease recently made and which is to be acted upon by the stockholders on Dec. 22.

LONDON, Nov. 24.--Sir Charles Warren, who recently resigned as Chief of Police of London, has been offered the command of the brigade at Aldershot. This shows that the Queen's confidence in him has not abated. He will doubtless accept the offer.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Ice formed in the Delaware and Hudson Canal last night. This forenoon several ice-breakers broke a track for boats. Canalers are hurrying along, as the company is anxious to get all the boats to tidewater. This afternoon the last permits for empty boats for Honesdale, Penn., were issued in the company's office here. Ice formed along shore in the Upper Hudson last night.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 24.--The Zoar oil field is situated just over the edge of Eric County, in Cattaraugus. Up to the present time Zoar has done nothing to distinguish itself, not withstanding the fact that it had a full-fledged mystery, with regulation guards and creeping spies.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 24.--Three white convicts and one negro were whipped at New-Castle this morning for larcenies and burglaries. They took from five to twenty lashes each, lightly laid. About 250 spectators were present.

Several ministers of up-town churches in Brooklyn have recently organized a Union Clerical Club. It is composed of ministers of all evangelical churches, and will hold its meetings every Monday afternoon from 1 to 4 o'clock at some place to be agreed upon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--Grover Cleveland's defeat in the recent election has been accounted for in many ways during the last fortnight. The men who regard the Republican victory as an assurance of continued and perhaps increasing customs duties attribute it entirely to the "free-trade" message sent by President Cleveland to Congress a year ago.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 24.--Judge Fred D. King yesterday rendered an interesting decision in the succession of Romain Buissiere, in which a large fortune is involved, and where the parties belong to a creole family of the highest respectability and culture. Buissiere died on the 8th of April, 1887. Two wills of the deceased were probated in this court.
