WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 24.--Judge Andrews in the Superior Court to-day overruled the demurrers of the defendant in the celebrated Bridgeport Hetchkiss will case, involving an estate of $12,000,000. This removes all the technical defenses and allows the case to go before the Superior Court on its merits.

Commander Ramsay of the Boston said that the Haytian Republic was captured coming out of the harbor of St. Marc for trying to raise the blockade. She was captured by the Haytian manof-war Dessaline. Commander Ramsay had several interviews with the President of Hayti, at which he interceded for the release of the Haytian Republic. The President refused and said the matter had been referred to the Secretary of State at Washington for final action.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 24.--The Lehigh University football team tied the University of Pennsylvania eleven for first place in the championship race by defeating Lafayette College here this afternoon by a score of 16 to 0.

James E. Bedell, the forger, who received a sentence of 25 years and 4 months in Sing Sing Prison and who was taken there on Friday afternoon, began his prison life in earnest yesterday. He occupied cell 224, in No. 5 gallery.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Nov. 24.--A peculiar case of insanity was developed here to-day in an examination before Probate Judge Myers. Frank Russell, a well-to-do farmer, became hopelessly insane, and was sent to the asylum at Toledo. Oil and gas men had pursued him day and night to obtain a lease upon his farm until he became so worried that his mental faculties could no longer stand the strain.

The Australian Government is building a fence of wire netting 8,000 miles long to ivide New South Wales and Queensland, in order to keep the jack rabbits out of the latter country. Australia is paying not less than $125,000 per year to keep the pests down in what are known as crown lands. The offer is still kept up of $100,000 to any man who will produce something that will exterminate the pests.

Verneseo, Minister of Justice; M. Lahovary, Minister of Domains; M. Marghiloman, Minister of Public Works; M. Mano, Minister of War; M. Majoresco, Minister of Public Instruction; M. The General Term of the Supreme Court has affirmed the order of the Special Term, made last June, imposing a fine upon the Meyer-Sniffer Company, Limited, of this city, for non-payment of a tax on its capital stock for 1885. The company was assessed for that year at $75,000, and taxed at $1,800.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 24.--This was the third day of the Fall meeting of the Louisiana Jockey Club. The weather was clear and pleasant and the track in good condition, but the attendance was light.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Nov. 24.--John Roche and Patrick Cavanagh, at work on the chimney at the new Pacific Mills, fell 120 feet with the elevator at noon to-day. The timbers holding the block to which the elevator was attached broke from their fastenings and the men went down with the frame. Roche received a bad wound on the hip and is injured internally. Cavanagh's injuries are very serious.

Benjamin Thompson, the Fifth Ward scientist, who says that the extensive use of electricity is corrupting the morals of the young, and gradually destroying all the virtue and charity in the land, is getting to be a wellknown figure around the City Hall and at the office of the Electric Light Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24.--Pitcher Pete Conway of the Detroit signed a contract in this city to-day to play with the Pittsburgh Club. Conway, with second baseman Frederick Dunlap and President Nimick of the Pittsburg team and Billy Carlin returned from New York yesterday morning, where they had been attending the big meeting of the League.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Pleuropneumonia among the cattle in this county has assumed alarming proportions, especially in the town of Monroe. Dr. McLane, United States Inspector, has been occupied for some days past in examining various herds.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Commodore Cicero Price, United States Navy, died here this evening of pleuro-pneumonia after a few days' illness. He was nearly 63 years old. He had lived in Troy for the past 36 years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24.--The Grand Jury today entered upon an investigation of the methods of Cashier Fallman of the bankrupt Traders' Bank. The prosecuting witness in the case is a business man who, a day or two before the failure, deposited $3,000 in the bank.

BEAVER, Penn., Nov. 24.--The curtain fell on the Hibbard-Fry farce this morning when the jury came in with a verdict for the defendant, after being out nearly 36 hours. As early as 6 o'clock this morning Beaver County was awake and waiting for the verdict in the Hibbard-Fry breach of promise. The defendant, Mr. Fry, was a trifle worried regarding the length of time it took the jury to arrive a conclusion.

Mrs. Alice Le Plongeon delivered an illustrated lecture at Cooper Union last evening on Yucatan. There was a large audience, including many teachers. Mrs. Plongeon described the habits of life of the Indians, the natives of the country, and pointed out many startling similarities between their gods and forms of worship and those of the Egyptians.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 24.--The rails and ties have arrived for the extension of the tracks of the Norwalk and South Norwalk Horse Railroad Company to Winnipauk. The contract for the work has been awarded, and operations will be commenced immediately.

BOSTON, Nov. 24.--Watson Allen, who was mentioned in yesterday's dispatches in connection with the murder of Miss White at Braintree, has been at work recently in Cambridge, and yesterday by reported himself to the police. They declined to place him under arrest, as they do not believe he had anything to do with the murder.

The sixteenth anniversary of the old Jerry McAuley Mission, at 316 Water-steet, was observed yesterday in the familiar old building by a great number of friends, who crowded the room to the doors. When those who had been converted in the mission were asked to rise over half of the audience stood up.

ROME, Nov. 25.--King Humbert to-day gave audience to M. Mariani, the newly-ap pointed French Ambassador. In welcoming the Ambassador his Majesty said that if France met the good intentions of Italy in a friendly spirit all differences of opinion could be easily settled.

CENTREVILLE, Penn., Nov. 26.--A boiler at Ralston's saw mills exploded to-day, killing George Kelly, the sawyer; Jesse Hall, the fireman, and Leslie Cross, a farmer. Lewis Ralston was badly scalded, but may recover. Joseph Dickson was tossed into the woods, but escaped unhurt. The men had gathered around the furnace in the mill to warm themselves and await the rolling in of some logs when suddenly the boiler burst.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 26.--Oil was struck to-day at the depth of 1,000 feet in a well being sunk in the Sequatchie Valley near this city. CHICAGO, Nov. 27.--This evening Mme. Hading appeared for the first time in Chicago at McVicker's Theatre. LONDON, Nov. 27.--In the House of Commons this evening Mr. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland, intimated that Mr. Harrington, Mr. Finucane, and other members of the Irish party under warrant of arrest, would be permitted to attend the sittings of Parliament during the time the Irish estimates were under discussion.

The spacious parlors of Mrs. William E. Dodge's residence, 225 Madison-avenue, were thronged with ladies yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the New-York Indian Association. Mrs. Theodore Irving presided, and interesting addresses were made by the Rev. Dr. Charles L. Thompson, the Rev. Mr. Frizzelle, ...

The first of a series of three readings by Mr. George Riddle attracted a numerous audience at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. The programme seemed promising, but the promise was not all fulfilled. Miss Marbury has often rendered a French subject into English...

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 27.--Atlantic's beach front property owners are actively engaged in removing the debris, which is all that remains of their holdings after the terrific storm of the last two days.

DANVILLE, Va., Nov. 27.--The Committee on Sales of premium tobacco Friday and Saturday on this market footed up the figures to-day, which show that 105,378 pounds were sold, bringing $19,617 31, an average of $18 60 per hundredweight. Taking into account the large amount of inferior grades offered the average is a capital one.
In the crowd of sea-sick and unsteadilywalking steerage passengers which the steamer Arizona brought to port yesterday were four who had been brought to this country very much against their wills.
The Goethe Society of the City of NewYork held its first monthly reunion for the season of 1888-'9 at the Hotel Brunswick last night.
Chief Arthur of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Grand Master Sergeant of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen were in this...

The Queen intends to place an equestrian statue of the late Emperor Frederick in Windsor Great Park, in close proximity to the statue of the Prince Consort which has been purchased out of the Women's jubilee offering, and which, by the way, will probably be unveiled by her Majesty in March next.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27.--Tne bronze bust of the tragedian, John McCullough, in the character of Virginius, will be unveiled to-morrow with imposing ceremonies on the pretty hillside overlooking the Elks' Rest, in Mount Morlan Cemetery.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 27.--Never before in the history of Connecticut has the rockribbed town of North Stonington yielded such a crop of Thanksgiving Day turkeys as this year. Nothing of the kind has been known in this antiquated town's history.

Nearly three years have passed since M. PASTEUR'S reported discovery of an effective method of inoculation for rabies became the subject of lively discussion in all parts of the civilized world. On the 14th inst. the Institute built in Paris by public subscription for the use of M. PASTEUR and his...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--Secretary Endicott said to-day that the staff and other vacancies in the army would not be filled until after the meeting of Congress.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 27.--The movement in behalf of a secret ballot in this State has gained ground rapidly during the past two months.

While Patrolmal James Foley of the Mercer-street police station was at the corner of Eleventh-street and University-place at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon he saw a tall, slim, rough-looking fellow running down University-place at the top of his speed. A man driving by in a wagon told him that a lady had been pursuing him, but had become exhausted and had given up the chase.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--Secretary Endicott said to-day that the staff and other vacancies in the army would not be filled until after the meeting of Congress.

The bloody handkerchiefs found near the West Ninety-second-street entrance to Central Park, the blood-bespattered ground, and rusted revolver, which caused something of a stir among the police last Friday, and were finally decided to have been the work of a practical joker, were aired afresh yesterday. It is now declared that a duel actually took place at the spot and some one was wounded.

Mr. Robert Garrett's miniature game preserve at Uplands, his beautiful country seat in Baltimore County, is still kept stocked. It occupies the western part of Uplands, and is in the middle of a tract of land originally known as Hunting Ridge. The property is in one of the most beautiful places to be found in the county.

BERLIN, Nov. 27.--In the Reichstag today the President announced that the office bearers of the House were received yesterday by the Emperor, who expressed the hope that the deliberations would be harmonious and rapid and for the welfare of the fatherland. The debate on the budget was then opened.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Nov. 27.--Mr. Garrett is likely to spend the holidays at the Miller mansion. A shelter house has been erected on the grounds expressly for the use of the millionaire in stormy weather when he cannot go out on his usual walk.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 27.--The Tea Garden Hotel, at Mississippi City, on the Gulf coast, was burned to the ground early this morning, the inmates barely escaping with their lives.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 28.--It is rumored here that the oleomargarine manufacturers of Chicago are manipulating the butter market for the purpose of disposing of the oleo product.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 28.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following causes were argued: No. 26--Mary Fitzgerald, Administratrix, respondent, vs. ...

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Nov. 28.--Two gangs of Russian and Italian miners, between whom there has existed a bitter feud for months, met on the streets of Mount Carmel to-day and for an hour a riot raged.
ROME, Nov. 28.--The Senate to-day, by a small majority, rejected the bill for the extension of political suffrage to women.

Wheat was firmly if not excitedly bullish on the Produce Exchange yesterday. The market was helped by reports of strength in Chicago, better cables, and free buying by some of the foreign houses for December.

A fire broke out at 5:30 o'clock last evening in the cellar of the five-story building 52 Lispenard-street. The upper floors of the building are occupied by Dreyfus Brother, manufacturers of upholstery trimmings, and over a hundred girls and men were at work on the upper floors.

There was an informal discussion at the meeting of the Park Board yesterday respecting what shall be done for the care of the great quantity of land for new parks that is about to be taken possession of by the board.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28.--Mrs. Sarah Jane Whiteling, who has been on trial before Judge Allison for several days, was convicted of murder in the first degree this afternoon. Mrs. Whiteling killed her husband and two little children at intervals by slow poison to obtain a paltry life insurance of about $125 on each.
PARIS, NOV. 28.--Mme. Patti's appearance in "Romeo and Juliet" this evening was the occasion of one of the most brilliant gatherings ever seen in the Paris Opera House.

The question whether a Territory is entitled to admission as a State ought of course to be decided without reference to the political opinions or affiliations of its inhabitants. But it is equally a matter of course that it will not be so decided while human nature and American politics remain what they are.
MONTREAL, Nov. 28.--A daring robbery was committed in St. James-street this afternoon about 5 o'clock, while the street was crowded.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Nov. 28.--The steamer Nickerson has arrived and reports having picked up on Middle Bank to-day the schooner M. and A. Morrison of Shelburne, nova Scotia, which has been abandoned. She was dismasted and waterlogged.

They are not acute but they seem likely to become so before the primary elections take place, on Dec. 27, for the choice of members of the General Committee of 1889. NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 28.--Joseph Barlow, an aged farmer, who lives near Piscataway town, was terribly beaten this afternoon by pot hunters who were crossing his farm. There were three of them, and they had followed a pair of rabbits on Barlow's farm and entered his cornfield after them.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28.--To-day the Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad chose Amos R. Little as a Director to fill the vacancy in the board caused by the death of John Price Wetherill.

Al Hayman has telegraphed to Mme. Modjeska, notifying her that he has concluded not to accept her terms for a tour of the United States next season, and he will now only act as her manager during her California tour this Winter, as originally arranged. CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--The monument to be erected over the tomb of the late John Wentworth, has been shipped from Hallowell, Me., over the Grand Trunk Railway, and is now on the way to this city.
Karl Hansen left the service of the Government as a marine at the Brooklyn Navy Yard to marry a widow who had grown rich keeping a grocery store near the navy yard gate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--A quintet of promnent Wisconsin politicans were at the Grand Pacific to-day. They were Senator J.C. Spooner, Senator Philetus Sawyer, Chairman H.C. Payne of the Wisconsin Republican Committee; Gov. Jerry Rusk, and George C. Ginty. A consultation between these gentlemen lasted some hours, after which Senator Spooner took a train for Washington.
Cholly--Well, old chappie, how did you enjoy the ball last night?

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 28.--Minnie McCarty and Mary Maloney, employed in the burner shop at Forestville, were swept by the storm from a footbridge into the Pequabuck River while going home last night.

The ocean steamers which arrived yesterday had experienced the full force of the big storm of Sunday, and passengers and officers bore testimony of its unusual severity. The Louisiana of the Cromwell Line. from NewOrleans, encountered the gale off Hatteras, and was obliged to heave to for 30 hours.

The ceremonies incident to the laying of the cornerstone of the new quarters of the Progress Club occurred yesterday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock upon the site of the building on the northeast corner of Fifth-avenue and Sixtythird-street. The exercises consisted merely of the presentation of a box containing coins, current literature, and the history of the club by ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--Some months ago, in order to save expense, the civilian watchmen at the navy yard in this city were discharged, and the duties of the watchmen devolved upon soldiers of the Marine Corps, who act as sentries at the entrance to the yard.
"Officer of the Day," ordered Commander Heilfertz of Farragut Post, No. 75 G.A.R., last evening, "you will present Comrade O'Beirne at headquarters." Comrade O'Beirne was duly presented.

Brooklyn has a Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children which believes in practical reformatory work rather than sensationalism. Its conduct on these lines has won for it a most cordial support from both the people and the authorities of Brooklyn, as well as in some of the neighboring towns to which its work has been extended.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 28.--The owners of wrecked property by the storm along the beach are either preparing to rebuild or are securing the remainder of their holdings against further damage by the Winter storms.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--The leave of absence granted First Lieut. D.B. Houghton, Third Cavalry, has been extended one month; that of First Lieut. Robert London, Fifth Cavalry, five months, and that of Capt. J.B. Rodman, Twentieth Infantry, one month. Capt. George E. Pold, Assistant Quartermaster, has been ordered to temporary duty at Fort Collins, Colorado.

TORONTO, NOV. 28.--Roland Gideon Israel Barnett, the celebrated financial "fakir," bucket-shop speculator, , of New-York, Toronto, London, and various other places, leaves London, England, to-morrow, in charge of an English detective, for this city.

It is pretty clear that sooner or later the Government of the United States will have to make some provision for the regulation of railroad charges, at least where commerce between States is liable to disturbance and derangement through the competition of different lines for the same traffic.
John A. Kasson of Iowa is at the Brevoort House. Gen. Joseph T. Torrence of Chicago is at the Windsor Hotel.

E. Robinson has been appointed manager of the trunk line joint ticket office at 1 Broadway, vice Henry Poggenburg, who resigned several days ago to take charge of the First Ward passenger business for the Baltimore and Ohio Road. Mr. Robinson has been with the joint office in the capacity of clerk since its opening.
The track at Clifton yesterday was very heavy, and consequently slow. The racing was fairly good, and was witnessed by the usual large gathering. Only one favorite won. Results follow:

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--W.B. Wharton, an insurance soliciter, has not been in the city for some time, and his accounts are short. No one seems to know the amount of the reported shortage, but it is estimated to be in the neighborhood of $5,000. Wharton is an old insurance man, having been with the Sun Insurance Company of New-York for 14 years.

Rutherford, and F.O. Beach, ...

News received from the interior of the State yesterday encouraged those who are favorable to the election of Fremont Cole to the Speakership of the Assembly. Ernest H. Crosby is confident that Mr. Cole will win. He said last evening:

The new steamer of the Atlas Line, the Adirondack, arrived at this port from Glasgow yesterday. The Adirondack is destined to carry passengers and freight to Southern waters, and is to take the place of the old Atlas which was so ignominiously sunk at the foot of Barclaystreet by a ferryboat.

New-York is a good city to work in and to live in, but to the minds of the tens of thousands of New-Englanders who reside here it is the poorest sort of a place in which to spend Thanksgiving Day. Brought up as they are to almost religiously view the day as one for family gatherings, their hearts yearn for the sight of "home," and intuitively they turn their foot-steps to-ward it.

The current report of Major-Gen. SCHOFIELD and Adjt.-Gen. DRUM and the various commanders of divisions and departments and heads of staff bureaus and corps suggest that our regular army has now arrived at a stage where careful revision and reorganization as a military peace establishment would be practicable and useful.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 28.--There is every indication that a passenger rate war between the lines running to Chicago is about to be inaugurated, and that the public will be given an opportunity to travel at cheaper rates than have been in force since the time when $1 was the prevailing fare for the round trip to the Garden City.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 28.--Dr. Hoyt of Albany, Secretary of the State Board of Charities, in company with members of the local branch of the association, recently visited the county buildings. They reported that the inmates were well fed and clothed, but that there were not a sufficient number of attendants, nor was there room enough in the buildings to properly accommodate the paupers.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 28.--The steamer Worcester, for whose safety fears were felt, has arrived, She left Boston on Saturday last.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--Coquelin and Hading gave to-day two performances in Chicago at McVicker's Theatre, playing at the matinee "L'Aventuriere." and in the evening "FrouFrou." The two stars appeared at both performances.

MONTREAL, Nov. 28.--Judge Mathieu rendered judgment this morning condemning Page, the young clerk now in St. Vincent de Paul Penitentiary for forging a check on the Jacques Cartier Bank, to pay $1,000 damages to Mr. Joseph Ducles, whom he had victimized by ...

The objections filed to the awards reported by the Commissioners for the new parks are being withdrawn in considerable numbers. The total amount comprehended in the protests was about $2,100,000, and the money represented in the withdrawals amounts to $400,000 or $500,000.

RACINE, Wis., Nov. 28.--The condition of Jay Eye See, Mr. Case's fast gelding, it is thought to-night is better, but his recovery is doubtful. He is receiving the best treatment which money can procure.
RINGWOOD, N.J., Nov. 28.--Mr. Garrett was quiet to-day, and there was no perceptible change in his condition.

OTTAWA, Nov. 28.--sheriff Hathaway of Helena, Montana, obtained papers to-day from the Department of Justice for the extradition of George Godin, a French half breed, who escaped from jail at Helena July 15 while under senttence of death for the murder of an old settler named Embody.

During the past three weeks the numerous tenants occupying the four tenement houses running from 1,002 to 1,008 Avenue A have been in a constant terror owing to the occurrence of two incendiary fires in one of the houses. Yesterday afternoon another suspicious fire occurred in the same house.

At the annual meeting of the New-York Society for the Relief of Widows and Orphans of Medical Men last night at the Academy of Medicine, in West Thirty-first-street, Dr. Henry Tuck was elected President.
Antoinette Blanco, a 16-months-old Cuban baby, the adopted daughter of Mrs. Jesus Blanco, a Cuban lady stopping at the Hotel America, had rather a funny experience yesterday afternoon.

Edward F. Underhill, assistant to the Surrogate, listened to the testimony in the contested will case of Jette Lissauer yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Lissauer was an old Hebrew lady who died Dec. 27, 1887.

BOSTON, Nov. 28.--The registers of voters furnish figures showing that 20,216 women out of the 25,000 who were assesed have registered and qualified to vote for members of the School Committee in the coming municipal election. Last year but 837 women registered and 725 voted.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 28.--Sing Sing's new forty-five-thousand-dollar schoolhouse, the building of which was commenced last Spring, and which by the beginning of the new year would have been ready for occupancy, was destroyed by fire this evening.

The sale of the J.B. Snyder and R.E. Hertman collection of paintings at the art galleries of P. Lihou, 845 Broadway, was concluded last night. The prices obtained were as a rule low and bargains were secured by purchasers.

The forty-fifth annual report of the NewYork Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, submitted by the general agent of the association at its annual meeting Oct. 8, has recently been published.

ITHACA, Nov. 28.--Persons who think that the long litigation between the Cornell University and the heirs of the McGraw-Fiske fortune is now ended will be disappointed. The season of grand opera in German at the Metropolitan Opera House was begun last evening with a performance of Meyerbeer's "Huguenots." Indications of a wide and deep public interest in the event were not lacking. One of the largest and most brilliant audiences that has ever gathered in the building was assembled.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 28.--The Minister of Finance was waited upon to-day a deputation which urged the Government to impose an export duty on all hemlock logs, which are principally produced in Essex and Lambton Counties, Ontario, for the American mills.

The man who does not have turkey for dinner to-day will be in hard luck indeed, for there never was a Thanksgiving when these birds were more plentiful or cheaper. Turkeys that were selling in Washington market Tuesday for 16 cents per pound could be bought there yesterday afternoon for 12 and even 10 cents per pound.

A long list of stocks, bonds, and other securities was disposed of at auction at the Real Estate Exchange yesterday afternoon, the sale attracting the usual crowd of bidders. A certificate of the New-York Produce Exchange brought $1,330.

For some time past, it appears, the attention of the Hungarian Minister of Agriculture has been directed to the fact that great quantities of spurious Hungarian wines ...

LONDON, Nov. 28.--The debate on the irish Land Purchase bill was resumed in the House of Commons this evening. Mr. Mahony, Nationalist, moved the insertion in the bill of a new clause to the effect that the Land Commission shall take as security for the payment by tenants of their installments the improvements executed by the tenant or his predecessor in his title.

Isaac Schnewind, wholesale dealer in boots and shoes at 104 Duane-street, confessed judgments yesterday for $10,943 to M. Cohn Brother, and $1,714 to Solomon Schnewind, for money loaned, and Deputy Sheriff Burns yesterday closed up the store.

A case that looked suspiciously like yellow fever was reported to the Elizabeth-street police station at 6 o'clock last night. The patient was Rafael Velana, an Italian, who arrived from Jacksonville. Fla., yesterday morning, with his wife and two children, and went immediately to his brother's apartments, on the second floor of 76 Mulberry-street.

Thanksgiving Day will be as generally observed by New-Yorkers this year as ever before. Besides the million of individual gastronomic observances which make the day a delight there will be an abundance of amusement, indoors and out, to fill in the time between meals. The unfortunate have not been overlooked, but will participate in the general festivity, as kind hands have provided for them the usual Thanksgiving dinners.

While David Hennessey, a young man who lives with his father at 583 Eleventh-avenue, was exhibiting a pistol which his father asked him to sell at a liquor store at 613 Eleventh-avenue, he accidentally discharged the weapon, and the bullet entered the brain of Hugh O'Keefe, a young unmarried butcher, causing almost instantaneous death.
The members of a facetious jury at Livingston were each fined $5 by Judge Liddell for returning a verdict that "this jury do hereby agree to disagree."--Helena (Montana) Journal.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 28.--It is reported that another great loan has been decided upon by the Government.

The police were directed yesterday to search for Yotta Reiner, a Hebrew 18 years old, who has been missing since Monday. The girl has only been two weeks in the country and cannot speak English. She was living with her sister-in-law at 242 Delancey-street.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 28.--The switchmen's strike has assumed a new and threatening phase. The strikers held a secret conference last night with the engineers and firemen, at which a very strong sentiment favorable to the switchmen was manifested.

Miss Annie Berry, daughter of John Berry, one of the old Mayors of Williamsburg before its annexation to Brooklyn, and sister of Mayor Hewitt's secretary, Arthur Berry, was married on Tuesday in St. Leo's Church, Twenty-eighth-street and Fifth-avenue, to Mr. Eugene Emile Varet of New-York.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 28.--The Alabama Legislature to-day met in joint session. A comparison of the journals of the two houses showed that yesterday John T. Morgan received all the votes cast for United States Senator, and he was declared Senator-elect from Alabama for the term beginning in March, 1889.
ALBANY, Nov. 28.--The report of the Fitchburg Railroad for the quarter Ended Sept. 30 shows:

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 28.--Receipts of wheat have fallen off this week at most points of farmers delivery in the Northwest.
Indications are that first and second class passenger rates must come down from the seaboard to all points. The fight for immigrant business is developing new phases almost every day.

Mayor Hewitt is decidedly of the opinion that there are people in this city who need washing. At the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, over which the Mayor presided, yesterday, Public Works Commissioner Smith asked for the transfer of $1,653 from one account to another to enable him to pay public ...

HULL, Mass., Nov. 28.--Early this morning three hardy men--Henry A. Tibbetts, John Johnson, and John H. Hatch--lauched a strong dory in the surf in front of the Atlantic House rocks, and after a hard pull against wind and tide succeeded in reaching the wrecked schooner H.C. Higginson.

Hermann Faust, a Jewish rabbi whose experience in being banished from one place to another has led him to seek a home in this country, arrived at Castle Garden on La Champagne on Sunday with his wife and seven children and is now looking for work.
A meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Association of Democratic Clubs has been called for Dec. 15, at the Albemarle Hotel, this city.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 28.--The report sent from here last night to the effect that President Bartlett of Dartmouth College was going to California on account of ill health is incorrect. The President is in perfectly good health, but goes on Mrs. Bartlett's account.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 28. News is just received of a lynching in Crittenden County, Ark. Jim Smith, a negro, met the wife of a white farmer in the road and made an insulting proposal to her. She fled and he pursued, and was about to overtake her when the approach of a horseman frightened him away.

BUFFALO, Nov. 28.--The authorities are much stirred up over the discovery of smallpox in the almshouse. The county's institutions seem to be in a bad way. Several cases have been developed in the penitentiary.

The threatened lock-out by the ale and porter brewers of their employes because of the latters' boycott of Stevenson's brewery, became yesterday, by reason of the action of the brewers, a thing of little dread. The Brewers' Association's advertisement for workingmen assembled 1,141 men at the headquarters, 2 Irving-place, before noon, and more than 1,000 ...

JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., Nov. 28.--Wesley Middleton and his son, William Arnandale and his son, and an unknown cooper, all of Sellersburg, went coon hunting yesterday. They had but one shotgun between them.

Miss Angela Mills, a daughter of Mrs. Clark Mills of Newark, N.J., and Mr. Henry Mason Cutting of this city, were married at noon yesterday in Grace Church by the Rector, the Rev. Dr. W.R. Huntington.

ROME, Nov. 28.--The Vatican has receivers hundreds of telegrams inquiring whether the Pope intends to quit Rome. Cardinal Rampolla has replied to the Nuncios abroad that nothing has been decided upon.

The exploiting of the big railroad trust failed to stimulate yesterday's stock market. Wall-street inclined to skepticism. Reports were abundant that the managers of the Rock Island Company would not join in the millennial scheme. Of course the refusal of any great competing line to enter the combine would render ineffectual every effort to make a trust practicable.
QUEENSTOWN, Nov. 28.--The Inman Line steamer City of New-York, which arrived here to-day from New-York, reaches Queenstown 6 days and 20 hours from Sandy Hook despite a heavy sea and opposing winds.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28.--The dedication of the monument to Tragedian John McCullough in Mount Moriah Cemetery, which was fully described in THE TIMES to-day, was attended by a distinguished company of members of the histrionic profession and friends of the dead actor.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--Prominent members of the Grand Army of the Republic in Chicago say that the defection from the order reported from Indianapolis will not extend to the posts in this vicinity. "I am for the organization," said Gen. M.R.M. Wallace, when asked about the threatened split.

Verestchagin, the Russian painter, was the guest of the Normal College at an informal reception yesterday morning to which he was invited by the Senior students. The artist was given a hearty welcome by the Faculty, to whom he was presented by Prof. Arthur H. Dunden ...

BERLIN, Nov. 28.--Cologne Gazette, alluding to a reported difference between Prince Henry of Reuss, the German Ambassador at Vienna, and Count von Taafe, the Austrian Prime Minister, says that Germany regards with ever-increasing disquiet the growing strength and significance of those Austrian parties which are at heart hostile to the German alliance.

BOSTON, Nov. 28.--The cornerstone of the new Boston Public Library Building, in Copleysquare, was laid to-day with due ceremony and literary flavor. Very sensibly, the preliminary exercises were held in the new Old South Church directly opposite the site of the proposed structure.

The National Dispatch, a Central Vermont fast freight line, yesterday lowered its rates to Chicago on through business to 35 cents on first-class, 28 cents on second, 26 cents on third, 24 cents on fourth, 20 cents on fifth, and 16 cents on sixth.

Gen. Daniel E. Sickles was the defendant Yesterday in a suit brought before Judge Ingraham and a jury in the Supreme Court, and although the verdict directed by Judge Ingraham was that he pay $2,598 26, he was the actual winner. The suit was brought by Emily A. Cave to recover $27,591 45.
PARIS, Nov. 28.--The feeling on the Bourse to day was better. Panama Canal shares gained 9f. 50c., and Suez Canal shares 15f. Foreign securities advanced per cent.

Mr. ALLISON has declared that the Senate will take up its Tariff bill in earnest this session and try to put it into a shape that will command the consideration, if not the approval, of the House. The Nebraska Senators have given expression to like views, only stronger.

It is reported that a negro died from fright on the train the other day. He was going from Selma to Clayton and was riding on the train for the first time in his life. When he started he was perfectly well, and before he arrived at Clayton he was dead. It is stated that he was scared to death.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--Commodore J.G. Walker, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, in his annual report calls especial attention to the subject of introducing electric lights into naval ships.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 28.--The town of Dedham furnishes one of the most remarkable instances of hide-bound partisanship that has been noted during or since the campaign just ended. The Merchants' Woolen Mill at that place is about to resume business. It is the property of Charles Harding, a millionaire manufacturer of Cambridge.
MONTREAL, Nov. 28.--The firms of Anderson Co. and F. Green Co. of London, managing proprietors of the Orient Line, have renewed their offer to the Ottawa Government to carry the Canadian mails.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 28.--The Jute Bagging Trust, which during the past Fall has controlled the market for the cornering of the cotton crop of this country and has obtained a price for its product far above its legitimate value, has now come to a point where the power of the trust is broken.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 28.--When the United States court opened this morning the Government attorneys were allowed to introduce trunks containing 1,500 pounds of smuggled opium as evidence in this Gardner case. The Hon. Richard Crowley, for the defendant, made another motion to dismiss the case on the ground that the indictment places the value of $10 per pound ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28.--A detective in the employ of Wells, Fargo Co. is authority for the statement that the recent series of stage robberies in Western California were the work of Black Bart, the famous lone highwayman, who robbed 30 stages in this Stage before he was finally captured five years ago and sent to San Quentin.

At the close of business yesterday, in accordance with their usual custom on Thanksgiving Eve, Messrs. Simpson, Crawford Simpson. Sixth-avenue and Nineteenth-street, distributed between 800 and 900 turkeys among their employes.

ALBANY, Nov. 28.--Miss Laura W. Savage has presented to the Court of Appeals an admirable portrait of the Hon. John Savage, who was Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court of the State under its former organization for 13 years, from 1823 to 1836.

The same man who swindled Dr. W.H. Thayer out of $15 by giving to his brother a worthless check for $35 in payment of an imaginary bill of $20, getting $15 in change, played the same trick on Dr. Westbrock of 198 Schermerhorn-street, Brooklyn, yesterday.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 28.--Detective Brower and Treasurer Spaulding of the Stonington Bank have to-day been investigating further into the methods of Samuel Halliwell, the forger, ...

An entertainment will be given in the Italian Christian Association's Home this afternoon. The home, at 14 University-place, is doing a grand work among the large and ignorant Italian population of the city, not only in the line of direct charity, but in practical teaching.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 28.--The fishing schooner Percy arrived to-day from the Georges Banks, having on board Capt. Darrah and the crew of the brig Mary Fink, who were picked up last evening 25 miles southeast of Thatcher's Island. Capt. Darrah states that he sailed from Bath at 5 o'clock Sunday morning for Philadelphia with 625 tons of ice.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--The widow of Gen. Philip H. Sheridan is entitled under the general pension laws to a pension of $30 a month, her husband having died while an officer in the United States Army.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28.--The Governor issued certificates of election as Congressmen from Maryland to-day to Charles H. Gibson, Herman F. Stump, Harry W. Rusk, Henry Stockbridge, Jr., Barnes Compton, and Louis E. McComas--four Democrats and two Republicans.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 28.--Edward H. Hopper of Easton and Miss Carrie L. Brady of Lyons Plains were to have been married Monday evening at the residence of the bride's parents on Elm-street.

PETTERSBURG, Va., Nov. 28.--Two children of Tom Boykin, near Ivor, in Southampton County, were fatally burned yesterday through the carelessness of a little brother who accidentally scattered hot coals upon them. One died in a short time, and the other cannot live.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 28.--Detective L. P. Elliott was to-day arrested on a charge of inducing five negroes from Georgia to vote in this city for the Republican Congressional candidate in the recent election. He gave bond for $1,000 for his appearance for a preliminary examination.

In the suit of George H. Tilden against Andrew H. Green, John Bigelow, and George W. Smith (as the Executors of the will of Samuel J. Tilden) and others, Delos McCurdy of Vanderpoel, Cuming Goodwin for the plaintiff and ex-Surrogate Daniel G. Rollins for the defendants ...
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28.--A panic occurred at the Blair school to-day, and nothing but the great presence of mind of the corps of teachers prevented great loss of life.

Owing to the fact that in the remote and sparsely settled portions of the State many voters did not come out to the election, Harrison's majority in Oregon is not quite so large as Hermann's majority was in June. As nearly as we can tell, it will be 600 or 700 less; that is, it will be 6,700 or 6,800, against 7,407 in June last.

JACKSONVILLE, Nov. 28.--President Neal Mitchell's official bulletin for the past 24 hours ending at 6 o'clock this evening is: New cases, 3; deaths, 0; total number of cases to date, 4,680; new white cases--Adam Legree, H.A. Rudolph, and Henry Rudolph.

Eleanor Boyle Ewing, the wife of Gen. W. T. Sherman, died yesterday morning at 9:30 o'olock at the family residence, 75 West Seventyfirst-street. Though Mrs. Sherman has been more or less of an invalid for the past five years, suffering greatly from an affection of the heart, her death came as a very sudden blow to her family.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 28.--The Railroad Commissioners have mailed to practical railroad men of the railroads in the State a circular concerning the adoption of an automatic car coupler, with a view to lessening the danger to life and limb among railroad employes.

The fourth and last of Mr. Frank Van der Stucken's classical concerts took place yesterday afternoon at Chickering Hall. The audience was the largest that has attended any musical entertainment in the building since Herr Seidl's first concert last season, and by its presence testified to the wide appreciation of Mr. Van der Stucken's worth as a musician.

Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday listened to argument in the motion to punish Denman Thompson for contempt in disobeying an order of the court forbidding him to dispose of his interest in the opera "Said Pasha," composed by Richard Stahl.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 28.--The report of the Erie showing a loss of nearly $350,000 in operating the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio caused a sensation among railway men here. President King's statement that a modification of the lease is necessary has aroused speculation.

Honora Deflebbe, a woman 50 years of age, who resided with her brother at 149 Second-street, Hoboken, was found dead in her bed Tuesday night, without any visible marks of violence upon her, except that her tongue protruded from her mouth.

BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Nov. 28.--Rudolph Nuch died this afternoon of poison. He was a German, who went to England with his wife and child some years ago. He abandoned his wife there and fled to this country with a pretty governess.
LONDON, Nov. 28.--The steamship Australia, (Br.,) Capt. McKitchie, sid. from Naples for NewYork ...
VIENNA, Nov. 28.--Baron Hirsch has made a donation of $5,000,000 for schools for Jews in Galicia and Bukovina.

Postmaster Pearson has learned that two persons representing themselves as employes of the New-York Post Office are engaged in peddling tickets for a ball to be given by the "High Tariff Association" or "Crescent Association,"...

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 28.--Charles Hubbard, aged about 26 years, of Norwood, St. Lawrence County, was found unconscious on top of a car of train No. 51 on the Rome, Watertwon and Ogdensburg Road at Watertown Junction at 5 o'clock this morning.

ASBURY PARK, Nov. 28.--Russell Hulick, the owner of a notorious place known as "The Farm," situated in the pine woods just beyond the one-mile prohibitory line from Asbury Park, appeared before Judge Walling in the Court of Oyer and Terminer at Freehold yesterday for sentence.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--The Criminal Court room was crowded this morning when the Hronek dynamite trial was resumed. Hronek had changed a good deal in his appearance since yesterday morning. He looked worried and shifted about nervously in his seat and eagerly listened to every word of the testimony.

MONTREAL, Nov. 28.--Mrs. McKean, a good-looking young Frenchwoman of 30 years, was arrested this morning for masquerading in man's attire. She said her husband is a large farmer at Lake St. John, and having threatened to kill her she ran away, and coming to Montreal...
Representatives of the firm of Brown, Howard Co., including its legal counsel, were in consultation with the Construction Committee of the Aqueduct Commission yesterday.
The body of Surgeon Simon, who died of yellow fever on the United States cruiser Boston, was removed from Swinburne Island yesterday on a launch from the navy yard and taken to Philadelphia.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 28.--Federal Judge Hill to-day sustained the demurrer of defendants to the bill of the Yazoo and Mississippi Valley Railroad Company against the Board of Levee Commissioners, and complainant appealed to the Supreme Court of the United States.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov, 29.--Elkwood Park, Monmouth Park's rival, was opened here to-day in the presence of about 1,000 people. The chilly weather and bad walking cut down the audience at least 1,500.

I am pleased to be able to announce that the Emperor William is now on good terms with his mother, a reconciliation having taken place between them. The Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha has worked zealously in order to terminate the quarrels and misunderstandings which have ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 29.--Judge Prendergast decided yesterday that the County Court had jurisdiction in the failure of Lindauer Brothers Co., and cited the members of the firm and George Einstein to appear before him at 4 o' clock for examination upon the allegations that an assignment has been made by the firm to Einstein.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29.--Dick Appling was carried before Judge Persons yesterday on a charge of lunacy, and after a careful examination by a jury appointed for that purpose was to-day adjudged insane.

One of Westcott's express wagons loaded with trunks and boxes, broke down at Washington and De Kalb avenues, Brooklyn, on Wednesday night, and the driver, Thomas Hanlon, unhitched his horses and went to get some help.

An unknown man was kicked by a horse at Front and Whitehall streets early last evening. His left leg below the knee was badly fractured and he died before the arrival of an ambulance. Who owned the horse and how the affair occurred is somewhat of a mystery.
There will be a musicale at the Manhattan Athletic Club, 524 Fifth-avenue, to-morrow evening.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 29.--The switchmen's strike shows no prospect of settlement. If the engineers and fireman propose to strike with a view of forcing a settlement of the switchmen's advances, they seem to have concluded to at least wait until after Thanksgiving Day, for they were all at their posts to-day.

The American Athletic Club Harriers had a paper chase from Odell's Hotel, at East Chester yesterday, across country through the mud and back. The hares, Messrs. Vale, Grode, Malloy, and Brady, started at 11:30, and six minutes later the hounds were let lose and started on the trail left by the hares.

President Chauncey M. Depew says the main purposes of the fight between the Eastern trunk lines has now been accomplished and a speedy settlement of the sensational rate war between the New-York Central and Pennsylvania Roads can be counted upon.

If the hundreds of people who were kept away from the Brooklyn Tabernacle yesterday morning by the threatening weather had gone to the church they would have been compelled to have retired to their homes.

Gen. Nelson A. Miles arrived in the city yesterday with his family. He comes to succeed Gen. O.O. Howard in command of the Division of the Pacific. He is accompained by Lieuts. Gatewood and Dupray, who are members of his personal staff.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 29.--A conductor on the Canadian Pacific Railway named James Van Alstine has fallen heir to all estate in Scotland valued at over a million dollars. A near relative died intestate. Van Alstine leaves for Scotland in a few days, accompanied by a Kingston lawyer.
The congregation of the Chelsea Methodist Episcopal Church, on West Thirtieth-street, enjoyed a sociable and concert last evening as a close to their Thanksgiving pleasures.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 29.--Washington Buck ley of this city went duck shooting on Cayuga Lake to-day, and when getting out of his boat his gun was accidentally discharged, the shot taking effect in his left side, causing almost instant death. He was about 45 years old and unmarried.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 29.--General Manager Jeffrey and other representatives of the Illinois Central Railroad held a secret conference with the Sreets and Landing committee of the City Council to-night at which Mr. Jeffrey stated the demands of his company.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 29.--Mr. Remi Poulin, engineer and surveyor of this city, has returned from Brazil, whither he was sent with other surveyors by a syndicate which is thinking of carrying out a vast railway project, promoted by the present Emperor.

All over the city yesterday were heard the rattle of little drums, the boom of big ones, the shrilling of fifes, and the harsh utterances of big and little brass instruments, that might have been musical if the weather had been better and the players less bad.
TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 29.--W.E. Owens, a well-known horse trainer, died to-day of inflammation of the lungs after a two days' illness. His name was a familiar one on every race course in America.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 29.--Officers and citizens are searching the woods and swamps back of Smithsburg, Monmouth County for Thomas Semon and his sons, Samuel Joseph, and Moses, who nearly killed Farmer ...
Three burglars in a wagon drove up in front of Marks Gunther's butcher's shop at 301 Tenthavenue at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. One of them crawled through the fanlight and admitted his companions.
Congressman John Dalzell of Pittsburg is at the Westminster Hotel. Paymaster Edwin Putnam, United States Navy, is at the Murray Hill Hotel.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29.--Twelve miles from Albany yesterday evening John Marshall fired at his friend John Brogden, the bullet entering Brogden's forehead and killing him instantly.

Dr. F.K. Priest, resident physician at the Reception Hospital, said last night that Raftaele Velana, who was taken there from 76 Mulberry-street, did not have yellow fever, but was recovering from fatigue and alcohol. He will leave the hospital in a day or two.
Chatelaine watches in morocco covered cases have launched out. A neat hairpin is one topped with a small oxidized silver revolver.

COHASSET, Mass., Nov. 29.--It is the opinion of Capt. M.H. Reamey, keeper of Minor's Light, that the Philadelphia collier Allentown is at the bottom of the ocean, lying about one mile northeast of the lighthouse, directly in the track of navigation, and that she struck on Jason's Ledge.

MONTREAL, Nov, 29.--The Allan Line steamship Pomeranian stands a very poor chance of getting to sea this season. She got down as far as Bellechasse, which masses of heavy ice were piled 10 feet high in places, and ...
AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 29.--Despite the fact that it was Thanksgiving, the United States court continued in session to-day, the object being to complete the opium conspiracy case as soon as possible.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 29.--For the last two days receipts of wheat in the north of Minnesota and Dakota have declined rapidly, and the indications lead to the conclusion that the heavy movement of the season is over.
The Manhattan Athletic Club will hold its twelfth annual Winter games Saturday evening, Dec. 15, at the Madison-Square Garden, beginning at 8 o'clock. The following events are open to all amateurs:
The first published outline of the plan of I.V. Williamson's munificent charity stated that it was his design to accommodate several hundred white boys and instruct them in a useful mechanical trade.
The Chicago News heads an article "Anarchy at Work." Guess not. If anarchy should go to work it wouldn't be anarchy.--St. Paul Pioneer Press.

MEXICO, Nov. 29.--President Diaz begins another term of office Saturday, and it is believed in best informed political circles that the coming four years will be the most remarkable ever known in the history of Mexico, regarded from the standpoint of trade and industrial enterprise.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29.--The Coquelin-Hading combination gave to-day two performance at McVicker's Theatre, "Camille" at the matinee, with Coquelin and Hading, and in the evening "Les Surprises du Divorce," ("The Lottery of Love,") Coquelin playing the part of Henry Duval.
Last Thursday a living bat, imbedded in solid rock, was found on the premises of W.V. Herriott, near Romney, West Va., by Mr. Herriott and Charles Corbin, who were quarrying the rock.

William Campian, who is suspected of having murdered Mrs. Honorah De Flobe, who was found dead in her apartments on Secondstreet, Hoboken, last Tuesday night, was taken into custody yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--If Mr. Joseph G. Cannon of Illinois fails to be elected Speaker of the Fifty-first Congress, it will not be because he did not enter the race soon enough. It is still a full year before the first session of the House of Representatives of that Congress will convene, unless Mr. Harrison should call an extra session, and one session of the Fiftieth Congress is still to be held.

BEAUFORT, N.C., Nov. 29.--After a perilons and eventful voyage there arrived yesterday and sailed to-day the boat Liberdad, of two and a half tons, with Capt. Slocum, his wife, and two children on board. The Liberdad sailed from Rio de Janeiro for Washington, D.C., on July 24. Capt. Slocum and family are in good health.

POUGHKEESIE, N.Y., Nov. 29.--At West Point to-day, Capt. Spurgin, the Commissary of cadets, regaled the corps with an excellent holiday dinner, the centre pieces being Dutchess county turkeys. Thanksgiving services were held in the chapel.
The attendance at the Clifton track yesterday was very large. The track was very bad. Six races were run, favorites and outsiders dividing them equally.

Street railway employes see in the proposition to put letter boxes in street cars a scheme to make the companies mail carriers. Interference by strikers would then be an infraction of the Federal law in regard to the protection of the mail service, and Uncle Sam could be called upon for assistance in such emergencies.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 29.--For a State that can give 50,000 majority to Democracy on the shortest possible notice, Kentucky probably has more politics to the square inch than any one of her sisters. One finds politics in everything; not a constable race in any county district is made without the drawing taut of party ...

Shoe dealers sell a good many articles designed for Christmas presents for men and children, but not so many for women, although the latter do most of the buying. Shoes are not suitable gifts for the fair sex.

The party of hunters who left Belfast and Monroe about 10 days ago on a hunting trip to Hancock County passed through this city on their return home to-day. The party numbered eight men, and had with them this morning 11 fine deer, some of them very large ones. This don't look as though deer were very scarce in that locality.

The body of Eleanor Boyle Ewing, wife of Gen. W.T. Sherman, was taken to St. Louis on the 6:30 train last evening. At 3 o'clock a service was held at the residence in West Seventy-first-street.
The Vienna section of the Austro-German Alpine Club has for a long time been occupied with the execution of a plan upon which it has spent a considerable sum of money.

The championship of the American Football Union was decided yesterday at the Polo Grounds by the game between the Crescent team of Brooklyn and the cleven of Orange, N. J. The former was victorious and now holds the championship without having suffered a defeat in the whole series of contests, the record standing 6 victories and no defeats.

The arrival of the steamship Prins Frederick Hendrick from Port au Prince yesterday morning aroused much interest in the Haytian Consulate. Consul Bassett and the son of Minister Preston visited the steamer and obtained what information they could from the Captain.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov, 29.--A dispatch, printed in THE TIMES a day or two ago from Hudson, quotes from the annual report of the Superintendent of the Columbia County Almshouse, figures showing that the average number of paupers supported by that county for the year ending Nov. 1 was 156, the total cost being $14,895 15, or an average weekly ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 29.--Col. John A. McCaull this afternoon, in the Leland's main dining room, sat at the point where the two lines of a series of tables arranged in the shape of a "V" converged, and looked upon 70 ladies and gentlemen who are now, or have been, members of the McCaull Comic Opera Company.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 29.--The sensation of the day has been the sermon delivered by Bishop A. Cleveland Coxe of Buffalo at Grace Episcopal Church here this morning. It was supposed to have partaken of a Thanksgiving nature, but evidently the Bishop was in a belligerent mood.

To-day there was published here the second volume of the Duke of Coburg's recollections, under the title "Aus meinem Leben, und aus meiner Zeit," of which the first volume appeared last Winter, and was then noticed at some considerable length in the Times.

After all the monstrous deal of talk over the new American novel, "The Quick or the Dead," an insular reader is apt, to be disappointed by the book. At last it has been published (cost you 6d.) by the Messrs. Routledge, and is now within the reach of the humblest purse and the least-experienced curiosity.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 29.--The Thanksgiving Day sports under the auspices of the Athletic Association of the United States Naval Academy began at 10:30 this morning. The running long jump was won by D.H. Camden, who jumped 21 feet 4 inches, McDonald second, 19 feet 8 inches.

The inmates of the city Asylum for the Insane, at Ward's Island, passed a Thanksgiving that was by no means uneventful. After recovering from the proverbial effects of a generous turkey dinner, they listened to a concert in the evening by the physicians and attendants and certain of their own number.

LONDON, Nov. 29.--Inspector Crane gave evidence before the Parnell Commission to-day as to the progress of crime in Ireland being coincident with the formation of branches of the League. Whenever a League organization was started, he said, outrages followed.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20.--John B. King, aged 22, a student in the law office of Prentice Chace, was mysteriously murdered early this evening. The stories concerning the affair are very conflicting and unsatisfactory. It appears that King was walking through one of the thickly-populated suburhan streets about 5 o'clock ...

NEVADA, Mo., Nov. 29.--A terrible crime was committed last night eight miles south of here, and as the principals were among the best-known people in the county the affair has caused a great sensation. George Gorb was a school teacher, and was regarded as a very exemplary young man.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29.--To-day's London cable, announcing that a race had been arranged to be rowed in England about April 15 between the Yale and Cambridge University eights, (the second announcement within a week,) is very puzzling to the Yale oarsmen.

The stanch schooner yacht Republic has been purchased by Thomas H. Hall of this city, The Republic is not one of the crack racers, but she is a fine sea boat and is admirably adapted to cruising, which is Mr. Hall's favorite form of yachting.

OZARK, Ark., Nov. 29.--A sad accident occurred here this morning. John W. Watson, a prominent planter, gave his sick wife by mistake a dose of carbolic acid, and she died after an hour of most agonizing suffering.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Nov. 29.--Mr. Garrett ate a hearty Thanksgiving dinner and spent a quiet day at the Miller mansion. He was out for a short walk with his attendants, but did not receive any visitors. There is no change in his condition.

PARIS, Nov. 29.--It is stated that the next issue of the Panama lottery loan will be privileged above all others in the matter of interest.

Mr. Z.R. BROCKWAY, for many years Superintendent of the State Reformatory at Elmira, discusses the question of "Prison Labor Competition" in the current number of the Forum with the full knowledge and mature judgment of an expert on the subject.

Some time before the election the Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur, who had been making a number of speeches during the campaign, said he did not see how, if Mr. Cleveland were reelected and received four years more in the White House, he would be able to preach a sermon of thanksgiving on the day set apart for such observances.
HAVANA, Nov. 24.--The Government finally has prohibited the sale of all lottery tickets except those of Havana.

The members of the Suburban Shooting Grounds Association enjoyed the holiday yesterday at their grounds at Claremont, N.J., in shooting sweepstake matches at clay pigeons.

Trustworthy information was to be had last night that the troubles of the trunk lines were being adjusted, and that a good deal of progress had been made toward bringing about a settlement. Talk among the Wall-street men at the Windsor last night was more confident in tone, and there was in many quarters an impression that the big transportation corporations were getting ready to bury the hatchet, for the time being, at any rate.

WYTHEVILLE, Va., Nov, 29.--Thanksgiving Day was celebrated in this quiet little town by a mob of 200 armed men entering the jail and releasing Wayman Sutton, a white man who was to have been hanged to-morrow for murder.

A large number of overdue ocean steamships and coasters arrived yesterday and brought news of heavy gales and high seas. The weather experienced by the Ancheria, from Glasgow, was very heavy, so severe that the few passengers aboard her were only too glad to stretch their legs ashore.

School Trustee Jeremiah Fitzpatrick has a daughter, Mary, 19 years old, who narrowly escaped drowning while at Bath Beach last Summer. She is a good swimmer, but, being taken with cramp when five yards beyond her depth, threw up her arms and screamed for help.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 29.--An attempt by the police to quell a disturbance among a crowd of disorderly negroes in the western part of the city this afternoon resulted in a riot, during which a negro was killed, two policemen and a white man who went, to their aid seriously injured, and several negroes wounded.
While James Lynch, a butcher, of 401 West Fortieth-street, was on his way home at 2:30 yesterday morning he was knocked down at Tenth-avenue and Thirty-seventh-street by John Sheehan.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 29.--The annual Cornell-Lehigh football game was played in this city to-day, resulting in the defeat of Cornell by a score of 4 to 0. The grounds never presented a worse appearance, and the mud was fully five inches deep with a pool of water covering one-half the area of the territory.

Cable of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Road to a belief in the big railway trust by which it is proposed to remedy all the evils and demoralization that abound now in the shape of rate-cutting wars.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29.--M.J. Pickering, President of the Commercial Travelers' National Protective Association, is in the city. Mr. Pickering states that a meeting of the National Board of Directors of this organization will convene in this city on Saturday next ...

The Boston papers continue to point out the enormous profits of the copper conspirators. The Commercial Bulletin publishes a table showing how the market value of the shares of Boston copper mining companies has advanced in the last twelve months as the direct result of the conspiracy that has raised the price of copper nearly 70 per cent.

NORWALK, Conn, Nov. 29.--The corner stone of the new Catholic church at Noroton was laid to-day with imposing ceremonies. The exercises commenced at 3 o'clock, and were conducted by the Right Rev. Bishop McMahon of Hartford, assisted by a number of the clergy from this and other States.

It is a very interesting and valuable, but a very curious, report that is made by the Royal Commission appointed by the British Government to "inquire into the recent changes in the relative values of the previous metals."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29.--The Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company announces that it will make no change in the price of anthracite coal for December. Next Saturday it will shut down 18 collieries and run about 37 on three-quarters time.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov. 29.--Albert L. Walker accidentally dropped two sticks of dynamite on the floor of his office here to-day and a terrific exposion followed, demolishing the interior of the building, tearing off both of Walker's arms, putting both his eyes out, breaking four of his ribs and one leg. ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1.--The Western Union Telegraph Company absorbed the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe telegragh system at 12 o'clock to-day. CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1.--The Harvard Freshmen easily defeated the Yale Freshmen eleven at Cambridge to-day. The Yale men were outplayed from the start to the finish, and the ball was kept in their territory almost all of the game. In the first half Harvard forced the ball toward Yale's goal and made four touchdowns.

The Junior and Freshman Classes of Columbia College played the final game in the inter-class football championship at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. The Juniors won by a score of 28 to 0. CHAMBERLAIN, Dakota, Dec. 1.--A large vein of coal has just been discovered on the farm of John L. David, eight miles south of this city. The coal is of good quality. The discovery causes the greatest interest in the surrounding country.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 1, via. Galveston.-- President Diaz took the oath of office to-day. This is the third term of President Diaz and his second consecutive term. The Government made a great display, with firing of cannon, parade of the troops, There was no popular demonstration.

The Italian quarter at the foot of Adamsstreet, Brooklyn, where the Brooklyn police on Saturday discovered a gang of thieves and several trunks filled with their booty, was visited again last night and five more prisoners were captured.
John B. Sherman of Chicago is at the Windsor Hotel. Gen. C.M. Wilcox of Washington is at the St. Denis Hotel.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 2.--A courtship of 35 years' standing was ended to-day by the marriage of two well-known people of this county, Joshua Shipe and Miss Margaret Douglas. Mr. Shipe was 25 years of age, and the bride of to-day was 10 when ...

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 2.--News was received from Berryville to-day that Philadelphia parties have laid claim, under an old Spanish grant, to 20,000 acres of land near that town. The tract embraces some of the most valuable farms in the county. Over 100 persons occupy the land, which is valued at considerably more than $200,000. The matter is causing the greatest excitement.

LONDON, Dec. 2.--Mr. Bright has again become worse, and his condition is now critical. A bulletin describing Mr. Bright's condition says he was restless and rather feverish during the day. This evening his lungs are worse than during the morning, though they are in better condition than they were yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--Dr. James P. Kimball, Director of the Mint, in his report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1888, says the value of the deposits of gold was $80,894,456, including $8,668,959 of redeposits.

The regular Sunday afternoon meeting of the American Temperance Union at Chickering Hall yesterday was unusually well attended. The Rev. Samuel W. Small of Atlanta, Ga., addressed the audience in his characteristic style.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 2.--The President-elect and Mrs. Harrison attended divine services this morning at their own church, the First Presbyterian, and listened to a sermon by the Rev. M.L. Haines.

HONESDALE, Penn., Dec. 2.--The last loaded boat of the season cleared for Rondout on the Delaware and Hudson Canal last night. The total coal shipments for the season are 930,000 tons, an increase over last year of 57,000 tons.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 2.--Chantauqua Lake is to have another resort. T.M. Clement of Buffalo has bought 80 acres of land adjoining Lakewood, the fashionable resort on the lake, and will at once have it surveyed into building lots for cottages. A hotel to cost $50,000 is also talked of.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 2.--The official board of the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Asbury Park has decided to adopt a unique plan for making the members of the church who are behind in their annual subscriptions pay them more promptly.

Through his London agent, Mr. Charles Overton, Mr. A.M. Palmer has secured the American rights to Vacquerie's new play "Jalousie," which was produced at the Gymnase Theatre, Paris, last Saturday night. This play will be done in England by Mr. Beerbohm-Tree.
ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 2.--Minnie Hawk gave her first concert here last evening. The house was crowded and the performance a great success.

The returns show that Mr. Rainbow was elected Sheriff of Kalkaska County in this State. --Detroit Tribune.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Dec. 2.--Mr. Garrett spent most of this afternoon in the shelter house, which was erected recently expressly for his use. During the morning he had a short walk with his attendants. Mr. Garrett will undoubtedly spend the holidays at the Miller mansion.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 2.--The present at tempt of Western millers to get control of flour values again without first getting prices of the grain in closer harmony with the cost of it in the East must in the end prove a failure.

--Henry Holt Co. are about to issue Sir Henry Maine's posthumous work on international law, which was in manuscript almost ready for the printers at the time of its author's death. The Rev. Dr. Justin D. Fulton began a series of addresses against Roman Catholicism at Cooper Institute yesterday afternoon, taking "Are Romanists Worth Saving?" for his subject. He had a moderate-sized audience, which seemed to be largely of his way of thinking, for it applauded frequently.

New-York was radiant yesterday with sunshine and enveloped in air as clear as crystal and as fresh as the breezes of the northwest could make it. It was a day to be spent out of doors, and the people set about to pass it in the most approved fashion.

Jewell, Supervising Special Agent of the Treasury, states that the amount recovered and paid into the Treasury through the direct services of the officers and employes of his division exceeds the total cost of such services by $227,800.

The Alumni of St. Francis Xavier College held their annual dinner at Pinard's last evening. It was the largest meeting that the Alumni of the college have ever had at one table, and the occasion was consequently a notable one. The clergy especially was well represented.

Every mother will like the pretty play, the children will be taken to see it, and few fathers will object to it. WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 3.--The following is the official vote of the State of Delaware cast at the late election: Harrison, (Rep. highest Elector,) 12,973; Cleveland, (Dem. highest Elector,) 16,414; Fisk. (Pro. highest Elector,) 400; scattering vote, 1. Total vote, 29,788. Cleveland's plurality, 3,441.

The Committee on Centenary of Washington's Inauguration, which will be celebrated in this city on April 30, invite the clergy of the city to meet in the Governor's Room at the City Hall, on Thursday, at 3 o'clock, to discuss a plan for religious services in all the churches of the city at 9 o'clock on the morning of the day of the celebration.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 3.--A special cable dispatch from Rome to the Boston Pilot, dated Dec. 2, says: "The Vatican to-day firmly denies the report relating to Gen. Harrison's election. CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 4.--The Auditing Committee has submitted its report on the expenses of the different athletic organizations of Harvard for the half year ending in July, 1888. One year ago the Baseball Association had on hand about $2,700.

Charles D. M. Smith, a well-to-do oysterman of East Rockaway, was drowned off Long Beach yesterday by the capsizing of his boat. Stephen and Edward Still well, who were in Smith's boat, were rescued by Robert Buchanan, a boatman.
HAVANA, Dec. 4.--Grinding has been begun on the Arcoiris sugar estate at Macurijes, this plantation being the first to begin that work. The weather is dry and cool.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4.--A Political blizzard struck this city this evening which almost surpasses in its effect upon the citizens the famous blizzard of last March. NewHaven is nominally Democratic by 2,500 majority. The city election took place to-day.

Mr. Augustin Daly gave the first of a series of 10 subscription performances at his theatre last evening, and revived his butling comedy, Seven-Twenty-Eight," as a special attraction for the occasion. The result was a brilliant audience, that watched the progress of the play as attentively as thought it had not been a long-running success five years ago.

Henderson delivered his second lecture on musical history before an audience composed of the students of the institution and a number of their friends. The subject of the discourse was "The Modern Orchestra and Its Music." The lecturer began by describing the development of the various instruments used in the modern orchestra and giving an account of their early use.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 5.--The trial of Luis Fleury, ex-Postmaster of Juarez, (Paso del Norte,) Mexico, and F. O'Farrel, ex-clerk in the same office, for thefts of mail matter was concluded yesterday before Judge Bustamente, and each of the prisoners was sentenced to 15 years in the penitentiary.

The guarded reference of the President's message to affairs in Samoa may perhaps be ascribed to the fact that current events in the islands are influencing the political status there. Recently the followers of MATAAFA gained another sanguinary victory over those of TAMASESE and drove them into still narrower limits.

LONDON, Dec. 5.--Owing to a report that Gen. Welseley had been in communication with Lord Randolph Churchill and had inspired the latter's attack upon the Suakin expedition on account of the inadequacy of the proposed force, Mr. Stanhope, the War Secretary, wrote a letter to Gen. Wolseley on the subject, asking him upon what military authority he supported Lord Randolph's views.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 5.--South Carolina will not recover from the political revolution of 1876 for 20 generations. The results of that contest, good and bad together, stick to the State like a porous plaster. The extraordinary methods resorted to then, under the spur of absolute necessity, have not served to purify elections nor to remove the cancer of the colored vote.

The old, patched-up pump at the High Service Water Works, Jersey City, collapsed yesterday. The pump supplied old Hudson City. It broke down six months ago and the district was without water for three days. The Commissioners of Public Works ordered a new pump, but the Board of Finance refused to concur. The Commissioners, in order to prevent a drought, have employed the Hackensack Water Company to supply the district.

The trial of Charles W. Green for the murder of his brother-in-law, Nicholas Goldenkirch, ended last night in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, in a verdict of acquittal. The jury retired at 4 o'clock, and at 6 returned for instructions in regard to the law of manslaughter.

BUFFALO, Dec. 6.--The sixth floor of Henry Diehl's malthouse gave way late this afternoon and crashed through into the cellar, bursting out the front wall of the building and burying the street under grain. Three men were carried down from the upper story. One escaped and the others were killed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased 4 per cent. registered bonds to the amount of $806,250 at 108, and $2,450 registered fours at 125.

DETROIT, Dec. 6.--The November product of the Franklin Copper mine was 193 tons and of the Quincy 350 tons. The amount of copper shipped by lake during the season just closed from the Lake Superior copper mines was 29,787 tons, of which the Calumet and Heela Smelting Works shipped 18,294 tons.

The schooner yacht Norna, Mr. Lee, Eastern Yacht Club, arrived at Tompkinsville, Staten Island, yesterday. She will be fitted out for a Winter cruise to Bermuda and the Windward Islands. The Norna will sail on Monday.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Dec. 6.--The Cortland Wagon Company, half of whose works were burned Wednesday morning, have decided to rebuild in brick, and in the meantime will perfect temporary arrangements and resume operations at once. The State Treasurer is President of this company.

In a letter recently received from Gen. Francis E. Spinner, ex-Treasurer of the Treasury, who is now at Pablo Beach, Fla., the General says that he is being treated for cancer of the face. His physician assures him that it can and will be cured.

JACKSONVILLE, Dec. 6.--President Neal Mitchell's official bulletin for the past 24 hours, ending at 6 o'clock to-day, is: New cases, none; deaths, none; total number of cases to date, 4,704; total number of deaths to date, 412.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 6.--The official vote of the State of Maine is as follows: Harrison, 73,734; Cleveland, 50,481; Fisk, 2,691; Streeter, 1,344; scattering, 16. The total vote was 128,266, and Harrison's plurality, 23,253.

A leap from the roof of a tenement house into the street brought death to Conrad Burkhardsmaier, a saloon keeper at 167 Allen-street, yesterday. Had he not jumped paris green would have accomplished the same result in a little longer time. His wife objected to letting him die by the poison which he had taken, and went for help.

Parsons, who escaped trial a few months ago by fleeing from the State, is not out of the country. He is confident that the fugitive is not in Canada, where the defaulting President of the Charter Oak Life.
