CHICAGO, Dec. 6.--The steamer Scotia set fire to the Ogden Canal this morning in the vicinity of Halsted and Division streets, and was damaged to the extent of about $100. The canal at that point is the receptacle for the refuse from the gas house. The refuse floats on the water, and in dumping the ashes from the boat the mass was set on fire.

OTTAWA, Dec. 6.--Several leading Liberal papers are agitating in favor of the Dominion sending delegates to attend the Congress of American nations to be held at Washington, D. C. in 1889. Senator John Sherman has written to the editor of the Ottawa Free Press on the subject. He says:

BELVIDERE, N. J., Dec. 6.--A bold attempt at robbery was made at Walfack Tuesday night. A masked robber entered the house of Oakey Stoll, a well-to-do farmer, at supper time, and demanded his money. Mr. Stoll refused, whereupon he was assaulted and terribly beaten. The robber secured what booty he could and departed. Mr. Stoll is in a critical condition.

Ernest Meyer came to this country three years ago and settled on Ninth-avenue, in this city. His cousin, Gretchen Trager, followed him across the waters a year ago. When he learned that she had $800 in money with her he became possessed of a desire to go into business, and she loaned him $700 in money.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6.--An auction sale of carpets was made by Judge knickerbocker in the Probate Court to-day. The goods belonged to the firm of William Hughes Co., the senior partner in which died in Colorado a few weeks ago.

The officers of Mr. Gerry's society, acting on a request of Archbishop Corrigan, have watched for young girls who accompany Sisters of Charity on their aims-seeking excursions, because they are brought into contact with persons and phases of life that are objectionable,...

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 6.--A bloody tragedy took place to-day in Elliott County, in which a cousin to the outlaw Craig Tolliver fatally wounded Dave Conley. The conflict took place at a sawmill, and Tolliver escaped. The weapon used was an axe, the victim being struck on the head.

The national convention of wholesale fish dealers, which is to meet in this city next week, will be asked to take decisive action on a number of questions, and probably more than one memorial to Congress will be proposed. A Wellknown wholesale dealer said yesterday that the business was sadly in need of organization, the advantages of concerted action not having yet been made sufficiently clear to the trade.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 6.--The Pittsburg Steel Casting Company will not cast another steel gun, unless the thorough investigation which will be made of the parts of the bursted gun develops a cause of weakness which could be avoided in the manufacture of others.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Dec. 6.--No local happening has so stirred up this town in a long time as the disappearance of the Rep. William Parker, for 12 years Rector of Christ Episcopal Church in this city. Evidence was produced to-day that conclusively proves that he committed suicide ...

DETROIT, Dec. 6.--Deputy Sheriff Smith of Wayne shot and killed a horse thief named Tasma at Dearborn this morning. The horse was stolen last night. Deputy Smith met the thief on the road this morning, and recognizing the horse, he called on its driver to stop. The man jumped from the buggy and ran. Smith fired, and the ball went through the thief's right lung, killing him instantly.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 6.--The Class of '89 held their class day elections in Examination Hall last night. The usual "row" at this election was happily absent, and everything passed off harmoniously.

Mr. Jay Gould ricochetted around in the stock market yesterday in quite his old-time fashion. The whole market went up, but Mr. Gould's own stocks led everything, his Missouri Pacific scoring a gain of over four full points.
Yesterday's session of the commission in elevated railroad condemnation proceedings

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 6.--This afternoon John E. Madden and L.B. Field ran a match race of a quarter of a mile with yearlings at the association course. Madden's chestnut filly by Onondaga, dam Fonwitch, won easily by a length and a half. Field's ch. f. Samantha, by Harry O'Fallon, dam Rita Elliott, was the contending animal. Time--0:23 2-5. Considerable money changed hands on the result.

The Fassett investigating committee will resume its sittings in this city next Thursday. It will take up in order the investigation of the offices of Jurors Commissioner Reilly, of the Department of Public Works, and of the Commissioners of the City Record.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 6.--All the Republicas politicians must have got word that Gen. Harrison was away shooting, for not one of them arrived in town to-day, and the Denison House, their favorite hotel, had not boon so dull since the beginning of the campaign. They compensated for their absence as well as they could by writing letters, and Gen. Harrison found a stupendous mail awaiting him to-night when he arrived home.

TROY, N Y., Dec. 6.--The Saratoga Daily Union was sold to-day at auction by J. L. Scott, Receiver. The paper was bought by C. W. Pierson and Capt. B. F. Judson. The former proprietor was appointed manager.
ZANZIBAR, Dec. 6.--The German warship Carola has captured a slave dhow. The rising among the natives along the coast is extending.
Lyman K. Bass of Colorado is at the Buckingham Hotel. Columbus R. Cummings of Chicago is at the Hotel Brunswick. Galusha A. Grow of Pennsylvania is at the Victoria Hotel.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 6.--The charred and dismembered remains of a woman were found in the ruins of a cottage which was burned at Dayton, Tenn., this morning. The body was found to be that of Mrs. Tom Gaun, and her husband is under arrest charged with killing her with an axe and then firing the house. The verdict of the Coroner's jury was to that effect.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 6.--The aggressive policy of the Soo line is constantly bringing some new advantage to the read, and as a matter of course to the entire Northwest. Negotiations are just being completed for a close traffic arrangement with the Michigan Central, and through it with its great Eastern connection, the New-York Central.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., Dec. 6.--Fred Hosmer, son of a wealthy citizen, had both legs broken and his side badly cut, besides suffering internal injuries, from a coasting accident here to-day. Kate Page, a little girl who was on the coaster, had her leg broken and suffered other serious injuries. Four other children were also slightly injured. There are some hopes of young Hosmer's recovery.

PARIS, Dec. 6.--In the Chamber of Deputies this evening M. Laroze, who is a friend of M. Ferry, and who favors severe anti-Boulangist measures, having intimated his desire to move a vote of lack of confidence in the Cabinet, Premier Floquet said the Government was quite ready to meet him. M. Laroze replied that he would introduce his motion at the proper time.

The spacious parlors of Mrs. Charles E. O'Hara's residence, at 45 West Forty-seventhstreet, held yesterday afternoon and evening a throng of charitably-disposed ladies and gentlemen, mostly members of All Souls' Church, who had assembled to participate in a "tombola," held for the purpose of raising funds to carry on the free kindergarten, a charity connected with their church.

Schuyler claimed that Hughes, in the Manhattan Club Chronicle, had charged him with making unfair decisions at the Detroit games. Hughes gave $1,000 bail.

ATLANTA, Dec. 6.--Four times a gallows was built upon which to hang Henry Blackman, a Sohley County negro, who was again saved from death by the clemency of Gov. John B. Gordon. The case illustrates the uncertainty of capital punishment in Georgia even when a negro's neck is in peril.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6.--The indications to-day were that Armour Co.'s protest against the adoption of the proposed new rates on dressed beef would not receive much consideration at the hands of the General Managers. The great bridge over the East River was no more than begun when the country was flooded with chromolithographs showing it as it was to be. While the piers were rising and the web of steel thickening the illustrated press had its innings; and before it was entirely finished the water colorists, engravers, and etchers had their little fling at the gigantic affair.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. Dec. 6.--The last phase of the Bates-Evans Congressional certificate fight in the Third District was the issuance to-day in Nashville by the Chancery Court of an injunction against Gov. Taylor issuing the certificate to Evans. The Governor insists that he will finally do so, and that he cannot be enjoined in the matter and manner adopted.
RED BANK, N. J., Dec. 6.--William, Morris, and Wesley Van Note, 8, 10, and 14 years old, respectively, of Little Silver, a village about a mile from here, were recently badly burned by slacked lime.

DETROIT, Dec. 6.--B. Hertzog, general merchant at Vassa, has made an assignment to T.W. Davis of Caro, with liabilities of $15,000 and assets of $6,000 to $8,000. R.V. Bray has possession of his stock under chattel mortgage.

GASPE, Quebec, Dec. 6.--Three men named Fournia, father, son, and a nephew, left here yesterday in a small boat for their homes on the Dartmouth River. This morning their dead bodies were found in the boat, which was full of water. Death resulted from exhaustion and exposure.

The New-York City Woman Suffrage League listened last night to an address by Miss Mary F. Eastman at its meeting at 4 Lexingtonavenue. Miss Eastman argued that the feminine quality was needed in the State Government as much as in the home.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 6.--R.R. Hawes, the father of May Hawes, whose dead body was found in East Lake, Tuesday, was last night arrested, charged with her murder. He married a young girl in Columbus, Miss., yesterday, and was arrested immediately on his arrival here with his bride. He denies all knowledge of the crime, but is still in custody pending further investigation.

The State Board of Arbitration yesterday morning began the investigation of the troubles of the feather workers who struck in the shops of Loewenstein Gray and Isidor Cohnfeld. Louis F. Post appeared as counsel for the girls and Charles Stewart Davidson for the manufacturers. Chairman Purcell explained that the board had unsuccessfully tried to settle the matter amicably.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 6.--Three additional arrests for illegal voting were made in this city to-day. The prisoners were J. J. Freeland, William Myers, and Henry Bachman. Freeland was admitted to bail, Myers was committed to jail, and Bachman was discharged from custody, he furnishing proof that he was of legal age on election day. Additional arrests are looked for to-morrow.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 6.--Capt. Henderson and crew of the abandoned schooner Albert H. Cross arrived here to-day on the schooner Garfield after a terrible experience. The Cross left Charlesson Nov. 15 for Petersburg, Va. The crew consisted of Capt. Henderson, five seamen, and a cook.

BLYTH, Ontario, Dec. 6.--Michael Dwyer's house, about three miles from here was burned this morning, and Mrs. Dwyer, her daughter, and three grandchildren perished in the flames.

Inspector Byrnes has under lock and key two men who he thinks were guilty of the shooting and attempted robbery last Monday of "Phil" Daly in the Fourth-avenue flat. They are Edward Meredith and Harry Herman, and they were arrested at their homes yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6.--Capt. John G. Knight, Corps of Engineers, has been ordered to visit Fortress Monroe and West Point, New-York, to examine and report upon methods of military instructions at those points. First Lieut. J. E. Sawyer, Fifth Artillery, has been granted six months' leave of absence, with permission to go abroad. Brig. Gen. The Commissioners appointed to revise the excise laws met yesterday morning at the Bible House and resumed the consideration of the bill drawn up by their lawyer, George B. Colby. There was a long discussion over section 4 of the proposed statute, which deals with the classification and fees for licenses.

The third night's sale of the Haseltine collection of modern paintings was held last evening at the Leonard Art Galleries, 290 Fifth-avenue. Eighty-two pictures were offered, of which 54 were withdrawn. Those sold realized $7,485.

ROME, Dec. 6.--Mgr. Deligni, the Papal delegate to China, will leave soon for that country. He is charged with the settlement of the diplomatic relations between the Vatican and the authorities at Pekin.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 6.--The Executive Committee of the Farmers' Alliance was compelled to hold an evening session yesterday in order to decide upon a proclamation to the people. The address was formulated by a committee of three--Ignatius Donnelly and Messrs. Nachbar and Hodgson. It was undoubtedly all dictated by the sage, and a portion of the original manuscript is in his handwriting.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 6.--To-night Joseph Thompson of the Dominion Steamship Company, while on his way to church from his home here, was struck by a train at the Mary-street crossing of the Pennsylvania Railroad and instantly killed. His body was carried on the locomotive pilot to Linden before it was discovered.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Dec. 6.--Eli Tully was found dead in the road near Cooper's Creek to-day. His skull was crushed, and a jug of whisky with which he had left town was missing. He had evidently been murdered for the liquor.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 7.--He told he was a widower and had one child. She listened to his suit and agreed to marry him on Wednesday last. Last Sunday the first wife of Hawes and his youngest daughter disappeared and have not been heard of since.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 7.--The fourth number of general orders of the Grand Army of the Republic was issued yesterday. The order gives instructions to the Inspector-Generals' changing the time of closing their annual inspection from Dec. 31 to June 30.

Meyerbeer's opera "L'Africaine" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening before the largest audience that has thus far assembled during the present season. QUEBEC, Dec. 7.-- A strong shock of earthquake lasting nearly half a minute was felt this morning at Rimouski, Father Point, Sainte Flavie and Trois Pistoles. At Rimouski the shock was so severe as to cause the Bishop's palace to tremble visibly, but no damage was done.

Mr. Augusto Soares, a Minneapolis boy and a student in the State University, is the recipient of what any young, American might justly regard a rare honor. BEVIER, Mo., Dec. 7.--Everything is quiet here now, but it is rumored that another consignment of arms has been distributed among the miners at work in the three mines. Sheriff Lyda is here with a posse and has telegraphed to the Governor requesting him to send a company of militia here at once.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 7.--The American Forestry Congress elected officers to-day as follows; President--Gov. J.A. Beaver of Pennsylvania; VicePresidents--H.G. Joly of Quebec, J.Y.W. French of Boston, Charles Moore of Mobile. Hubert Welsh of Philadelphia, and George H. Parsons of Denver; Secretaries--J.B. Hudson of New-Hampshire and N.H. Eggleston of Washington. The congress then adjourned sine die. The next meeting will probably be held in Philadelphia.

In the opinion of Controller Myers, one of the most important offices under the City Government is that of Collector of City Revenue, which was made vacant two weeks ago by the death of James J. Kelso. It is his purpose to appoint a man to the office who, he thinks, will reorganize the Collector's Bureau to the end that the revenues of the city may be increased.

DETROIT, Dec. 7.--Edward Kennedy, a clothing dealer at Ishpeming, has assigned to Thomas Flannigan, and an inventory of the assets and liabilities is now being made. The assets will be about $6,000, but the liabilities are supposed to be much greater.

A dead heat and run-off made six races at Clifton yesterday. The results were as follows: FIRST RACE.--Three-quarters of a mile. Bishop, (Kelly.) 108 pounds, first. Time-1:21. Monte Christe (Reagan) 104, second; Lakewood. (H. Lewis,) 106, third, Betting.--Against the winner, 7 to 1 straight, 2 to 1 place; Monte Christo, for place, 2 to 1.

CARLISLE, Penn., Dec. 7.--John H. Kinler of Dillsburg and Miss Mary E. Brannon of this city were married this afternoon at the residence of Magistrate Bretz. Kinler is a Republican and Miss Brannon a Democrat, and this marriage is the payment of an election bet, Miss Brannon having promised that if Clevelend was defeated she would procure the marriage license and defray all expenses, and to-day she carried out her promise.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 7.--At 6 o'clock this morning a freight train ran off the track at the entrance to the Victoria Bridge on the Montreal side and was dragged into the tube. Three of the cars were derailed, stopping traffic for four hours. The track is now clear and trains are running as usual.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7.--Prof. Wiggins, the weather prophet, in an interview with THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day, said he was greatly interested in the eclipse of the sun on the 1st of January next. This eclipse will only be visible at sundown in New-York.

Another meeting of the Directors of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad Company was held yesterday to try again to induce Gen. Samuel Thomas and Col. Calvin S. Brice to consent to re-election as President and Vice-President of the company. No progress was made, however, and another meeting will be held next week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7.--Robert Gill, a clerk in the employ of the Fidelity Loan and Trust Company of this city; has been missing since Thanksgiving, and it is believed that he has committed suicide.

BUFFALO, Dec. 7.--Alexander McPherson, general bookkeeper of the Merchants' Bank, has disappeared, and is supposed to be either in Canada or California. He left a wife and two children behind him as well as numerous unpaid election bets. His accounts were in bad shape, but, when straightened out, no shortage or crookedness was discovered. Games of ten-dollar "seven up" and drink are said to be the cause of his ruin.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 7.--The catch-as-catchcan contest in Turner's Hall here to-night between Tom Cannon and Antonio Pierre, the stalwart Greek, was a terrible exhibition of strength and skill. It was decided in favor of the Greek amid a burst of applause from more than 1,000 throats.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7.--General Master Workman Powderly of the Knights of Labor, in company with a couple of members of the Executive Board, was in the city to-day. He goes to Washington to-morrow, returning to attend the meeting of the Executive Board on Dec. 18. He had not said anything on the labor situation since the General Assembly adjourned at Indianapolis.

Warlike preparations still go on with unslackened zeal and alacrity at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Instructions have just been received from Washington ordering the vessels Yantic and Richmond, in addition to the Galena, to be got ready as soon as possible in anticipation of immediate sailing orders.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7.--Panic drove all thoughts of prescriptions out of the minds of 200 students at the Chicago College of Pharmacy, in State-street, this morning. They were pursuing their studies on the second and third floors, when they discovered that a volume of smoke was pouring up from below and that the Fire Department was at work on the blaze. A stampede resulted.

TORONTO, Dec. 7.--Two men were burned nearly to death here to-day. They were Charles Hansdorf and John Cargey, both young men who are employed in large copper works. They were engaged in emptying a copper air chamber full of rosin, and to do this they heated it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7.--S. Corning Judd, exPostmaster and a charter member of the Iroquois Club, sent in his resignation as a member of that organization to-day, and at the meeting of the Executive Committee it was promptly accepted. Gen. Newberry is Chairman of the Executive Committee.

Finally Wall-street has got most of the good news that it has been hoping for, anticipating, and discounting for weeks and weeks past. Rates have been put up in the Southwest. The Eastern trunk line fight is over.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 7.--Morgan G. Bulkeley, who will be elected Governor of Connecticut on the assembling of the Legislature in January, has selected the following members of his staff: Adjutant-General--Col. Lucius A. Barbour of Hartford, formerly Colonel of the First Regiment. C.N.G., and now President of the Willimantic Thread Company; Quartermaster-General--Col. William B. Rudd of Lakeville, a member of the Republican State Committee, and formerly an aide on Governor Bigelow's staff.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7.--The vestibule train known as the "Golden Gate Special," that left Omaha Wednesday morning at 8 o'clock, arrived here at 9:45 to-night, making the run from the Missouri River in 61 hours and 45 minutes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7.--One of the decisions handed down by the Appellate Court Judges this morning revives memories of the great wheat corner of 1887, C.J. Kershaw, the broker, took a great interest in the fluctuations of the market at that time, and on June 20 he filed a bill asking for an accounting of the assets of his firm.

UTICA, N. Y., Dec 7.--At the sixth annual convention of City Superintendents of Schools, held here, C. C. Cole of Albany presented a report on educational laws, which is to be put into the shape of a bill to be presented to the Legislature to provide for the elementary education of children. The report was adopted.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 7.--Few People have any idea of the immense traffic on the great lakes. In the matter of hard coal alone 2,546,905 tons have left this port and gone to 55 different receiving ports. Chicago received 1,082,560 tons, Milwaukee 627,655 tons, Duluth 262,475 tons, and Superior 135,175 tons. The number of cargoes was 2,071. The last boat cleared on Wednesday.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 7.--The last boat on the Delaware and Hudson Canal reached tidewater here from Honesdale, Penn., this afternoon. The canalers say they have had a profitable season. The work of repairing the canal at various points will be begun as soon as the water is drawn off.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 7.--Millers of Minneapolis are considerably exercised over a report now being circulated through Eastern markets that "something is the matter with Minnesota flour," as it does not "work" well.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 7.--The tongues of Republican politicians in Indianapolis are wagging over two subjects--the leading editorial in the News to-night and the determination of Judge Woods of the United States District Court to adjourn the court peremptorily to-morrow before the important investigations of the Grand Jury are half completed.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 7.--There are no tidings of the missing Gen. Clitz. His intimate friends are more and more inclined to the belief that he jumped or fell into the Niagara River, as all clue to his whereabouts stops there. They think him a too important man to remain so long alive without recognition. His mental condition when he left this city bordered on insanity.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7.--Parliament rejected a bill last session favoring reciprocity in wrecking between Canada and the United States on the great lakes. The Hon. George Kirkpatrick, member of Parliament, the author of the pleasure, is in town. He says he will reintroduce the bill this session, and feels confident that it will become law.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 7.--Marcus Birch, a rich farmer of Galenville, Ulster County, was thrown from his wagon last evening while returning home from this city, and was run over by his vehicle and killed near Cromomer's Hill, in the town of Newburg. He was 67 years old.

The principal topic of conversation in the hotel corridors last evening was the sale of the unbeaten English racehorse Ormende "for 17,000 to an American," as the cable dispatch put it. "Who has bought him?" was the question on all sides, and Mr. A.J. Cassatt, who is known to have made an offer for him, was generally pitched upon as the most likely purchaser.

RIVERHEAD, Long Island, Dec. 7.--The evidences of Matthew Quay's political rascality, which inspired the conduct of the last campaign on Long Island on the part of the Republican County Committees, are slowly being gathered, put in places where tampering cannot interfere with them, ready to be placed before the prosecuting authorities of the counties, and if judgment fails there before State officials.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 7, via Galvoston.-- The Legislature of the State of Durango has granted to the International Railroad the right of way from Torreon, its present junction with the Central, to the city of Durange.

OSHAWA, Ontario, Dec. 7.--Dr. McBrein, a druggist and practitioner, has absconded. There is great excitement among-his creditors. His liabilities amount to fully $50,000; assests nominal.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec 7.--Gov. Beaver, as Chief Marshal of the inaugural parade, is receiving a great many applications from people who want to be aides on his staff. The Governor will try to make an equitable division of honors.

PINE HILL, N.Y., Dec., 7.--Hunter Ennist shot a fine silver-gray fox near this village a day or two ago. Foxes of that species are rare in the Catskill Mountains.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 7.--Turfmen from all parts of the country are arriving to attend the great horse sales which will begin next Tuesday by the Melbourne Stables. This sale has catalogued some of the best strains, including such as Gallifet. The Lioness, Once Again. Twenty-three coming 2-year-olds will be offered.
SYDNEY, New South Wales, Dec. 7.--The drought continues in Victoria. Fine rains have fallen in Queensland.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 7.--Redwed, a bay colt, 3 years old, by Jay Gould, dam by Young Jim, has been purchased of W.R. Brasfield Co. of this city by Joseph Greer of Winton Place, Okio, for $2,500.

GILBOA, N.Y., Dec. 7.--The champion raccoon hunter of these parts is John Edwards, who claims to have captured 24 of the animals. Edwards had a plucky fight with a wildcat near Prattsville one day recently. The cat was clubbed to death, but not until it had inflicted various scratches and bites on Mr. Edwards's face and hands.

BOSTON, Dec. 7.--The last act in the controversy over the ordination of William H. Noyes as missionary to Japan took place tonight, when the Berkeley-Street Congregational Church held a farewell reception to Mr. Noyes prior to his departure for Japan.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 7.--The Monroe County branch of the Irish National League decided this evening to at once forward $1,000 to aid Parnell in his fight against the London Times.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 7.--Adolphus Wheeler and Samuel Phifer, colored, were hanged together on the same scaffold in the county jail at Yorkville to-day. Wheeler killed George Beckham on July 27 for interferring in his family affairs. Phifer murdered the mulatto daughter of his white wife.

Harris of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Michigan. Already the matter is naturally exciting a good deal of interest and quiet discussion, but, the clergy, without exception, refuse to give any expression of preference.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7.--Justice Peter Foote is lying at the point of death at Mercy Hospital, and his eventful career in Chicago is nearly rounded out. In addition to other ailments he recently contracted typhoid pneumonia and has gradually grown worse, until now he is expected to die at any moment.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 7.--To-day a call was issued by the Northwestern Miller for a meeting of the millers of the United States, to be held at the Plankinton House, Milwaukee, Dec. 17, to consider the state of the trade. A large attendance has been guaranteed by millers from all parts of the country.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7.--While cleaning out an oil still of the Peerless Refining Company at Findlay, Ohio, to-day, William Lightfoot was overcome by gas and fell unconscious. Ephraim Weirick was sent to his assistance, and he, too was overcome. Phil O'Connell undertook to rescue them, with the same result. The three were finally gotten out of the still. Lightfoot is dead, Weirick dying, and O'Connell will recover. The first two leave families destitute.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 7.--William F. Walsh, who for several years has conducted an extensive cooperage business in this city, was found dead on the floor of his office on North Front-street this afternoon.

Owing to the increase in the work of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, its Board of Directors has been compelled to enlarge its appliances for the rescue of helpless little children. In the 14 years of its existence the society has investigated 37,894 complaints, involving more than 113,682 children.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7.--Collector J.S. Hager to-day seized the steamer Westmeath and her cargo of sugar which arrived here from Java last Monday consigned to the American Sugar Refinery of this city. Duty amounting to $150,000 was paid on the cargo, which is valued at $400,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn, Dec. 7.--A breach of promise case which has some very peculiar features was begun in the District Court to-day. HEMPSTEAD, Long Island, Dec. 7.--On Monday last an attempt was made to poison an entire family in this town, but for some reason that can only be surmised the affair has only leaked out now. Andrew Le Furge is the biggest grocer in the community.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 7.--Officers of steamboats arriving at this city from all parts of the Chesapeake this morning report oyster pirates at work on the forbidden grounds. The oyster navy is completely cowed. So far the cannon borrowed from the Federal Government have not been put to use.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 9.--The police have had reason to believe that gambling was being carried on in a Chinese establishment on Main-street. It is a combined store and laundry and is the only Chinese store in town.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 9.--Michael Liske met a horrible death in Edwards's coal breaker, near this city, late last night. He was repairing the immense cogs which are used to crush coal, when in some why his clothing was caught, and he was drawn between the steel teeth. It is not at all surprising that the situation in France should continue to excite the anxious attention of all the statesmen of Europe. American railroad securities were unsettled.

ESCANABA, Mich., Dec. 9.--A pool of capitalists from Delta and Menominee Counties has been organized to prosecure work at a point where free gold was found four months ago. BARNEGAT CITY, N.J., Dec. 11.--The Bonnat Gunning and Fishing association has been organized by a number of well-known New-Jersey gunners. His father was the noted John Mitchel who was one of the Irish leaders in 1845.

Theodore Brinkmann was arrested at Jersey City yesterday on a warrant issued by Justice Aldridge on the complaint of Miss Theresa Malley. Complainant and defendant were engaged, but quarreled, and the defendant insisted upon her returning some gifts, including a clothes wringer. The later miss Malley would not surrender, and Brinkmann in his desire to secure it caused a disturbance. He gave bail to keep the peace.

Papers found in his pockets show that he is Joseph L.B. Freyand. A letter from L.M. Braun of Twenty-third-street and seventh-avenue, New-York, was also found in his pockets.
HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 11.--The House of Refuge for Women here was the scene of considerable excitement last evening.

At the meeting of the Harlem Republican Club last night a resolution was offered by Charles M. Patrick, to the effect that officers of the club should pledge themselves not to hold any office in the Twenty-third District organization, which is run by Frank Raymond.

The Board of Aldermen did little but wrangle yesterday over the resolution to license applicants for permission to keep stands in the streets. There were 4,000 applicants, and the Law Committee reported that they should be licensed.

ALBANY, Dec. 11.--For social, fishing, and hunting purposes the Paradise Fin and Feather Club was incorporated to-day. Its principal office is at 123 Weat Thirty-ninth-street, New-York City, and the Trustees are Henry A. Gildersleeve, Birket Clarke, William F. Duncan, J. Charles Davis, Joseph Kline Emmet, Jr., and James T. Davis.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 11.--The great Coal Trust of the Northwest has extended its from grasp over another broad expanse of territory.

The State Board of Canvassers has put out of its consideration the 186,197 votes cast in this city in favor of the constitutional amendment presented to the citizens at the late election. It has also discarded the votes cast for the amendment in the counties of Onondaga and Oneida.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 11.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and Associates present, the following decisions were handed down:

ELMIRA, Dec. 11.--George Bergett and Oscar Leonard, boys, aged 15 and 17 years, respectively, after returning from hunting about 5 o'clock this afternoon, went into Hamlin's hardware store at Lawrenceville, Penn. The boys commenced a quarrel for the possession of ...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 11.--Fire broke out last night in Deputy Warden Keete's quarters in the Dorchester Penitentiary, the maritime provinces of the Dominion prison, and the Deputy Warden was suffocated before he could be rescued. His wife had a narrow escape. The prisoners' quarters were uninjured by the fire.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11.--John James Ingalls, Senator of Kansas, gave his own estimate of himself a few days ago in an interview with a reporter, in which he declared: "I am a thoroughly immoral politician and may as well confess my turpitude. No disguises will avail me. In this respect I am known to be a very bad man."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 11.--The managers of the Fox Coal and Coke Company at Graysville, Tenn., has reduced their miners' wages 10 per cent. The men would not accept the reduction, and a strike has followed. It is not known yet whether the company will resume work or not.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased 4 per cent registered bonds to the amount of $602,000 at 108 1/8, and $82,000 at 108.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 11.--The case of Preble against Bates, called in the United States Circuit Court this morning, will attract attention from its interesting features and the touching misfortunes of the plaintiff.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 11.--The cutnail manufacturers of the Ohio Valley from Steubenville to Ashland, Ky., and including Ironton, Middleport, Bellaire, Mingo, and the Wheeling mills, met here this morning.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 11.--Railroad conductors in the Southwest have become dissatisfied with the order of Railway Conductors, whose headquarters are at Chicago, and have formed a new Brotherhood of Conductors of the United States and Canada.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec., 11.--At a Conference of the anti-Mahone Republican leaders of this State held here to-night, a movement was set on foot which those who participated in it hope will counteract Mahone's efforts to obtain recognition at the hands of Harrison.
ALBANY, Dec. 11.--The most interesting case before the Court of Appeals to-day was that of the People ex rel, Third-Avenue Railroad Company against John Newton as Commissioner of Public Works.

That agreement which caused various degrees of interest in the hearing of the Stewart will contest on Monday remained the bone of contention in the Surrogate's Court yesterday, and a big crowd assembled to see ex-AttorneyGeneral Russell assume the role of Samson.

The Business Men's Republican Association of the City of New-York, an organization designed to be permanent and including the various political clubs which joined in the Republican parade of Nov. 3, was formed at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last night. A constitution was adopted and these officers were elected:

It is now authoritatively declared that that the New-Yorkers who went to Manitoba to purchase controlling shares in the new opposition to the Canadian Pacific Railway bought instead full rights for all Manitoba blizzards and brought the bill of sale home with them.

BERLIN, Dec. 11.--Count Herbert Bismarck's expected exposition of the Government's policy in East Africa was made to the Foreign Committee of the Reichstag to-day. At the request of Count Herbert the committee will maintain secrecy regarding his statement and the subsequent debate. Despite the attempt at secrecy, however, it has learned that Count ...
It was pouring rain at Riverhead, Long Island, yesterday morning, when Francis ASbury Hawkins was hanged for the murder of his mother, Mrs. Cynthia Hawkins, on Oct. 2 of last year.

Mayor Chapin's plan for repaying Brooklyn's streets at a total cost of $3,800,000, the money to be raised by floating bonds bearing 3 per cent. interest, formed a subject which was widely discussed yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 11.--The Sunday Courier of this city has changed hands, Thomas G. Nichols, its editor, founder, and proprietor, having sold the entire establishment to A.G. Tobey, who has been engaged on the paper for 16 years. Mr. Nichols has been an invalid for years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11.--Three men are known to have been killed, one fatally injured, and a number of people badly bruised and shaken up early this morning by an explosion of meal dust which completely wrecked the three-story brick building on North Halstedstreet, occupied by David Oliver as an oatmeal mill.

The cablegram from London published in yesterday's TIMES stating that the true source of the alleged Parnell letters had been discovered created considerable of a stir among leaders of the National movement in this city.
PARIS, Dec. 11.--The Bank of France announces that the subscriptions for the new Russian loan amount to 2,600,000 bonds, or 1,250,000,000f. nominal.

TORONTO, Dec. 11.--Roland Gideon Israel Barnett, the crooked financial man of London, England, and New-York, and the man who played a prominent part, as it is alleged, in wrecking the central Bank of this city over a year ago, arrived in Toronto this morning, ...

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 11.--The State Senate to-day passed a bill making it a misdemeanor, punishable by expulsion, for any member of the Legislature to accept a free pass from any railroad. The measure will also pass the House. It is intended to prevent undue railroad influence.

Mr. Frank Thomson will entertain the Clover Club of Philadelphia at 6:30 o'clock tomorrow evening at Corkerhill, near Merion station, on the Pennsylvania Railroad. Trains will leave the Broad-Street Station, Philadelphia, at 5:45, 6:15, and 6:45 o'clock P.M. Returning trains will leave Merion at 9, 9:30, 10:30, 11:14, and 11:30 o'clock P.M.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 11.--The body of Thomas Goodson, United States Deputy Marshal, was found to-day in a laurel thicket in Carter County, Tenn., near the foot of Roan Mountain.

Peter Hogan of Albany was before the Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday, at the request of the Central Taxpayers' Association, to discourage the Quaker Bridge Dam project. The drift of his testimony, while not so statistical as that of Civil Engineer Samuel McElioy, Monday was in the same like as to the impracticability of the plan and a preference for the proposed system of small reservoirs in the Croton Watershed.
Letters indorsing the plan of the NewYork Board of Trade and Transportation to establish a naval militia continue to be received by the board's special committee from all parts of the country.
That long-expected event, the peaceful settlement of the Speakership contest, has passed into history.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 11.--It is currently reported that the Diamond Match Company has been bought out by a company of New-York capitalists.

PARIS, Dec. 11.--The Chamber of Deputies to-day, by a vote of 545 to 9, adopted the extraordinary budget for 1889, the estimates being fixed at 138,800,000f. M. Lamarzella, a member of the Right, declared that he had no confidence in the Cabinet, but would vote for the credits because they were necessary for the defense of the country.

Wall-street had a sensation yesterday of a sort that has not been known in many a day. A stock jumped up eight full points at one leap. Delaware and Hudson Canal Company's stock was the one that did it. It closed at 122 on Monday. When the Stock Exchange opened yesterday it rose at once to 130.

George A. Eddy and Harrison Cross of Kansas were yesterday appointed Receivers in the suit of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company against the Mercantile Trust Company of this city. The bond executed by the Trustees has been accepted by Judge Brewer of the Kansas Circuit.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 11.--Pending the journey of Mr. Morton and Senator Quay to this city, the Republican politicians are to-day disturbed over the aspirations of Gen. Lew Wallace for a Cabinet place. Gen. Wallace has not taken much part in Indiana politics of late, but he was the campaign biographer of Gen. Harrison and a prominent campaign speaker, ...
LONDON, Dec. 11.--"The American Commonwealth," Prof. Bryce's book, in three big volumes, which was published to-day, is given unexampled prominence by the London press.
BIG RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 11.--C.A. McManus, the well-known actor, with the Mlle. Rhea company, was found dead in his bed this morning. The cause of his death in unknown.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 11.--Notwithstanding all efforts made to capture him, and the large reward offered, Eugene Bunch, the train robber, it is now definitely known, is in the vicinity of this city, and is liable to be heard from at any unexpected moment.
CARBONDALE, Penn., Dec. 11.--The Delaware and Hudson Canal Company is busily engaged in fitting its cars with steam heat fixtures. It expects to have the work finished before the end of the year.

BOSTON, Dec. 11.--Thomas N. Hart was to-day elected Mayor of Boston, defeating Mayor O'Brien by over 2,000 votes. Last year Mayor O'Brien defeated Hart by over 1,500 votes. The result to-day was brought about by many causes, not the least important of which was the race question and also the school agitation.

NYACE, N.Y., Dec. 11.--The Rockland County Shrievalty case is not yet settled. Judge Brown, at Newburg, yesterday handed down a decision denying a motion made by Mr. Pye's counsel in relation to a technical point of law.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11.--An important argument was had before the Court of Common Pleas this afternoon, involving the duties of commercial agencies to their subscribers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11.--The members of the Advisory Board on the construction of naval vessels have been for some time engaged in settling up the affairs of the estate of the late John Roach, who constructed what are known as the Roach cruisers--the Chicago, Atlanta, ...

The Ladies' Health Protective Association held a meeting yesterday, and talked over several matters which investigation has satisfied them stand sadly in need of reform. For some time past the association has been attempting to arouse a public sentiment which shall demand that New-York City be furnished ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11.--Mr. Plumb's confidence that a reduction would be made in the rate of 1.10 cents per pound on structural shapes of iron and steel fixed by the Finance Committee's substitute for the Mills bill has turned out to be well founded.

There are still doubting Thomases in the world. Over in Manchester, England, lives a skeptical gentleman who signs his name C.E. Wanebrough to a letter that Mr. P.T. Barnum enjoyed with his breakfast yesterday.

Miss Mary D. Brooks, daughter of Charles H. Brooks of 38 East Sixty-fifth-street, was a complainant in Judge Cowing's court in General Sessions yesterday against Patrick McCarthy of 518 East Fourteenth-street and John Lynch of 34 Madison-street, dog catchers, indicted for robbery and assault.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday to consider the final estimates for next year. It was expected that some taxpayers would appear before the board to object to the provisional estimates, but it was not until the work of the board was finished ...

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 11.--The Hillside Coal Company's breaker at Moosie, about five miles below this city, was entirely destroyed by fire tonight. The loss is $60,000; insurance not known, There were between 200 and 300 men and boys employed at the work.
Surrogate Ransom yesterday handed down a construction of the will of Mahlon sands, who was thrown from his horse last May in London and killed.

An unexpected result of the Democratic primaries in Kings County on Monday night was the utter defeat, of Cornelius Furgueson, the boss of New-Utrecht and the ally of John Y. McKane. Just before the last election Furgueson made his peace with the McLaughlin ring and on election day supported the whole Democratic ticket.

The second of the subscription nights at Daly's Theatre was, like the first, a brilliant social event and a notable artistic triumph. The house was crowded, and what is called society was fitly represented by many persons whose names and faces are familiar. The stage performance was distinguished by rare intelligence, perfect good taste, and excellent skill. The night was full of mirth, for both of the plays, Cibber's ...

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 11.--A general assignment was made yesterday by Smith Brothers, dry goods merchants of Saratoga. The house is one of the oldest in Saratoga. The First National Bank of Saratoga holds judgment of $10,004 against the firm. There are a number of other judgments, and a number of chattel mortgages have been given.

At the end of a long and stormy session yesterday afternoon the Committee on Nominations of School Trustees resolved, upon a close vote, to report the nominations of George S. Cornell to be Trustee of Schools in the Tenth Ward and of William J. Van Arsdale to be Trustee of Schools in the Ninth Ward.
ASBURY PARK, N.Y., Dec. 11.--It has stormed heavily along the northern portion of the NewJersey coast since 12 o'clock last night. The wind blew with great force, and the surf ran high and strong.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 11.--The mysteries and marvels of natural gas multiply, Stockholders of the Independent Company organized less than a year ago in Wilkinsburg are in secret session in that suburban borough of Pittsburg under most remarkable circumstances. They are entertaining, or at least considering, two propositions.
TORONTO, Dec. 12.--Thomas W. Beggs was blown to atoms here to-day by the premature explosion of a blasting cartridge.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 12.--The various rumors recently circulated as to proposed changes in the executive officers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company have resulted in the issuing of a statement by the parties now in control of the Board of Directors.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 12.--The excitement here is still intense, but no hostile demonstrations are now being made against the Sheriff who gave the order to fire on the mob against the prisoner Hawes.
The saying that old editors, like pins, disappear mysterioulsy was illustrated in the corridors of the Gilsey House yesterday, during the recess of the meeting of the New-York State Associated Press.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 12.--During the progress of the Olsen murder trail to-day in the District Court Judge Kelly let his temper get the better of his judgment and issued an order to prevent the publication of certain proceedings in the case.

The Wesleyan University Club will hold its twentieth annual reunion at Clark's, 22 West. Twenty-third-street, to-morrow at 5 o'clock. Dinner will be served at 6 o'clock. George G. Reynolds of Brooklyn will preside.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12.--The General Managers of the South western Missouri River lines met to-day at Chairman Midgley's office to further consider the restoration of live stock and other rates from Kansas City to Chicago. The conference was brief, but stormy.

NYACK, N.Y., Dec. 12.--The most fashionable wedding of the season here occurred this afternoon, the bride being Miss Mary Towt, daughter of John W. Towt, one of Nyack's wealthiest and best-known citizens, ...

There was a very close pool contest at A.M. Frey's room, 234 Broadway, last night between A.K. Darby and Albert Trnett. Darby is a small young man with a large mustache, and Truett is a tall young man with a Manhattan Athletic Club badge.

HARTFORD, Dec. 12.--At the annual meeting of the Yale Alumni Association of this city to-night the Hon. Henry C. Robinson was chosen President, Charles H. Clark Vice-President, John M. Holcombe Secretary, and William L. Matson Treasurer.

PARIS, Dec. 12.--Another scene of excitement was witnessed at the offices of the Panama Canal Company to-day. The crush was even greater than that of yesterday. At 4 o'clock a hush fell over the throng, and M. de Lesseps appeared.

DENTON, Texas, Dec. 12.--Joseph Waller of Waco and W. L. Rushing of Fort Worth, two officers, arrested Frank Howe here last night and started for Waco to-day. Howe is the man who robbed the express office at Waco in September of $4,000.
ERIE, Penn., Dec. 12.--Trainmen on the Lake Shore Railroad received orders to-day to hold back New-York Central freight and to-day off at Collingwood. The tracks between Erie...

ZANZIBAR, Dec. 12.--The plunder secured by Bushiris has increased his influence, and influential Arab chiefs are joining him. There is little prospect that the rebellion will soon subside.

Joseph Swift, Vice-President and Manager of the New-York office of the Diamond Match Company, at 157 Duane-street, denied yesterday morning that there was any truth in the report that the company had been bought out by a syndicate of New-York capitalists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12.--The following nominations were sent to the Senate this afternoon: Interior Department.--Walter L. Bragg of Alabama to be an Inter-State Commerce Commissioner. Treasury Department.-Orrin B. Hallam of Ken tucky to be Deputy First Auditor of the Treasury, vice F.P. Baldwin, resigned.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Dec. 12.--The chorus of the Philharmonic Society Musical Festival sang three times to-day--at 9 o'clock this morning, 2 o'clock this afternoon, and at the first grand concert to-night. Blaisdell's full bank of Boston was the orchestra, Carl Zerrahn the conductor, and Mrs. Martha Dana Shepard accompanist.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Dec. 12.--Capt. Reed, representing the Seventy-second Pennsylvania Regiment, was to-day arrested on a capias in trespass sworn out by the Battlefield Memorial Association and put under $500 bail.

LONDON, Dec. 12.--Mr. Morley, in a speech at Clerkenwell this evening, condemned the Government's policy in East Africa. In regard to Suakin he said: "If we are not careful we shall have on our hands another abominable, profitless, and purposeless Soudanese war.

At the annual meeting of the MedicoLegal Society, held last night at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, Clark Bell was re-elected President, Dr. W. H. Stevenson Vice-President, Albert Bach Secretary, and E.W. Chamberlain Treasurer.

BOSTON, Dec. 12.--That Boston was very much stirred up in the Mayoralty contest of yesterday goes without saying, but there was in it less of politics than in any election for many years. Of course, strong efforts were made to keep the Democrats in line for O'Brien, but they signally failed ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12.--The stockholders of the Keely Motor Company did not hold their annual meeting to-day owing to a clause in the by-laws which provides for an attendance of three-fifths of the members.

The concert given at the Academy of Music last Sunday evening by the Seventy-first Regiment Band proved so successful as to warrant the management engaging the band for three more concerts. Col. Anson Mills, United States Army, is at the Gilsey House. George M. Robeson of New-Jersey is at the Westminster Hotel.

The State Senate committee--appointed to investigate oombinatione and agreements oommonly known as "trusts," that there may be legislation for the correction of abuses, resumed work in this city yesterday morning. ALBANY, Dec. 12.--Adjt.-Gen. Porter to-day gave out the information that the Twenty-fifth Separate Company of Canandaigua, commanded by Congressman-elect John Raines, would be mustered out of the National Guard Dec. 18. This induced a listener to remark: "This is the first thing John Raines is ever known to have let go."

The Western Union Telegraph Company yestcrday issued the statement of its business for the quarter ending Dec. 31, the earnings for the present month, of course, being estimated. The "net revenues" are set down at $1,650,000, an increase of $150,000 over the corresponding period of last year.

At the meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday Aaron Vanderbilt, for the Naval Militia Committee, reported that while the committee was at work on a bill Secretary Whitney eent it the draft of an act specially designed for adoption in the State of New-York. To-morrow--evening "Faust" will be sung for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12.--A New-York paper to-day says that at a conference of Colorado Republicans in that city yesterday Senator Teller said that if ex-Senator Tabor were elected to succeed Senator Bowen, he (Teller) would resign.

Rossini's masterpiece, "William Tell," was repeated at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. There was a large audience present and the applause was abundant. The performance was smooth, but did not differ in its general effect from the first one.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 12.--The return of Senator Sabin to the State and his announcement that he proposes to stay here now until the Senatorial contest is settled has had the effect of imparting new interest to the fight at headquartors in St. Paul, and is bracing up the lines on all sides.

An interesting incident of the charitable work done by the Jacksonville Relief Society is found in the action of the Morning Side Club, an organization of little girls in Metuchen, N. J., which has formally adopted an infant now in a Jacksonville orphan asylum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12.--Capt. David J. Young, Ordnance Storekeeper, was placed on the retired list of the army to-day. Capt. William I. Reed Seventh Infantry, has been granted one month's extension of leave of absence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12.--The River and Harbor Appropriation bill was reported to the House of Representatives this morning by Chairman Blanchard.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 12.--For some time capitalists have been interesting themselves in examining a survey which has been made from the Hocking Valley coal fields to Saugatuck, a port on the eastern coast of Lake Michigan.
DENVER, Dec. 12.--Word reached here today from Ouray Agency, Green River, Utah, that Colorow, the celebrated chief of the Southern Utes, had died at the agency yesterday of pneumonia.

CHATTANOOGA, Dec. 12.--Since the result of the late Presidential election became known there is great activity among the moonshiners in the mountains of East Tennessee.
Yesterday morning was the time set for the annual election of officers and Directors of the New-York City Mission and Tract Society, whose headquarters are at the Bible House.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 12.--Attorney-General Garland has telegraphed to Emory B. Sellers that the President desired him to withdraw his resignation, and it is expected that he will do so. The storm of public indignation is probably more than he can stand, even if the President had not made this request.

The steamer Claribel, that came in yesterday from Kingston, Jamaica, had a very rough passage in its way out and another storm coming back. She started from here on Nov. 24 and had a continuous gale until Nov. 27.

HASTINGS, Neb., Dec. 12.--"Kid" Nelson, the negro desperado who killed Officer Balcomb last August while resisting arrest, was sentenced to imprisonment for life last night. Nelson is the 15year-old boy who held seven officers at bay while he was in ambush.

STUTTGART, Dec. 12.--It is expected that a change in the Wurtemberg Ministry will soon take place, and it is reported that after this has been accomplished the American favorites of the King will return to their places in his Majesty's service.

The coming of Mr. Morton and Senator Quay has put politicians all over the country on the qui vive, and telegrams poured in all day inquiring about them.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15--The menhaden fishing season for 1888 has closed, and, from the accounts coming in from the try works at Niantle, New-London, and on Long Island, the season in this comparatively great industry has been a prosperous one--so prosperous, in fact, that many of the fishermen will individually share an average of $400 profit for the Summer's work.

READING, Penn., Dec. 15,--J.C. De Hart Co., extensive shoe dealers of this city, this after, noon made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors of considerable real estate and stock. The cause of the failure is dullness in the trafic. The liabilities may reach $12,000; assets, $20,600.

Twelve-year-old Joseph Stevenson died at his home on Wednesday night of symptoms resembling hydrophobia. The boy was bitten in the lip and cheek by a dog on Oct. 24 last. The wounds were promptly cauterized and soon healed, leaving two ugly scars.

MADISON, Ind., Dec. 15.--True bills have been found against Capt. Charles Supplee, Robert King, Thomas Banta, and other pilots and officers of the Ohio River steamers here on account of Sunday excursions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--It is announced here that the Whisky Trust has decided on a campaign of extermination against the distillers who have refused to come into the combination. This is to be put in force on Jan. 1 by a decided reduction in the price of whisky.

GLASCO, N.Y., Dec. 15.--While the wife of Capt. F. Carle of the boat Washband was showing a revolver, which her husburn had brought home, to her 5-year-old daughter Mattie and a neighbor's little girl here to-night the weapon was discharged. The ball, of large calibre, instantly killed the woman's own child. She did not know the revolver was loaded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--The total amount of bonds purchased to date under the circular of April 17 is $100,686,200, of which $51,398,650 were 4 per cents., and $48,389,550 were 4 per cents. The cost of these bonds was $119,247,668, of which $66,010,877 was paid for the 4 per cents., and $54,236,791 for the 4 per cents.

Dr. Rufus L. Wilder died yesterday morning rather suddenly at his home, 113 West One Hundred and Thirty-third-street. He was 45 years of age, was born in Leominster, Mass., and was graduated from Harvard College as a physician in 1876 and then studied medicine in London and Edinburgh.

Yesterday's closing prices were only fractionally changed from those of the previous week, except for the coal stocks. QUEENSTOWN, Dec. 15.--One of the passengers of the steamer Umbria, from New-York, who landed here this morning, was a woman named Gallagher. On reaching the shore she was arrested and searched, and 50 cartridges were found concealed in her dress. She was remanded.

Mr. Henry George, who arrived home on the Etruria yesterday, talked for an hour to the reporters last evening very enthusiastically of his unexpectedly-long visit to England. He sailed Nov. 10, with William Saunders, Radical member of Parliament from East Hull, intending to stay a week for the benefit of his health, but he found so much to interest him in the political situation that his stay was prolonged to a month.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 16.--For a long time the Knights of Labor have been hovering on the outskirts of a question that was bound to make a clash. Ever since Powderly began to lose prestige the order has been in danger of a religious war. Powderly has, in one way, tried to stave it off and if possible to kill it; in another way he is the sole cause of it.

At the Windsor Hotel, as in other places where Wall-Street men and railway managers met yesterday, there was no other topic discussed with half the interest that attached to Charles Francis Adams's review of the railroad situation. Some wordy efforts were made to offset the stinging effects of his strictures, but men who made attempts of this sort were few.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18.--The well-known comedian, Charles Rogers, who has been for some time confined to his bed in this city by consumption, died on a Fort Wayne train to-night. PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18.--The United States steamer Dispatch, which has been anchored in the Delaware near Cramp's shipyard for some time, was blown aground by the high wind this morning, and four tugs were unsuccessful in their efforts to get the vessel off during the day. Another effort will be made to-morrow. It is not thought that any se rious damage will result from the grounding of the steamer.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19.--The regular monthly meeting of the Board of Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company was held to-day. All the Directors elected by the shareholders at the annual meeting on Nov. 19 were qualified and took their seats.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Dec. 19.--Crawfis College, built by John Crawfis, a farmer who had a surplus of wealth and wanted to build a monument to himself, is nearly completed. It is situated in Blanchard Township, Putnam County, just across the line from this county, and cost about $15,000.
HARTFORD, Dec. 19.--The river is apparently stationary at 20.7 feet, the highest point since April, 1887. Heavy ice from the upper valley is running out this evening.

The new White Star Line steamer Teutonic will be launched on Jan. 5. She is 645 feet long, of 10,000 tons burden, and is expected to prove very fast. She will probably make her first voyage to this port in June. A sister ship, the Majestic, is also well on the way toward completion. Both vessels can be quickly turned into cruisers.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 19.--John Frost, whose dead body was found near a country store on the Tennessee and Georgia line, was, it seems, killed by John Pyburn, who assumed the quarrel raised by a woman with Frost, and shot the latter several times as he ran. No attempt was made to learn the result until the body was found. Pyburn and the woman are in jail at Trenton, Ga.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Dec. 19.--A deed of trust made by the firm of Hartsfield Roe, retail furniture dealers, to E.E. Chase, was filed in the District Court this evening. It was to secure $13,000 due on notes to the Merchants' National Bank.

The Park Presbyterian Church held a very large congregation yesterday morning The Paster, the Rev. E.G. Thurber, D.D., had signified his intention of announcing his decision in regard to the call he had received to the American church in Paris. Dr. Thurber was not present, the Rev. A.E. Myers, Pastor ...

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 19.--At 6 o'clock this evening, while the family of A.G. Richey, a wealthy lawyer, were at dinner in their West State-street residence, a sneak thief climbed up to the veranda fronting the second story and, ...

The difficulties in the way of selecting a Trustee of Schools to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of James A. Seaman of the Ninth Ward were simplified by the resignation of E.M.L. Ehlers, whose term would have expired next year.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19.--The inventory of the estate of the late A.S. Abell, founder of the Sun, was filed in the Orphans' Court of Baltimore County this morning. By Mr. Abell's will the Sun newspaper and everything thereunto belonging and appertaining was bequeathed absolutely to his three sons, Edwin F., George W., and Walter R. Abell.

"I am in some doubt," said ex-Mayor William R. Grace yesterday, "as to the wisdom of noticing anything that emanates from Mr. Stephen B. French. His character is so well known that it is probably a loss of time to pay any attention to him.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 19.--Quay is now the uncrowned King of the Republican Party. Blaine is dethroned and prostrate. Indiana Republicans acknowledge Quay's supremacy both in words and deeds. His stay here was of only 17 hours' duration, and 8 of these hours were hours of darkness, yet he had scarcely an hour to himself.

The spellbinders, having formed a permanent organization, are now wrestling with the question what to do with themselves. They met at the FifthAvenue Hotel yesterday afternoon to talk of the future. The establishment of a bureau was favorably discussed.

The National COnvention of the Republican National League, held at the League haadquarters, 202 Fifth-avenue, yesterday, was a very short affair. There were delegates from 27 States and 2 Territories present, and they all said, excepting the two delegates from Kansas, that it was better to hold ...
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 19.--A local syndicate consisting of S.G. Cook, E.T. Elwell, and others are negotiating with C.J. Jones of Kansas for the purchase of his herd of Manitoba buffalo.

Several humorous letters have reached Mr. Rudolph Aronson, written by some of the Casino patrons who attended the fiftieth performance of "The Yeomen of the Guard" some days ago, and received one of the little metal souvenirs.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 19.--Charles A. Pillsbury was seen at his desk this morning. He said: "Our firm was not represented in the Milwaukee gathering. I notice the papers say Fred Pillsbury was there, but it must have been an error. He was in Chicago.

The trouble among the Boston railroads over the question of advancing west-bound rates has apparently been ended and promising arrangements made to put full tariffs into effect. When the trunk lines ordered an advance in rates, to take effect on Dec. 17, the Boston roads were left to take care of themselves.

ALBANY, Dec. 19.--Miss Miriam R. Hoy of Albany, daughter of Mr. John Hoy, was married this evening to Mr. Clark Horton Porter of Winona. About 100 guests from out of town were in attendance. Mr. John S. Hoy, brother of the bride, was best man. Miss Essie L. Hoy, her sister, was bridesmaid. The marriage was the social event of the season in this city.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 19.--Thomas McConnelly, a school teacher at Andale, a town a few miles west of this city, got into a fight with his pupils to-day and received injuries from which he died in a few minutes.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19.--The end of Toddtown's double tragedy was the burial to-day of John Ferguson, the jealous husband, and Mary Ferguson, his pretty wife, whom he murdered. The burials were wide apart.

It is to be hoped that the movement represented by the Alabama and Georgia delegation that visited Gen. HARRISON on Tuesday will be successful. Its object is to build up a political organization in the South in general harmony with the incoming National Administration and thereby to dissolve the solidity of that section.
H. Theobald of Easton's National Horse and Cattle Exchange of this city yesterday bought the brown colt Galere, a 3-year-old, at the Newmarket (England) sales.

COLUMBUS, S.C., Dec. 19.--The House of Representatives to-night passed the Senate bill to punish frauds at primary elections. It imposes a penalty of $100 and five or six months' imprisonment in the penitentiary for neglect of duty on the part of managers, and a fine of $500 and one year's imprisonment for fraud-- illegal voting, ballot box stuffing, such elections.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 19.--The unprecedented rainfall of the past few months has raised the water in the Watuppa Ponds to an unusual height for this time of year and is causing the municipal authorities and many manufacturers a good deal of anxiety.
QUINCY, Ill., Dec. 19.--The wedding was announced to take place in this city about 10 days ago of Frank Wilford, who is said to be of noble blood, and Miss Dora Hartung of this city.

The refusal of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children to return Mrs. Diss Debar's children to her has aroused that lady's ire. Her counsel, John D. Townsend, says he has prepared a writ of habeas corpus asking that the child Alice, who was placed in Mrs. Diss Debar's custody some years ago, and her ...

Harry W. Lacey, the sporting editor of Turf, Field and Farm, lives at Larchmont, on the Sound, where he has a fine kennel of valuable hunting doge. Early this month he hired a young man named William Sheldon to work about his place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--Several of the witnesses subpoenaed by the House Committee on the Merchant Marine and the Fisheres to testify regarding the alleged outrages in Alaska were in attendance when the committee met to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19.--The Connecticut Almanac for 1889 is edited by Prof. A. W. Phillips of Yale. A new feature introduced this year is a treatise on the ancient inhabitants of the Connecticut Valley by Dr. E.H. Barbour, for the last six years assistant in the United States Geological Survey.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19.--Daylight is now visible through the darkness of Southwestern railway affairs, and the action taken at to-day's meeting of the General Managers seems to warrant the expectation that notice will be given at once of a restoration of all freight rates, and ...

All the milk of human kindness is not to be found in the hearts of the great and prosperous. Down among the little gamins of Newspaper-row exists a charity as sweet and springing from as pure motives as is any carried on by the great incorporated institutions and societies which grace this city.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 19.--A. Ebert of the crystal Hall, 79 West Fourth-street, made an assignment this afternoon. Assets, $35,000; liabilities, $50,000.

The agitation over the proposition to include actors in the restrictions of the contract labor law is growing, not only in this city out throughout the country. J.H. McVicker, the Chicago manager, a member of the Actors' Order of Friendship, has written a letter in which he expresses his views earnestly and strongly. He says that it is a disgrace to the theatrical profession ...

ALBANY, Dec. 19.--The situation in regard to the position taken by the State Board of Canvassers as to the allegations widely printed that certain votes upon the question of the proposed amendment to section 6 of Article VI. of the Constitution of this State were rejected by the board is expressed in the following statement:

Having learned their own value as a distinct political power, women will not be content to relapse into political nenentity. Every woman who has voted is a more independent, thoughtful, public spirited person for having done her duty as a citizen.

The Committee on the Centennial Celebration of Washington's Inauguration have received information of the appointment of the following Commissioners, whose duty it is to see that their States are properly represented at the Celebration in this city next April:

Under the statute the Board of County Canvassers of this county will be required to meet Tuesday, Jan. 1, before 1 P.M., for the purpose of canvassing the votes cast in the Sixth Senate District at the special election, which is to be held Dec. 28 in that district for a successor to Senator Edward F. Reilly, resigned.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 19.--A milk train on the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad encountered a cyclone yesterday morning near Newfoundland, N.J. As the train was passing a huge tree was torn up by the roots and came crashing down upon the cars, breaking through the roof of the baggage car and ripping off the hood of the passenger coach. No one was hurt.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 19.--Old Harrison Hogan, the Indiana farmer who recently sprang into note as "The Bull Creek Terror," on account of his determined resistance against arrest, is still at large.

The Rev. Calbraith B. Perry, who, while Rector of the House of Prayer at Nowark, N.J., was charged with gross immorality, has been exonerated by the committee appointed by the Bishop to investigate the case. The committee's report was concluded in these words:

DETROIT, Dec. 19.--Some legal complications are likely to arise from the action of "Deacon" White and "Jack" Rowe in quitting the National League without the consent of the stockholders of the old Detroit Club and purchasing a controlling interest in the Buffalo International team.

The Republicans in the Senate have taken a long step toward securing for the trusts, combinations, and monopolies a new lease of power. Warned by the demonstration made in the recent campaign that they cannot safely go to the country again on the naked issue of high protection with a surplus revenue pouring into the Treasury, ...

There is much significance in the simultaneous announcements that the investigation of the case of DUDLEY is being vigorously pushed in Indiana and that the Republican Senators are preparing to reject the nomination of Mr. BAILEY to be District Attorney of the Northern District of that State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--Representative Holman intends to secure, if possible, some affirmative action by Congress that will tend to check the corrupt use of money at elections. To-day he introduced a bill which will put the matter before the House in a well-defined shape. Its provisions are as follows:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 19.--Parties from Northwest, this State, bring news of a desperate fight between a mad dog and an aged woman, some miles from Bentonville. Mrs. Mary Rollman was on her way to visit a neighbor, when she was attacked by a large dog.

The Oritani Snowshoe Club held its annual dinner and meeting at F. Vianest's, 87 Fultonstreet, last night. Officers were elected as follows: President--George M. Fairchild, Jr.; Honorary President--Erastus Wiman; Vice-President--J.E. Learned; Captain--William P. Ellery; Vice-Captain --W.A. Shortt; Secretary and Treasurer--Wakeman Holberton; Whippers-in--W.J. Weldon and Prof. Wells of Columbia College.

Kane Lodge, No. 454, F. and A.M.--Master-- Rollin M. Morgan; Senior Warden--Claudius M. Roome; Junior Warden--Lilian H. Andrews; Treasurer--Charles A. Whitney; Secretary--Henry W. Pennoyar; Senior Deacon--Joseph M. Ward; Junior Deacon--George E.W. Stivers; Masters of ...

Frank Oakes Rose will make his first appearance at the Star Theatre next Sunday evening, when he will give what he characterizes as a Dickens Christmas entertainment. He will illustrate the "Christmas Carols" and other Christmas stories of Dickens, ending with "Gabriel Grubb, the Sexton Who was Stolen by Goblins."

It was an off night at the opera. Perhaps it was the cold weather that did it; perhaps it was the necessity of preparing for the approaching festivities of Christmas. At any rate there were more empty boxes last evening than there have been at any previous performance.

It is now almost certain that the Manhattan Club will purchase the Stewart mansion, at Thirty-fourth-street and Fifth-avenue, and after refitting it, take possession next year. Nearly a year ago the Stewart house was looked upon as the most eligible building in the city for the Manhattan's use.
Gounod's St. Cecilia mass was the principal work presented at the Gounod Cheral Club's fist concert at Chickering Hall last evening. It was an enjoyable performance, though somowhat uneven.

Peter Bruce, a salesman in the firearms store of Hartley Graham, 19 Maiden-lane, was accidentally shot in the leg yesterday afternoon by Andrew L. Panchel, another salesman, who was half way across the store showing ...
TROY, Dec. 19.--A shock of earthquake was felt in Washington and Warren Countries at 5:45 this morning. The vibration lasted about four seconds. Buildings were violently shaken.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 19.--The Presidents of the New-York and New-England, Housatonic, and Danbury and Norwalk Railroads went down the Danbury and Norwalk Railroad this afternoon on a special train to organize the new corporation which is to connect the latter road with New-York City by boat.

LONDON, Dec. 20.--A dispatch from Geneva gives the correspondence that passed in March, 1880, between the Hon. William M. Evarts, the American Secretary of State, and M. Max Outrey, the French Minister at Washington, in reference to the Panama Canal.

The Turf, Field and Farm announces that James B. Clay of Lexington, Ky., has bought of Capt. L.C. Bruce of New-York the blk. s. Vocalic and three well-bred mares for $10,000. Vocalic was foaled in 1881 by Virgil, dam Acoustic, by imported Australian. He is a handsome horse and has a good record as a racehorse.
"The Yeomen of the Guard," will be withdrawn from the Casino stage on Jan. 14, when it will be replaced by a revival of "Nadjy."

ROCKLAND, Me., Dec. 19.--In the case of Mrs. Helena Lawrence Gardener of Philadelphia, defendant in a libel for divorce brought by William H. Gardener of Camden, for the custody of three sons, Judge Libby to-day announced a decision giving the youngest son, a boy of 10 years, to the mother, and the other two to the father.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--Col. George H. Mendall, Corps of Engincers, has been ordered to temporary duty at San Diego, Cal. Capt. William H. Nash, Commissary of Subsistence, has been ordered to duty at Fortress Monroe, Va. First Lieut. John F. Guilfoyle, Ninth Cavalry, has been ordered to temporary duty at St. Louis, Mo.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 19--A dispatch from Kentville says: "The Windsor and Annapolis Railway bridge at Cambridge has been carried away by a freshet. Three dams above the bridge gave way, and the heavy volume of water pouring down was too much for the structure.

The wedding of Miss Lillian Chambers, daughter of Isaac P. Chambers, to Mr. Willard B. Young, in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Madison-avenue and Forty-second-street, was attended by many friends last night.

A meeting of the Bottlers' Protective Union of New-York, Brooklyn, and vicinity will be held at 2 o'clock this afternoon in Goerwitz Hall, 194 Third-avenue. The bottlers assert that they are subjected to great financial loss by the illegal sale of bottles by saloon keepers, dealers in junk, and others.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 19.--A horrible accident has just robbed a home here of a lovely young girl. John Bladdon, a carpenter, went home last night under the influence of liquor. He had in his room an old army rifle, which he took down and began to load.

Ladies will play cards. I wonder, really, if they mean to cheat. I don't think they do. I think they have an idea that it is wrong and wicked and unprincipled to play cards, and that there can't be anything more wrong in getting the best of their opponents.
CALCUTTA, Dec. 19.--The Chittagong hill tribes have raided the lowlands and killed several persons. An expedition consisting of 1,200 men has started out to punish them.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 19.--Ice is forming rapidly on the Hudson River to-night. Incoming towboats this evening reported heavy ice between here and Coxsackie. The night boats, the James W. Baldwin and the City of Kingston, will make their last trips to New-York City for the season on Thursday and Friday nights, respectively.

There was a lively time in the office of the City Record, in the City Hall, yesterday morning. The actors in the scene were ponderous Thomas Costigan, the usually jovial Supervisor of the City Record, and Accountant William J. Best, who is commonly very suave, although his bright-hued hair and whiskers suggest a choleric disposition.

ALBANY, Dec. 19.--George Hotis, employed as switchman in 1883 by the Central Hudson Railroad, lost his leg while switching a train. He sued the company for $25,000 damages. In the Circuit Court here to-day he was awarded $12,000 damages and $400 extra allowance. The case will be carried up.

HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 19.--Charles E.
