Clow, a trainman on the fast train on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad due in this city at 7:45 A.M., bound north, died on the train just before it reached here this morning from hemorrhage, and his body was removed to the station. He resided at 448 West Fortyseventh-street, New-York.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 19.--The new schooner Ella J., from Sackville for St. John, lumber laden, ran ashore at Quaco on Monday night and became a total wreck. The crew were saved, but lost everything. The vessel was not insured.

Nearly half the 300 Republicans who were expected to attend the "glorification dinner" at West End Hall, in Harlem, last night, stretched their limbs under the elaborate pine board tables, admired the decorations of the hall, and discussed the elaborate menu that ended with pie.
In 1884, when Sheridan Shook and James W. Collier were managing the Union-Square Theatre, Robert Buchanan engaged to write them an American society drama, for which he was to receive 1,000.
Yesterday was another boom day on the Stock Exchange. So the see-sawing goes; one day bearish, one day bullish--all days dull.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19.--The rumor that the Pennsylvania Railroad is to abandon the Delaware and Raritan Canal is denied by members of the company, who say that although the canal company is not making as much money as formerly, it is still making a little.

John Meyer Doremus was handed at Hackensack yesterday morning for the murder in June last of his son, whom he stabbed with a carving knife for interfering in behalf of his mother. Only 26 witneeses were admitted to the execution. Doremus has seemed during the past two weeks to be sincerely penitent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19.--Another sensation was developed in the now noted Lindauer insolvency case before Judge Prendergast in the County Court to-day. Mr. Rosenblatt, a member of the firm, while in the witness chair admitted that just before the failure he had taken $4,000 from the cash drawer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19.--This evening men employed by Republicans to keep the tally of the vote for Congress in the Fifth District reported a net gain of 82 for Phelps, Republican, which gives him a majority of 31 over Clunie, Democrat, to whom the certificate of election has been issued.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 19.--Pension Agent Carpenter received orders to-day to restore the name of Eliza McGill, an aged colored woman of Vicksburg, Miss., to the pay rolls of his office. The history of her case is interesting. Her husband was a soldier in the Union Army, and lost his life in the service.

PARIS, Dec. 19.--In the Senate to-day, during the debate on the budget, M. ChallemelLacour said the present was not the moment to consider French finances, but the future of France. He condemned the policy now pursued in the schools, which, he said, struck at the root of the traditional principles of parental control.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 19.--The leading anti-Mahone Republicans in this State, some of whom are believed to be in constant communication with those close to Harrison, assert positively that they know Mahone will not be given a place in the Cabinet.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 19.--The Canadian Pacific Railway has dispatched to Boston a special train conveying poultry consigned to Boston dealers. The consignment was sent from Smith's Falls by a train of 20 refrigerator cars. The contents weigh 200 tons and were entered at the Custom House as valued at $45,000. The price paid was higher than the price obtained in the market in this city.
The fifth annual meeting of the American Historical Association will be held in Washington on Dec. 26-28. The headquarters of the association will be at the Arlington Hotel.
SYDNEY, New-South Wales, Dec. 19.--A game of baseball was played here to-day between the American teams. The result was as follows: All America, 6: Chicago 8.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19.--A local paper this morning says: "Mrs. Cleveland says she is enjoying her stay here very much, as she always does.
MONTREAL, Dec. 19.--Train service in the province is greatly delayed by the fall of snow. Monday afternoon six farmers started from Boucherville for this city with wagonloads of produce.

The will of Julia Augusta Teresa Clinch, one of Mrs. A.T. Stewart's sisters, has been filed for probate in the Surrogate's office. Anna Catharine Clinch and Emma Allen Clinch, sisters of the testatrix, are given the household furniture and jewelry absolutely and a life interest in all the property except $1,000, which goes to cornelia M. Fitch, and $500 to Mrs. Ellen Oakport.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 19.--Mr. Jacob Ramser or Barbour County, Ala., gives an interesting account of the pedigree of R.R. Hawes, the Birmingham engineer who is charged with the murder of his wife and two children.
CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 19.--The Concord Railway bridge at Hookset fell this morning, carrying with it nine men, three of whom were drowned.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19.--Important steps were taken to-day looking to the speedy improvement of the passenger rate situation. The special committee of several General Managers appointed to submit a statement of principles and a plan of agreement to govern the lines in the territory of the Western States Passenger Association, made a report of the full meeting of managers at Chairman Abbott's office.

The Presbyterian Hospital has just published its twentieth annual report, concluding with this year, and showing the growth in efficiency of the institution. It declares, to show how its work has increased, that in 1880 there were treated in the hospital 575 patients, who in the aggregate received 23,627 days of treatment; of these 21,157 days were entirely free and 2,227 were upon endowed beds.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 19.--Late in the afternoon the American Turf Congress met for business in executive session. The report of the Committee on Rules was adopted. This made two changes.

All along Washington and Greenwich streets are scores of booths and stores green with mistletoe and holly in every combination and shape that Christmas fancy can suggest. Anglomania has very little to do with it, for the beauty of the two is far more than sufficient to make them favorites.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 19.--The most brilliant social event that has occured in this city for many years was the marriage this afternoon of Miss Lilian Mary Selleck, only daughter of Judge Andrew Selleck, to Mr. William Wallace Keys or Bridgeport.

Among the visitors at the last exhibition of the Ladies' Art Association was the famous Russian artist, Vasili Verestschagin. He was so much pleased with the work of the association that he became a permanent paying member.
Ex-Alderman Bartholomew F. Kenney, once an influential politician of this city, yesterday went over to Part II. of the Brooklyn Supreme Court with his sister-in-law, ...

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 19.--James Angus, proprietor of a hotel at Washingtonville, has lawsuits sufficient on his hands now to last him a lifetime. They will probably satisfy him, as he is a man fully 70 years of age. Angus was formerly a New-Yorker, served on the police force, kept a sporting resort, and later a roadhouse just outside of the city.

Don Francisco de Paula Alvarez is at the St. James Hotel, on his way from London to Havana. He recently completed a deal in the English capital, whereby the famous "Henry Clay" cigar factory of Havana was combined with that of Book Co. of the same place, and ...

Three schemes for supplying this city with more water ware presented to the Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday. The first was that of John R. Bartlett and others to bring water for the lower part of the city from the Passaic and Ramano Valleys, in New-Jersey.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 19.--A big raid was made on the gambling houses at Tonawanda recently and a number of the keepers of taro and keno banks were arrested. The Grand Jury to-day presented indictments against John Annin, Frank Hardenbug, Richard Hays, William B. Hayes, ...

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 19.--Milton Young of this county wired to-day to Tattersalls, London, to buy for him at $10,000 Ossory, 3-yearold colt, by Ben d'Or, dam Lily Agnes, by Macaroni. Ossory is brother to the great Ormonde.

YANKTON, Dakota, Dec. 19.--The Trustees of the insane asylum to-day removed the Superintendent, Dr. R. Buchanan, by a vote of the majority of the board, and appointed Dr. James Roane of Yankton. Buchanan was appointed by the present board as soon as it was granted full powers by the courts.

READING, Penn., Dec. 19.--A new municipal bill in place of the one which has been declared unconstitutional for the government of all the cities in Pennsylvania, excepting Philadelphia and Pittsburg was prepared by a committee of eminent lawyers from all over the State, in this city this week.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 19.--The Picayune's Wahalak special says: "The tragedy is about over. Three of the leading actors are in the hands of avengers, and six more are hedged in so that escape seems impossible. The hunt began early this morning. The names of the three captured are Dick Cheatham, Anthony Wilder, and Zach Maury. The first two are in custody and the latter under surveillance.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 19.--Gen. Jacob D. Cox has resigned as Chancellor of Cincinnati University on the ground that the money paid him as salary can be better expended for apparatus and library.

Mr. Auguste, the representative of the Hippolyte or Northern faction in Hayti, who arrived by the steamer Saginaw, left for Washington yesterday. He, however, would not admit that he was on a mission from the Northern Government, and said that he was bound for Paris.

LONDON, Dec. 19.--Three actions brought against ex-City Treasurer Axworthy of Cleveland, Ohio, were settled to-day in the Court of Queen's Bench. The actions arose from banking disputes. With the sanction of the court, Axworthy agreed to pay 32,000 and surrender his property in America in settlement of the actions.

Two gentlemen called on Capt. Ryan of the East Thirty-fifth-street station yesterday afternoon, and said they knew how James Delamater of 153 East Thirty-fourth-street had received his injuries last Thursday.

READING, Penn., Dec. 19.--A new municipal bill in place of the one which has been declared unconstitutional for the government of all the cities in Pennsylvania, excepting Philadelphia and Pittsburg was prepared by a committee of eminent lawyers from all over the State, in this city this week.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 19.--The Picayune's Wahalak special says: "The tragedy is about over. Three of the leading actors are in the hands of avengers, and six more are hedged in so that escape seems impossible. The hunt began early this morning. The names of the three captured are Dick Cheatham, Anthony Wilder, and Zach Maury. The first two are in custody and the latter under surveillance.

There have been many unique and beautiful charitable entertainments given in NewYork, but it is no exaggeration to say that the ladies and gentlemen who projected and opened last night the Directoire Bazaar in the Hotel Brunswick can well lay claim to something in that line which is exquisite in taste, clever in execution, and very attractive altogether.

BOSTON, Dec. 19.--A report of a serious disaster at sea came to Boston from Rockland, Me., late this afternoon. It purports to be the story of Second Mate Alfred Doran of the British steamer Almira, bound from Birmingham, England, to New-York, via Halifax.

LONDON, Dec. 19.--The announcement of the disbandment of the Honorable Artillery Company has caused a sensation, and the action of the Prince of Wales, which led to the disorganization of the ancient body is unfavorably commented upon by both the press and people.
A woman who had been twice divorced came into the Superior Cours for a third divorce Saturday. She was advised to wait three years before she asked the court for another divorce.

LONDON, Dec. 19.--A dispatch from Auckland says that news has been received from Samoa that the Samoans under Mataafa have succeeded in capturing the most of Atna after a long battle with Tamasese's forces. The losses included 100 killed and several hundred wounded.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 19.--The special lecturers in the Yale Divinity School for next term will be the Rev. John A. Broadus, the Rev. John Hall, and Gen. S.C. Armstrong, Dr. Broadus, who is now Professor in the Southern Theological Seminary of Louisville, Ky., will deliver a course of eight lectures on "Preaching and the Ministerial Life."

A few days ago the leading manufacturers of copper in this country were induced to buy supplies for the first three months of next year from the Copper Syndicate. The price was reported to be 16 cents a pound.

The commission appointed to revise the excise law at its session yesterday in the Bible House began its work by adding skating rinks to the list of places of amusement where intoxicating liquors cannot be sold.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 19.--Judge Welford of the Circuit Court of Richmond City to-day made a decree directing the sale of the Richmond and Alleghany Road, with all its property and franchises.

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 19.--Surrogate John D. Teller handed down his decision to-day in the celebrated Soule will contest. The decision sustains the will, the Surrogate having found that old Lyman Soule, although 90 years old, was mentally sound. The will disposed of over a quarter of a million of dollars.

The fact that William H. Arnoux, counsel for the Society for the Prevention of Crime, applied this week to the Board of Police Commissioners for a certified list of the sureties on the bonds of Superintendent Murray and Inspectors ...

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 19.--The State Bar Association of Alabama met here in eleventh annual session to-day. The meeting was called to order by Wilbur F. Foster of Mason County. The President in his annual address strongly advocated a reform of the present conviet system of Alabama.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--The Democratic Senators will have their holiday recess and the Republican Senators will have a final vote on the Tariff bill at least 10 days before the 1st of February. This is the upshot of the game of bluff played by the Republicans yesterday and the series of party caucuses and joint conferences which were held to-day.
SUAKIN, Dec. 19.--A troop of cavalry patrolled for a distance of four miles to-day. They did not see any Arabs. The enemy repaired the damage done to their works during the night.

The case of Mrs. Emily Stewart for damages to her property at 156 West Fifty-thirdstreet, caused by the elevated road, was begun before the Commissioners yesterday. It is the first of the cases for damages in this street, and is particularly interesting from the fact that the street is practically the only one where the road admits that there is some damage.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19.--George Hartley, excashier of Browning, King Co., confessed to stealing $3,000 from his employers in Judge Baker's court this morning. His employers and the State's Attorney asked the Judge to be merciful on account of Hartley's young wife, who sobbed heartbrokenly while sentence was being pronounced upon her husband.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19.--An accident similar to that which befell the Joggins ocean raft of 1887 has somewhat affected the construction of the immense steel and iron railroad swing drawbridge which the Stonington ...

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 19.--On Monday Inspector Doyle arrested Melville Bateman at the request of the Chief of Police of Utica, N.Y., where he is wanted for embezzlement from his employers, William M. Owens Co. They claim that Bateman ran away, leaving a deficit of $1,800.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 19.--The canvassers of the State vote were hard at work to-day, and the result of their labors was announced as follows: Highest Elector, Republican, 142,492; Democratic, 104,385; Prohibitionist, 115,311, plurality for Harrison, 38,107.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19.--At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the NewYork, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company to-day 97,040 shares of stock were represented by about 300 individuals.

ASBURY PARK, Dec. 19.--The contest between the Adams Express Company and the United States Express Company which began here last June has assumed new complications, which may result in a long and spirited struggle in the courts.

In connection with the movement in this State for ballot reform it may be interesting for those who are pushing the matter to learn that a similar struggle occurred in Ohio as a result of intimidation and fraud at the polls. Honest men of both parties drifted into the movement, and nearly four years ago the Legislature was obliged to take cognizance of it.

The Dock Commissioners propose to improve the East River front so as to make places for the Eastern steamboats and sailing craft and generally accommodate traffic that now helps to clog the North River front.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 19.--Matthew G. Elliott, the oldest bank President in this city, has resigned the Presidency of the Tradesmen's National Bank because of advanced age and continued ill health. He is 86 years of age, and has been President of the bank since its institution in 1855. He will be succeeded by George A. Butler, now Vice-President of the bank.
You will not keep abreast with the times if you fail to attend an afternoon performance of "Little Lord Fauntleroy" at the Broadway Theatre. The audience is quite as interesting as the play.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19.--The steam pilotboat No. 1 was run into and sunk this morning by the Allan Line steamship Peruvian, Capt. Stevens, in the lower Craighill Channel, off North Point. No lives were lost, and the Peruvian kept on her course.

Edgar Y. Harris, employed as a ticket seller for the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad at the Grand Central Station, has been missing since Monday, and it is stated that he has taken some of the company's money with him. Harris was at the station Sunday. Monday he did not appear.
PITTSBURG, Dec. 19.--W.T. Lewis, Secretary of the Miners' Progressive Union, and lately Master Workman of District Assembly No. 135, Knights of Labor, is in the city to-day.

The Special Assembly Committee on Rules held a meeting at the office of John B. Pine, 50 Pine-street, yesterday morning to discuss certain proposed amendments to the rules governing the Legislature. The members of the committee present were Chairman James W. Husted, George S. Weed, Charles T. Saxton, William F. Sheehan, and Joseph Blumenthal. Simon Sterne and John B. Pine Look part in the discussion.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20.--A gentleman cognizant of Baltimore and Ohio affairs, and whose opinion is worthy of consideration, made the following comment to an Associated Press reporter on recent changes in the Board of Directors...

A rebellion is in progress in the medical department of the University of the City New York. The students have met daily since Tuesday last in the college building, in East Twenty-sixthstreet, to discuss what they consider their grievances and the means of redress.

TOLEDO, Dec. 20.--This evening's Blade is authority for the statement that suit will be entered in the Common Pleas Court of this county to-morrow to recover from the State of Ohio large tracts of canal lands in this city and in Paulding County.

"Farinelli," a new operetta, and the first composed by Hermann Zumpe, orchestral conductor under Polini at Victoria Theatre, Hamburg, was given with eminent success at Amberg's Theatre last night for the first time in America.

A congress of colored Catholics, which will open in Washington on Jan. 1, will begin a series of events of great interest to the church. The centennial of the establishment of the first Catholic college in the country--that at Georgetown--will be celebrated in February.

While waiting for the guillotine to do its work upon him the condemned murderer Prado tries is make the time pass as pleasantly as possible in his cell at the Grande Roquette. He at first stated emphatically that he had no faith in the success of his appeal against the verdict of the Court of Assizes, but his spirits have risen since then.
PARIS, Dec. 20.--The workmen on the Eiffel tower, which is being constructed as one of the features of the exhibition next year, have gone on a strike for increased wages.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 20.--Grain men of Minnesota and other States will await with interest the answer of the Board of Railroad and Warehouse Commissioners in the matter of maintaining the integrity of what are known as the "Minnesota grades."

ALBANY, Dec. 20.--The veterans of the Ninety-first New-York Veteran Volunteers had a reunion here to-day, and this afternoon called upon Gov. Hill. He received them in the Executive Chamber. Capt. Palmer, President of the Regimental Association, made a short address to the Governor.

BOSTON, Dec. 20.--The annual catalogue of Harvard University will be published tomorrow. It shows gains in nearly all of the nine departments, the total number of students being 1,899, against 1,612 last year. The number of officers rises to 245 against 228 last year.

PARIS, Dec. 20.--The newspapers commend M. Challemal-Lacour's speech in the Senate yesterday as a masterly effort, although several of them reproach him for striking a blow at the republic by attacking the Radicals. The Journal Des Debats credits him with the courage of his convictions.

LONDON, Dec. 20.--The battle at Suakin has been the solitary topic of conversation to-day, and although the House of Commons to-night cheered to the echo the official announcement of the victory, the general public is not so well pleased by it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--Western and Southwestern freight rates are to be restored Jan. 1. This was the understanding arrived at by the meeting of General Managers of the lines in the territory of the Western Traffic Association yesterday, and official notice was given by all the...

The Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday listened to declarations of former inspectors of masonry on the aqueduct, to the effect that men have been retained as inspectors who passed bad work for the contractors.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 20.--Senator Quay is one of the children of this world who prefer darkness rather than light as far as his political acts are concerned, and he is about the hardest man in the United States for a newspaper man to get any information out of.

MACON, Ga., Dec. 20.--A local paper this morning intimates that the indignity to the flag mentioned in yesterday's dispatch was a joke intended for a local candidate for City Sexton who was defeated for re-election.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--If a printed report from Washington is correct the eye of a Congressman from Egypt has discovered a want in Chicago which was first realized when the dispatch was road.
BOSTON, Dec. 20.--The Congregational Club celebrated Forefathers' Day this evening by a banquet in Music Hall. Nine hundred covers were laid.

FORT BALFORD, Dakota, Dec. 20.--An epidemic has broken out among the principal horse ranches of the Lower Yellowstone. It first made its appearance about three weeks ago and was considered of little importanced, but it has become so dangerous and is spreading with such alarming rapidity that it is causing much anxiety in this section of the country.

The announcement made yesterday that Gilbert and Sullivan's opera, "The Yeomen of the Guard," would be withdrawn from the stage of the Casino on Jan. 14, and that the old favorite, "Nadjy," would take its place, proved somewhat of a surprise to the public at large as...

A dark domestic tragedy has just occurred in a highly-respectable family in Paris. A few weeks ago the hand of a young lady, whose father was a Professor in a college, was asked in marriage by a well-to-do engineer.

An erroneous impression has gone abroad that, because the Coney Island Jookey Club has reduced the value of its purse races from a uniform rate of $1,000 to $600, $750, and $1,000 for the season of 1889, the club has reduced the amount of added money it has hung up next year for competition.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 20.--The breaking of a boom at the Amoskeag gate house, which enabled a large mass of ice to reach the canal, has resulted in the most disastrous jam that ever occurred here.

DETROIT, Dec. 20.--President Angell, of the university, spoke before the Political Science Association last night on "The Recall or Ambassadors from Foreign Courts." He said no Minister has any business to interfere with the domestic relations of the Government to which he is accredited.

For some reason the Brooklyn Park Commissioners have never used the $300,000 given them last Spring for the purchase of sites for small parks in various parts of the city. A committee was appointed to investigate the advisability of the scheme and to select desirable sites.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 20.--The American flint glass schedule for the coming year will remain the same as that in force during the past year. The old scale expired on Dec. 15, at which date any change desired by either workers or manufacturers is required to be presented. Neither asked any modifications, and the old schedule continues in force.
The announcement is made that the Presidential Electors of this State will meet at the Astor House to-morrow afternoon at 1:30 o'clock.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Dec. 20.--Under a decree of the United States court here the Commissioners in Chancery, in the case of the Fidelity Trust Insurance and Safe Deposit Company of Philadelphia, against the Shenandoah Iron Company in Page County, this State, have advertised to sell on Jan. 8 the works and personal property, 33,000 acres of mineral lands, three mansions, and 77 tenant houses.

Some Aldermen left the Aldermanic Chamber in an angry mood yesterday. Their anger was directed against Vice-President Dowling, and they charged him with having violated a rule of the board in a successful attempt to prevent the application of the Harlem Railroad...

"The Sagamore Club of the City of NewYork" was the name adopted by the new club of Harlem Democrats at their meeting last night. Resolutions and by-laws were adopted. One interesting law of the club is that it shall not indorse any nominees for office other than those on the Democratic State and national ticket.
MITCHELL, Dakota, Dec. 20.--A mass convention of South Dakota Damocrats opened here to-day for the purpose of urging the movement for Statehood.

The question that now chiefly agitates the sages of the Republican Party is the question what to do with Mr. BLAINE. It seems to be agreed that it is almost equally impossible to put him into the Cabinet of President HARRISON and to leave him out.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 20.--Scores of American buyers have arrived in Canada to purchase live stock at prices over 75 per cent. lower than during the same time last year.

HELENA, Montana, Dec. 20.--As a result of a suit filed in the Livingston District Clerk's office last Thursday the great mine known as the Cumberland property, the mainspring of the mining camp of Castle, was closed yesterday by the Sheriff. The first attachment filed was by Stebbins Son, bankers, for $29,400.

Everything now points to the successful completion of the new Pennsylvania, Poughkeepsie and Boston, (old South Mountain,) which is intended to connect with the Poughkeepsie Bridge. From the river to Pine Island the work is practically finished, and from there to Deckertown, Sussex...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 20.--The Liberal press of the Dominion has temporarily dropped the annexation question to assail the Hon. George E. Foster, Minister of Finance. They are accusing him of lending five millions, borrowed in England last Summer, to New-York brokers and speculators at 1 per cent. on his bargain.

When the County General Committee of the United Labor Party was in session last evening a member of the Auditing Committee rushed in breathless exclaiming that the Executive Committee had made an effort to gag the Auditing Committee and prevent it from making a full report about the accounts of the campaign.

LONDON, Dec. 20.--A dispatch from Suakin says: "The combined force of British and Egyptians have made an attack upon the rebel position. They stormed the redoubts and trenches, and after a brilliant engagement, lasting half an hour, drove the enemy into the bush.

It is generally believed that if the Commissioners who in 1811, under direction of the Legislature, made the plan of that part of the city of New-York lying north of Fourteenthstreet, could have foreseen the city's growth and present necessities, they would have provided a greater number of thoroughfares north and south on the west side.

The annual Charity Ball, the proceeds from which are to be devoted to the needs of the Nursery and Child's Hospital, will take place on Jan. 8. It will be opened by Mr. Gerry and Mrs. Astor and is expected to be the usual brilliant affair, with the twofold object of social enjoyment and charity.

A letter was sent to Mayor Hewitt several weeks ago inviting him to accept a complimentary banquet from citizens of all political parties and factions and of every profession and trade. It ran as follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 20.--There is no longer any attempt to disguise the fact that there is a very bitter fight now going on between the Knights of Labor and the new National Progressive Union of Miners and Mine Laborers.

The Governor of Vermont has sent to the Committee on the Centennial Celebration of George Washington's Inauguration the names on the following gentlemen, who will act as Commissioners, to see that the State of Vermont is properly represented at the celebration on April 30 next: The Hon. Levi K. Puller, Brattleborough, and Gen. Theodore S. Peck, Burlington.

A special train left Long Island City station at 11:10 yesterday morning having on board Mayor Hewitt, Controller T.W. Myers, and Tax Commissioner Michael Coleman of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment; Commissioners Thomas S. Brennan and Henry H. Porter of the Department of Public Charities and Correction, and Charles V. Adee, Secretary...

The commission which is engaged in the task of revising the excise laws of this State has a perplexing question on its hands. The members present at yesterday's meet ing spent a good deal of time in considering whether any legal sanction should be given...

A large meeting of the Columbian Club and the Tammany Hall General Committee of the Sixth Assembly District was held last evneing at the district headquarters, 518 Grand-street, John C. McDermott in the chair.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 20.--Ossory, 3 years old, full brother to Ormonde, was bought to-day by Milton Young, this county, for $10,000.

An explosion took place just before 1 o'clock yesterday morning at a manhole over the conduit of the Edison Electric Company on the northeast corner of Maiden-lane and Nassua-street, opposite 29 Nassau-street.

The following bids for building an addition to the Brooklyn Reservoir were opened yesterday, by City Works Commissioner Adams: Edward Freel, $293,770; Crawford Valentine, $314,364; A.W. Blaze, $325,575; John H. O' Rourke, $361,420; Charles Hart, $369,230; John McNamee, $374,930, and Thomas McCann, $434,375. The work must be completed in 600 days, and when finished the new reservoir...

CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--Mr. Thomas C. Platt of New-York, who aspires to be Secretary of the Treasury, is reported here to have a slippery memory, but perhaps he will remember the following telegraphic dispatch:

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 20.--Apropos of the new organization of local railway lines it may be stated that during the last wheat blockade in Minneappolis the officers of the local roads, comprising 14 lines, held several meetings to consider plans to facilitate the handling of transfer cars from one road to another and the general management of local yard service.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 20.--Gov. Martin has signed the pardon of Thomas C. Thurston, once a leading attorney of Leavenworth, who was convicted in September, 1880, of assault with attempt to kill Col. D.R. Anthony of Leavenworth, and of an assault on John P. Douglas, and was sentenced to 18 years' imprisonment.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--At the meeting of the East-bound Passenger Committee to-day the scalpers received another blow. It was agreed by all the lines to redeem at their full tariff value any and all tickets that might be purchased for the purpose of testing fares.

The southwest corner of Wall and Broad streets is soon to lose the old buildings which have served as a sort of landmark for many years. Five lots, forming a plot with a frontage of 90 feet on Wall-street and 70 on Broad, have gradually been acquired by Matthew Wilks, owner of the corner building.

The Manhattan Athletic Club enjoyed its second ladies' day and musicale yesterday afternoon at its Fifth-avenue clubhouse. Over a score of vocalists, Instrumentalists, and elocutionists filled out a programme which made the afternoon seem very short to the 400 or more guests who were present.
ISHPEMING, Mich., Dec. 20.--The fire in the Calumet and Hecla mine was extinguished to-day. The mine will be cleared of smoke and gases, and work will be resumed as early as possible.
BOSTON, Dec. 20.--The case of Sarah M. Preble against Bates Walley terminated in the United States Circuit Court to-day when the jury returned a verdict for Mrs. Preble of $34,772 88.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--Receiver McNulta's report of the receipts and disbursements of the Wabash Railway Company for the month of November was issued to-day.

The parents and friends of the scholars in De La Sane Institute were entertained last evening by the students. The programme consisted of vocal and instrumental music, oratorical selections, and gymnastics.

Among those who have called upon Mr. HARRISON in Indianapolis since the election are several persons who appear to be interested deeply in the public lands. They have spoken with great indignation about the "persecution" of honest settlers by the...
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 20.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and Associates present, the following business was transacted:

Chancellor McGill of New-Jersey has granted a rule on Thomas Lyniack of Paterson to show cause next Monday why a Receiver should not be appointed for sundry real estate held by him in that city, partly in trust for his sister and partly in common with her.

ST. THOMAS, West Indies, Dec. 20.--The ship B.P. Cheney of Bath, Me., Capt. Hughes, from Manila for Boston, has put in here with the loss of some sails. The Cheney is of 1,322 tons and was built at Bath in 1874.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20.--The Chamber of Commerce adopted a memorial to Congress to-day denouncing the aggressive action of the German Government in the Samoan Islands as destructive to American interest and cruel to all residents.

Fred Leslie and Nellie Farren of the London Gayety Burlesque Company, made a trip to Philadelphia on Wednesday as the guests of Rudolph Aronson and attended the matinee performacne of "Erminie," returning in time for the performance of "Esmeralda" at the Standard in the evening. Both expressed themselves highly pleased with the opera and the performance of the Casino company.

HEMPSTEAD, Long Island, Dec. 20.--The case of the people against Hubert Gillegan, one of the slippers in the rabbit coursing tourney on Dec. 8 at Hempstead Plains, was resumed at 5 o'clock this afternoon in the Court of Special Sessions before Justice Clowes and a jury of six citizens.

PARIS, Dec. 20.--About 700 holders of bonds and shares in the Panama Canal Company held a meeting to-day and decided to forego for the present the payment of the coupons and the redemption of the shares.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 20.--The Merchants' Bridge and Merchants' Bridge Terminal Company are now assured. Bids have been received from the King Bridge Company of Cleveland, the Union of New-York, and the American.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 20.--The delegation of manufacturers, , from this city who visited Gen. Harrison returned this morning. The Age-Herald to-morrow will public interviews with several of them in regard to the object of their visit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--The following is the official programme for the President's reception on New Year's Day:

Detectives of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company are on the trail of Edgar Y. Harris, the fugitive defaulting ticket agent of the Grand Central Station, and expect to capture him before he spends the whole amount which he is alleged to have pilfered.

Upon the recommendation of District Attorney Fellows, the indictment for murder against William Lord Palmer, Jr., now confined in the State Lunatic Asylum at Utica, was dismissed by Judge Martine yesterday.

For many years there has been a strong sentiment in Paterson in favor of a Government building. Congress at its last session appropriated $80,000 for the purpose, and many poople were glad. Now many of them are not.
The ball of the Junior Class in Columbia College to-night will be given in the college library, which will be decorated with rare flowers and handsome ferns.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--Capt. John S. Loud, Ninth Cavalry, has been relieved from recruiting duty on Jan. 1 and ordered to join his troop; Second Lieut. John J. Pershing, Sixth Cavalry, has been ordered to conduct a detachment of recruits from New-York to the Department of Arizona; Capt. Frank C. Crugan, Second Artillery, has been granted three days' further extension of leave of absence.

At a recent meeting of the Executive Committee of the New-York Civil Service Reform Association several resolutions were adopted that are of special interest at this time. The association, as is well known, is made up of members of each of...
Alonzo T. Harmer, the Treasurer of H.R. Jacobs's new Lyceum Theatre, on Montreseavenue, Williamsburg, has been missing for several days, and yesterday his wife asked the police to search for him.

ALBANY, Dec. 20.--The Hon. James William Husted's eagle eye has pierced the dark cloud that now hangs over the State prisons. That cloud, as is well known, is the compulsory idleness of prison inmates--idle by act of the Legislature.
HAVANA, Dec. 20.--News from Hayti has been recently a difficult thing to get, the blockade and the revolution combining to make communication with the island almost impossible.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Dec. 20.--Concerning the petition presented by Senator Wilson for an investigation into the action of the District Attorny for failing to bring suit against the Sioux City and St. Paul Railroad to recover unearned lands, United States District Attorney Murphy, in an interview to-day, said the case was of great importance. He was working on it, and would bring suit, so that the interests of the people concerned would be well protected.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20.--Cardinal Gibbons has just completed a new literary work entitled "Our Christian Heritage," and to-day handed the manuscript to John Murphy Co., his publishers. It will take a book of about 500 pages and is purely religious in character.

The Kings County Democratic General Committee had one of its old-time fights last night at a special meeting held in Jefferson Hall, at Adams and Willoughby streets, Brooklyn, to consider the ward troubles growing out of the recent primaries. There were protests from the Fifteenth and Nineteenth Wards and from the towns of Gravesend and New-Utrecht.

BOSTON, Dec. 20.--The old Doty Tavern, on Blue Hill-avenue, in Canton, was burned last night. The building was a noted stopping place in revolutionary times. Both Washington and Lafayette dined there, and it is, said that a rough draft, of the Declaration of Independence was prepared under its humble roof.
BERLIN, Dec. 20.--The Emin Relief Committee announce that, after a careful examination of Osman Digna's letter, they have concluded that proof of Emin Pasha's capture has not been established.

Three bold Celestials entered the laundry of Sing Wah, at 265 West Twenty-third-street, yesterday afternoon, determined to rifle the money drawer. Sing Wah, the proprietor, took exception to this proceeding, and in the row which followed he received some ugly neck and face wounds from a knife in the hands of Yom Back Doee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--The partnership between Jacob Schaefer and John Burns, who have been conducting a billiard room in Clarkstreet, near the Grand Pacific Hotel, terminated to-day, Burns retiring. "Dick" Roche of St. Louis will be here Saturday, and it is believed that as a result of his visit Schaefer and he will run the billiard room together.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 20.--The Bell Telephone Company scored another legal victory to-day in the Supreme Court of Missouri, and the city of St. Louis is at present at the mercy of the corporation.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 20.--The break in the Augusta Canal caused by the September overflow of the Savannah River is now repaired and the water was turned on gradually to-day from the river.
The Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby presided yesterday at the meeting of the commission appointed to revise the excise laws. Messrs. Thomann, Smart, Storn, and Kruse were present.

LEWISBURG, Penn., Dec. 20.--Chauncey B. Ripley, LL.D., has informed those who urge upon him the Presidency of Bucknell University, Lewisburg, that he cannot encourage the use of his name as a candidate on account of professional and other engagements.

The funeral of Gen. Charles G. Dahlgren took place yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Second Presbyterian Church, of which he was a member. The Rev. H.J. Van Dyke officiated and made an appropriate address.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 20.--L.R. Sanborn Son of Sanborn, this county, who have been conducting a large lumbar business in Alpena, Mich., have assigned. Their liabilities are placed at $70,000 and the assets at $115,000. This assignment will in no way affect the business at Sanborn. Leo R. Sanborn is a prominent Republican and has represented this district in the Assembly.
The new passenger station of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad at Niagara Falls built to replace the structure burned some months ago, has recently been completed.

BONHAM, Texas, Dec. 20.--Meagre information was received at this place to-night of a tarrible tragedy at Monkstown, in the northern part of this county. The constable had occasion to leave the town yesterday and deputized Charlie Choate to serve during his absence.
HARTFORD, Dec. 20.--The Housatonic Railroad Company was represented by President William H. Starbuck, General Manager Stevenson, Simeon E. Baldwin of New-Haven,...
BELVIDERE, N.J., Dec. 20.--Charles Arnold, son of Justin Arnold, one of the largest land owners and best known men in Warren County, committed suicide yesterday morning in a fit of anger.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 20.--The racing was continued to-day. The weather was clear and cool and the track in good condition.

Sixty-seven examples, comprising the first portion of the paintings belonging to Mrs. B.F. Dawson, were sold last night by John H. Draper, auctioneer, at the Fifth-Avenue Auction Rooms, 240 Fifth-avenue.
Frank A. Pierson of the Sturtevant House was yesterday indicted by the Grand Jury for violating the law relative to fire escapes, in not supplying the rooms in his house with ropes.

The Bottler's Protective Union held a meeting yesterday, at which they said they were determined to put a stop to the illegal sale of their registered bottles by junkmen who sold them to bottlers who never made any of their own. They had the law on their side, and were determined to prevent junkmen from dealing in registered bottles.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--A decision by the Supreme Court of Missouri, holding that the city of St. Louis has no power or authority to regulate telephone charges, as it sought to do by passing an ordinance reducing the yearly rental from $100 to $50, is of great interest here where a similar movement against the telephone monopoly is on foot.
EDINBURGH, Dec. 20.--In the case of Mr. Parnell against the London Times the court today considered the proofs of the validity of the arrestments which had been made by the plaintiff.

DETROIT, Dec. 20.--The differences between "Deacon" White and "Jack" Rowe and the National League are becoming more interesting. White has returned from Buffalo. The main point in the dispute, the "Deacon" says, is whether a club has a legal right to sell a player, and the courts will likely be asked to settle it.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 20.--The bill to punish fraud and corruption at primary elections has been passed by both houses.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--Mitchell and Kilrain, the pugilists, who have been giving an exhibition of sparring in connection with the performance at a north side place of amusement, were yesterday informed by the Chief of Police that they must cease or they would be arrested for violation of the law against that kind of sport.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 20.--In the Supreme Court to-day the injunction cases against the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific and the Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Northern were dismissed.

Such strenuous efforts have been made by Brooklyn Republican papers to prove to the public that there was no truth in the published statements of dissension in the party owing to Franklin Woodruff's candidacy for the Presidency of the General Committee that the rank and file were astonished yesterday to learn...

There could be no doubt in the minds of the large audience assembled at the Brooklyn Academs of Music last evening that the performance of "Billee Taylor" was an "amateur opera." Even though the close likeness to professionalism which existed in the acting, the singing, and the variegated stockings of the...

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20.--William C. Howard, alias "Hungry Joe," the notorious New-York bunko steerer, this afternoon pleaded guilty in the Criminal Court to the charge of swindling William G. Bansemer out of $5,000, and was sentenced to nine years in the penitentiary.

Among the particularly worthy charities of this city is the Post-Graduate Hospital, including the babies' ward. Its third annual report, just published, shows that 382 patients were treated last year in its wards, including 100 babies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--The committee appointed by the representatives of the Colorado lines to prepare a plan of reorganization reported to day. The plan contemplates a separate organization of the roads engaged in ColoradoUtah traffic entirely independent of the Western Freight Association, of which it now forms a part.

It became known at the offices of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad yesterday that General Superintendent Shepard will to-day issue an order discontinuing the Washington night express train.

BOSTON, Dec. 20.--The funeral of Nathaniel J. Bradlee was held at noon to-day from the South Congregational Church and was attended by a large number of those with whom he had been associated. Ex-Mayor Prince, Mayor O'Brien, and Mayor-elect Hart were among those present. The interment was at Mount Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge.
There is a disposition among horsemen in this city to doubt the accuracy of the report from Kentucky that Mr. J.B. Haggin has bought the famous 2-year-old, Proctor Knott, for $30,000.
MEXICO, Dec. 20, via Galveston.--The London, Mexico and South American Bank will establish a branch in San Luis Potosi.

Louis Kersten, the keeper of a grocery groggery on Columbia-avenue, Jersey City Heights, was convicted in Judge Lippincott's court yesterday of having violated that section of the new high license act which forbids the sale of liquor and groceries under the same roof. It is the first conviction achieved under the new law.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 20.--The jury in the United States court to-day, in obedience to instructions from Judge Hammond, returned a verdict of not guilty in the case of James Badinelli, Clark M. Brewer, and Ben Featherstone, charged with frauds at the November election.

The 5-weeks-old daughter of Leopold Ber-- inger of 1,002 Avenue A developed a little cough last Sunday afternoon and Mrs. Beringer went to Dr. George D. Spon's drug store at 972 Firstavenue for some medicine to stop it.
At the meeting of the Republican County Committee, held last night at the Grand Opera House under the Chairmanship of Col. S.V.R. Drugor, Jan. 25 was fixed as the date of the re-enrollment...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 20.--After solemnly taking testimony till late this afternoon counsel in the contest over the codicil to the Christopher Meyer will suddenly announced that all objections to the codicil would be withdrawn. This was the result of a compromise between the parties.

The claim of Mr. Rapallo, the counsel for the elevated railroad, that his clients were only required to pay damages to property caused by the interference with light, air, and access, and were in no measure responsible for decrease in rental values caused by change of occupants, or objectionable...

BOSTON, Dec. 20.--Edward N. Dingley, editor and proprietor of the Kalamazoo (Mich.) Telegraph, and son of Representative Dingley of Maine, was married to-night to Miss Miriam Robinson of Dorchester. Mr. Dingley and bride left immediately for New-York and Philadelphia on a wedding trip.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 20.--The ceremonies of dedicating and transferring the Arnot-Ogden Memorial Hospital, on Roe-avenue, this city, to the Board of Management took place in the main building to-day in the presence of a large number of prominent citizens, as well as Protestant, Catholic, and Jewish clergymen of the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--It was hard work for the Republican Senators to keep from laughing in the faces of their Democratic colleagues when the Senate met to-day, for they were very greatly tickled at the way they had purchased all they wanted of the Democrats...

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 20.--John S. Scott, a prominent and successful agriculturist of Marion County, this State, has been appointed by the Russian Government to go to their territory in Eastern Asia and instruct the inhabitants in cotton growing. A liberal salary is attached to the position, and Mr. Scott is practically his own master in the work he is to undertake.
Chancellor McGill yesterday granted a writ of habeas corpus requiring Mrs. Charles W. Preston to produce a 5-year-old daughter, for whose custody her father is suing in court.
The Directors of the Montreal Telegraph Company are expressing dissatisfcation with the report of Erastus Wiman, President of the Great Northwestern Telegraph Company.

An audience that comfortably filled the large hall of the Cooper Union assembled last evening to give Henry George a reception and a welcome on his return from Great Britain, and to hear what he had to say on the attitude of the people there on the land question.

Charles Leitow, a veteran of the Franco-German war, committed suicide yesterday afternoon in his room in the tenement house 165 Essex-street, by taking concentrated carbolic acid. He had been employed for 10 years as a porter in Crampton Brothers' rice mill at Monroe and Jefferson streets and was discharged three weeks ago. On Tuesday last he had a quarrel with his daughter, and since then has been despondent. He had no money.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Dec. 20.--Arguments in the Royce case closed at 3 P.M. Judge Phelps's charge was brief, clear, and impartial. He said it was not enough to convict that Royce had made false entries, for that he admitted himself, but claimed no fraud.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 20.--The ice in the Hudson Highlands is about three inches thick. The West Shore Railroad ferryboat is still making connections between Cornwall and West Point.

The sale of subscription seats for the Theodore Thomas concerts at Chickering Hall began yesterday morning. The extent of the public interest in the revival of the famous orchestra may be estimated from the fact that the day's sale closed at the remarkably high figure of $2,731.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 21.--Now that the war between the Chicago lines is temporarily settled the lines between St. Paul and the Pacific coast have become involved in a conflict with each other. The first break in the market was caused in Chicago yesterday, when the Northern Pacific Road issued a notice that it would accept second-class ...

DES DOINES, Iowa, Dec. 21.--The Iowa Supreme Court, in the case of the State against certain intoxicating liquors, Cummings, claimant, decided to-day that any liquor containing alcohol, no matter how much it may be diluted, is intoxicating. The court below declared the liquors not intoxicating, and the State appealed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--The president today returned to the Attorney-General the papers in relation of the application for the pardon of Benjamin Hopkins of Ohio, under sentence for embezzling and misapplying the funds of the Fidelity National Bank of Cincinnati, with the ...

PITTSBURG, Dec. 21.--This was a cold, blustery day for the bulls. The bears, with their shaggy coats and squeezing proclivities, rather gave the overexpectant and overloaded bulls the finger, and with a satisfied yell they pushed the price down almost 4 cents before the "Standard supporters" could lock at their hands.

M. Vassili Verestehagin's paintings were to have been taken down at the end of this week and shipped to Chicago, but there have been such throngs to see them that the collection will probably be kept on view one more week. This exhibition will never in all probability be seen again in New-York. M.Verestchagin himself will probably lecture once more before leaving New-York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 21.--The Harvard University Glee Club starts for New-York to-morrow morning. The glee club will be accompanied by the banjo club, and the two organizations given a concert in Chickering Hall on Saturday evening.

Rear Admiral Gherardi, who was requested some time ago by the New-York Board of Trade to express his views on the proposed establishment of a naval reserve, forwarded an answer to Chairman Aaron Vanderbilt yesterday, in which he says:

Charles A. Silliman was appointed a Dock Commissioner by Mayor Hewitt yesterday. He is to serve the remaining four months of the term of Commissioner L.J.N. Stark, who died about six weeks ago. Mr. Silliman was commended to the Mayor by John P. Townsend, ...
SUAKIN, Dec. 21.--The British force passed a quiet night. A few of the enemy's horsemen have been seen in the distance. The men-of-war have been recalled from Handoub.

Mrs. Helena Foclken returned to her home at 261 Stagg-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday from a Christmas shopping tour, and found the dead body of her father, William Zeit, hanging by a bedcord from the transom of the door.

An application was made to the Armery Board yesterday by Col. Michael Cavanagh for a new armory for the Sixty-ninth Regiment. The regiment has long occupied the rooms over Tompkins Market, but they are thought to be inadequate, as the organization has now a very large roll.

A fencing bout and set-to with broads words was held last night at the New-York Athletic Club for the Championship of the club. Prof. Senec officiated as starter, and H.K. Bloodgood, Engene Higgins, and W.T. Lawson as judges. The prizes consisted of a handsome dueling sword, which was won by C.F. O'Connor; a pair of roils, which were awarded to E.M. Hammond, and a pair of broadswords, which were won by A. Gregor.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 21.--The steamer City of Kingston made its last trip of the season of New-York City this afternoon. It left here at 3 o'clock, three hours in advance of the usual time, on account of the heavy ice in the Hudson River.

The men of various ages but with exceedingly youthful proclivities who compose the body of students attending the medical department of the University of the City of New York, and who have assisted in the process of whitening the heads of the Faculty of that institution during the last few days, held another ...

About two years ago the body of an Italian who had evidently been murdered was found in the Passaic River at Newark. A junk dealer known as "Matty Wade," living on Springstreet, Elizabeth, N.J., who has an extensive ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 21.--The propeller Lake Ontario of Windsor, Ontario, was burned at the dock at Charlotte this afternoon. The vessel in said to belong to T.M. Ryan of Buffalo. She was rated at Lloyd's as valued at $11,000, and is a total loss; no insurance.

Chief-Justice Larremore and a jury, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday listened to evidence that bore very heavily on the character of Robert Greenthal, a lawyer. The suit was brought against Greenthal by Samuel J. Blank, committee of the person and estate of James McNeill, who is insance and in the city ...
Rudolph Aronson is about to finish his comic opera "Captain Kydd." He has the music nearly done and is negotiating with George R. Sims to write the libretto.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--The president to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 21.--Burglars broke into two stores at Long Meadow a little village 2 miles out of this city, this morning, and exchanged a number of shots with a young man who pursued them. The men first broke into E.K. Colton's general store by prying open the doors.

The annual meeting of Plymouth Church was held last night, Deacon Henry L. Pratt presiding. The choir, under Walton N. Ellis, was congratulated upon its good work, and the Advisory Committee appointed just after Mr. Beecher's death was discharged.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 21.--Dr. John W. Vanduyn, a leading physician and Health Officer of this city, has made some shocking exposures regarding the treatment of smallpox patients at the city pest house. At a secret meeting of the Board of Health, held last night, ...

The ordinance passed by the Board of Aldermen requiring that all vegetables, fruits, and berries should be sold by weight, and that the weight or contents or every package be plainly marked on the outside, has caused a great deal of excitement among the vegetable receivers and jobbers and also among the Long Island farmers.

William J. Best, the accountant of the Fassett committee, asserts that Thomas Costigan, Supervisor of the City Record, foully slandered him in the course of their controversy the other day over the books and vouchers of the City Record, which Mr. Best is anxious to examine with care.
Mr. HOLMAN of Indiana has introduced in the House of Representatives a bill intended to prevent an improper use of money in elections over which Congress has jurisdiction.

Persons who are devoted to the collection of alleged "old masters," in which there is a certain amount of gambling interest, inasmuch as there is a large proportion of uncertainty attached to them, must have been delighted at the opportunities offered to them yesterday at Silo's auction rooms, 817 Broadway, where the collection belonging to L. Lunghi of Florence was sold.

Scholars attending the evening classes of the Pratt Institute, Ryerson-street, near De Kalb-avenue, Brooklyn, were found hard at work last night by the bands of visitors who made tours of inspection through the school. All kinds of work was going on.

A tall, portly gentleman, of florid countenance, reddish-gray beard, smooth upper lip, and with an aureola of black hair surrounding a smooth, white space on the crown of his head, is the Hon. W.H. Anbrey, the distinguished Liberal of England.
PANAMA, Dec. 21, via Galveston, Texas.-- A "norther" is blowing at Colon and all steamers which were in port have put to sea. A very heavy sea is running.

Judge Wallace in the United States Circuit Court yesterday confirmed the report of Master Samuel H. Blatchford in the case of Hoolis M. Berry, Charles Zabriskie, J. Alfred Davenport, and James Cant against the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company and the Union and Mercantile Trust Companies in all specifications relating to interest due the plaintiffs up to June, 1888.

A meeting of the dry goods auxiliary of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association was held yesterday afternoon in the office of Walter H. Lewis of Lewis Brothers, 86 Worth-street, at which steps were taken for a thorough canvass of the dry goods trade.
"The Panama Canal as it is" was the subject of an illustrated lecture delivered at Chickering Hall last night by Dr. Wolfred Nelson.

A valuable lot of blooded fox terriers from the Tranquillity Kennels at Allemucky, Warren County, N.J., owned by Messrs. L. and W. Rutherford, the Liberty-street real estate dealers, were sold at auction at the American Horse Exchange, this city, yesterday afternoon.

"Apple" Mary Doran, who for many years has sold apples, candy, and sandwiches in the Court of General Sessions, was taken into custody yesterday afternoon by Capt. Curry and hurried into Part II., where Judge Gildersleeve was holding court. She looked terribly frightened and grew more so when Clerk Moser called out: "Mary to the bar."

CHARLESTON, S.C. Dec. 21.--The NewEngland Society of Charleston will celebrate Forefathers' Day by banquet to-morrow night. Congressman W.C.P. Breckinridge will respond to the "Pilgrim Fathers" toast and Assistant Secretary of Treasury Thompson will ...

Since the smashing of the window of the jewelry store at Twenty-second-street and Broadway and the theft of a $4,500 diamond necklace, the jewelers in that neighborhood have been regarding the crowds which assemble nightly about their windows with more or less anxiety. A jeweler at Twenty-ninth-street and Broadway the other night employed a negro, dressed him up in a Seventh Regiment uniform, made him shoulder a rifle, and ...

While the Board of Estimate and Apportionment was considering yesterday the estimates of the expenses of the Fire Department next year Mayor Hewitt said: "I am not in favor of adding to the force of firemen unless the public safety absolutely requires an addition. The whole force was used as a political machine in the last election."

There was something old-fashioned and tonic in the way the stock market boomed yesterday. There were few favorites. Everything soared. It was a great day for men of faith. Profits were scored in the handsomest sort of fashion. It seemed a downright cruelty to close the Stock Exchange, the financial landscope was so altogether beautiful and exhilarating to gaze upon.

One of the ways which the National Prohibition Bureau hopes to advance its cause is through the education of the youth by means of elocutionary contests. A contest was held last evening in the large hall of the Cooper Union.
BERLIN, Dec. 21.--The Emperor will open the Prussian Landtag on Jan. 19.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 21.--Yesterday morning, near Montevallo, in this State, a young white girl, daughter of a farmer by the name of Shelby Cushcutt, was riding along the road, when suddenly a negro boy stepped out from the roadside with a gun on his shoulder.

PARIS, Dec. 21.--A dinner was given at the National Club this evening in honor of Mr. McLane, the American Minister. Among those present were MM. Le Royer, Cochery, Founcher de Carell, Peyrat, Lafayette, and Bartholdi, Mr. Blanchard, Secretary of the American Committee ...

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 21.--The trust in jute cotton bagging has made that article very unpopular with planters, and when the Acme Manufacturing Company of Wilmington, N.C., so far perfected its machinery as to make a superior article of bagging from the pine needles ...

The question of the future of the rifle range at Creedmoor has been revived by a recent discussion among the managers of the National Rifle Association upon the bill prepared by them for turning over their property to the State.

Willis S. Hill, pilot of a tugboat, was convicted in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday for throwing garbage into the East River. The evidence against him was furnished by Policeman King of the Twenty-fourth Precinct, who July 24 last, saw Hill tow a scow, which contained dirt, along the East River. When he started from Seventy-sixth-street the scow was filled with dirt, but it was empty when it reached the foot of Thirtyninth-street.

For all that is dainty, exquisite, and sweet-scented, let the Christmas shopper go to the Woman's Exchange. Until after the holidays he can go by night as well as by day. He will find there everything to gladden the heart of a child, to please a fastidious woman, and to make himself comfortable.

Charles I. De Baun, who ran away to Canada after robbing the National Park Bank of which he was Acting Cashier, of $95,000, ar rived back in this city yesterday in charge of Detectives Sheldon and Heard, who brought him from Sherbrooke, Canada. His crime be came public May 1, and he was then across the ...

Among the paragraphs in the Senate Tariff bill concerning which very little was said in the recent debate is the one relating to the duty on steel rails. The duty now is $17 a ton; the Senate bill would make it $15.68.

William Jackson and his wife, colored, who live in Bayonne, N.J., were arrested yesterday in that city for cruelty to their 5-year-old son. When they went to their work yesterday morning they ting the other end to a rafter, left the lad hanging so that only his toes touched the floor.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21.--Max Goldberger was to-night convicted of murder in the second degree. The jury were out just an hoar and a half. The verdict was a surprise to every one in view of the evidence and the law, as it was the general opinion that it would be murder in the first degree.

The boys of Grammar School No. 3 had a high old time yesterday. It was the last day of school until after the holidays. Vocal and instrumental music and recitations delighted the numerous guests, but the boys all the while appeared somewhat preoccupied.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 21.--The Independance Belge announces that President and Mrs. Cleveland will visit Europe soon after the expiration of Mr. Cleveland's term of office, and that they will remain for some time in this city.

The Aqueduct Commission resumed yesterday its hearing relative to the proposed construction of the Quaker Bridge Dam. Gen. James C. Duane presided, and Commissioners F.M. Scott, J.J. Tucker, and Walter Howe were present, Judge James C. Spencer and Gen. Henry E. Tremain appeared for the Taxpayers'
Steamship Tyrain, (Br.,) Haig, Kingston, Jam., , 6 ds., with fruit, , to order--vessel to Henderson Bros.

"Johnny" Irving, an old-time safe burglar and bank robber, was before the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday under the name of George Mason on a charge of entering New's grocery at 870 Jackson-avenue, Long Island City, last October, blowing open the safe, and stealing its contents.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 21.--An important experiment was successfully made at the Naval Academy proving grounds to-day. A steelpointed iron projectile weighing 250 pounds was fired from one of the new stoel breechloading ritled guns of the new cruiser Chicago, which penetrated a steel target 10 inches thick and out through a solid oak back. The experiment is considered as likely to have an important bearing on modern naval warfare.

The news in regard to Hayti which was most talked of among merchants yesterday was the report which came from France that the Government of legitime had been ignored by the French administration. This news came in the form of cable dispatches to a mercantile firm doing business with Hayti.
BOSTON, Dec. 21.--A case of kleptomania has come to light in this city and additional interest is added by the fact that the culprit is the wife of a well-known and wealthy Back Bay minister.

Importers of hat trimmings were cheered yesterday by a letter sent to Collector Magone by Assistant Secretary Maynard of the Treasury Department, directing that the new rate of duty of 50 per cent. be not applied to invoices of hat trimmings entered at this port before Jan. 1, unless the Collector perceives some valid objection to such a course.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 21.--The famous Purcell failure case that has been in the courts a number of years has received the attention of the Supreme Court, which to-day handed down the following decision.

The most unsatisfactory performance of Wagner's noble music drama, "Siegfried," ever given at the Metropolitan Opera House was hat of last evening. Herr Alvary was the here, as heretofore, but his voice showed signs of wear, and before the evening was over he sang with considerable effort and a poor quality ...

Beginning on Wednesday next a conference will be held in this city between committees representing the Presbyterians of the North and South with a view to bringing about co-operation and possibly an organic union between the two churches of substantially the same faith and order in these several latitudes. The sessions will be held in the Presbyterian House at 53 Fifth-avenue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--The report that Mr. Haggin was negotiating for the purchase of Sam Bryant's famous gelding, Proctor Knott, naturally attracted considerable attention when it was promulgated early in the week, and for ...

The Tammany Hall General Committee last night approved the resolution of the Committee on Organization to change the date of the primaries for the election of the delegates to the General Committee of 1889 from Dec. 28 to Dec. 29, because the special election in the Sixth Senate District takes place on the former date.

The work of laying the conduit for the North and East River Electric Railway Company on Fulton-street was begun at 6 o'clock Thursday night. Two lines of iron conduit are required to carry the copper bands which supply the motive power for the cars.

The New-England Society will hold its annual banquet at Delmonico's to-night at 6:30 o'clock. The two upper floors will be devoted to the use of the society and its guests. Arrangements have been made for accommodating 425 people.

The New-England Society in the city of Brooklyn held its ninth annual banquet at the Academy of Music Assembly Rooms, Brooklyn, last night. The hall was handsomely decorated with a profusion of national flags draped between and about the coats-of-arms of all the States of the Union.

ALBANY, Dec. 21.--Ralph Brandreth, Edward B. Sherwood, S. Olin Washburn, Edwin T. James, Joseph Thompson, B. Stuyvesant Gibson, Francis Larkin, Jr., Charles Schsde, and Isaac B. Noxon are Trustees of the Sing Sing Yacht Club, which is a body corporate under the laws of the State, having filed a certificate of incorporation.

Chairman Daniel G. Rollins and ex-Attorney-General Dents O'Brien were again absent from the meeting of the Excise Laws Revision Commission yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby presided, and the first business considered was the question of Sunday selling.

NEW-ORELEANS, Dec. 21.--In 1881 C.P. Huntingdon, representing a controlling interest in a number of railroads in Louisiana, Texas, New-Mexico, Arizona, and California, entered into an agreement with Jay Gould, who then controlled a number of railroads in Louisiana, Missiseippi, and other States.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--The monotony on 'Change was broken to-day by a little excitement over a ballot vote on two propositions. One was to adjourn the board from Saturday at 1:15 to Wednesday morning. The grain receivers fought the adjournment fiercely.

ALBANY, Dec. 21.--William Barnes, Jr., to-night closed negotiations by which he becomes sole owner of the morning Express. The consideration is said to have been $25,000. Mr. Barnes is a grandson of the late Thurlow Weed and son of ex-Superintendent of Insurance William Barnes.

The Junior Class of Columbia College proved last night that social matters at the college are not of small consequence. The ball, given in the library, was a grand success in every way. All day long tickets had been selling at a premium, and numbers were unable to ...

Barney Doonan, 9 years old, of 400 Madisonstreet, was run over by car No. 22 of the Grandstreet line at the corner of Lewis and Grand streets last night. He was removed to the Gouvernour. Street Hospital, where it was discovered that he had sustained a broken leg. The surgeons believe that it will be necessary to have the injured limb amputated.

The Board of Managers of the German Evangelical Alliance, composed of representatives of Protestant German denominations in this city and vicinity, held a meeting yesterday afternoon at the rooms of the German branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 142 Second-avenue, to organize and arrange for the incorporation of the association. About 30 members were present.

Mayor Hewitt was not present at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Electrical Control, which first went into executive session to consider the draft of its annual report to the Legislature. The Commissioners, when they emerged from their private session, resolved to hold their next meeting in the Mayor's office after Jan. 1.

Beginning on Monday next, the street cars on the Greene and Gates avenues line, Brooklyn, will be run half hourly after midnight. They will connect withe the Fulton Ferry boats and the bridge trains leaving this city at 12 o'clock and every 30 minutes thereafter. This will be a great convenience to those living in upper Brooklyn.

LONDON, Dec. 21.--The body of a woman whose name is unknown was found yesterday morning in the streets of Poplar, in the suburbs of London. An empty vial was at the side of the body, and the impression first formed was that the woman had committed suicide. At the Coroner's inquest to-day, however, the physicians ...
TUCSON, Arizona, Dec. 21.--At Fort Grant Corp. William Wellington, of Troop G. Tenth United States Cavalry, yesterday shot and mortally wounded Sergt. James Logan.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 21.--The body of S.J. Hughes of the United States Coast Survey, who fell overboard from the steamer T.J. Potter two weeks ago, two miles out from Olympia, Puget Sound, was recovered to-day in the Narrows, 30 miles from the scene of the accident.

ANNAPOLIS, Dec. 21.--The fourth lecture of the course on the ram as a naval weapon was delivered to-night before the Naval Institute by Commander Harrington. The lecture consisted of a full discussion of the manoeuvres of a rain opposed to a ship armed with guns and torpedoes, with drawings illustrating the various movements.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 21.--The Congressional Immigration Investigation Committee began its session here to-day. The committee was represented by Congressman M.H. Ferd of Michigan, Chairman of the committee, and Congressman Richard Guenther of Wisconsin.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 21.--In the Supreme Court in Equity this morning, before Judge Field, the hearing on the demurrer in the wellknown case of the Board of Visitors against the Trustees of Phillips Acadomy, Andover, was begun.

PARIS, Dec. 21.--A meeting of the National Republican Association was held to-day. M. Rouvier presiding. In a speech M. Rouvier combated the dissolution and revision programme and appealed to those engaged in commerce and industry to reject such utopian chimeras.

The second public rehearsal of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society took place in the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. The audience was considerably larger than that which attended the first rehearsal, and by its attention manifested a commendable amount of interest in the proceedings.

The attendance last night at the Fifth-Avenue Auction Rooms at the sale of the balance of the paintings comprising the Dawson collection was not so large as on Thursday night, and the prices, notwithstanding that several examples of rare merit, including a marine by Arthur Quartley and a group of cattle by Schouter were offored, were correspondingly low.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--Senator Sherman was this evening serenaded at his home on Franklin-square by the recently-organized "John Sherman Republican League (colored) of the District of Columbia." An address on behalf of the league was read and presented by its President thanking the Senator for his great and unremitting services on behalf of the colored race.

The feather workers' union held a special meeting in the large meeting room at the Cooper Union last night and further arranged their scale of prices. The manufacturers will be requested between now and Jan. 1 to adopt the new scale before Jan. 15, and a meeting will be held at the Cooper Union Jan. 3, to hear reports of the manufacturer's decision.

LONDON, Dec. 21.--An official order is published instructing the British consul at Zanzibar to issue regulations for the government of British subjects there and empowering the Consul to punish violations thereof by fines or imprisonment.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 21.--When the Court of Appeals opened this morning the following minute was directed to be entered:

For some time past there has been much discontent among the patrons of the Morris and Essex Division of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, and the trains have resounded with bitter complaints against the overcrowding and generally had management of the Hoboken ferryboats, running from the foot of Barclay-street, Several communications ...

WARSAW, N.Y., Dec. 21.--There is a blizzard here to-day. A heavy fall of light snow is being blown hither and thither by a wind which shows considerable energy. The farmers from the hills say it is blocking up the roads badly.

Mr. John Allen, proprietor of the Hotel Hamilton, at Eighth-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, intrusted to C.C. Duff, an auctioneer, who has an office at 23 Parkrow and sales stables in West Eighteenth-street, two horeses to be sold. The horses disappeared and Duff could not explain their disappearance. After a long search Mr. Allen found one. The other, valued at $175, has not yet been recaptured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--Capt. David A. Lyle, Ordnance Department, has been ordered to temporary duty at Providence, R.I. Second Lieut. S. M. Foote, Fourth Artillery, has been ordered to duty at the Artillery School, Fortress Monroe, Va. capt. John S. Loud, Ninth Cavalry, has been granted four months' leave of absence.

ALBANY, Dec. 21.--The Society of American Etchers has been incorporated. Its principal office is in New-York. The object is the advancement and promotion of the art of etching and engraving. The Directors are Thomas Moran, Charles Y. Turner, Frederick Dielman, James C. Nicoll, Henry Farrer, Hamilton Hamilton, and William Sartain.
The lower classes of the academic and scientific departments of Columbia College celebrated their release from studies for the present year yesterday by cane rushes on the campus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--H.A. Glidden, an agent of the Treasury Department at the seal islands of St. Paul and St. George from 1882 to 1885, was called to-day as a witness by the House Committe on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries, investigating the alleged outrages in Alaska.

LONDON, Dec. 21.--Mr. Rowntree asked Mr. Raikes, the Postmaster-General, in the House of Commons to-day if the Government would arrange to extend the parcels post system to the service with America. Mr. Raikes said that with the exception of the United ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 21.--Senator George Erwin and Senator Commodore P. Vedder called upon Gen. Harrison to-day, boomed Mr. Platt, and left on an afternoon train in a demoralized condition. Something opened Gen. Harrison's mouth to-day as it has not been opened since election.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21.--The large four-story building, corner of Berks and Palethorp streets, was destroyed by fire this evening.
