It was owned by Charles Ashoff, manufacturer of saddles and loom harness, who occupied the first floor and a portion of the fourth floor for storage of his material and manufactured goods.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 21.--A strange incident happened on the Brunswick and Western Road last night. As the south-bound freight train pulled up at Aliapaha the engineer and firemen were suddenly startled by the sound of a voice close to the engine calling them to get off.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 22.--After midnight this morning the large six-story picture frame and molding factory of L.A. Strobel Co., on the southeast corner of Elm and Canal streets, took fire.

WILLIAMANTIC, Conn., Dec. 21.--The jury in the case of Henry F. Royce, ex-Treasurer of the Williamantic Savings Institute, who was charged with falsifying his accounts to cover defalcations, failed to agree on a verdict. They stood 6 to 6.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--The General Managers of the lines in the territory of the Western States Passenger Association met again to-day, and spent the entire day in considering ways and means of reforming the methods of conducting passenger traffic.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--Importing Austrian kreutzers and palming them off as one-cent pieces may not be a rapid way of making a fortune, though there is 100 per cent, profit in the business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--The President to-day transmitted to both houses of Congress, in accordance with the promise contained in his annual message, a communication from the Secretary of State, inclosing correspondence relating to affairs in Samoa, covering the period ...

At the Tammany Hall convention in the Sixth Senate District, which is to be held tonight at 518 Grand-street, Thomas F. Grady will be nominated for Senator, to serve the unexpired year of the term for which County Clerk-elect Reilly was chosen in 1887. So far as the individual preferences of the delegates to the convention are concerned, those delegates ...

Ben Asuli, the Arab whose alleged wrongful imprisonment by the clerk of W. Reed Lowis, United States Consul at Tangier, Morocco, has already been much spoken of by the press, arrived yesterday in the steamer Australia from Gibraltar.

An important meeting of the managers of Western railroads was held in this city yesterday. The Presidents of nearly every road west of Chicago were either present or represented. Representatives, too, of the biggest Wall-street banking houses, including Drexel, Morgan Co., Kidder, Peabody Co., and Brown Brothers Co., were also present.

Henry Carlton, who killed Policeman James Brennan at Thirty-third-street and Thirdavenue Oct. 28, was sentenced to be hanged Feb. 13, by Judge Martine, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 21.--The steamship Amalfi, (Ger.,) capt. Kraeft, at Hamburg from New-York, went aground.

The committee of clergymen who have in charge the preparations for the religious services to be held April 30, 1889, in commomoration of those that were held in this city when George Washington was inducted into the Presidency of the United States on April 30, 1789, met yesterday ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21.--An officer of the Reading Railroad Company said to-day that President Corbin and Mayor Fitler have agreed upon terms which. If approved by Councils, will enable the Terminal Company to build the elevated road to Twelfth and Market streets.

HARRISBURG, Dec. 22.--Near the backwoods village of Tannersville there is a long and very steep hill in the road. It has a sharp bend in it about half-way down. On the outer curve the bank is quite high. At the foot of that bank a field stretches away in a gradual slope for probably 100 yards, when it drops suddenly to an incline of 45 degrees.

ALBANY, Dec. 22.--Edward Gallagher, a machinist, who lived above the Boulevard, on Westernavenue, was found frozen to death by his sons this morning 500 feet from his house. He was 51 years of age, and leaves a widow and eight children.

Parker, the Grand Marshal, has been remarkably active. DETROIT, Dec. 22.--The annual report of the Labor Commission is devoted largely to an elaborate showing of the condition of labor in the copper mines of Lake Superior, where 5,500 men are employed. Four-fifths of these are foreign born, one-half are married, and oneseventh own their own homes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22.--Two bodies that should have been buried years ago have been found in a San Francisco undertaking establishment. One is that of Mrs. Helen E. Luther, who died in 1881, and whose body has ever since remained in a casket at Cowan Porter's place on Geary-street.
The Brooklyn Park Commissioners held a special meeting last night and appointed Henry D. Styles to succeed John Hamilton as Supertendent of Prospect Park.

A certified check for $5,000 was deposited in the Clipper office yesterday with an acceptance of John L. Sullivan's challenge to "Jake" Kilrain to fight for $10,000 a side and the heavy-weight championship of the world.

MENOMINEE, Mich., Dec. 22.--News has reached here of the total destruction by fire of the town of Hermansville, 47 miles north of here, on the Chicago and Northwestern and the Seo Short Line Railroad. No particulars have been received. Hermansville is a lumbering settlement with a population of about 400, and as the weather is very cold, there must be great suffering among the people.

CHATTANOOGA, Dec. 22.--Last evening five men attempted to cross the Tennessee River in a yawl below Dayton at a dangerous place. One remarked as a joke, "We are gone." Moses Houlston, affrighted, jumped into the stream, which is very rapid, and was not seen again. A searching party worked all day, but failed to find the body.

Those who keep a rosary of days need no reminder that Monday, Dec. 17, is the eightyfirst birthday of John G. Whittier. I was glad to find that time had dealt so kindly with him, for a growing deafness is the only infirmity of his fourscore years.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Dec. 22.--While at a shooting match at Shaffersville this afternoon Danre Goodman, one of the contestants, was accidentally shot and almost instantly killed by Jacob Isett, who was getting ready to shoot. BENNINGTON, Vt., Dec. 22.--John Keenan and James Gunshannon, who have been on trial here for murder, were to-day found guilty of murder in the first degree. LONDON, Dec. 22.--In relation to complaints of the inferior quality of the bayonets used by the troops at Sunkin, Wilkinson Son, the arms manufacturers who furnished the weap ons, explain that they are unable to make bayonets in England now, owing partly to their inability to secure skilled workmen and partly to the incompletion of then new factory, work on which is being pushed forward.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22.--Chairman Blanchard of the Central Traffic Association is on his way home from Europe, sailing to-day from Liverpool on the steamship Umbria.

The meeting of the stockholders of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad Company which was arranged for yesterday has been postponed for 30 days, when it will be held at Knoxville, Tenn., to act upon the plan to lease the East Tennessee lines to the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company.

HARTFORD, Dec. 22.--An effort will soon be made by the friends of James M. Meech and Charles Webb, the Norwich bank culprits who are now serving a five years' term in the Connecticut State Prison at Wethersfield, to secure their pardon from the Government.
WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 22.--"Pawnee Bill" arrived to-day from Philadelphia to take charge of and head an immense Oklahoma invasion.
Congressman Henry Cabot Lodge of Boston was the guest at a breakfast given by Gen. Stewart L. Woodford at the Hamilton Club, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 22.--Judge Conrad decided to-day that liquors shipped into Iowa in packages the contents of which are not stated on the outside are not subject to seizure under the State law until they are delivered to the consignee by the common carrier in charge. This is a point not heretofore passed upon and will result in greatly increasing the package business with the express companies.

The announcement was made some time ago by a military writer that grave fears were being expressed in Belgian military circles that in the event of a war between France and Germany the neutrality of Belgium would not be recognized. This announcement, coming as it did from an observer on the Continent, made public a fact which military observers the world over have been considering in their study ...

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 23.--Sheriff John G. Crane, wife, and son Walter, aged 10 years, went driving this afternoon. At a bluff about 30 feet high on the United States Government farm on Severn River the horse stopped and staggered as if about to fall.

LONDON, Dec. 24.--The Daily Telegraph's correspondent at Suakin says: "I am assured that the Khadive's letter to Emin Pasha, a copy of which Osman Digna sent to Gen. Grenfell, was positively a state secret, and that no copy ever left Cairo. The news of Stanley's return to the Aruwhimi is not considered here as necessarily conflicting with the report of the capture of Emin.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Dec. 23.--Col. J.A. Mitchell, a citizen of Wahalak, Miss., reached this city to-day, and on being asked about the riot there he said: "Wahalak is the quietest place you ever saw.

It does look to us like an unreasonable thing and an outrage for an outside crowd to enter a car or for those on board of it to compel any inoffensive and decently-behaved person to vacate his seat, which his ticket entitled him to.

Signor Perugini and four others of the Clara Louise Kellogg-Strakosch opera company arrived in the city yesterday, having seceded from that organization on account of the tardiness with which financial settlements have been made. It is understood, however, that Miss Kellogg and her manager, who is also her husband, will continue to fill their engagements.

Ellen Thomas, the negress who was shot Saturday night at 144 West Thirtieth-street by her husband, Joseph Thomas, who claimed that he found her with William Tilman and vindicated his honor by shooting both of them, died yesterday afternoon in the New-York Hospital.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 23.--Passenger train No. 20 was wrecked at 6:30 this morning on the western and Atlantic Road, 11 miles from the city. The cause was supposed to be a misplaced rail, the work of train wreckers.

The popular comedian, Nat. C. Goodwin, who will preside at the Christmas table of Niblo's this week, is a native of Boston. He says he has turned handsprings on about every square lot in that city and knows intimately every twig, stone, and tree on the "Common". As a youngster he was as full of "Old Nick" as...

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 23.--A.A. Freeman of La Crosse, now loader of the new movement for the foundation of a Flour Trust, is charged by grain men here with having, in his elevators on the Hastings and Dakota Road, paid relatively higher for wheat than even Minneapolis prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23.--The State Department has no knowledge of what Canada proposes to do with the modus vivendi now in force between the United States and the Dominion, and since the rejection of the fisheries troaty by the Senate last Summer no communication relative to the fisheries has passed between...

Frank Smith and Thomas Ryan, young men, entered the hallway of 319 Broadway at noon yesterday. Adjoining the hallway is the saloon of Louis Brendt, who gas buried on Friday. The saloon was closed and unoccupied.

The attempt to renew the unpopular and much-hated trust by the polite word association to ingenious, but will hardly prove effective in making the Sugar Trust sweeter to swallow or the general trust schemes more popular.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 23.--If the Legislature grants Milwaukee the privilege of raising by direct tax the amount necessary to defray the expenses of the National Encampment of the Grand Army next Summer, and such a tax is imposed, it will not be without a pretty strong protest from many property holders.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 23.--A fatal collision occurred early this morning on the Erie Railroad, near the Neversink Bridge, at Port Jervis.

LODNON, Dec. 23.--Sir Francis De Winton estimates that it will be at least another fortnight before the reception of news from Stanley himself via the Congo. Sir Francis believes that Stanley will return to Zanzibar either by Wadelai, occupying nine months, or via Ujiji, occupying from five to seven months.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 23.--At 11 o'clock this morning the body of Capt. Charles L. Ditsch was found lying on the grave of his daughter in the Union Cemetery, south of this city. The entire upper portion of the skull was blown off and the brains were scattered over the grass.

A little more than two weeks ago the Hon. PRESTON B. PLUMB of Kansas enlivened the tariff debate in the Senate by making a forcible protest against the re-- tension of high duties for the enrichment of combined manufacturers at the expense of the people.

Judge David McAdam went to Clarendon Hall yesterday afternoon to make one of his felicitous speeches to 600 newsboys, who had been invited to a mixed entertainment by the management of the Markstein Sunday concerts for working girls.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23.--The oceanic steamer Zealandia arrived here late last night from Sydney and Auckland, via Samoan Islands and Honolulu. The special correspondent of the Associated Prees at Apia, Samoa, writes as follows, under date of Dec. 7:

Daniel A. Rudd, editor of the Catholic Tribune of Cincinnati, the only Catholic paper for colored people in this country, addressed a meeting in St. Benedict's Church, Bleeckerstreet, last night, called for the purpose of choosing delegates to the convention of colored Catholics to be held in Washington Jan. 1.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the delegates from the Brushmakers' Union said that William Martin, the brush manufacturer, had compelled his men to march in the Republican parade, and had declared himself as one of the champions for the protection of the American workingman.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 23.--William Crossley, an engineer at the Solvay Process Company's works, shot and killed his wife at 10 o'clock to-night, and then blew out his own brains with a revolver. Crossley lived about an hour. He and his wife had lived apart for six months of their year of married life. The murder and suicide were the result of domestic infelicity.

Lord Sydney visited the Queen at Windsor last week, when, I hear, he submitted to her Malesty a precis of his scheme for reducing the expenses of the royal household, of which I gave a sketch on Nov. 8.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 23.--The William H. Whittaker three-story brick building on the corner of the Bowery and Furnace-street this city, was destroyed by fire at about 2 o'clock this mornidg.

The mother of Major-Gen. O.O. Howard, of the army, of Gen. Charles H. Howard, and of Rev. Rowland B. Howard, Boston died at the home of her son Charles, in Glencoo, near Chicago, Friday morning of last week. She had just passed her eighty-fourth birthday.

A somewhat peculiar case was tried before Judge Sherman in the Superior CivilCourt at Dedham during the past week. William H. Doble, a grocer, was arraigned on the complaint of Henry H. Faxon for violating the liquer law, the offense specially charged being the sale of Jumaica ginger as an intoxicant.

The sensational 3-year-old race of the year, one which is destined to throw all others into the shade, is the Realization Stakes of the Coney Island Jockey Club to be raced for next June. Assuming that there will be but 10 starters in it, and that number is certainly a small lot for so rich a stake, it will be worth...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23.--The biggest Chirstmas gift that will be made in this city is the present that Adam Forepaugh is going to send the Zoological Garden. Bolivar, the largest elephant in captivity, will not in future be a feature of the Forepaugh show.

PARIS, Dec. 8.--The author of "Tragaldabas" and of "Jean Baudry" has given a new play called "Jealousy" Go the Gymnase Theatre, and, in spite of much respectful esteem, the result has been lamentable. The subject was intended by the author to be a very grave one.

Mrs. Lillie Devereux Blake held forth on woman's rights and wrongs, as is her custom, at Mott Memorial Hall, 64 Madison-avenue, last evening. She asked her audience to rejoice with her over the revolution caused by the fair sex in Boston's Municipal Government, and continued:

ROME, Dec. 23.--Cardinal Lavigerie made an address on the slavery question in the Gesu Church to-day. He said that a general expression of public opinion was needed to force European Governments to take action in the matter. The Mussulmen Princes must be compelled to fulfill their engagements. It was im possibel to expect the abolition of domestic slavery, but the traffic in slaves must be suppressed.
The riot at Birmingham, United States, during which the Sheriff turned a Gatling gun on the mob, is sure to be used to point a moral over here.

George Carroll, who keeps at 129 West Twenty-fifth-street a place where negroes and white men and women resort, refused to trust some of his customers a few days ago and they threatened to wreck his bar. At 4 o'clock yesterday morning nine colored men and a white woman were carrying out the threat, and when Carroll interfered he was struck on the head with a billiard cue.

The Christmas welcome of the Brothers of La Salle Academy was an event in Academy Hall, on Second-street, yesterday afternoon, that interested more persons than could be comfortably accommodated. The hall was elaborately and tastefully decorated with evergreens, holly, and banners.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 23.--The steamer Kate Adams, the fastest and finest boat of her type on the Mississippi, was burned to the water's edge this morning near the little town of Commerce, which is 40 miles south of this city. Twenty-three persons, a great majority of them colored, were drowned or died from exposure.
The Cadet Corps of the First Battery of Artillery gave its second annual ball and review lest evening at the armory 344 West Forty-fourth-street.

The cocoanut schooner Frederika Schepp, in regard to whose safety there had been much doubt, arrived at this port yesterday after a very stormy voyage, but with no serious damage to report. The Schepp left San Andreas, on the Mosquito Coast, Nov. 27.

A map of the old subdivisions of Sweden is prefixed to this handsome work on the antiquities of that land, which includes the northern part of Denmark as well. Its chief value, however, lies in the illustrations, of which there are no fewer than 205, giving, as they do, a very considerable...

MENOMINEE, Mich., Dec. 23.--The town of Hermansville, in the Upper Peninsula, 47 miles north of here, has been entirely destroyed by fire. Hermansville is a lumbering settlement at the crossing of the Menominee Division of the Chicago and Northwestern and the Sault...

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 23.--Old Mrs. Madden, a centenarian, who lived with her aged husband in a tiny cottage at Wilbur, which is a part of Kingston City, met with a horrible and sudden death this morning.

A Wyoming jury has found a verdict in favor of a Territorial pioneer who sold an Eastern capitalist a ranch and a bunch of cattle said to number 2,500, only 1,300 of which could be found on the round-up. The verdict indorses the "book-account" system of determining the number of cattle on a range without tallying.

The big express companies opened their down-town offices yesterday for the benefit of belated Christmas purchasers. They did a larger business than was expected. From up town as far as Seventieth-street anxious present givers rushed down to lower Broadway in order that their packages might reach their friends in time.
Ex-Congressman H.G. Burleigh of Whitehall tells a good story of Harrison, which goes to show that the President-elect is not so much of an iceberg as he had been painted.

The price of cremation, notwithstanding the cold weather, has been reduced at the Cholten Hill Crematory to $28 per body. That is the present market value of one share of stock. One share of stock is accepted in exchange for one cremation.

Late in August last John L. Reybert, a seafaring man whose home was in Sumter County, Fla., was taken ill while in Brooklyn and went to the Marine Hospital on Staten Island for treatment, and died there.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 23.--The Journal will announce to-morrow that Gen. Harrison will receive no callers during the holiday week. This is understood to mean that he has had enough advice for the present and will go to work in earnest on a Cabinet and a policy for his inaugural address.

SARANAC LAKE, Dec. 23.--The past week has been very enjoyable. The heavy fall of snow on Tuesday has given the best sleighing of the season. The event of the week has been the opening on Friday of the new toboggan slide from in front of the Ampersand.

Chief Templar J.B. Jackson conducted a large temperance meeting yesterday at the Masonic Temple, corner Sixth-avenue and Twenty-thirdstreet, under the auspices of the County Lodge of Good Templars, Metropolitan Temperance Society.
NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 23.--The story of an alleged body snatching and the reported resurrection of a body in the Lantern Hill district of New-London County is now said to be a eanard.

Capt. Leonard G. Sheppard and Capt. Michael Healy of the United States Revenue Marine arrived in this city yesterday from San Francisco, on route 40 Washington. These officers have been ordered to appear at department headquarters for the purpose of giving their views to the board lately convened...

ST. PAUL, Dec. 23.--Living at Clifton Hotel, St. Paul, is an individual six feet in height, and 200 pounds avoirdupois, who goes by the name of Prof. d'Henzel. Just now he is in a state of terror, and from all accounts has good reason to be.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Dec. 23.--The low temperature of the past 60 hours has caused ice to form rapidly in the Hudson River. The ferry here and the ferries at Poughkeepsie, Highland, Fishkill Landing, and Newburg are still running.
Among the guests of the New-England Society at its annual dinner was Mr. JOHN S. WISE of Virginia, a well-known Republican, who took occasion to give his view of "The Electoral Problem of the South."

Open and persistent defiance of public sentiment and law and abuse of granted privilege has made many of the thoroughfares of the city worse than country turnpikes for travel and transformed them into slumbering volcanoes, liable at any moment to break out in violent eruption.

QUEBEC, Dec. 23.--The steam schooner Lady Belleau, which left here recently to engage in seal fisheries at Maniconagan, is ashore five miles above the latter place. She lies about one mile from shore. THe crew were landed safely, but the vessel and cargo are probably a total loss.

Among the worthies who figured in the congregation at St. Paul's Church in its earlier days was Daniel Webster, who helped to build the church and whose stately figure and noble head were especially conspicuous.

A letter has been received at the State Treasury from an ex-member of the General Assembly, with $10 inclosed, which the writer wanted paid into the conscience fund. In explanation he paid that when a member of the General Assemly he drew stationery from the State to the amount of $10 more than he required, and he considered it his duty to pay for it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23.--The proposed Anarachist meeting this afternoon did not take place. Throughout the day the hall chosen remained closed and the gathering of the so-called Arboiter Bund was quietly but effectually prevented by the police.

FORT WINGATE, New-Mexico, Dec. 15.-- From the slopes of one of the New-Mexican spurs west of the great continental divide, rises the little cluster of slate-colored houses that marks the picturesque site of Fort Wingate. It is 90 miles from Albuquerque and 3 miles from Wingate station of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad.

BOSTON, Dec. 23.--The attempt is being made in some quarters to create a sensation out of alleged illegal voting by women in the recent city election, and rumors are not wanting of intent to invalidate the election through the courts.

LONDON, Dec. 24.--A dispatch to the News from Paris says: "It is stated in financial circles here that the American Committee of the Panama Canal Company has offered to refund to the liquidators the sum of 9,000,000f., this being the amount of commissions received from the company.

The little town of Brookline, Mass., which is nearly surrounded by Boston, is valued for purposes of taxation at $407,454,028, which is more than one and a half times as much as the valuation of the whole State of New-Hampshire. It is the wealthiest town of its size in America, and mainly because it has the reputation of being a taxpayer's paradise.

At 7 o'clock yesterday morning fire broke out in Christ Episcopal Church, East Orange, N.J., and within an hour the structure was burned to the ground. The building was a frame structure to the erection of which H.W. Bishop, the Rector, had largely contributed.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 23.--As train No. 8 on the New-York Central, an express from the West due here at 6:15 P.M., was passing through Churchville, 18 miles west of here, at about 7:30 P.M., going very fast in an effort to make up lost time, it was thrown from the track and into a ditch by a spread rail, as is supposed.
Mr. Frank Sanger, Manager of the Broadway Theatre, is lying cangerously ill at the Vendome Hotel in this city. He was forbidden by his physician last night to see any visitors at all.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 23.--When the night exprees of the Georgia road ran into the car shed here this morning a horrible spectacle met the view of those around. On the pilot of the engine, the tender wheels, and the steps of the ladies' car were fragments of a human body, while adhering to the steps was a piece of bloody clothing.

The anti-Quinn faction of District Assembly No. 49 held a convention yesterday at Pythagoras Hall. There were 120 delegates present fronn about 45 labor organizations, most of which have heretofore been connected with No. 49.

BOSTON, Dec. 23.--The funeral of Samuel E. Sewall, at the Church of the Disciples to-day, brought together a notable body of men and women interested in philanthropic work, but more particularly in those reformatory movements coming under the head of woman's rights.

William Dempsey accidentally shot his brother James at their residence, 502 West Thirty-third-street, early Saturday evening, in a dispute over a revolver. The young man died an hour and a quarter later. William was put in the keeping of his older brother, Michael, who must produce him at the inquest before Coroner Levy this morning.
CATSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 23.--Two welldressed swindlers, of easy address, are traveling along the Hudson River tier of counties victimizing farmers and other "innocents."

The German Press Club of New-York held its annual "Skat Tournier" in the club rooms yesterday afternoon. Skat is a game at cards of which one is said to know less the longer he studies it. The first prize was awarded to August Thieme, the second to Theodore Boetterling, the third to Herman Looser, the fourth to Paul Looser and Karl Karow, and the consolation prize to Dr. C.A. Honthumb.

The recent death of Mr. Alfred Kusenberg, formerly an active and public-spirited citizen of Philadelphia, recalls the fact that on the 22d of February, 1871, he presented to the then Prussian Crown Prince (since then Emperor Frederick) at Versailles a sword of honor on behalf of the Germans of this city.

ALBANY, Dec. 23.--Eighteen million more persons patronized the railroads which traverse New-York City during the year ending Sept. 30, 1888, than there did the preceding year. The patrons who paid five-cent fares foot up the grand total of 376,913,586.

During the 20 years Mr. and Mrs. Childs have occupied their white marble city residence at Twenty-second and Walnut streets they have entertained in it some of the most notable men of the country and most of the distinguished strangers who have found their way here. An Emperor and Empress, lords and ladies, Princes and poets have slept within its...

Augustus Zerega, an old coffee merchant and shipowner, died yesterday at the residence of his son-in-law, Horace Barnard, 26 East Thirty-fifth-street, of pneumonia and heart failure after an illness of 10 days. Mr. Zerega was born Dec. 4, 1803, in Martinique...
LONDON, Dec. 23.--The United States war ships Juanita and Enterprise have arrived at Gibraltar.

ALBANY, Dec. 23.--The removal of the books in the law department of the State Library from the Golden Corridor in the Capi-- tol, where they have been crowded since the old State Library Building was demolished, to the new permanent quarters provided for them, will begin to-morrow, and it is expected that...

A very fine bust of Gen. Gordon has just been placed in the private apartments at Windsor Castle. It stands on a pedestal in the grand corridor, just opposite to the door of the sitting room belonging to the Empress Frederick's suite and close to the celebrated crystal casket in which the Queen deposited Gen. Gordon's Bible, which, by the way, is open at the first chapter of the Gospel according to St. John.

HAVANA, Dec. 23.--Advices have been received from Hayti to the effect that the dispute over the seizure of the American steamer Haytian Republic has been settled. The steamer has been delivered to the American men-ofwar, and the latter have honored the Haytian flag with a salute of 21 guns.

The case of W.J. Hibbard, who sustained several paralytic strokes a few months age in this city, is attracting attention. He has so far recovered as to be able to go anywhere about the city at his pleasure.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23.--The week at the Chicago playhouses has not been marked by large business, though the attractions have been fairly food. The weather has been excellent for shopping, aad Christmas expenditures have absorbed money and time to such an extent that there have been little of either left for amusement.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 23.--People in this city and neighboring places were startled last evening by what was believed to have been earthquake shocks.

The man or woman with agreeable manners will make headway in the face of the worst difficulties. Every one is against the disagreeable people, whose best chance lies in secluding...

Intense excitement among nearly 100 persons in peril made a fire which broke out on the ground floor of the double tenement house, 146 East Broadway, last night, painfully interesting to many hundreds of spectators. The building is owned by Abraham Cohn, a Bowery hatter.

The forthcoming divorce of Gen. Boulanger is scarsely news, because everybody knew that it would come sooner or later. The beginning of the misunderstanding arose two years age, when the General used to make use of the painter Vibert's house for gay suppers, of which Mile. Reichemberg was the Queen.

NAPLES, Dec. 23.--Mr. Gladstone arrived here last night. The railway station was crowded with members of the Municipal Council and other officials. A company of carbineers had great trouble in preventing students from invading the platform.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23.--The steamer Belgic arrived from Hong-Kong yesterday. The China papers brought by the steamer are full of details and rumors of the Mitkiewicz-Barker concessions. They say that Barker will be given the concessions with Mitkiewicz left out and that a protocol will soon be signed.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 23.--Everybody knows that Michigan is rich in copper. Comparatively few know much about the people who dig this metal out of the ground and prepare it for market. Michigan has a Bureau of Labor and Industrial Statistics, and this has just issued its sixth annual report.

RAPID CITY, Dakota, Dec. 23.--A prairie fire started southwest of here late yesterday and spread rapidly before the brisk northwest wind which was blowing at the time. A large tract was soon burned over and much loss is feared. The damage cannot now be estimated. Many farm buildings are in the line of the fire.
A superstitious rumor is current in Athens to the effect that there is a rock is Clarke County, about six miles from town, upon which no man dares to tread.
Edwin Booth was initiated in Edwin Forrest Lodge of the Actor's Order of Friendship yesterday, in this city.

PUEBLO, Col., Dec. 23.--Yesterday morning at Cucharas, 40 miles south of this city, the Denver and Rio Grande freight Conductor William E. Comstock and Brakeman Henry Borst were killed by the brake wheel giving way. Both men were turning the brake when it gave way. Borst was run over by the train and instantly killed. Comstock's skull was fractured and he only lived a few minutes.

LONDON, Dec. 24.--The General Transatiantic Line steamship La Normandie, Capt. de Kersabiac, from New-York Dec. 15, arr. at Havre at 1 A.M. to-day. The Gulon Line steamship Arizona, Capt. Brooks, from Liverpool, sld. from Queenstown for New-York at 1 P.M. yesterday.

We may look forward to an early canonization of Joan of Are. A number of devout Lorrainers bought in the course of this year an "authentic standard" of the heroine to lay on the shrine of Notre Dame de Lourdes. They asked the Bishop of Nancy to receive and bless them before they set out to fulfill their purpose which they fully explained to him by letter.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23.--The CoquelinHading combination closed last evening the first week of their engagement at the Baldwin Theatre. They played all the week to large and fashionable audiences. Their performances have been a succession of triumphs, and almost after every act Coquelin and Mme. Hading have been repeatedly called before the curtain. Last evening a reception was tendered to Coquelin by the Bohemian Club.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 23.--Nearly 300 members of the Grand Order of Railway Conductors, representing the New-England, Middle, and Western lines, attended the union meeting of the order in Music Hall to-day, under the auspices of Providence Division, No. 151. A number of officials connected with the local...

ALBANY, Dec. 23.--Thomas J. Dowling, District Master of Assembly No. 147, Knights of Labor, brought action for criminal libel against the Morning Express, which published a statement that Mr. Herrick stated that Mr. Dowling was purchasable politically, though a high-priced man.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23.--The appointment of a General Manager for the St. Louis, Arkansas and Texas, the Cotton Belt Line, has been a matter discussed in railroad circles for some time.

The Evangelical Alliance has issued a circular in reference to dangers to the public school system, the school fund, and religious freedom. The chief object of the alliance is the promotion of religious freedom, and in this line it cherishes the public school as a bulwark of civil and religious liberty, and of the purity and integrity of republican institutions. According to the circular:
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Dec. 15.--A number of additional purchases of real estate in the suburbs have racently been made by the agent of Mr. George H. Vanderbilt.
A correspondent adds his experience in regard to the manner in which the boats of the Hoboken Ferry are run and passengers inconvenienced.

Mrs. Potter begins her long season of eight weeks, under the management of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, at Palmer's Theatre to-night, appearing in "'Twixt Axe and Crown." BALTIMORE, Dec. 23.--Baltimoreans read with considerable interest this morning the cable dispatch which stated that Capt. Duverge had shot and killed Victor Stanwood, United States Commercial Agent at Andixcole, Madagascar. Capt. Leon de Rathier Duverge is well known here.

Thomas F. Grady will represent the Sixth Senate District in the approaching session of the Legislature. The County Democrats of the district added to its certainty last night. They met in the Jefferson Club's rooms, Avenue C. and Sixth-Street, and decided not to name a candidate against Grady.

The Baptist Pastors held their usual Monday morning conference yesterday at 9 Murraystreet. The Rev. H.B. Mason acted as Moderator. Before the usual reading of an essay the Pastors were called upon for remarks on books recently read, and the Rev. Dr. Eddy gave his views on "John Ward, Preacher," which he termed a counterpart of "Robert Elsmere."

LONDON. Dec. 24.--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Chamberlain arrived at Birmingham to-day, They drove from the railway station to Highbury, Mr. Chamberlain's residence, in a closed carriage.

A collision on the bridge during the greatest stress of traffic last evening resulted in the injury of three persons and in a blockade of the cable road which lasted for an hour. The accident occured at the Brooklyn end of the big connecting thoroughfare at 5:35 o'clock.

A resident of Arizona who asserts that he is "not a copper baron," but who seems to be interested pecuniarily in some copper mine, writes to us that THE TIMES'S comments upon the operations of the Copper Syndicate are not satisfactory from his point of view.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24.--Col. Herman Jacobson, a lawyer having an office with ex-Congressman Ward, was to-day the victim of a brutal assault in his office as a result of has prosecution of David Blumenfield, the head of a gang of swindlers infesting South Canal-street.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 24.--Gen. D.S. Stanley, Commander of the Department of Texas, and his aide, David J. Rumbaugh, were arrested here to-day on a civil warrant issued from the court of Justice Sturt, and executed by a constable. There is a valuable block of property belonging to the United States Government in Austin.

The resolution lately passed by the Municipal Council to change the name of the Boulevard Haussmann to that of the "Boulevard Baudin" has caused as much indignation here as it doubtless has astonishment in England. The change is not yet an accomplished fact, for the Council's decision must be ratified by the Government before it can be carried into effect.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 24.--The Secret Service of the Missouri Pacific, or what is less offensively known as the special service, will cease to exist after Jan. 1.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24.--There was no session of the Chicago Board of Trade to-day, and less than even the usual holiday interest was manifested in the markets in the offices of speculators.
The Merritt Wrecking Company has been compelled by the run of ice in the North River and the cold snap to suspend operations temporarily on the sunken steamer Atlas.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 24.--Word was received here this morning of a terrible fire in the little village of Forest City, a few miles above here, on the Erie Railway. In the fire an aged woman and her grandson lost their lives yesterday.

SILVER CITY, New-Mexico, Dec. 24.--A.L. McAfee was shot and instantly killed on the road about five miles east of Fort Bayard Saturday night.
PARIS, Dec. 24.--A second ballot in Ardennes to fill the vacancy in the Chamber of Deputies resulted as follow: M. Linard, (Opportunist,) 36,609; M. Aufiray, (Revisionist and Royalist,) 28,794.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--The collections of internal revenue during the first five months of the fiscal year ending June 30, 1889, amount to $33,091,736, being an increase of $1,231,186 over the collections during the corresponding period of last year.

WATERTOWN, Dec 24.--Winter has set in with some severity in this part of the State, but it did not get here in time to spoil the fun of several mighty bear hunters, who have made a score during the past few days.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 24.--The Westinghouse Electric Company will not consolidate with its rival, the Edison. "The story," said Assistant General Manager J.S. Humbird, originated in New-York. I have no doubt that the rival concern feels the inroads we are making in their business and that they desire some...

PARIS, Dec. 1.--It is generally conceded that the present political state of affairs cannot last long. This sentiment or belief will not prevent the half-disguised turbulent statu quo from blundering on, until some ambitions overt act leads to a sudden change of Governmental authority or to some outside complication.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 24.--There is almost as much excitement to-day as yesterday over the loss of the steamer Kate Adams, and rumor is gradually increasing the number of passengers who were drowned or burned. The impression is becoming general that the loss of life is greater than was at first supposed or was reported by the officers of the steamer.
The question of reviving the use of the lance in the French Army is again being discussed.

The trial of Frank B. Brouty for the murder of Policeman Thomas Woods at Mount Vernon last Summer was brought, to a close in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge Cullon at White Plains yesterday. The jury retired at 5 o'clock, and at midnight brought in a verdict of murder in the second degree. Brouty was remanded for sentence.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24.--The report of the Commissioners appointed by Secretary Whitney to inquire into and report upon needed improvements at the League Island Navy Yard, with its recommendations, has been forwarded to Washington.
SEATTLE, Washington, Dec. 24.--The steamer Lief Erickson was burned at Alki, a point five miles west of this city, at 5 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--Secretary Whitney to-day received a cable message from RearAdmiral Luce, in command of the United States ship Galena, at Kingston Jamaica saying that the American steamer Haytian Republic, recently seized at Port an Prince by the Haytian authorities, had been surrendered to him upon demand.

An alarm of fire from Reade-street and Broadway at about 8 o'clock last night, fol-- lowed soon by a second alarm summoned the fire companies within the call to 74 Readestreet, a five-story stone-front building dovoted to manufacturing.

Taylor, and Otis Corbett. Corbett is the father-in-law of Shaw, and until a short time ago was a dry goods merchant at Rock Island.

A committee of grocers called upon Mayor Hewitt yesterday to ask him to approve of the ordinance to compel farmers and other wholesale sellers of vegetables, , to give certain weights in their packages.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 24.--Henry and John Van Wormer, brothers, aged respectively 55 and 58 years, were killed by an Albany and Susquehanna train near Oneonta this afternoon. They had just stepped out of the way of an east bound train when the west-bound train ran over them, mangling them in a horrible manner.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24.--An execution for $753.73 was levied on the stage property of Frederick Warde, the actor, Saturday night while he was playing at McVicker's Theatre.

In the United States court what has proved to be a most interesting case was brought to an end yesterday morning. It was the case of a man named McCloskey, who was arrested about two years ago on warrants from the State and United States courts on the charge of violating the internal revenue laws.

The accident which occurred on the NewYork Central Road at Churchvill Saturday evening proves to have been quite serious in its results, notwithstanding that no lives were lost. UNIONTOWN, Penn., Dec. 24.--The funeral of the late Chief Justice Boyle of Washington Territory, this afternoon, was one of the largest ever seen here.

PANAMA, Dec. 15.--The canal works have suffered no serious injury from the recent bad weather. Ample warning of the coming flood was received from the canal station at Gamboa, at the head waters of the Chagres, so that preparations were made as far as possible to meet the rise of the river.

DULUTH. Minn., Dec. 24.--This morning while a gang of men were at work at the Ohio Coal Company's dock one of the bins, holding 600 tons of stone coal, burst and buried John Jackson and John Olson under the mass. Both were killed. Olson was unmarried, but Jackson left a widow and two children in destitute circumstances.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 25.--Jospeh H. Thompson, who farms the place of Jose F. De Navarro, on Rumson Neck, recently killed four of the largest hogs ever slaughtered in this section. The weight of the largest was 577 pounds, and the aggregate weight of the four was 1,888 pounds. The hogs were a little ever of year old.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec, 25.--Two thousand persons to-day witnessed the first game of baseball ever played indoors in this city. The game was played in the big main building on the State fair grounds.

The latest mechanical device invented for the theatres--the automatic opera glass box--promises to furnish profitable litigation for several lawyers. There are two companies in the field claiming the exclusive right to the patent, and the initial introduction of the device at the Casino has precipitated a legal war, the opening gun of which may be fired to-day.

The newspaper, with the telegraph in its service, makes the people of California and the people of New-York neighbors, and enables them to understand each other. When the States of Mexico get more newspapers and telegraphs they will have fewer revolutions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25.--Superintendent Carman of the Western Railway Weighing Association announces that every thing is in readiness for putting into effect Jan. 1 the live stock tariffs based on the weighing system.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 25.--James Carey, an orphan about 10 years of age, a walf about this town, was drowned this afternoon while skating on Pocahontas Lake. He ventured on weak ice and broke through and was dead before assistance could be given. Little is known of the boy except that he came here from New-York some time ago and has lived as he pleased.

BOSTON, Dec. 25.--A conflagration is raging in Marblehead, the larger part of the town being on fire. Help has been sent from Salem, Lynn, and other places, but the firemen seem unable to check the flames. Salem reports that all telephone wires to Marblehead are down and that nothing can be obtained from there by telephone.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 25.--The switchmen's strike in the Union Pacific yards, so far as the company is concerned, appears to be near its end. Five crews returned to work to-day and others will go to work to-morrow. The company are to-night working about half force, but while several trains have been made up, they have experienced considerable difficulty in getting them out on time on account of the interference of some of the strikers.

Great crowds ebbed and flowed along the aisles of the big Church of the Paulist Fatheres, in Fifty-ninth-street and Ninth-avenue, yesterday. All heads were bowed and all faces bore an expression of grief. The lofty interior of the church was dimly lighted and the only accompaniment of the thousands' march was the noise of their movements.

CHARLESTON, West Va. Dec. 25.--This afternoon Found Horner, aged 20, became crazy with drink, and obtained a club ran through the street knocking down and severly injurying several people. The last man be struck, Edward Aimes, drew a knife and killed his assailant. Aimes was arrested but afterward was discharged.

LONDON, Dec. 25.--Before withdrawing entirely from Suakin the British will build strong permanent forts on which guns will be mounted so as to sweep the plains. Black regiments will be left to garrison the place.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 25.--Fourteen prisoners escaped from the Hamilton County Jail at 2 o'clock this morning by cutting off six iron rods an inch in diameter and sliding down a rope, made of blankets, to the ground. Officers have been searching the country in all directions, but none of the fugitives have been recaptured.

A meeting of Hawaiians was held Nov. 22 to organize a native political organization. Among the resolutions was one "that all officers of the Hawaiian Government who are under the present Constitution appointed to office by his Majesty the King and his Majesty's Ministers should be elected by the people, and that the Constitution should be amended so as to have all Government officers chosen by popular election."

Letty Lind of the English Gaiety Company, now playing at the Standard Theatre, told her manager last evening that she was under contract to marry an Australian stock broker, and it would be neecessary for her to retire from the stage. The manager wished her a "Merry Christmas and many of them." Who the Australian stock broker is she would not tell.

No investigation was held yesterday as to the cause of the accident Monday evening on the Brooklyn Bridge. Chief Engineer Martin summoned witnesses to appear before him and give testimony in the matter, and they were ready at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, but were dismissed before any evidence was taken. They were told, however, to hold themselves in readiness to testify at some future time, probably to-day.

Yesterday was as green a Christmas as has ever been known in this section. In point of weather the day was such as might be expected in California, but not in New-York. The season was set back quite a month, with a mellow sky and a sun so genial that heavy wraps were altogether de trop.
A patent refrigerator car belonging to the Pennsylvania Railroad and loaded with potatoes was by some means burned yesterday at the Thomas-street crossing in Newark, The loss is $6,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 25.--This has been one of the quietest of days here. Gen. Harrison passed the day at home, spending most of the time in his library writing his inaugural address, which he hopes to finish by the end of the week, subject to modifications, of course.
